MÃ¤rz 1565 wurde Dolfin  durch Papst Pius IV. zum Kardinal erhoben und folgenden September Kardinalpriester von Santa Maria in Aquiro. Am Konklave von 1565 bis 1566, aus dem Pius V. hervorging, nahm er teil. Kardinal Delfino wechselte im Jahr 1578 seine Titelkirche  und erhielt kurzzeitig Santo Stefano al Monte Celio und bereits 1579 Santâ€™Anastasia. Unter Gregor XIII. erhielt er 1573 das Vizeprotektorat Ã¼ber die Deutsche Nation.  Auf Dolfin geht der Vorschlag zurÃ¼ck, Nuntien nach SÃ¼ddeutschland zu senden, woraus sich schlieÃŸlich die Nuntiatur in Graz entwickelte. Nach seinem Tod am 29. Dezember 1583 wurde er in Rom in der Kirche Santa Maria sopra Minerva beigesetzt.  Einige behaupteten seinerzeit, er wÃ¤re ein Mensch, der zwei Herren dienen wollte - dem Kaiser und dem Papst.
English Bio: Zaccaria Dolfin (Delfino) (born March 29, 1527 in Venice,   December 29, 1583 in Rome) was Cardinal and Apostolic Nuncio at the Imperial Court in Vienna. As a scion of a Venetian patrician family, he completed his studies of philosophy and jurisprudence in Padua. He was one of at least seven sons of Andrea Dolfin and Deia Mocenigo. At the age of nearly 23, Dolfin was ordained priest in 1550 and began his ecclesiastical career in Rome. Three years later, he was on May 5, 1553 Bishop of Lesina (now diocese of Hvar in Croatia) appointed. In 1554 Dolfin was sent to Vienna as a pope's nuncio, where he remained until 1556. In the royal residence he was able to make excellent contacts with the Jesuits, and apart from that he was in favor of sending young men from the provinces and Germany to study in Rome. In addition, he was a great supporter of the Clementinum in Prague. Dolfin sat down like Pope Julius III. for the appointment of Peter Canisius as bishop of Vienna, but in spite of all diplomatic efforts, they decided on another candidate. He accompanied Cardinal Morone to the Reichstag in Augsburg - and as the Cardinal's Morone and Truchseu for the death of Julius III. returned to Rome, Dolfin remained alone as a representative of the Pope in Augsburg. In 1555 he left for Rome. Paul IV sent him again in December 1555 to Emperor Ferdinand, who was very wary of him. Dolfin tried to limit the negative effects of the decisions of the Reichstag to Augsburg for the papal church and he was very much looking forward to the implementation of the church reform. Nevertheless, he had to watch as the Reformed were repeatedly made large concessions by the emperor. At the end of 1556 he returned to the pontifical court and reported to Paul IV about the relations in the empire. At the same time he taught Ferdinand Rome about the Roman situation. Because of these contacts sent the new Pope Pius IV, since 1559, Dolfin 1560 again to Emperor Ferdinand. His task was to win this for the reopening of the Council in Trent, as the Emperor wanted a new council in Innsbruck. After all, Dolfin reached the approval of Ferdinand for Trent, and he subsequently traveled through the German lands to invite the papers to the Council. He also participated in the gathering of Protestants in 1561 in Naumburg (Saale). Here, however, the Protestants completely refused to participate in the Council in Trent. After Dolfin's return to Vienna, he again became the Pontifical Nuncio, this time until 1565. He also strove for a positive settlement of the question of the laity goblet and the marriage of priests. In addition, he was instructed to transmit the decisions of the Council of Trent to the German clergy. On 12 March 1565 Dolfin was made cardinal by Pope Pius IV and next September cardinal priest of Santa Maria in Aquiro. At the conclave from 1565 to 1566, from which Pius V. emerged, he participated. Cardinal Delfino changed his titular church in 1578 and briefly received Santo Stefano al Monte Celio and in 1579 Sant™™Anastasia. Under Gregory XIII. In 1573 he received the Vice-Protectorate on the German Nation. Dolfin's proposal is to send nuncios to southern Germany, from which the Nunciature in Graz finally developed. After his death on December 29, 1583, he was buried in Rome in the church of Santa Maria sopra Minerva. Some claimed at the time that he was a man who wanted to serve two masters - the emperor and the pope.

Name: Heinrich III. von Wildenstein, O.F.M. davor Bischof von Kroja und Triest
German Bio: Heinrich von Wildenstein (* ca. 1330; â€  1409) war Bischof von Kruja, Triest und Pedena.  Heinrich von Wildenstein absolvierte vermutlich sein Theologiestudium bei den Franziskanern in Avignon, wo er engen Kontakt zum Papstpalast aufbaute. Am 5. Juli 1372 wurde Wildenstein von Papst Gregor XI. zum Bischof von Kruja im heutigen Albanien erhoben. Wildenstein freundete sich spÃ¤ter mit Kaiser Karl IV. und Herzog Leopold III. von Ã–sterreich an. Bei Karls Tod hielt Wildenstein im Dezember 1378 die Leichenpredigt.  Herzog Leopold von Ã–sterreich verhalf Wildenstein auf den Bischofsstuhl von Triest, das sich 1382 unter die Schutzherrschaft der Habsburger gestellt hatte. 1383 wurde Wildenstein schlieÃŸlich vom Papst in seinem Amt bestÃ¤tigt. Zu einer seiner Amtshandlungen zÃ¤hlte am 27. November 1385 die Weihe der nach langjÃ¤hriger Bauzeit fertiggestellten Kathedrale von Triest. Vermutlich aufgrund von Uneinigkeiten zwischen Wildenstein und dem ansÃ¤ssigen Klerus, der eine strikte Trennung zwischen Staat und Kirche forderte, wurde Wildenstein 1396 in die DiÃ¶zese von Pedena im heutigen Kroatien versetzt.
English Bio: Heinrich von Wildenstein (* ca. 1330 ;,   1409) was Bishop of Kruja, Trieste and Pedena. Heinrich von Wildenstein probably graduated in theology from the Franciscans in Avignon, where he established close contact with the Pope's Palace. On July 5, 1372 Wildenstein was Pope Gregory XI. raised to the Bishop of Kruja in today's Albania. Wildenstein made friends later with Emperor Charles IV and Duke Leopold III. from Austria. At Charlemagne's death Wildenstein held in December 1378 the funeral sermon. Duke Leopold of Austria helped Wildenstein to the episcopal see of Trieste, which had placed under the patronage of the Habsburgs in 1382. In 1383 Wildenstein was finally confirmed by the Pope in his office. One of his official acts on 27 November 1385 was the consecration of the Cathedral of Trieste, completed after a long period of construction. Presumably due to disagreements between Wildenstein and the local clergy, which demanded a strict separation between church and state, Wildenstein was transferred in 1396 in the diocese of Pedena in today's Croatia.

Name: Georg von Slatkonia
German Bio:
Georg von Slatkonia oder Jurij Slatkonja (* 21. MŠrz 1456 in Ljubljana - Laibach, (Krain);   26. April 1522 in Wien) war katholischer Bischof von Wien.

Er studierte in Laibach, Ingolstadt und Wien, wurde zum Priester geweiht, war Kantor an der Wiener Hofmusikkapelle und ab 1498 deren Leiter. Er baute die Kapelle aus, nahm Laien als Musiker auf und lie§ sie auch weltliche Werke auffŸhren. Durch ihn kamen Komponisten wie Paul Hofhaimer, Heinrich Isaac und Ludwig Senfl nach Wien. Von seiner eigenen KompositionstŠtigkeit sind keine Werke erhalten.

Er wurde Domherr und Propst von Laibach und 1506 Administrator des Bistums Pedena (Piben) in Istrien. Am 1. MŠrz 1513 wurde er von Kaiser Maximilian I. zum Bischof der Dišzese Wien ernannt und am 12. August von Papst Leo X. bestŠtigt. Seine Bischofsweihe am 13. November im Wiener Stephansdom war die erste seit der GrŸndung der Dišzese im Jahr 1469.

1521 kam der reformatorische Prediger Paul Seperatus nach Wien, den Slatkonia am 12. JŠnner 1522 im Stephansdom predigen lassen musste.

Er ist im Wiener Stephansdom begraben.

Die Erzdišzese Wien verleiht seit 2000 den Bischof-Slatkonia-Preis fŸr neue liturgische Musik.
English Bio:
Georg von Slatkonia or Jurij Slatkonja (born March 21, 1456 in Ljubljana - Ljubljana, (Krain),   April 26, 1522 in Vienna) was a Catholic bishop of Vienna.

He studied in Ljubljana, Ingolstadt and Vienna, was ordained a priest, was cantor at the Vienna Court Orchestra and from 1498 its director. He expanded the chapel, took laymen as musicians and let them perform secular works. Through him composers such as Paul Hofhaimer, Heinrich Isaac and Ludwig Senfl came to Vienna. From his own compositional work no works have been preserved.

He became canon and provost of Ljubljana and 1506 administrator of the diocese of Pedena (Piben) in Istria. On March 1, 1513, he was appointed Bishop of the Diocese of Vienna by Emperor Maximilian I and confirmed on August 12 by Pope Leo X. His episcopal consecration on November 13 in St. Stephen's Cathedral in Vienna was the first since the founding of the diocese in 1469.

1521 came the Reformation preacher Paul Seperatus to Vienna, the Slatkonia had to preach on January 12, 1522 in St. Stephen's Cathedral.

He is buried in St. Stephen's Cathedral in Vienna.

The Archdiocese of Vienna has awarded the Bishop Slatkonia Prize for New Liturgical Music since 2000.

August 1622 war er bei der Weihe des Triester Bischofs Rinaldo Scarlicchio anwesend. Sein Lebenswandel in geistlicher und religiÃ¶ser Hinsicht widersprach den in einen Bischof gesetzten Erwartungen. Er trug weltliche Kleidung und interessierte sich fÃ¼r militÃ¤rische Angelegenheiten. Zudem organisierte er militÃ¤rische Paraden, trug selbst Waffen und hielt sich hÃ¤ufig in WirtshÃ¤usern auf. Dadurch machte er sich in seinem Sprengel unbeliebt. Nachdem er mit der Bezirksregierung in Mitterburg in Konflikte geraten war, beschwerte sich diese 1623 beim Kaiser. Zugleich beklagte sich Bischof Scarlicchio Ã¼ber ihn in Rom. Die mit ihm gefÃ¼hrten Verhandlungen fÃ¼hrten zu keinem Erfolg. Deshalb zog Ferdinand II. 1625 seine Nomination zurÃ¼ck; Weinberger musste seinen Sprengel verlassen. Im selben Jahr starb er im Ã¶sterreichischen Retz.
English Bio: Karl Weinberger OFM (also Karl Weinperger (* 1582 in Graz,   1625 in Retz) was from 1620 to 1625 titular bishop of Nazianzus and Auxiliary Bishop in Wroclaw. From 1621 to 1625 he was nominated Bishop of Pedena. As a member of the Franciscan Order, Karl Weinberger became Commissioner of the Vicar General, responsible for the Hungarian and, later, the Austrian Province Province. On 27 January 1620 he was appointed Titular Bishop of Nazianzus (Ep. Tit. Nazianzenus) and Auxiliary Bishop in Wroclaw. Although he did not meet the expectations of Emperor Ferdinand II, he was nominated by the latter in 1621 Bishop of Pedena. Although the pontifical confirmation was not yet available, Weinberger went straight into his ward to take possession of it. There he changed jurisdiction, and on August 25, 1622, he was present at the consecration of the Bishop of Triest Rinaldo Scarlicchio. His life in spiritual and religious respects contradicted the expectations set in a bishop. He wore worldly clothes and was interested in military affairs. He also organized military parades, wore weapons himself, and often stayed in hostels. As a result, he made himself unpopular in his sprengel. After he had come into conflict with the district government in Mitterburg, this complained in 1623 to the emperor. At the same time Bishop Scarlicchio complained about him in Rome. The negotiations with him were unsuccessful. Therefore Ferdinand II withdrew his nomination in 1625; Weinberger had to leave his parish. In the same year he died in the Austrian Retz.

Juni 1646 Bischof und somit auch Graf von Triest.[3]  Anton und seinem Verwandten Ludwig (Ludovico), Verweser der Hauptmannschaft in Triest, wurde wegen ihrer Verdienste um das Haus Ã–sterreich der Reichs- und erblÃ¤ndisch-Ã¶sterreichische Freiherrnstand mit â€žvon Marenzfeld und Scheneckhâ€œ sowie Wappenvermehrung und Palatinat (Primogenitur) zu Prag, am 15. September 1652, durch Kaiser Ferdinand III. verliehen.[4] SchlieÃŸlich erhielt er 1659 Sitz und Stimme auf der Herren- und Ritterbank von GÃ¶rz. Beim Besuch Kaiser Leopolds I. in Triest brachte er die Huldigung der Stadt dar.[5]  Der Bischof besaÃŸ â€“ auch aufgrund pÃ¤pstlicher Schenkungen â€“ eine umfangreiche Reliquiensammlung, welche er seinen Bischofskirchen, vor allem der Antoniuskapelle im Dom zu Triest, hinterlieÃŸ.[5]  Anton lieÃŸ die â€žCasa Marenziâ€œ in Triest erbauen.[6] Er vollendete den Bau dieses Familienpalais am Rosarioplatz Anno 1650.[2]  1654: Geviert und belegt mit geviertem goldenen Herzschild, darin a) und d) ein rotbewehrter und gekrÃ¶nter schwarzer Adler, b) und c) drei von Blau und Silber geschachte schrÃ¤grrechts Balken (Stammwappen). â€“ 1 und 4 in Blau eine beiderseits geflÃ¼gelte silberne Kugel, 2 und 3 in Rot eine in vier Windungen einwÃ¤rts aufgerichtete rotbezungte, goldgekrÃ¶nte silberne Schlange. â€“ Drei Helme, auf dem rechten mit blau-goldenen Decken die beiderseits geflÃ¼gelte silberne Kugel, auf dem mittleren mit rot-silbernen Decken ein rot-bewehrter und gekrÃ¶nter schwarzer Adler, auf dem linken mit blau-goldenen Decken die gekrÃ¶nte Schlange.[7]
English Bio:
Anton Georg (Antonio Georgio) Marenzi of Tagliuno and Talgate, Baron of Mahrensfeld and Schšnegg (born September 20, 1596 in Trieste,   October 22, 1662 ibid), was a religious dignitary, Bishop of Pedena, then of Trieste, from the Marenzi family.

He studied the liberal arts at the Jesuit schools in Trieste and Graz. In 1620 he was accepted together with his brother Franz in the advisable Decurionate of Trieste and held in 1623 the office of a Judex and Rector of the city. He married on February 16, 1624 Lucretia de Calo and had a son, Francesco. After his wife had died in 1628, he chose the spiritual status and received in 1631 the priestly ordination. As Vicar General of the Bishop Pompeo Coronini from Triest, Anton, who was also Pastor of Gurkfeld (Kr_ko) and Apostolic Protonotar, was very successful for five years. As a result, he was nominated in 1635 by Emperor Ferdinand II for the bishopric of Pedena (Piben) in Istria, consecrated in 1638.

In 1639 he dedicated the Emperor Ferdinand a translated into Latin and two of his own epigrams extended version of the "Vite di S. Niceforo martire e di S. Niceforo vescovo di Pedena", which had been written in 1611 Nicol˜ Manzioli in Italian.

Appointed imperial councilor in 1641, he acquired the rule of Schšnegg, and for four years he was vicar general of the imperial Wallenstein troops and councilor of the Archduke Leopold Wilhelm. Again, on the nomination of the Emperor, he was bishop on June 30, 1646 and thus also Count of Trieste.

Anton and his relative Ludwig (Ludovico), Verweser the main team in Trieste, because of their services to the House of Austria, the imperial and ErblŠndisch-Austrian Freiherrnstand with "von Marenzfeld and Scheneckh" as well as coat of arms and Palatinat (Primogenitur) to Prague, 15 September 1652, by Emperor Ferdinand III. awarded. [4] Finally, he received in 1659 seat and vote on the men's and Ritterbank of Gorizia. When visiting Emperor Leopold I in Trieste, he brought the homage of the city dar.

The bishop possessed - also due to papal donations - an extensive collection of relics, which he left his episcopal churches, especially the Antonius chapel in the Cathedral of Trieste.

Anton had the "Casa Marenzi" built in Trieste. He completed the construction of this family palace on Rosarioplatz Anno 1650. [2]

Wooden coat of arms for Bishop Anton Marenzi in San Giusto 1650
1654: Square and covered with quartered golden heart shield, therein a) and d) a red-armored and crowned black eagle, b) and c) three oblique beams made of blue and silver (root coat of arms). - 1 and 4 in blue a silver ball winged on both sides, 2 and 3 in red a red-edged, gold-crowned silver snake arranged in four turns inwards. - Three helmets, on the right with blue-golden blankets the silver ball winged on both sides, on the middle with red-silver ceilings a red-armored and crowned black eagle, on the left with blue-golden blankets the crowned serpent.

English Bio: Andreas Daniel Baron von Raunach, Lord of Schillentabor and Munian (* 1627 in Schillentabor;,   December 9, 1686) was a clergyman, pastor and bishop of Pedena. Raunach's parents were Heinrich Bernhardin I. and Ludovika Lukretia Freiin von Panizolli. Since April 1661 he was together with his two brothers Hans Jakob and Heinrich Bernhardin II. Owners of the rule Schillentabor. "Erbl‡tisch-Ã¶sterr. Baroness with, riders of Raunach, gentlemen to Schillentabor and Miunian,€œ, dd Vienna April 4, 1661 for the three Brands of Raunach, Johann Jakob, ordained in Carniola, Heinrich Bernhardin, Commissarius of Landscape Krain and Andreas Daniel, canon to Ljubljana. " With the elevation of the Raunach in the Barons in 1661 their coat of arms was improved: shield four, 1 and 4 split by silver and black, in each case an inwardly curved, with the top upstanding JŠgerhorn (GamskrÃ Cover) in confused colors; 2 and 3 in silver a red ring; on the shield three crowned spangenhelme; middle crown has black - and - white ceilings with five black feather feathers set at the bottom with golden handles and with the tips pointing downwards; the right helmet has red and white blankets with ring like 2 and 3, the left black and white blankets with JagdhÃ¶rner like 1 u. 4; Raunach acted longer time until the year 1657 as pastor in TÃ¶plitz. The parish belonged to the rule Seisenberg (Slovenian: Å½uÅ¾emberk) on the Gurk / Krka in Lower Carniola. The pastorate was occupied by the Fuerste Auersperg. In the period from 1657 to 1670 Raunach Canon and Dombenefiziant in Ljubljana at the altar of St. Barbara. The benefit was donated in 1499 by Hanns Rauber and his mother Katharina born by Luegg, widow Caspar von Raubers. The Rauber retained the Erbvogtei and the Jus praesentandi (award right). On the occasion of the tribute ceremonies in Ljubljana for Emperor Leopold I. sat Raunach as canon on the board of the Erbfalkenmeister of Carniola. In 1670 Raunach was elected Bishop of Pedena and consecrated by the Bishop of Ljubljana Josef Rabatta. He held this office until 1686. Soon after the inauguration of the bishop he complained in a letter sent by the pastor Grgur Karlovic to Rome that in 1653, at the time of the peasants' revolt in the bishop's palace, all B And documents with the exception of the manuscript, €œJuria episcopalia,€œ were destroyed. He also expressed his opinion on the bad economic situation in his diocese: receipts of a priest at a welcome are a loaf of bread, a maÌ¤u wine and a candle of the value of a cruiser. He attested in 1686 and died in the same month of Christ.

English Bio:
Simeon Vratanja (  1630) was the first bishop of the historical eparchy Mara and the founder of the church union of KriÅ¾evci. About the childhood and adolescence of Simeon Vratanja, there is probably no information to be found, transmitted or preserved. Historically, Vratanja grew in the area of __southeastern Europe, also called the Balkans, in 16./17. Century, which had been part of the Ottoman Empire. About the church career Vratanjas, whose surname is Sime Vretanji‡‡ hieÃŸ, preserved biographical sources indicate that he was pastorally active as an orthodox priest in the territory of present-day Slavonia, under Turkish rule , Whether Vratanja came from the monastery Hrmnja, which was located along the river courses of the Una and the Unac, remains historically speculative. Probably Vratanja came from the monastery Remete in Orahovica, in the territory of the Croatian Prigorje. Simeon Vratanja was appointed Vladika for orthodox Christians in the areas of Hungary, Croatia and Slavonia by the eparte Kozma in Îur on October 30, 1607. In order to emphasize his now attained ecclesiastical position, which at the same time brought legal, even political prestige among the Orthodox Christians, Vratanja went to PeÄ‡ to the patriarch Jovan Kantula II.-Sokolovi‡, who was patriarch of the historically important Serbian Patriarchate PeÄ‡ [1] and contacts [2] After the defeat of the Ottomans in the Battle of Sissek (Sisak), an inflamed uprising of the Orthodox population in Ottoman territory. The military border posts of the Ottoman Empire were predominantly Orthodox Christians, soldiers or so-called defensive peasants. In the Croatian territories under Habsburg, along the Croatian military frontier, Ferdinand I. Herberstein's military commanders Ivan Lenkovi_ and Ban Ivan Draskovi_a strove to get Orthodox Christians on their side. The project succeeded and it settled on the 60,000 Orthodox Christians, who were commonly referred to as, €Walachen,€œ, in the Generalate VaraÅ¾din, including Simeon Vratanja. The Bishop of Zagreb, Petar DomitroviÄ‡, himself the son of orthodox parents from OÅ ¡ trc, recognized the need to ensure pastoral pastoral care for Orthodox Christians. Domitrovi‡‡, Martin Dubravi‡‡, who was a Catholic pastor from Ivan’‡‡ and also from an Orthodox home, commissioned this matter. Dubravi‡a addressed in the Generalate of VaraÅ¾din Simeon Vratanja, who joined the effort to provide appropriate pastoral care, which Vratanja then took over and did not oppose a union with the Church of Rome. In the spring of 1611 Simeon Vratanja was worldly confirmed by Ferdinand I as bishop. Before the Union could be carried out ecclesiastically, Vratanja was with DubraviÄ‡ at the Apostolic Nuncio at the court of Vienna. There Vratanja and his companion DubraviÄ‡ received a letter on September 10, 1611, in which Vratanja was confirmed as bishop for Christians of the Byzantine rite. In November 1611 Simeon Vratanja and Martin Dubravi‡ arrived in Rome. There followed a question about lawful consecration of Vratanja. Although the Roman Catholic Church fully recognizes the Orthodox sacrament of Holy Orders, Simeon Vratanja was re-ordained bishop after the Latin rite by Cardinal Robert Bellarmin. In the following years it became customary for the next four successors of Vratanja to receive episcopal ordination in the Eparchy of Pe–‡, according to their native rite in Church Slavonic liturgy and in Rome, through the respective Pope as bishop for the united Christians Were killed. The appointment of Vratanja by Pope Paul V took place on 21 November 1611. In addition, the Pope Vratanja issued the Apostolic Constitution "Ad perpetuam rei memoriam". In this, the erection of the Eparchie Mara was canonically confirmed, in addition Vratanja confirmed to ecclesiastically sovereign Bishop of the Eastern Rite and jurisdiktiv the ecclesiastical territory of the eparchy was established. Simeon Vratanja left the Eparchie Mara after his return from Rome in 1612, located between Ivan’Ä‡-Grad and ÄŒazma, on the Catholic church ruins of All Saints' Day. In the eparchy, moreover, monks who became involved in pastoral tasks had become members. Vratanja dedicated the eparchy to Archangel Michael. The eparchy had received a political significance in addition to the ecclesiastical. Vratanja vowed this status ecclesiastically and turned to the Bishop of Zagreb, Petar DomitroviÄ‡, with whom he was in friendship. On 16 February 1618, a deed of donation was issued by Domitrovi‡‡, authorizing Vratanja Mara.
Simeon Vratanja resided in the eparchy of Mara until his death in 1630.

Ãœber das Leben des hl. Euphrasius ist wenig bekannt. Er wurde zwischen 530 und 540 Bischof von PoreÄ. Er wurde eingesetzt, um nach der byzantinischen Eroberung Istriens die Kirchenpolitik Kaiser Justitians durchzusetzen.[1] Ab 543 lieÃŸ er die Basilika des Bistums unter Verwendung alter Bauteile neu errichten; sie ist heute nach ihm benannt.[2]  Euphrasius von PoreÄ wurde in einer Kapelle in der neuen Basilika bestattet.[2]
English Bio: Euphrasius of PoreÄ (* late 5.Â   / early 6. century in Thrace,   560 in PoreÄ, also Euphrasius of Parenzo, Croatian Eufrazije) is a Christian saint and was the second by name known bishop of PoreÄ. About the life of St. Euphrasius is little known. He was bishop of PoreÄ between 530 and 540. It was used to enforce the church policy of Emperor Justitian after the Byzantine conquest of Istria. From 543 onwards, he rebuilt the basilica of the diocese using old building blocks; she is named after him today. [2] Euphrasius of PoreÄ was buried in a chapel in the new basilica. [2]

Er starb 1564.
English Bio: Lorenzo Campeggi (* 1474 in Milan,   July 25, 1539 in Rome), less correct sometimes also Campeggio, was an Italian lawyer and cardinal. The eldest son of the famous lawyer Giovanni Zaccaria Campeggi studied law in Padua, taught in Venice from 1496 to 1499 and became professor at the University of Bologna in 1500, in the same year he married Francesca Guastavillani. The marriage had three sons and two tutors, the 1504 born Alessandro was also bishop of Bologna and Cardinal. After the death of his wife in 1509 Lorenzo entered the spiritual state and was appointed by Pope Julius II, who had helped the family Campeggi to rule over Bologna, first to the auditor of the Rota, but already half a year spÃ Sent as nuncio to Maximilian I, where he found the support of Gurk Bishop Matth¤us Lang. In 1512 Campeggi was appointed bishop of Feltre and sent as nuncio first to Milan, then again in 1513 to the kingdom. Pope Leo X. created him in 1517 as cardinal and appointed him in 1518 the cardinal priest of the titular church of San Tommaso in Parione, 1519 of Sant™™Anastasia. Clement VII transferred him in 1528 to Santa Maria in Trastevere. In 1534 he was admitted to the cardinal bishops' class by Clement VII. In 1519 he went as a pontifical legacy against the initial resistance of Cardinal Wolsey to England, where Henry VIII gave him an exspect on the diocese of Salisbury and gave a palace in Rome [1]. Henry VIII appointed him in 1523 Cardinal Protector of England. In 1523, the new Pope Clement VII transferred him to the bishopric of Bologna, which was to remain family property until 1563. Campeggi 's best known broadcast is to the Reichstag of Nuremberg in 1524, where he knew how to skilfully avert the resolute demands of the authorities for a reform of the church, while at the same time making some German leaders at the Regensburg Convention firm Connection to the pope won. A new mission to England to dissuade Henry VIII from divorce or to persuade Catherine to renounce voluntarily was unsuccessful (1528). After attending Charles V's appointment in Bologna, in 1530 he accompanied the Emperor to the Diet of Augsburg, where he urged him to adamantly oppose the Protestants and, in an emergency, to use violence. After he was elected in 1534 for the election of Paul III. He died in 1539. His brother Tommaso Campeggi accompanied him on several missions, followed him as bishop of Feltre, took part in the Worms Religious Talk (1540/41) as Pontifical Nuncio and was in the first period of the Trent Council psalmic legate. He died in 1564.

Pippin, von dem Kretschmayr annimmt, er habe die Eroberung Venedigs nicht nur versucht, sondern erfolgreich zum Abschluss gebracht, verstÃ¤ndigte sich zunÃ¤chst mit Niketas zu einem bis August 808 gÃ¼ltigen Frieden. English Bio:
Fortunatus II, also Fortunatus of Grado, more rarely of Trieste (* in Trieste,   March 12 825 or 826 in Rome), was from 777 Bishop of Treviso, from 806 to 810 of Pula and from 803/810 to about 820 Patriarch from Grado. He is considered in the struggle between the Franconian and the Byzantine emperors as an exponent of the pro-Frankish party. According to Roberto Cessi and Gherardo Ortalli, the patriarchal survey was an expression of distrust of the doge of Venice, with the aim of reversing their pro-Byzantine orientation. Simone Dellagiacoma, he was considered the greatest of the 60 Patriarchs of Grado, who ruled between 725 and 1451. [2] Either because he joined a conspiracy against the Doge of Venice, or because he supported Ljudewit, a possibly early Croatian regional ruler against the Franks, he had to flee to Constantinople. From there he returned to 824/25, but died on the way to Rome or in the city. He was buried there as abbot of Moyenmoutier.

In 777, Fortunatus, born in Trieste, was elevated to Bishop of Treviso, whom the Franks had recently conquered by the Lombards and made the capital of their margraviate Verona. Fortunatus sought successfully in the course of the following years, the alliance with the Franks under Charlemagne. It can not be confirmed, as it is called in a 12th century commentary in the oldest patriarchal list, a survey of the Bishop of Trieste.

After his uncle John, the Patriarch of Grado and the Fortunatus predecessor in office, 802 was murdered at the behest of the same Venetian doge John, Fortunatus was his successor. He settled in 803 by Emperor Charles and Pope Leo III. confirm in his office. He received the pallium on March 23, 803.

First, he tried to overthrow the two Doge John and his son Mauritius (II) to take revenge on the murder of his predecessor, but the plan failed and he had to flee together with his relative and ally Obelerius to Treviso to to place it under the protection of the Franks. After the two Dogen 804 had finally been overthrown with Franconian support, joined Fortunatus' confidant Obelerius the office of doge. At the Frankish court Fortunatus received a diploma in March 803, in which he was granted immunity in the face of his merits, as well as his clerics and followers. In a diploma, possibly issued at the same time, he also received tax exemption for transit in any place in the empire for four of his ships. He should soon have become economically independent. In addition, he received the Abbey Moyenmoutier as Benefizium. During his absence, Grado was taken by the Dukat Venice. The Franks could hardly accept this.

Although Karl also promoted the church in north-eastern Italy, there were rivalries such as those between Aquileia and Grado. This was true for Istria, where Charles wanted to strengthen the rights of Aquileia, on the other hand, Fortunatus was important for the common struggle against the pro-Byzantine groups in the Upper Adriatic. Therefore, in 803 he turned to Fortunatus as "Venetiarum et Istriensium patriarcha", which he legitimized his Obodienzforderungen with a view to the Istrian bishoprics, especially Pola. Fortunatus went after the Venetian military strike to Istria, where he 804 together with five bishops and other representatives from his birthplace Trieste, as well as Istria, the decision of Risano, initiated the Placito del Risano. The Patriarch and his entourage presented the royal messengers (Missi Dominici) Emperor Charles their demands, which were largely recognized. The region was granted extensive duty-free status, and - which was an uncommon right in the Frankish feudal system - permission to regulate its own internal affairs and to choose its own bishops and officials.

805 had to leave Fortunatus Grado for the first time, and he was replaced by the deacon John, who has received an inscription in Grado. It reads: "John siquidem patriarcha, qui per quattuor annorum spacia Gradensem sedem vivente pastore usurpavit, sinodali censura depositu est". [4] The patriarch therefore usurped the patriarchal chair for four years, ie until 809.

As part of this "usurpation" Fortunatus was raised on the initiative of Charles, who turned to the Pope, the Bishop of Pula in Istria, an office that he completed to 810. Since Fortunatus formally continued to hold the office of the Patriarch of Grado, Pope Leo III. his appointment as Bishop of Pola first off. Only after the agreement to relinquish the bishop's chair in Pola, as soon as he could resume his seat in Grado, which he had "propter persecutionem Grecorum seu Veneticorum", confirmed the Pope Fortunatus in his office as Bishop of Pola. Karl is said to have desired, as a spiritual father, after a reference to the author of the Chronica de singulis patriarch Nove Aquileie, Fortunatus. [5] The Pope, however, admonished the emperor not to listen to the apologists of Fortunatus, for his whole behavior was unworthy of an archbishop, and the said apologists had been corrupted. This accusation probably confirms the reclamation of goods by the successor of Fortunatus, the patriarch Venerius, who had bequeathed the said goods to his nephew Domenico.

In 810 King Pippin of Italy, one of the sons of Charlemagne, conquered a number of places in the lagoon of Venice. Although the Venetians had successfully resisted the Franconian invasion and Obelerio had to resign from his doge by virtue of his alliance with the Franks, Fortunatus was able to return to Grado. Karl recognized 810 that the lagoon belonged to the eastern empire. Fortunatus' ambitious plans lost their foundation, even though a source dating back to 819 calls him "Patriarch of the Church of Aquileia and Grado." In the following years, the cultural influence of the Franks, as can be seen in works of art of the time, grew in the Patriarchate Grado.

In 815, at the instigation of Fortunatus, Charles' son Louis the Pious renewed the right of the Istrian region to raise its own bishops and officials. As late as 820, Fortunatus participated in a conspiracy to overthrow the new doge of Venice, the Agnello Particiaco. The plot, however, flew open and Fortunatus was banished; as the Venetian chronicler Johannes Diaconus claims, after 27 years of rule. His office as Patriarch of Grado took over the Abbot of San Servolo as John V.

According to Franconian sources Fortunatus was overthrown for quite different reasons. He is said to have supported a rebellion in 821 in Pannonia inferior under the leadership of the Ljudewit, whose nucleus was the Croatian Sisak. There was a war, which the Franks ended victoriously; Constantinople was probably unable to support the rebellion. [6] This victory can also be archaeologically detected, because in the west of Croatia disappeared an idiosyncratic archaeological culture with relations to Bohemia. After a request to go to the imperial court, Fortunatus traveled to Istria to pretend to obedience - after all, he was obliged to obedience to the emperor as abbot of Moyenmoutier - but soon fled to Zara, ie to the Byzantine empire. The local Prefect of the province of Dalmatia immediately sent the refugees to Constantinople. Either the Treaty of Aachen from 812 had led to a change in relations between the Franks and Byzantines in the area Grado -Istrien, or Emperor Louis had given up the until 814 led by his father's policy of protection. Fortunatus stayed until 824 in the Byzantine capital. Whether he used the stay, about which nothing else is known, to acquire relics or ornaments for his Gradeser church, is not to be proven from the narrative sources.

Fortunatus returned to the Frankish court with a group of Byzantine ambassadors, probably to return to patriarchal office. But Ludwig referred the deposed patriarch to Rome. According to the chronicler of Moyenmoutier, he died in 826 during this stay in Rome, while he finished his life after John Diaconus in Frankish territory. The said Franconian sources are not interested in Fortunatus since he was sent from Ludwig to Rome. In December 824, the patriarch stayed in his Frankish monastery Moyenmoutier. A chronicler of the early 11th century, who in his Liber de sancti Hidul fi successoribus on the successors of St. Idulfo or Hydulphe Moyenmoutier (  707) writes: "Mira autem dispositione divinitatis repertus est ibidem Fortunatus patriarcha venerabilis, qui gratia salutandi famosum principem, from Hierosalimis peregre disgressus erat", so Fortunatus had returned from Jerusalem. The same chronicler also reports how Fortunatus sent an embassy on behalf of Emperor Charles to Harun ar-Rashid a few years earlier, although it remains unclear whether he himself may have participated in this legation.

After the necrosis of the monastery Moyenmoutier Fortunatus died on March 12, probably at the latest in the year 825 or 826, also the 26th February is given. He was buried in the monastery near the altar of Gregory the Great. In a sort of letter, possibly from the Byzantine exile he sent to his clerics in Grado, which resembles a will, Fortunatus lists his contributions to the Graden church and expresses his hope for a speedy return. The document is not dated. Meanwhile, this source is seen more as the excerpt of a court record in which the patriarch tried to prioritize his merit while being accused of robbing the Grades church. [9]

An archaeological find speaks for a stay Fortunatus' in Jerusalem. During the excavations at the Grades church S. Maria delle Grazie came in 1925 on a ciborium an inscription that was highly fragmented (Grado, Museo Lapidario). Deciphering their meaning did not succeed for decades, especially since some letters are missing, and the subsequent arrangement of the fragments did not yield meaningful text. Maurizio Buora proposed in 2017 as a reading "GLORIO (sis) TEMPORIB (u) S TER B - caput - EATI M [VN] HE (a) Q (uae) E SION [DVX] IT SE (cum)" [tul] IT "is conceivable. "Sion" stands for "Jerusalem" (pp. 36-38), the inscription thus reminds of the said stay in Jerusalem and the "munera" that Fortunatus brought with him.

This is significant insofar as it is known that Harun ar-Rashid sent a piece of the Cross of Christ to the Frankish Emperor, which Helena, the mother of Constantine the Great, had received. Also in Grado is a piece of the said cross, and thus one of the most important relics. Although the container is much younger, it may be a relic that Fortunatus had procured. The temporal proximity to the robbery of the relics of the evangelist Markus in the year 829 from Alexandria makes this scenario, according to Maurizio Buora, even more probable. In addition, the assumption suggests that Fortunatus wanted to prepare with these foundations to the Grades Church his return.

Pietro Marcello noted in 1502 in his later translated into the Volgare under the title Vite de'prencipi di Vinegia translated work, that it was "Mauritio Galbaio" succeeded, which until then no one had managed to make his son his successor. Marcello reproaches John above all for his behavior towards the patriarch Fortunatus and the subsequent military intervention Pippins. Fortunatus, who had to flee after his conspiracy against the Doges had flown, had spoken badly to the Venetians to Karl and so upset him ("lo attizz˜ in tal modo") that he had given his son the said command.

Francesco Sansovino (1512-1586) believes in his Opus Delle cose notabili della cittˆ di Venetia, Libri II published in Venice in 1587, to a congiura led by Obelerio and Fortunatus, the nephew of the murdered Patriarch of Grado, who " i dogi "(the 'Doge') forced 804 to flee. [11]

In the translation of the Historia Veneta of Alessandro Maria Vianoli, which appeared in Nuremberg in 1686 under the title The Venetian Hertzogen Life / Government, and Death / From the First Paulutio Anafesto to the itzt-reigning Marcum Antonium Justiniani, [12] the Patriarch John of Grado, who had fallen from a tower, was "a very sincere and honest man" whose assassination meant that the two exponents Fortunatus and Obelerio, "the then guild master of Malamocco," began to "rebel against them". In doing so, Fortunatus has "made a fortune to avenge the unbilished and innocent death of his ancestor" (p. 67). But the conspiracy was exposed - "because they were not attacked the best / nor with the necessary secrecy ... been linked" - and Fortunatus and Obelerio had to flee with their supporters.

Johann Friedrich LeBret knew from 1769 in his political history of the Republic of Venice, that after Obelerius had been chosen by the Treviso fled supporters of Fortunatus and remaining in Venice, anti-dynastically thinking "nobles" to the "Duke", the mere rumor of this proclamation "," John and Morizen so timid "have made that they are determined to flee. Like the Doges, the bishop "Christoph", who was appointed by the two Doge, fled to "France," and was never allowed to return. John, while still in office, tried to neutralize the suspicious Pippin by sending "Nicephorus," the East Emperor Nikephorus I, a fleet to "hold Pipin in check" (p. 123). Obelerius, according to LeBret, first came to Venice after learning about the flight of the doge. The driver of the coup attempt, which had failed at the time, was Fortunatus, who felt that he was justified in seeking revenge for the death of his predecessor (p. 122). In a letter from Pope Leo to Charlemagne, the pontiff states that Fortunatus "sends himself better to a court than to the care of the soul". "Fortunatus, the troubled Patriarch of Grado, who played such a masterful role in destroying the state, destroying his role, came back from France and brought with him the fleeting Bishop Christopher of Olivolo." LeBret does not seem to explain that why he brought Christopher with him, although his predecessor had not wanted to consecrate him, and although he had been a supporter of the overthrown Doge. "These two clerics must therefore have entered into such a close friendship through a special connection, of which we find no trace." The author surmises that Karl himself may have reached a balance between the clerics. When Fortunatus, "a man full of intrigues," had to flee from the fleet of Niketas and thus finally flee, "Thus the state was liberated from a prelate whose greatest joy was when the fatherland was put into the utmost disarray." 125). Finally, the author mentions that after the death of his benefactor Charles, Fortunatus fell out of favor with his overly self-contained policy, especially when he supported "Lint-witus," whom he "gave much encouragement," and "sent many skilled workers," whose he used to fortify his castles and cities "(p. 140). "But the matter was betrayed by one of his priests to K. Ludwig, who therefore called him to his court." Fortunatus traveled to Zara after a detour via Istria, where he sought Byzantine protection. As a result, Fortunatus, who had already incited Karl ("knowing from experience what this man had blown for a fire at the court of Charlemagne"), was deposed. At Fortunatus' place stood the abbot of the "Monastery of the H. Servulus, John". The new Emperor Michael sent the fled to Constantinople Fortunatus with an embassy to Emperor Ludwigs court. Louis sent him to Rome with the legation, accompanied by some of his men, but Fortunatus died en route.

Samuele Romanin believes in the first volume of his ten-volume opus Storia documentata di Venezia, [14] Fortunatus had begun a "vendetta" to avenge the death of his predecessor, the author follows Johannes Diaconus. According to this Fortunatus especially the Obelerius, the tribunes of Malamocco, but also numerous other men to accomplices ("complici", p. 136). In the interpretation of the negotiations between Karl and Nikephoros Romanin follows the statements of Andrea Dandolo, according to which all of northern Italy should go to the Frankish kingdom, while Venice and the cities of Dalmatia, because they were loyal to Byzantium ("costanti nella sincera devozione all'imperio orientale" ), should remain with the East, as its southern Italian areas. [15] Also follows the author Andrea Dandolo, who describes how Fortunatus incites Charlemagne by reporting that the Venetians were completely attached to Byzantium - qui Constantinopolitano Imperio totaliter adhaerere videbantur ", he quotes Dandolo - and they had murdered his predecessor (p ). The Doge fled, with Father John went to Mantua, his son Mauritius but found an overpowering opponent at the imperial court. On the other hand, Fortunatus (this contradiction does not dissolve Romanin) recommended the bishop "Cristoforo". Even when 'his friend' Obelerius was elected Doge, he could not dare to bring him back to the patriarchal chair because of his friendly attitude. In addition, there had been renewed fights between Jesolans and Equilians. The leading families are said to have moved from Equilio and Grado to Malamocco. Meanwhile, Fortunatus was returning from Campalto. First, however, he sat down with the support of Charles on Istria, where he became Bishop of Pola. Together with Cristoforo, who again became Bishop of Olivolo, he operated the Franconian cause after returning to Grado. With the fleet of the Niketas the power relations changed again. Another Cristoforo became Bishop of Olivolo, Fortunatus fled to the Frankish kingdom. With the Treaty of Aachen Charles recognized the special role of Venice and Fortunatus was able to return to Grado (p. 158). But in 820 the Patriarch stumbled upon another attempt to overthrow a doge. He went to the Frankish kingdom, where he died, or, as others say, in Rome.

August Friedrich Gfršrer (  1861) believed in his 1872 posthumous history of Venice from its founding to the year 1084, [16] Fortunatus had also expressly submit to the bishoprics of Istria, which had been withdrawn from the Patriarchate 771 by the Lombards. At the same time, as Andrea Dandolo observed, Karl did not consider Lake Veneto as part of his kingdom (p. 97). According to Gfršrer, this fits in with the Franke's "Eginhard": "In 803, the patriarch Fortunatus, coming from the land of the Greeks, appeared at the Frankish court." Fortunatus also complained to Gfršrer that the Venetians had murdered his predecessor, and that "that the Venetians had made the decision to adhere entirely to the realm of Constantinople." In Treviso, his supporter Obelerius was elected Doge, who came from Malamocco, "as the center of the Lombard party, which by the power of circumstances gradually turned into a Frankish one since the fall of King Desiderius" (pp. Fortunatus and Christopher remained "in the village of Cypriano (near Mestre), for they were barred from entering the islands." By cunning he brought another Johann, the bishop of Olivolo in his power, but he was able to escape and complained to the doge about his mistreatment. Nevertheless, Fortunatus succeeded first in enforcing Christoph again in Olivolo, and then returning to Grado himself (p. 103). Until then, Obelerius had probably been unable to enforce the return of his ally, either because of the Greek party - Gfršrer sees only this party and the Franconian party at work - or because of enemies from the Frankish party itself. Consequently, it was Fortunatus who made the promise to be supported, namely by the pro-Byzantine groups, first brought the former opponent Christoph back, and then again take his Doge's seat.

After the posthumous editor Dr. John Baptist of White the translator into Italian, Pietro Pinton, had forbidden to annotate the statements Gfršrers in the translation, appeared Pintons Italian version in the Archivio Veneto in the annual volumes XII to XVI. However, Pinton had enforced that he was allowed to publish his own account in the said Archivio Veneto, which, however, appeared only in 1883. Although Pinton often came to entirely different, less speculative results in his research than Gfršrer, but he largely agreed with the author in connection with the first dog dynasty. But Pinton believes that Gfršrer had been threatened by the Franks by claiming that at the time of the assassination of the bishop almost all the land over which the two doge ruled. [17] He told Gfršrer that he came through a wrong chronology to inaccurate conclusions about the motivations of those involved. This is proved, for example, by the fact that he wrote that Andrea Dandolo copied from Paulus Diaconus, but after that he only followed the doctrine of the Doge, without Gfršrer perceiving the differences between the two authors (pp. 40-42). , Pinton also does not believe that under the aegis of the Franks there was a conspiracy followed by the escape of Fortunatus, for after the seizure of power by Obelerius he was hardly refused a return without reason (p. 53), and above all Obelerius According to Gfršrer, one of the heads of the Fortunatus franc conspiracy, assisted by a fleet to recapture Dalmatia, and his brother Beatus was given the title of ipat, a consul (p. 55). The Byzantine fleet also anchored beneath it in the lagoon. Overall, although Pinton recognized the links between Fortunatus and the Franks, Gfršrer misinterpreted the composition of the 804 subversionists, or rather their role in the dispute between the empires.

In 1861, Francesco Zanotto believes in his Il Palazzo ducale di Venezia that Fortunatus had a "vendetta" against the Galbaii, a bloodthirst that was finally crowned with success. At the behest of Charlemagne, this act led both Doge into exile. [18]

For Heinrich Kretschmayr Fortunatus was "a personal favorite of Charlemagne," he was "violent, ambitious, unsteady, bitter by the murder of relatives, personally threatened by reprisals of the Greek party." [19] He was the champion of a Frankish party, but also of those who felt "indignation" "about the violence of Grado". He fled with his followers to Treviso, "then hurried alone to the court of Charlemagne to Selz". Kretschmayr assumes that the "haughty refusal he received from his alliance claim by Emperor Nikephoros" was the reason he supported Fortunatus in his effort to overthrow the "faithful Duces". Fortunatus received not only the monastery Moyenmoutier and the said trade freedoms, but also the commitment to subordination of the Istrian dioceses under Grado. In 804 Obelerius overthrew the pro-Byzantine Doge and raised his brother Beatus to fellow-doer. Rhetorically, the author asks: "Was this revolution of 804 the victory of a Frankish party in Veneto?" "Even in 805, both Duces decided to strict submission to the Frankish kingdom" and "In Reich division law of 6 February 806 Venetia, Istria and Dalmatia assigned to King Pippin's shares "(p. 55 f.). A Byzantine fleet appeared in the spring of 807, Obelerius surrendered, the Greeks took Beatus, Christopher of Olivolo, "the protŽgŽ Fortunats," and the tribunes Felix as hostages, "one of the chief conspirators of 804". Fortunatus had already withdrawn from the rumor of the approaching fleet by fleeing to the Frankish kingdom of capture. Pippin, of whom Kretschmayr assumes that he not only attempted the conquest of Venice, but successfully brought it to a conclusion, at first agreed with Niketas on a peace valid until August 808. Beatus returned, "trained in Greek interest", and the third brother, Valentinus, was also raised to doge. Again a fleet from Constantinople appeared in 809, but failed to conquer Comacchio. The withdrawal of this fleet Pippin now used the decisive attack on the lagoon, in revenge for "the fall of 807 and the malicious cross-rubbings of 809" - the Doge had brought the Frankish-Byzantine negotiations to failure. After "Heracliana in the north, Brondolo, Chioggia, Pelestrina and Albiola in the south", after fierce fighting at Albiola "also Malamocco fell - there is no doubt about that". After Kretschmayr also the doge prisoners Pippins were. Rialto, however, might not be conquered, perhaps Pippin's army even suffered a defeat. Otherwise, the author believes that Rialto has been conquered, "despite all the Venetian fables". Venice remained Franconian, even when another Byzantine fleet appeared that could only fend off a Frankish attack on Dalmatia. During this time, Fortunatus returned to Grado, before or after the Treaty of Aachen. One and a half centuries later, according to Kretschmayr, "Constantine Porphyrogennetos" reports only two events from Venice's history, namely the escape from Attila and the conquest by Pippin (p. 58).

In his History of Venice, John Julius Norwich, who largely ignores the reception history, [20] emphasizes that Fortunatus, "more bitterly opposed to the regime of Galbaii, than even his uncle had been," immediately fled to the Frankish kingdom. Under the alleged leadership of Obelerius, the opposition gathered in Treviso, who finally made the breakthrough in 804. But now there were fights within the lagoon, especially between Heraclea and Malamocco, the new regiment came into a similar situation as the Galbaii before. But now Fortunatus appeared, "fresh from the court of Charlemagne with an offer". This offer consisted in the reinstatement of his person and the recognition of Franconian sovereignty over the lagoon, in return, the two Doge remained under Frankish protection safely in office. After Norwich neither Obelerio nor his brother Beatus had sympathy for the Franks, but the two brothers now had little choice. Therefore they made the Christmas in 805 the emperor in Aachen the Homagium. Obelerius even went so far as to find a wife from the women of the court who was for Norwich the "first dogaressa known to history".

Name: Giovanni VIII. Morosini oder Marcello Administrator

Reginbrand
German Bio: Reginbrand (â€  988) war der erste Bischof von Aarhus.  Er empfing 948 durch Erzbischof Adaldag von Hamburg-Bremen mit ausdrÃ¼cklicher Erlaubnis von Papst Agapitus II. die Bischofsweihe. Mit zwei weiteren BischÃ¶fen neuer BistÃ¼mer, nÃ¤mlich Hored (Oredo) in Schleswig und Leofdag in Ribe, nahm er am 7. Juni 948 an der Universalsynode von Ingelheim teil. Dies bezeichnete einen bedeutenden Fortschritt in der Geschichte der dÃ¤nischen Kirche, denn von nun an konnten alle liturgischen Feiern von einheimischen BischÃ¶fen durchgefÃ¼hrt werden.  Nach Reginbrands Tod wurden die drei DiÃ¶zesen in JÃ¼tland gemeinsam verwaltet. Erst um 1060 wurde Aarhus wieder Bischofssitz.
English Bio:
Reginbrand (  988 ) was the first bishop of Aarhus .

He received the episcopal consecration in 948 by Archbishop Adaldag of Hamburg-Bremen with the express permission of Pope Agapitus II . With two other bishops of new dioceses, namely Hored (Oredo) in Schleswig and Leofdag in Ribe , he participated in the Universal Synod of Ingelheim on 7 June 948 . This marked a significant step forward in the history of the Danish church, since from now on all liturgical celebrations were performed by local bishops.

After Reginbrand's death, the three dioceses in Jutland were jointly administered. It was not until around 1060 that Aarhus became bishop again.

Der Artikel beruht im Wesentlichen auf dem Artikel von Thelma Jexlev, Henry Bruun.
English Bio:
Peder Jensen Lodehat , Latinized Petrus Johannis Lodehat (  October 19, 1416 ) was a Danish bishop and close confidant of the regent Margarethe I.

His parents, birthplace and date of birth are unknown.

He belonged to a noble family from Zealand . This resulted in his coat of arms a men's head with a round headgear similar to a Jew's hat . Hence her nickname , which the family members never used themselves. Peder Jensen is mentioned for the first time in November 1375, when Margarethe I. the canon Peder Jensen immediately after the death of his father in Roskilde Cathedral with land ownership in Udby . In 1382 she procured for him the diocese VŠxjš . It was part of her policy to occupy the dioceses with well-educated men of the lower nobility , who were then devoted to her.[1] Their political goal was the widest possible loyal support for the election of her son Olav winning king. [2]

When the diocese of Aarhus became vacant in 1386 , Peder Jensen was transferred there. The following year he participated as a Danish Reichsrat in the election of Margarethes I as the "authorized guardian of the Reich". From then on he remained at her side as a friend and counselor until her death. In 1395 he took over the diocese of Roskilde , became Chancellor and kept the imperial seal.

He took part in important union meetings in Helsingborg and Lindholmen in 1395 and in the following year at the meeting with Gerhard VI. participated in Assens , as the question of the Lenten obligations of the Schaumburger against the newly elected King Erich first came up. In 1397 he sealed with others the Treaty of Kalmar. He supported with the means of his diocese Margarethe also financially. In 1401 he had against this a loan claim of at least 40,000 LŸbische Mark and got Skan¿r and Falsterbowith the associated customs revenue as a pledge, which was redeemed in 1407. He took special care of the nunnery founded by Margaret of the Dominicans of Saint Agnethe ( Agnes ) in Gaun¿. He was also entrusted with managing Margaret's large financial foundations for churches, monasteries, and poor people in all three kingdoms . In July 1413 he pronounced the judgment on the Lehnsgericht in Nyborg against the Holstein nobility and declared the family of Henry III. of Schauenburg-Holstein of the fief of Schleswig because of breaking law for lost.

In addition to his political work, he also campaigned for church matters. In Aarhus Cathedral he donated an altar to the Holy Cross and in Roskilde Cathedral he built a chapel dedicated to Saint Siegfried, patron saint of VŠxjš.

English Bio:
Erland from the Faroe Islands (from Bergen ,   June 13, 1308 ibidem, Faroese Erlendur , Norwegian Erlend ) was from 1269 to 1308 bishop in Kirkjub¿ur , Faroe Islands .

Erlendur was a teacher and canon in Bergen, when he was consecrated bishop of the Faroe Islands in January 1269. He played a significant role not only in church but also in politics in the Faroes and in Norway. He was, for example, one of the seven bishops who supervised the coronation and swearing-in of Erik Magnusson on July 25, 1280 in Bergen.

Erlendur had its seat in the old farm Kirkjub¿argar_ur and built next to the Magnus Cathedral . In 1298 he wrote together with Lagmann Sigurd of Shetland on behalf of Duke HŒkon Magnusson the oldest known document of the Faroe Islands, the sheep letter .

It is possible that Erlendur was also at HŒkon Magnusson's coronation to King HŒkon V. on November 1, 1299 in Nidaros , but there are no documents about it. Only on December 5, 1305 Erlendur reappears as aiding the consecration of the canons Arne Sigurdsson to the Bishop of Bergen. King HŒkon also participated in this ceremony. Erlend's position is also expressed by the fact that he was one of the sixteen clergymen who countersigned a decree of the king on December 10, 1305, in which he, among others, gave his wife Eufemia of RŸgen the island of Bygd¿y near Oslo. Then he appears in other documents of prominent contemporaries.

Later, the relationship between Bishop Erlendur and King HŒkon worsened by heavy accusations. In particular, he was accused of collecting all taxes and all the land in the Faroe Islands. Ultimately, Erlendur (and with him the church) seems to have been successful, because never before had the church in the Faroe Islands so much power and land - but the Faroese coveted on. Legend has it that Erlendur was killed in a fight in the church at Kirkjub¿ur when, in a kind of civil war, the inhabitants of the north of the Faroe Islands, on whose side he stood, were inferior to those of the south. Much more likely, however, is that he had to leave the Faroe Islands because of his growing unpopularity as a greedy tax collector.

A letter from his friend Bishop Arne von Bergen of 22 June 1308 to his colleagues on SkŒholt (Iceland) and Greenland indicates that Erlendur died on 13 June 1308 not at all in Kirkjub¿ur, but probably in Bergen. After Erlend's death, there was no bishop in the Faroe Islands for the next four to five years, because Arne von Bergen and Archbishop J¿rund of Nidaros could not agree on a successor. In the end, J¿rund's proposal prevailed after the intervention of Archbishop Nicholas of Uppsala , and Lodin of Borgund became Bishop of the Faroe Islands.

Allegedly, Erlendur is buried in Kirkjub¿ur. In 1420 the Faroese bishop Jon is said to have exhumed the German prisoner's body because there were signs that he should be canonized. Allegedly, a rune stone was found, which was said to be a praise to Erlendur in Latin and reported that his cathedral burned down, so he had them rebuilt in stone (the Magnus Cathedral).

A sculpture by Erlendur stands in the western front of the Nidaros dome in Trondheim , Norway.

Ein Reformationsstreit, der Ã¼berall im dÃ¤nisch-norwegischen Reich stattgefunden haben muss, denn ChristianÂ III. verlangte in einem Rundschreiben an alle Superintendenten die DurchfÃ¼hrung spezieller Gebetstage, da â€žsich SÃ¼nde und das BÃ¶se vermehren und Zeremonien nicht eingehalten werdenâ€œ. Riber wurde 1557 Bischof von Stavanger, obwohl er als charakterlich schwach und uninteressiert galt. Das Dansk biografisk leksikon spricht sogar vom â€žgrÃ¶ÃŸten Missgriff in der norwegischen Kirchengeschichteâ€œ.[2] Aus dieser Zeit sind keine herausragenden Dinge Ã¼berliefert, auÃŸer dass er 1564 zum Umbau des Doms von Stavanger beitrug, indem er unter anderem eine Sondersteuer zum Erhalt des heruntergekommenen Bauwerks durchsetzte.  1565 stellte man ihm den ambitionierten Gemeindepfarrer und Lehrer Jakob Matsson zur Seite, aber als dieser 1569 starb, verschlechterte sich die Zustand im Bistum noch einmal. 1571 griff der Lehnsherr von Bergenhus, Mads Skeel, ein und ernannte JÃ¸rgen Erikson (ErikssÃ¸n) zum Assistenten des nunmehr 90-jÃ¤hrigen Riber, der sich aber weigerte, etwas von seinen EinkÃ¼nften an Erikson abzutreten. Eriksen kehrte unverrichteter Dinge nach Bergen zurÃ¼ck und ging nach Kopenhagen, wo KÃ¶nig FriedrichÂ II. English Bio:
Jens Gregersen Riber or Jens Gregoriussen Riber or Jens Gregerss¿n Riber (* 1480 (?) In Ribe , Denmark ,   August 9, 1571 in Stavanger , Norway ) was the first Lutheran bishop in the Faroe Islands and later in Stavanger.

Riber was Kapellan at the Domkirche zu Bergen when he was reigned in 1540 by King Christian III. was called to the Superintendent over the Faroe Islands to introduce the Reformation in the Faroe Islands . He replaced the last Catholic Bishop çmundur îlavsson and took his seat in Kirkjub¿ur .

In 1556 or 1557 he left again the Faroe Islands. The later chronicler Lucas Debes writes that Riber had fled out of fear of pirates after they had invaded the bishopric in Kirkjub¿ur. Absalon Pederss¿n Beyer , who himself worked at the Dom church in Bergen, does not mention anything like that, but reports that Riber had gone to Copenhagen and asked for dismissal from office in the Faroes, because he had too many adversaries there and no great authority would have. [1]

The Faroese historian Hans Jacob Debes considers it likely that the Faroese struggled to accept the new denomination. A Reformation dispute that must have taken place everywhere in the Danish-Norwegian Empire, because Christian III. In a circular letter to all superintendents, it called for special prayer days to be held because "sin and evil multiply and ceremonies are not kept". In fact, many Faroese are said to have reluctantly removed tithes to the new church and held on to the Catholic faith, especially as the Reformation was imposed on the Faroes from outside. [1]

When Jens Riber left office, the diocese of Faroe Islands was laid down, and the Faroes became a provost of the Bishopric of Bj¿rgvin (Bergen) .

Riber became Bishop of Stavanger in 1557 , although he was considered weak and uninterested in character. The Dansk biografisk leksikon even speaks of the "biggest mistake in Norwegian church history". [2] From this time, no outstanding things are handed down, except that it in 1564 for the reconstruction of the Cathedral of Stavanger contributed, by imposing, among others, a special tax to maintain the run-down building.

In 1565, the ambitious parish pastor and teacher Jakob Matsson was placed at his side, but when he died in 1569, the situation in the bishopric deteriorated again. In 1571, the lord of Bergenhus , Mads Skeel, intervened and appointed J¿rgen Erikson (Erikss¿n) as assistant to the now 90-year-old Riber, who refused to relinquish some of his income to Erikson. Eriksen returned home to Bergen and went to Copenhagen, where King Frederick II finally deposed Bishop Riber and appointed Erikson as the new Stavanger superintendent.

Jens Riber learned nothing of his dismissal because he died before.

Name: Gustav Trolle

Schon 1515 geriet er deshalb in Konflikt mit dem schwedischen Reichsverweser Sten Sture dem JÃ¼ngeren, der Schweden aus der Union herauslÃ¶sen wollte und vergeblich versuchte, Trolle auf seine Seite zu ziehen. Als klar war, dass Trolle dem dÃ¤nischen KÃ¶nig Christian II. zuarbeiten wÃ¼rde, um die Union auch in Schweden zu stÃ¤rken, lieÃŸ Sture Trolles Burg AlmarestÃ¤ket im Herbst 1516 belagern. Ein militÃ¤rischer Konflikt mit DÃ¤nenkÃ¶nig Christian II. stand kurz bevor, so dass Sture, oder â€žHerr Stenâ€œ, wie er in der Sture-Chronik genannt wird, Trolle entmachten musste, bevor dieser AnhÃ¤nger unter den Adeligen Schweden sammeln konnte. Als Sture Trolles Burg 1517 einnehmen konnte, lieÃŸ er Trolle verhaften. Die Burg wurde dem Erdboden gleichgemacht und Trolle auf Beschluss des StÃ¤ndereichstags als Erzbischof abgesetzt. Dieser Beschluss, der von den Ratsmitgliedern per Siegel bekrÃ¤ftigt wurde, diente spÃ¤ter als Beweismaterial beim Stockholmer Blutbad.  Die Invasion der DÃ¤nen begann im Winter 1519â€“1520. Christian II. nahm die Entmachtung Trolles als Anlass, fÃ¼r die Wiederherstellung der Ordnung in Schweden zu sorgen, und marschierte mit seiner Armee in Schweden ein. Sein Heer bestand aus Berufssoldaten, SÃ¶ldnern, die er aus ganz Europa angeworben hatte und die erbarmungslos und kampferprobt waren. Stures MÃ¤nner waren Ã¼berwiegend Bauernsoldaten, denen Steuerfreiheit versprochen wurde, wenn sie ihr Land verteidigten. Die Schlacht bei Bogesund, heute Ulricehamn am See Ã…sundens im heutigen VÃ¤stergÃ¶tland, war eine fÃ¼r die DÃ¤nen wie auch fÃ¼r die Schweden entscheidende Schlacht. Im Kampfverlauf wurde Reichsverwalter Sten Sture der JÃ¼ngere von einer Kanonenkugel getroffen und starb wenig spÃ¤ter an seinen Verletzungen. DÃ¤nenkÃ¶nig Christian II. ging siegreich aus der Schlacht hervor, und zog weiter bis nach Stockholm. Mit dem Tod Stures fehlte eine starke FÃ¼hrungsperson auf schwedischer Seite. Seine Frau Kristina Gyllenstierna Ã¼bernahm zwar das Kommando des Widerstands gegen die Union, aber es gelang ihr nicht, eine klare Einheit hinter sich zu vereinen. SchlieÃŸlich gelang es den DÃ¤nen, Schweden im Herbst 1520 zu besetzen, wobei sich die Stadt Stockholm, unter der Leitung von Kristina Gyllenstierna, noch behaupten konnte. Christian II. lieÃŸ Trolle als Erzbischof wiedereinsetzen und erlieÃŸ eine Amnestie, die seinen Gegnern Straffreiheit garantierte, wenn er, Christian selbst, als UnionskÃ¶nig anerkannt wÃ¼rde. Kristina Gyllenstierna und die am Widerstand beteiligten schwedischen Adeligen gingen auf das Amnestieangebot ein. Am 4. November 1520 wurde Christian II. durch Erzbischof Gustav Trolle in Stockholm zum KÃ¶nig von Schweden und damit zum KÃ¶nig der gesamten Union gekrÃ¶nt.  Es folgten Festlichkeiten, die drei Tage lang andauerten und an denen ebenfalls Kristina Gyllenstierna und Adelige des Widerstands teilnahmen. Aufgrund der ausgesprochenen Amnestie fÃ¼hlte man sich sicher. Am Abend des dritten Tages aber lieÃŸ der KÃ¶nig alle schwedischen Adeligen in einen Raum rufen und um sich versammeln. Die TÃ¼ren wurden geschlossen und mit Wachen besetzt. In einem kurzen Prozess wurden die Anwesenden der Ketzerei beschuldigt, wobei Gustav Trolle eine entscheidende Rolle zukam: durch die Amnestie konnte niemand fÃ¼r den Widerstand gegen die Union verurteilt werden. Dies war durch den KÃ¶nig garantiert. Doch die Absetzung des Erzbischofs im Jahr 1517 war Ketzerei und ein Verbrechen gegen die Kirche, gegen das der KÃ¶nig keine Amnestie erlassen konnte. Der damalige Beschluss mit den Unterschriften der Ratsmitglieder wurde hervorgeholt und 94 Personen zum Tode verurteilt. Damit hatte Christian II. einen Weg gefunden, sich seiner Gegnerschaft mit einem Mal zu entledigen.  Die Hinrichtungen wurden kurz darauf auf dem Marktplatz (Stortorget) in Stockholm ausgefÃ¼hrt und dauerten 2 Tage. Man lieÃŸ die Leichen zunÃ¤chst liegen, schaffte sie dann auf eine Bergkuppe auf der benachbarten Insel SÃ¶dermalm, wo sie in einem weithin sichtbaren Feuer verbrannt wurden. Sogar die Gebeine des ehemaligen Reichsverwalters Sten Sture des JÃ¼ngeren wurden ausgegraben und mit den anderen Leichen verbrannt. Dieses Ereignis ging als das â€žStockholmer Blutbadâ€œ in die Geschichte ein.  Das Blutbad in Stockholm war AuslÃ¶ser fÃ¼r einen groÃŸangelegten Aufruhr in der schwedischen BevÃ¶lkerung. Dem jungen Adeligen Gustav Vasa gelang es, eine Armee von Bauern hinter sich zu vereinen, die im Stande war, die DÃ¤nen innerhalb von nur drei Jahren aus Schweden zu vertreiben. Vasa wurde 1523 in StrÃ¤ngnÃ¤s durch den Reichstag zum schwedischen KÃ¶nig ernannt und 1528 im Dom zu Uppsala gekrÃ¶nt.  Aufgrund der Geschehnisse erkannte Gustav Vasa Trolle nicht als Erzbischof an. Es kam zu Streitigkeiten mit dem Papst in Rom, der Trolle stÃ¼tzte. Infolgedessen wandte sich Vasa von der katholischen Kirche ab und leitete die Reformation in Schweden ein. Die Kirche wurde verstaatlicht, wobei ihr Besitz an den Staat Ã¼berging (Schwedische Staatskirche).  Bereits 1521 flÃ¼chtete Trolle wegen AufstÃ¤nden in SmÃ¥land und Dalarna nach DÃ¤nemark. Dort setzte er seinen Kampf an der Seite Christians fort. 1534 wurde er Bischof von FÃ¼nen in Odense. Bei der Schlacht von Ã˜ksnebjerg 1535 auf der Insel FÃ¼nen wurde er verwundet und starb in Gefangenschaft nach dem 11. Juni 1535 in Gottdorf.
English Bio:
Gustav Eriksson Trolls (* 1488 in Bergkvara , SmŒland ,   1535 on the island of Funen , Denmark) was the son of Erik Arvidsson trolls and Swedish archbishop.

In the genesis of the Swedish state Gustav Trolle plays a role that should not be underestimated. His support for the Danish King Christian II led to a conflict with the Swedish Governor Sten Sture the Younger and finally to his dismissal as Archbishop . This circumstance was decisive in the Stockholm bloodbath , which was initially a bitter setback for the separation of Sweden from the Kalmar Union , but significantly strengthened unity in the country. Gustave Vasa was able to fight back the Danes with the help of the rural population and later, as king, laid the foundations for the Swedish state.

After several years studying in Cologne and Rome, the scion of the Troll family was appointed in 1513 dean of Linkšping . In Sweden he was one of the most educated and powerful men of his time. A year later he became archbishop in Uppsala , where he succeeded Jakob Ulvsson .

Sweden was in the Kalmar Union since 1397 , a federation that united the states of Denmark, Sweden and Norway under a king. Each country retained its own advice. Since much of Finland was governed by Sweden, and Iceland was part of the Norwegian krone, the Kalmar Union comprised almost the entire north of Europe. Denmark was the dominant power, while in Sweden only a few nobles supported the Union. Uprising against the Union took place again and again, with the Danes always sending troops to restore order.

Like its predecessors, Trolls began a Union-friendly policy. As early as 1515, he came into conflict with the Swedish administrator Sten Sture the Younger, who wanted to liberate Sweden from the Union and tried in vain to attract trolls to his side. When it became clear that Trolls would work for the Danish King Christian II to strengthen the Union in Sweden, Sture Trolles had the castle AlmarestŠket besieged in the fall of 1516. A military conflict with Danish king Christian II was imminent, leaving Sture, or "Mr. Sten," as he is in the Sture ChronicleTrolls had to be disempowered before this follower among the nobles could collect Sweden. When Sture Trolles castle in 1517 could take, he had arrested trolls. The castle was razed to the ground and trolls deposed as archbishop by decision of the estates day . This decision, by Council members per Seal reaffirmed served later as evidence in the Stockholm Bloodbath .

The invasion of the Danes began in the winter of 1519-1520. Christian II took the disempowerment of Trolles as an opportunity to restore order in Sweden and invaded his army in Sweden. His army consisted of professional soldiers, mercenaries whom he had recruited from all over Europe and who were merciless and battle-hardened. Sturgeon men were predominantly peasant soldiers who were promised tax exemption if they defended their land. The Battle of Bogesund , today Ulricehamn on the lake sundens in today's VŠstergštlandwas a decisive battle for the Danes as well as for the Swedes. In the course of the fight, Reich Administrator Sten Sture the Younger was hit by a cannonball and died shortly afterwards of his injuries. Danish king Christian II won the battle victoriously and moved on to Stockholm . With the death Stures missing a strong leader on the Swedish side. His wife Kristina GyllenstiernaAlthough taking the command of resistance to the Union, but she managed to unite a clear unity behind them. Eventually, the Danes succeeded in occupying Sweden in the fall of 1520, with the city of Stockholm, under the leadership of Kristina Gyllenstierna, still able to hold its own. Christian II had trolls reinstated as archbishop and issued an amnesty that guaranteed his opponents impunity if he, Christian himself, would be recognized as a Union King . Kristina Gyllenstierna and the Swedish nobles involved in the resistance went into the offer of amnesty. On November 4, 1520 Christian II was crowned King of Sweden by Archbishop Gustav Trolle in Stockholm and thus the king of the entire Union.


This was followed by festivities that lasted for three days and were also attended by Kristina Gyllenstierna and the nobles of the Resistance. Because of the pronounced amnesty you felt safe. On the evening of the third day, however, the king summoned all Swedish noblemen to a room and assembled. The doors were closed and staffed with guards. In a short process, those present became heresyaccused Gustav Trolle of decisive role: no one could be condemned by the amnesty for resisting the Union. This was guaranteed by the king. But the deposition of the archbishop in 1517 was heresy and a crime against the church, against which the king could not issue an amnesty. The then decision with the signatures of the council members was brought out and 94 people sentenced to death. Thus Christian II had found a way to get rid of his opponent suddenly.

The executions were carried out shortly thereafter in the market place ( Stortorget ) in Stockholm and lasted 2 days. The bodies were first left lying, then they were taken to a hilltop on the neighboring island of Sšdermalm , where they were burned in a fire that was visible from afar. Even the bones of former administrator Sten Sture the Younger were dug up and burned with the other bodies. This event went down in history as the " Stockholm Carnage ".

The bloodbath in Stockholm triggered a large-scale uprising in the Swedish population. The young nobleman Gustav Vasa managed to unite an army of peasants capable of expelling the Danes from Sweden within just three years. Vasa was appointed in 1523 in StrŠngnŠs by the Reichstag to the Swedish king and crowned in 1528 in the cathedral of Uppsala .

Due to the events Gustav Vasa did not recognize trolls as archbishop. There were quarrels with the pope in Rome , who supported trolls. As a result, Vasa turned away from the Catholic Church and initiated the Reformation in Sweden. The church was nationalized, with her ownership passed to the state ( Swedish state church ).

Already in 1521 Troll fled to Denmark for riots in SmŒland and Dalarna . There he continued his fight at the side of Christian. In 1534 he became bishop of Funen in Odense . At the Battle of ¯ksnebjerg 1535 on the island of Funen he was wounded and died in captivity after June 11, 1535 in Gottdorf .

At the place where the aristocratic opponents of the Union were burned, stands today the St. Catherine's Church ( Katarina kyrka ). The church burnt down twice since its construction in 1695.
When trolls were deposed in 1517 as archbishop, councilor Bishop Brask hid a note under his seal. On this note was written: "For this sealing I was coerced and forced". Brask escaped his execution. The note saved his life.
Trolles Castle AlmarestŠket was built on a narrow spot in Lake MŠlaren and guarded the entrance to important cities such as Sigtuna and Uppsala . The remains of the bishop's castle can still be seen on the grounds of the farm "AlmarestŠkets HerrgŒrd". The nearby town StŠket north of Stockholm had in 2005 exactly 2093 inhabitants.
According to legend , on November 7 at midnight each night, the spirits of the 94 executed men are meeting in Stockholm's marketplace and dragging down the streets as a white fog.

English Bio:
Jakob Madsen Vejle (also: Jacob Matthias Villus, Jacon Matthiesen Viellg , born July 24, 1538 in Vejle ,   September 24, 1606 in Odense ) was a Danish Protestant bishop of Funen .

Jakob Madsen was the son of the mayor in Vejle Nils Madsen (  1539) and his wife Ellen (Lene) Kristen (  1556), the daughter of the mayor Nils Kristen in Varde . [1] He had initially attended school in his hometown. In 1548 he moved to the school in Ribe , 1551 to the school in Odense , 1553 to the Viborg school and 1555 he moved to the University of Copenhagen . After completing his academic education in 1561 he traveled to the University of Louvain and to the University of Paris . He continued his studies on 4 December 1562 [2] at the University of WittenbergOn August 10, 1563, he obtained the academic degree of Master of Philosophy there. [3]

Returning to Denmark, he first worked at the Frauenkirche in Copenhagen, held lectures at the university and waited for the opportunity to use his person more effectively in the Danish civil service. In 1565 he became rector of the city school in Ribe, took over in 1567 a parish office at the Cathedral of Ribe and received in 1568 a canon in the cathedral chapter . As a theological expert, he was involved in 1572 in the witch trials in Ribe and later on rules for weddings. In 1587 he was elected Bishop of Funen. However, his community wished him back. At the king's intervention, he was bishop in 1588 in the church of St. Knud in Odense by his cousinHans Laugesen from Ribe consecrated. He participated in the removal of Catholic relics in his diocese and banned in 1595 the Konkordienformel . In 1596 he took part in the solemn coronation of Christian IV .
