English Bio:
Thomas Hansen Kingo (born December 15, 1634 in Slangerup Commune ,   October 14, 1703 in Odense ) was a Danish Lutheran bishop and poet of hymns , the so-called Kingopsalmen .

Thomas Kingo is the son of Karen S¿rensdatter and the weaver Hans Thomsen Kingo, whose ancestors came from Scotland. [1] Although coming from a humble background, she allowed her son to school in Slangerup and later in Frederiksborg , where he, among other literary history learned and in 1654 completed his schooling. 1658 followed the theology exam .

He was then a private tutor in Frederiksborg and from 1659 on the estate Vedbygaard, where he wrote his first poems . In the Danish Biographical Encyclopedia (1887-1905) it is emphasized that the humor and closeness of these poems were unusual for their time - but also for his later secular work . [2]

1661 Thomas Kingo auxiliary pastor and 1668 finally parish priest in his birthplace Slangerup. There he married the pastor's daughter Sille Balkenborg from Norway, who had three daughters from previous marriage. The marriage remained childless and his wife died in 1670. To her he dedicated the sage Chrysillis, you min Verden's Guld (Chrysillis, you my gold of the world). About four years later, he married the widow of his steward, Johanne Laurdsdatter Lund, 13 years his senior. This marriage was to last 20 years, but is not described as happy, which his Danish biographer in the 19th century, however, describes as normal for that time, where not so much emphasis was placed on marriages out of love.

In those years he came into fierce conflict with the satirical poet Jacob Worm . Both wrote one above the other abusive verses, of which Kingos Kalot is the most famous poem. It appeared anonymous then. In addition, he created in his time as parish priest a number of poems, which can be divided into three categories:

love poems
Homeland poems
Spiritual poetry
The Danish Biographical Encyclopedia describes its secular poetry as not particularly outstanding, where seldom does the fog of tastelessness clear and poetic inspiration emerge . [3] His patriotic verses dealing mostly with the glorification of the absolutist ruler Christian V. , but this was common at that time, not only in Denmark. These works are under significant influence from Germany.

Kingo's spiritual poetry (in Danish , it is called the psalm seal ), however, enjoys a far higher status. Here he went for his time new ways, which was marked by a certain stagnation after the Reformation (in Denmark in 1536). Although he was considered a good pastor, this lively work was probably decisive for the fact that he was appointed Bishop of Funen in 1677 . 1679 followed the inclusion Kingos in the peerage. In 1682 he became a doctor of theology.

In 1683 he was commissioned by the king to publish a new hymn book, as the previous one by Hans Thomiss¿n (1569) was no longer up to date for the taste of the time. After six years of work, the first part ( Vinterparten - winter part) of the Danmarks og Norges Kirke forordnede Salmebog ( Decree Hymnal for the Church of Denmark and Norway) appeared. For this Kingo had set up his own printing house at his bishopric. The book contains 267 songs for the church year between the 1st of Advent and Easter, half of which are Kingos own works. However, it did not come to the hoped-for extradition to all communities in the kingdom. Instead, appeared in 1699 Den Forordnede Kirkepsalmebog , which still contained 85 Kingopsalmen . Many of them are still in the hymnbooks of the Danish and Norwegian national churches and like Grundtvig's hymns are part of the Nordic spiritual heritage.

Already in 1694 his wife Johanne died. At age 60, Kingo remarried. This time a 30 years younger woman, Birgitte Balslev, doctor's daughter from Odense. This marriage is described as happy, but remained childless.

Thomas Kingo suffered in his last years of stones and Wundrose . He died in 1703 at the age of 68 years. His grave chapel designed by Thomas Quellinus is located in Fraugde Kirke near Odense .

While Kingo's work is regarded as the culmination of the Danish baroque poetry , his hymns in Denmark and Norway are still part of the hymnbooks today, and especially in the Faroe Islands they are a living part of the local heritage - an independent musical genre. In Odense and Slangerup remind monuments and epitaphs (as by Thomas Quellinus ) to the poet, but his greatest monument are the psalms that live today in Scandinavia.

You, O Lord, know best what I need, 
also happiness is in your hands. 
And what you do in every way for the best, 
you already see; my soul, what more do you want? 
Just let God do it!

(Thomas Kingo: Nu rinder solen op af ¿sterlide 1674)

In the Faeroe Islands Kingos Hymnal of 1699 has gained importance, which is still noticeable today. Based on the Kingopsalmen, developed a separate genre of Faroese music , which until the 19th Century without accompaniment of instruments such as the church organ got along, which slowly after the construction of the Faroese wooden churches were introduced. The German Faroese traveler Carl Julian von Graba wrote in his diary in 1828 , led on a trip to Faroe to the Kingolieder the Faroese:

"The singing was the most dreadful thing I have ever heard in my life; Everyone roars the first sound that comes to mind. "

Of course, this does not change the meaning of the songs, nor does Graba have any respect for the high spiritual level of education of the common people.

Around 1900, the Kingopsalmen lost their dominant position in the religious life of the Faroese , but were still locally kept alive as the hymn.

Known in this context is the community of Tj¿rnuv’k in the extreme north of the island Streymoy , where only in 1983 an organ was introduced. For almost three centuries, people relied primarily on Kingo. The village's Kingo Choir played a pivotal role in the House of the North Project's 1988 record of the Faroese Kingo vocal tradition. As early as 1984, the Suite Kingol¿g by Kristian Blak , which had the old songs of various villages as a basis.

The Kingo group from Tj¿rnuv’k not only performed at the national art festival in 2001, but was also invited to the festivities by the Copenhagen bishop in 2003 . Eiv¿r P‡lsd—ttir provided modern interpretations of the Kingopssalmen, which since 2003 have also been mentioned as an important part of music education in the Faroe Islands. Listastevna F¿roya, the national art festival of the time, was themed Kingos, and special Kingo services were held in various village churches.

The original kongo singing books can be found in the archives of the Faroese National Library , but are also exhibited in the Historical Museum . In the hymnbook of the Faroese national church there are 31 Kingopsalmen, including one in old Danish, while all others were translated into Faroese .

English Bio:
êsleifur Gissurarson (* 1006 ,   July 5, 1080 ) was the first bishop of Iceland and Greenland .

In 1000, the then Republic of Iceland took over Christianity by parliamentary decision as state religion. The Christianization was initiated by the brought along Irish slaves and their influence and strengthened by the sending of missionaries in the 10th century.

êsleifur Gissurarson, the son of _—rd’s _—roddsd—ttir and Gissur Teitsson from the Mosfellingar -Clan received his ecclesiastical training in East Westphalian Herford and was consecrated in 1056 by the Archbishop of Bremen Adalbert to the first bishop of Iceland and Greenland . [1]

He settled in Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland , where his family owned land, and founded the first Icelandic school there. At the same time he also took over the godhood of his father.

His wife was Dalla _orvaldsd—ttir . With this he had three sons, _orvaldur , Teitur and Gissur , who took over after the death of his father's episcopate. One of his students was J—n …gmundarson , who later served as Bishop of H—lar .

When êsleifur died in Sk‡lholt on July 5, 1080, he had held the episcopal see there for 24 years. [2]

His son Gissur êsleifsson followed him in the office.

Heinricus danach Bischof von Orkney

Johannes von Pentlar vorher Bischof von Orkney
Eskil
German Bio: Eskil von Lund (* um 1100; â€  1181) war ein dÃ¤nischer Geistlicher, MÃ¶nch und Erzbischof von Lund, das damals zu DÃ¤nemark gehÃ¶rte.  In jungen Jahren verbrachte Eskil viele Jahre im Ausland, meist in Hildesheim und im Clairvaux. Hier kam er in Kontakt zu Abt Bernhard von Clairvaux, einem der bedeutendsten KirchenmÃ¤nner seiner Zeit. 1131 wurde Eskil Dompropst in Lund, 1134 Bischof in Roskilde und 1137 schlieÃŸlich Erzbischof in Lund als Nachfolger seines Onkels Ascer. Als Bischof wurde er in einen Streit mit dem dÃ¤nischen KÃ¶nig Erik Emune hineingezogen, als Erzbischof kÃ¤mpfte er gegen dessen Neffen Olof, der versuchte, KÃ¶nig zu werden. Schon vor seiner Ernennung zum Erzbischof stiftete Eskil KlÃ¶ster, so u.Â a. 1135 das Kloster St.Â Peter in NÃ¦stved, 1144 Kloster Herrevad in Schonen und 1145 Kloster Esrom (Esrum) auf Seeland. Im selben Jahr konnte der Dom zu Lund von ihm in Anwesenheit von BischÃ¶fen aus ganz Skandinavien eingeweiht werden.  Als ein neues Erzbistum in Nidaros eingerichtet werden sollte, dem Norwegen, Island und die anderen Stifte im Westen angehÃ¶ren sollten, unternahm der Erzbischof von Bremen einen letzten Versuch, die kirchliche Macht Ã¼ber Skandinavien zu halten. Mit der UnterstÃ¼tzung durch Kaiser Barbarossa versuchte er Eskil davon abzuhalten, doch gelang es diesem, sich gegenÃ¼ber seinen Widersachern mit pÃ¤pstlicher UnterstÃ¼tzung durchzusetzen. Dazu reiste er nach Clairvaux und von dort aus im Jahr 1156 weiter nach Rom. Eine Zeit lang war Eskil Gefangener des Kaisers. 1164 erhielt er als pÃ¤pstlicher Legat den Auftrag, ein drittes Erzbistum in Skandinavien zu grÃ¼nden. Die Wahl fiel auf Alt-Uppsala und erster Erzbischof wurde Stefan von Uppsala.  Durch einen langen Streit mit WaldemarÂ I. war Eskil gezwungen, von 1161 bis 1168 im Ausland zu leben. Er verbrachte die meiste Zeit in Clairvaux. Erst durch die Vermittlung von Absalon von Lund konnte er zurÃ¼ckkehren. SpÃ¤ter nahm er 1169 am Feldzug gegen die Wenden und am Krieg von 1171 teil. Zuvor hatte er Waldemars Sohn Knut in der Klosterkirche von Ringsted zum KÃ¶nig von DÃ¤nemark gekrÃ¶nt. Der Papst erlaubte Eskil schlieÃŸlich 1177 von seinem Amt zurÃ¼ckzutreten. Sein Nachfolger wurde Absalon von Lund, wÃ¤hrend Eskil MÃ¶nch in Clairvaux wurde.
English Bio:
Eskil of Lund (* 1100,   1181 ) was a Danish clergyman, monk and archbishop of Lund , which then belonged to Denmark.

At a young age Eskil spent many years abroad, mostly in Hildesheim and Clairvaux . Here he came into contact with Abbot Bernard of Clairvaux , one of the most important churchmen of his time. 1131 was Eskil provost in Lund, 1134 bishop in Roskilde and in 1137 finally Archbishop in Lund, succeeding his uncle Ascer . As a bishop, he was involved in a dispute with the Danish king Erik Emune , as archbishop he fought against his nephew Olof, who tried to become king. Even before his appointment as archbishop donated Eskil monasteries, so u. a. 1135 the monastery of St. Peter in N¾stved, 1144 Monastery Herrevad in Schonen and 1145 Monastery Esrom (Esrum) on Zealand . In the same year, the cathedral of Lund was inaugurated by him in the presence of bishops from all over Scandinavia.

When a new archdiocese was to be established in Nidaros , to which Norway , Iceland, and the other pens in the west belonged, the Archbishop of Bremen made a last attempt to keep ecclesiastical power over Scandinavia. With the support of Emperor Barbarossa he tried to prevent Eskil, but this managed to prevail over his adversaries with papal support. For this he traveled to Clairvaux and from there in 1156 on to Rome. For a time Eskil was a prisoner of the Emperor. In 1164 he was appointed as a papal legate to found a third archdiocese in Scandinavia. The choice fell on Old Uppsala and became first archbishopStefan from Uppsala .

Through a long dispute with Waldemar I Eskil was forced to live from 1161 to 1168 abroad. He spent most of his time in Clairvaux. Only through the mediation of Absalon of Lund he could return. Later he took part in 1169 in the campaign against the Wends and the war of 1171. He had previously crowned Waldemar's son Knut in the monastery church of Ringsted as King of Denmark. The pope finally allowed Eskil to resign from office in 1177. His successor was Absalon of Lund, while Eskil became a monk in Clairvaux.

Als Sohn von Sven Torgunnson und dessen Frau Inga gehÃ¶rte Asker zur damaligen Oberschicht und war mit dem dÃ¤nischen KÃ¶nigshaus verwandt. Am 18. November 1089 wurde er zunÃ¤chst zum Bischof von Lund geweiht, unterstand jedoch noch dem Erzbistum Bremen-Hamburg. Auf einer Reise 1095/96 zu Papst PaschalisÂ II., den KÃ¶nig Erik um Vermittlung in einem Streit mit dem Erzbistum Hamburg bitten wollte, sprach der KÃ¶nig auch den Wunsch nach einem eigenen Erzbistum fÃ¼r den Norden aus. Weitere Verhandlungen mit einem Legaten 1102/03 verliefen offenbar positiv, da bereits in einem Brief des Papstes vom 8. Mai 1104 von einem Erzbistum Lund die Rede ist. Somit wurde die kirchliche UnabhÃ¤ngigkeit vom Erzbistum Bremen-Hamburg erreicht und Lund zum kirchlichen Zentrum DÃ¤nemarks, dem auch die Kirchen von Island, Norwegen und Schweden unterstanden. Von diesem Zeitpunkt an war Asker Erzbischof.  Asker hatte mehrere BrÃ¼der, die ebenfalls in hohen Ã„mtern waren. Eskil, der Sohn von Askers Bruder Kristian, wurde nach Askers Tod dessen Nachfolger.
English Bio:
Asker (*?;   May 5, 1137 ), also Ascer, Asser, Asger or Asker Svennson, was a Danish clergyman and the first archbishop of Lund , which then belonged to Denmark .

Asker's son Sven Torgunnson and his wife Inga Asker belonged to the then upper class and was related to the Danish royal family. On 18 November 1089 he was first consecrated bishop of Lund, but was still subordinate to the archbishopric of Bremen-Hamburg . On a journey in 1095/96 to Pope Paschal II , whom King Erik wanted to ask for mediation in a dispute with the archbishopric of Hamburg, the king also expressed the desire for a separate archbishopric for the north. Further negotiations with a legate1102/03 apparently went well, as already in a letter from the Pope dated 8 May 1104 by an archdiocese Lund is mentioned. Thus, the ecclesiastical independence was achieved by the Archbishopric of Bremen-Hamburg and Lund the ecclesiastical center of Denmark, which was also the churches of Iceland , Norway and Sweden . From that time on Asker was archbishop.

Asker had several brothers who were also in high office. Eskil , the son of Asker's brother Kristian, became his successor after Askers death.

Name: Absalon
German Bio: Absalon (* 1128 in Fjenneslev; â€  21. MÃ¤rz 1201 in SorÃ¸ auf Seeland in DÃ¤nemark) war ein Bischof von Roskilde und Erzbischof von Lund (heute Schweden), Kirchen- und KlostergrÃ¼nder, HeerfÃ¼hrer und Berater der DÃ¤nenkÃ¶nige Waldemar I. der GroÃŸe (1157â€“1182) und Knut VI. (1182â€“1202). Der Erzbischof ist auch als Axel von Lund bekannt und als eine der bedeutendsten Gestalten der dÃ¤nischen Kirchengeschichte des Mittelalters in die Annalen eingegangen. Er trieb die dÃ¤nischen MachtansprÃ¼che im Ostseeraum voran.  Absalon stammt aus dem einflussreichen Adelsgeschlecht der Hvide (Weiss); sein Vater war Asser Rig (ungefÃ¤hr 1080â€“1151), Freund von Knud Lavard und der mÃ¤chtigste Mann des Reiches, seine Mutter vermutlich dessen Ehefrau Inger Eriksdatter. In seinem Elternhaus wuchs der spÃ¤tere KÃ¶nig Waldemar I. auf. Mit ihm verband ihn eine lebenslange ZiehbrÃ¼der-Freundschaft.[1] Absalons Ã¤lterer Bruder war Esbern Snare.  Absalon studierte in Paris Theologie und Kirchenrecht. Er schloss Freundschaft mit dem Kanoniker Vilhelm des Klosters St. Genoveva, den er so schÃ¤tzen lernte, dass er ihn spÃ¤ter zum Abt erst Ã¼ber das Kloster EskilsÃ¸, spÃ¤ter Ã¼ber das Kloster Ã†belholt berief. 1157 war er im Gefolge Waldemars bei den Vergleichsverhandlungen zwischen den MitkÃ¶nigen Knut und Sven in Roskilde und entkam dort nur knapp dem Mordanschlag Svens. SpÃ¤ter beteiligte sich Absalon und sein Bruder Esbern Snare an der Schlacht auf der Grathe Hede (bei Silkeborg), bei der Sven, ein Konkurrent Waldemars um den Thron DÃ¤nemarks, getÃ¶tet wurde.  Mit 30 Jahren wurde er Bischof von Roskilde und mit 50 Primas der dÃ¤nisch-schwedischen Kirche und als Nachfolger Eskils Erzbischof von Lund in Schonen. Dass er 1167 am Ã–resund ein Kloster grÃ¼ndete, aus dem die dÃ¤nische Hauptstadt Kopenhagen erwuchs, ist inzwischen widerlegt.[2] Mit Waldemar I. und Absalon erhielt das durch den â€žPrinzenkriegâ€œ geschwÃ¤chte DÃ¤nemark wieder zwei fÃ¤hige und energische Potentaten an der weltlichen und geistlichen Spitze des Reiches, die die dÃ¤nische Hegemonie im Ostseeraum vorantrieben. Beide konzentrierten sich zunÃ¤chst auf die Eroberung der slawischen Insel RÃ¼gen und der Vernichtung des heidnischen GÃ¶tzenkults der einheimischen Ranen.  Im Mai 1168 erwies sich der Zeitpunkt dafÃ¼r reif. Eine vereinigte Flotten- und Heeresmacht der verbÃ¼ndeten DÃ¤nen, Mecklenburger und Pommern unter dem Oberbefehl Absaolons landete an der WestkÃ¼ste RÃ¼gens. Danach marschierten die Truppen unter FÃ¼hrung Waldemars und Absalons auf Kap Arkona zu. Eine wochenlange Belagerung des Hauptheiligtums der Insel begann. Die ranischen Verteidiger Arkonas unter ihren FÃ¼rsten Jaromar I. und Tezlaw kapitulierten angesichts der feindlichen Ãœbermacht am 15. Juni 1168, nach anderen Quellen, bereits zu Pfingsten, ohne grÃ¶ÃŸeren Widerstand. Ranische UnterhÃ¤ndler unterbreiteten Absalon, der den groÃŸen hÃ¶lzernen GÃ¶tzen Svantovit verbrennen lieÃŸ, die Kapitulation und verhinderten damit die ErstÃ¼rmung und Niederbrennung der Tempelburg. Die archÃ¤ologische StÃ¤tte Jaromarsburg auf Arkona erinnert heute noch daran. AuÃŸerdem musste von der Priesterschaft der Tempelschatz ausgeliefert und die Annahme des Christentums garantiert werden. Der Feldzug endete damit, dass Mecklenburg der deutschen und das FÃ¼rstentum RÃ¼gen der dÃ¤nischen Herrschaft unterworfen wurde. Die PommernherzÃ¶ge Bogislaw I. und Kasimir I. sahen sich bei der Abfindung betrogen und zogen sich als BÃ¼ndnispartner DÃ¤nemarks zurÃ¼ck. Absalon und sein KÃ¶nig wurden nun entschiedene Gegner Pommerns.[3]  Als Erzbischof Eskil 1177 sein Amt niederlegte, bestimmte er Absalon gegen dessen Willen zu seinem Nachfolger. Absalon fÃ¼rchtete, seine Machtbasis in Seeland zu verlieren. Deshalb erlaubte ihm der Papst, neben seinem Erzbischofsamt weiterhin Bischof von Roskilde zu bleiben.[4]  Sein DrÃ¤ngen auf AbfÃ¼hrung des Zehnten und strenge DurchfÃ¼hrung des PriesterzÃ¶libats fÃ¼hrte 1181 zum Bauern- und Priesteraufstand in Schonen und u.Â a. zur â€žSchlacht an der DÃ¶sjebroâ€œ.  Seine Reiterstatue steht auf dem HÃ¸jbro Platz in Kopenhagen. Sein Nachfolger (1201â€“1222) in Lund wurde Andreas Sunononis (dÃ¤n. Suneson).  Auf Absalons Veranlassung verfasste Saxo Grammaticus zwischen 1185 und 1208 die 16 BÃ¼cher der Gesta Danorum oder Â»Historia DanicaÂ«, eines der Quellenwerke zur nordischen Geschichts- und Sagenwelt.  Absalons Ã¤lterer Bruder Esbern Asserson Snare lieÃŸ die Burg von Kalundborg errichten. 1179 baute oder erwarb er die Kirche von Ubby.  Nach Absalon von Lund ist die Klasse von Kommando- und UnterstÃ¼tzungsschiffen der dÃ¤nischen Marine sowie das ihr zugehÃ¶rige Schiff Absalon benannt.
English Bio:
Absalon (* 1128 in Fjenneslev ,   March 21, 1201 in Sor¿ on Zealand in Denmark ) was a bishop of Roskilde and Archbishop of Lund (now Sweden ), church and monastery founders, army commander and adviser to the Danish kings Waldemar I the Great (1157 -1182) and Knut VI. (1182-1202). The archbishop is also known as Axel von Lund and one of the most important figures of the Danish church history of the Middle Ages in the annalsreceived. He pushed the Danish claims to power in the Baltic Sea region.

Absalon comes from the influential noble family of Hvide (Weiss); his father was Asser Rig (about 1080-1151), friend of Knud Lavard and the king's most powerful man, his mother probably his wife Inger Eriksdatter. In his parents' house, the later King Waldemar I grew up . A lifelong brother-brother friendship connected him with him. [1] Absalon's older brother was Esbern Snare .

Absalon studied theology and Canon Law in Paris . He made friends with the canon Vilhelm of the monastery of St. Genoveva , whom he learned to appreciate so much that he later called him abbot first through Eskils¿ Monastery and later through Klosterbelholt Abbey . In 1157 he was in the wake of Waldemar in the settlement negotiations between the co-kings Knut and Sven in Roskilde and escaped there just narrowly the assassination attempt Svens. Later Absalon and his brother Esbern Snare participated in the battle on the Grathe Hede (near Silkeborg), in which Sven, a competitor of Waldemar for the throne of Denmark, was killed.

At age 30, he became Bishop of Roskilde and with 50 Primate of the Danish-Swedish Church and as successor Eskils Archbishop of Lund in SkŒne . The fact that he founded a monastery in …resund in 1167 , from which the Danish capital Copenhagen grew, has since been refuted. [2] With Waldemar I. Absalon and received by the "Prince war" weakened Denmark again two capable and energetic potentates to the temporal and spiritual tip of the realm that drove the Danish hegemony in the Baltic Sea area. Both initially focused on the conquest of the Slavic island of RŸgen and the destruction of the pagan idolatry of the nativeRanen .

In May 1168, the time proved ripe. A united naval and army power of the allied Danes, Mecklenburg and Pomerania under the command of Absaolons landed on the west coast of Ruegen . After that, the troops, led by Waldemar and Absalons, marched towards Cape Arkona . A weeks-long siege of the island's main sanctuary began. The Iranian defenders Arkonas under their princes Jaromar I and Tezlaw capitulated in the face of hostile superiority on 15 June 1168, according to other sources, already at Pentecost, without much resistance. Ranish negotiators submitted Absalon, who Svantovit the great wooden idolburned down, the surrender and thus prevented the storming and burning of the temple castle. The archaeological site of Jaromarsburg on Arkona is still reminiscent of it today. In addition, the priesthood had to deliver the temple treasury and guarantee the acceptance of Christianity . The campaign ended with Mecklenburg being subject to German rule and the Principality of RŸgen to Danish rule. The Pomeranian dukes Bogislaw I and Casimir I saw themselves cheated on the severance pay and retired as allies of Denmark. Absalon and his king were now decided opponents of Pomerania. [3]

When Archbishop Eskil resigned in 1177, he designated Absalon against his will as his successor. Absalon feared losing his power base in Zealand. Therefore, the Pope allowed him to continue to remain Bishop of Roskilde in addition to his Archbishop's Office. [4]

His insistence on the removal of tithing and strict execution of the priestly celibacy led in 1181 to the peasant and priest rebellion in Schonen and u. a. to the "Battle of Dšsjebro".

His equestrian statue stands on H¿jbro Square in Copenhagen. His successor (1201-1222) in Lund was Andreas Sunononis (Danish Suneson).

At Absalon's instigation, Saxo Grammaticus wrote the 16 books of the Gesta Danorum or Historia Danica between 1185 and 1208 , one of the source works on Norse history and mythology.

Absalon's older brother Esbern Asserson Snare had the castle built by Kalundborg . In 1179 he built or acquired the church of Ubby .

After Absalon of Lund the class of command and support ships of the Danish Navy and its associated ship Absalon is named.

Name: Jakob Erlandsen
German Bio: Jakob Erlandsen (* im 12. oder 13. Jahrhundert; â€  18. Februar 1274 auf RÃ¼gen) war Erzbischof von Lund. Seine Eltern hieÃŸen Erland und Caecilie.  Er nahm als Dompropst in Lund als Advokat fÃ¼r Erik Plogpenning 1245 am ersten Konzil in Lyon teil. Aber er stimmte gegen den Wunsch des KÃ¶nigs fÃ¼r Niels Stigsen als Bischof von Roskilde. Daraufhin wurden seine kirchlichen EinkÃ¼nfte und sein Erbe beschlagnahmt. SpÃ¤ter kam es zu einem Vergleich mit dem KÃ¶nig. 1250 wurde er zum Bischof von Roskilde ernannt. Auf Veranlassung des Papstes erhielt er sein Gut zurÃ¼ck und Kopenhagen dazu. Kopenhagen erhielt von ihm 1254 sein erstes Stadtrecht. Im selben Jahr wurde er Erzbischof in Lund. Er errichtete Schulen in Roskilde und Lund. Er geriet in einen schweren Konflikt mit KÃ¶nig Christoffer, weil er den absoluten Primat der Kirche Ã¼ber alles weltliche Recht vertrat.  Auf der Synode von Vejle 1256 wurde beschlossen, dass jedwede Gewalt gegen einen Bischof oder Gefangennahme eines Bischofs zum Interdikt fÃ¼hre.  Im Konflikt mit dem KÃ¶nig wurden ihm alle Privilegien abgesprochen. Er weigerte sich, den Sohn des KÃ¶nigs Erik als Thronfolger zu krÃ¶nen und verbÃ¼ndete sich mit den Feinden des KÃ¶nigs, so dass er 1259 gefangengesetzt wurde. Er wurde nach dem Tode KÃ¶nig Christoffers, der im selben Jahr starb, von der KÃ¶niginwitwe Margarete Sambiria freigelassen. Er setzte seinen Widerstand gegen das KÃ¶nigshaus fort, hielt sich aber meist im benachbarten Ausland auf.  1272 legte er seinen Fall dem Papst in Rom vor, wo er zu einem Vergleich aufgefordert wurde.  Als er aus Rom zurÃ¼ckkam, wurde er 1274 in RÃ¼gen mit einem Schuss aus einer Armbrust ermordet, wie eine neuere Untersuchung der Leiche ergeben hat.
English Bio:
Jakob Erlandsen (* in the 12th or 13th century;   18th February 1274 on complaints ) was Archbishop of Lund . His parents were named Erland and Cecilie.

He participated as a provost in Lund as a lawyer for Erik Plogpenning in 1245 at the first council in Lyon . But he voted against the king's request for Niels Stigsen as Bishop of Roskilde. As a result, his church income and inheritance were confiscated. Later it came to a comparison with the king. In 1250 he was appointed Bishop of Roskilde . At the instigation of the Pope, he received his estate back and Copenhagen . Copenhagen received from him in 1254 his first city __law . In the same year he became archbishop in Lund. He built schools in Roskilde and Lund. He got into a serious conflict with King Christofferbecause he represented the absolute primacy of the church over all secular law.

At the Synod of Vejle in 1256 it was decided that any violence against a bishop or the capture of a bishop would lead to interdict .

In conflict with the king, all privileges were denied him. He refused to crown the son of King Erik as heir to the throne and allied himself with the enemies of the king, so that he was imprisoned in 1259. He was released after the death of King Christoffers, who died the same year, by the Queen's Dowager Margaret Sambiria . He continued his resistance to the royal house, but mostly stayed in neighboring countries.

In 1272 he presented his case to the pope in Rome , where he was asked to make a settlement.

When he returned from Rome, he was murdered in 1274 in RŸgen with a shot from a crossbow, as revealed by a recent investigation of the corpse.

English Bio:
Peder Bang (  June 23, 1277 ) was from 1254 to 1277 Bishop of Roskilde .

He became the successor to Jacob Erlandsen when this archbishop of Lund became. He was the sister-son of Jacob Erlandsen and his most faithful follower. His father is unknown.

When King Christoph I captured the archbishop on February 6, 1259, Peder Bang fiercely resisted. On April 9, 1259 he imposed the interdict over his diocese, and in April of the same year he moved with the army of Prince Jaromar II. , His uncle, [1] of complaints to Copenhagen, it conquered and destroyed the castle.

On May 29, 1259 King Christoph died suddenly in Ribe . Queen Dowager Margaret Sambiria mobilized the farmers of Zealand, but Jaromar inflicted a bloody defeat on them. In the subsequent argument, the bishop proved both the young King Erik Klipping and the Queen's widow with the excommunication . However, he had to go out with the now-released archbishop. There he had to experience that Pope Alexander IV transferred the administration of his diocese to his adversary Tyge von Arhus.

In 1268 he most likely moved with the archbishop to Rome, where he remained for several years. It seemed possible to make a comparison between the counterparties. On the way home to Denmark, the archbishop was murdered in February 1274 on RŸgen. Peder Bang traveled alone, and in May 1274, he and the king were compared.

Neben seinem politischen Wirken setzte er sich auch fÃ¼r die kirchlichen Belange ein. English Bio:
Peder Jensen Lodehat , Latinized Petrus Johannis Lodehat (  October 19, 1416 ) was a Danish bishop and close confidant of the regent Margarethe I.

His parents, birthplace and date of birth are unknown.

He belonged to a noble family from Zealand . This resulted in his coat of arms a men's head with a round headgear similar to a Jew's hat . Hence her nickname , which the family members never used themselves. Peder Jensen is mentioned for the first time in November 1375, when Margarethe I. the canon Peder Jensen immediately after the death of his father in Roskilde Cathedral with land ownership in Udby . In 1382 she procured for him the diocese VŠxjš . It was part of her policy to occupy the dioceses with well-educated men of the lower nobility , who were then devoted to her.[1] Their political goal was the widest possible loyal support for the election of her son Olav winning king. [2]

When the diocese of Aarhus became vacant in 1386 , Peder Jensen was transferred there. The following year he participated as a Danish Reichsrat in the election of Margarethes I as the "authorized guardian of the Reich". From then on he remained at her side as a friend and counselor until her death. In 1395 he took over the diocese of Roskilde , became Chancellor and kept the imperial seal.

He took part in important union meetings in Helsingborg and Lindholmen in 1395 and in the following year at the meeting with Gerhard VI. participated in Assens , as the question of the Lenten obligations of the Schaumburger against the newly elected King Erich first came up. In 1397 he sealed with others the Treaty of Kalmar. He supported with the means of his diocese Margarethe also financially. In 1401 he had against this a loan claim of at least 40,000 LŸbische Mark and got Skan¿r and Falsterbowith the associated customs revenue as a pledge, which was redeemed in 1407. He took special care of the nunnery founded by Margaret of the Dominicans of Saint Agnethe ( Agnes ) in Gaun¿. He was also entrusted with managing Margaret's large financial foundations for churches, monasteries, and poor people in all three kingdoms . In July 1413 he pronounced the judgment on the Lehnsgericht in Nyborg against the Holstein nobility and declared the family of Henry III. of Schauenburg-Holstein of the fief of Schleswig because of breaking law for lost.

In addition to his political work, he also campaigned for church matters. In Aarhus Cathedral he donated an altar to the Holy Cross and in Roskilde Cathedral he built a chapel dedicated to Saint Siegfried, patron saint of VŠxjš.

English Bio:
Peder Palladius (* 1503 in Ribe ,   January 3, 1560 in Copenhagen ) was a Lutheran theologian and reformer of Denmark .

Palladius worked first as Rector of the Latin School in Odense . In 1531 he went to the study of theology in Wittenberg and studied with Martin Luther and Philipp Melanchthon . In 1533 he earned a master's degree and in 1537 doctorate in theology . He then returned to Denmark, where he was commissioned by King Christian III. was ordained by Johannes Bugenhagen to the first bishop of Zealand (Sj¾lland) and thus to the primate of the Danish church . At the University of Copenhagen reorganized by Bugenhagentaught Palladius at the same time as a professor of theology and officiated twice as rector. [1] As a bishop, he worked mainly through visitations and building a Protestant school system. His translations of works by Luther and other Wittenbergers into Danish, as well as his participation in the first complete translation of the Bible, made him meaningful for the entire Lutheran Church in Denmark .

Als Nachfolger von Hans Poulsen Resen (1561â€“1638), mit dem er befreundet war, 1615 zum Professor der Theologie aufgestiegen, folgte er diesem 1639 auch im Amt des Bischofs von Roskilde, das er bis zu seinem Tod im Alter von 66 Jahren ausÃ¼bte. 1617â€“1620 amtierte er als Lehrer des Kronprinzen Christian, des Sohns des KÃ¶nigs Christian IV., sowie 1623/24 und 1629/30 als Rektor der UniversitÃ¤t Kopenhagen[1].  Brochmand wird zu den wichtigsten Vertretern der lutherischen Orthodoxie gezÃ¤hlt. Er setzte sich nicht nur in DÃ¤nemark gegen den Einfluss von Reformierten sowie Jesuiten ein, sondern wirkte mit seinem an der Konkordienformel orientierten Systema auch in Deutschland. Als Bischof fÃ¼hrte er die flÃ¤chendeckende FÃ¼hrung von KirchenbÃ¼chern ein, schaffte den lateinischen Chorgesang ab und begrÃ¼ndete die mittwÃ¶chlichen Predigten in der Fastenzeit. Seine Hauspostille wurde noch im 19. Jahrhundert benutzt.
English Bio:
Jesper Rasmussen (also Caspar Erasmus ) Brochmand (born August 5, 1585 in K¿ge ,   April 19, 1652 in Copenhagen ) was a Danish Lutheran theologian .

Brochmand was born the son of Mayor Rasmus S¿rensen Brochmand (1537-1599). After receiving his first education at the then famous Herlufsholm School and studying at Leiden and Franeker Universities from 1603 to 1608 , in 1610 the University of Copenhagen introduced him as a professor of pedagogy . Three years later, he took over the teaching of the Greek language . As successor of Hans Poulsen Resen (1561-1638), with whom he was friends, 1615 rose to the rank of professor of theology, he followed this in 1639 also in the office of Bishop of Roskildewhich he practiced until his death at the age of 66 years. 1617-1620 he served as a teacher of the Crown Prince Christian , the son of King Christian IV. , And 1623/24 and 1629/30 as rector of the University of Copenhagen [1] .

Brochmand is counted among the most important representatives of Lutheran Orthodoxy . He not only campaigned in Denmark against the influence of the Reformed and the Jesuits , but also worked in Germany with his system of conciliation- oriented Systema . As a bishop, he introduced the comprehensive guidance of church books , abolished the Latin choir singing and founded the Sermons in Lent during the week . His house mail was still used in the 19th century.

Von 1659 bis 1661 war er Rektor der UniversitÃ¤t.  Wandals berÃ¼hmtestes Werk, die Â«Juris Regii libri VIÂ» (Sechs BÃ¼cher Ã¼ber das MajestÃ¤tsrecht), erschien 1663â€“1672. Hier rechtfertigte Wandal den kÃ¶niglichen Absolutismus, den KÃ¶nig FriedrichÂ III. im  Kongelov (KÃ¶nigsgesetz) 1661 formulieren und 1665 verfassungsmÃ¤ÃŸig festlegen lieÃŸ. English Bio:
Hans Wandal (also Johann Wandalin ) (born January 26, 1624 in Viborg ,   May 1, 1675 in Copenhagen ) was a Danish Lutheran theologian and bishop .

Wandal, son of the bishop Hans Iversen Wandal , studied from 1642 in Copenhagen as well as on a longer trip abroad in Leiden , Strasbourg , Basel and Leipzig . Returning to Denmark in 1651, he became Professor of Hebrew at the University of Copenhagen in 1652 , Professor of Theology in 1655 and Ph.D. theol. From 1659 to 1661 he was rector of the university.

Wandal's most famous work, the Juris Regii libri VI (Six Books on the Law of Majesty), appeared in 1663-1672. Here Wandal justified the royal absolutism , King Frederick III. formulated in the Kongelov ( royal law ) in 1661 and constitutionally stipulated in 1665. Wandal argues mainly with the position of the kings in the Old Testament , but also draws on the theology of Martin Luther .

In 1668, the king called him bishop of Zealand (Sj¾lland) and thus the primate of the Danish church . Wandal remained Dean of the Theological Faculty. His eponymous son Hans Wandal (theologian, 1656) also became a professor of theology in Copenhagen.

English Bio:
Gunner (* 1152 ,   August 25, 1251 in Asmild (now part of the municipality Viborg )) was a Danish clergyman and bishop of the diocese of Viborg . He has special significance as the main author of Jutland law .

Gunner studied in Paris and was considered one of the most important scholars in Denmark. In 1208 he entered the Order of the Cistercians and 1216 abbot in the monastery ¯m . When he was elected bishop in Viborg in 1222 at the age of 70, he was considered only a transitional candidate. He promoted the monastic life and liked to retire to the monastery of Asmild, where he died after his 1245 request for resignation. Almost a decade after his death, the Vita Gunneri episcopi Viborgensis was written.

To commemorate his work serves the 2000 founded Bisp Gunners Guild .

English Bio:
Hans Iversen Wandal (born August 20, 1579 in Ribe ,   December 16, 1641 in Viborg ) was a Danish Lutheran theologian and bishop .

After studying at the University of Copenhagen Wandal 1601 traveled to Germany to visit Wittenberg and other universities. After his return in 1602 he became a private tutor and undertook further trips abroad. In Strasbourg he obtained the master's degree . In 1613 he became pastor in Odense .

In 1617 King Christian IV appointed him Bishop of Viborg. In 1620 he was promoted to Dr. theol. PhD. He campaigned for a sharper church discipline. Theology professor and Bishop Hans Wandal (1624-1675) was his son.

Die Meinungen hinsichtlich der Natur dieses Zuges decken ein breites Spektrum ab, von einem klassischen Kreuzzug mit Missionierungscharakter Ã¼ber einen MilitÃ¤rfeldzug zum Zwecke der StÃ¤rkung der Position gegenÃ¼ber Russland bis zu einem gewÃ¶hnlichen Raubzug. Gesichert ist jedenfalls die Erkenntnis, dass das Christentum im sÃ¼dwestlichen Finnland, in welchem Heinrich von Uppsala gewirkt hat, bereits seit der Mitte des 11. Jahrhunderts FuÃŸ fasste und bis zu Eriks angenommenem Kreuzzug bereits in der Mehrheit war.[7] Eine Kirchenorganisation gab es jedoch bis zu Heinrichs Ankunft nicht.  Weiterhin offen ist auch die Frage, in welchem Jahr Heinrich nach Finnland kam. Nach heutiger Forschung werden als wahrscheinlichste Zeitpunkte die Jahre 1155, 1157 oder 1158 genannt. Entsprechend ist auch das Todesjahr Heinrichs â€“ der auf den â€žKreuzzugâ€œ folgende Winter â€“ nicht geklÃ¤rt. Die Unsicherheiten der Datierung spiegeln sich auch in den JubilÃ¤umsfeiern der finnischen Kirche wider, welche die Ankunft Heinrichs als ihre Geburtsstunde ansieht. Ihre 700-Jahr-Feier beging man im Jahr 1857, wÃ¤hrend der 850. Jahrestag im Jahr 2005 gefeiert wurde.  Soweit Heinrich als historische Person anerkannt wird, nimmt man an, dass die Verehrung Heinrichs als Heiliger bereits sehr bald nach seinem Tod begann. Nachweise fÃ¼r die Existenz des Kultes gibt es jedoch erst ab der zweiten HÃ¤lfte des 13. Jahrhunderts. Gegen Ende des Jahrhunderts wurde Heinrich in die finnischen kirchlichen Kalender aufgenommen. Seiner Liturgie wurde sein Ã¼berlieferter Todestag, der 20. Januar, gewidmet. Die Heiligenlegende Heinrichs wurde vermutlich ebenfalls wÃ¤hrend dieser Zeit, zwischen 1270 und 1290, verfasst.  Die Gebeine Heinrichs wurden an seiner HauptwirkungsstÃ¤tte in der Kirche von Nousiainen begraben. Diese Kirche war der Ausgangspunkt der Heiligenverehrung Heinrichs und das erste Zentrum der finnischen Kirche. Der Bischofssitz wurde nach 1229 zunÃ¤chst nach Koroinen und um die folgende Jahrhundertwende schlieÃŸlich einige Kilometer weiter sÃ¼dlich nach Turku verlegt. Zu dieser Zeit wurde Heinrich auch zum Schutzpatron des Domes zu Turku bestimmt und seine Reliquien feierlich hierher Ã¼berfÃ¼hrt. Heinrich wurde damit zum Schutzheiligen des gesamten Bistums, welches das gesamte damalige Finnland umfasste.  Als einziger â€žeigenerâ€œ Heiliger des Bistums genoss Heinrich in Finnland eine Sonderstellung. Seine Verehrung erstreckte sich jedoch geographisch auch in das schwedische Hauptland. Sein Namenstag wurde auÃŸerhalb Finnlands allerdings auf den 19. Januar vorverlegt, da der 20. Januar durch die als wichtiger empfundenen Heiligen Sebastian und Fabian belegt war. In Finnland wurde der Kalender erst am Ende des 17. Jahrhunderts angepasst. AuÃŸerhalb des damaligen Schwedens erlangte Heinrich als Heiliger keine nennenswerte Bedeutung.  Mit der Reformation wurde in Schweden und Finnland die Heiligenverehrung als solche beendet. Das Gedenken an Bischof Heinrich blieb aber auch in der lutherischen Zeit ein identitÃ¤tsstiftender Teil der finnischen Kirche. Ein evangelisches Erinnern an Heinrich gibt es auch auÃŸerhalb Finnlands: Die Evangelisch-Lutherische Kirche in Amerika hat einen Gedenktag fÃ¼r ihn am 19. Januar eingerichtet.[8] Heute ist Heinrich Schutzpatron der katholischen Kathedrale in Helsinki, in welcher sich auch einige der Reliquien des Heiligen befinden.  Dem heiligen Heinrich werden durch die Legende elf Wunder zugeschrieben, die sich alle nach seinem Tod ereignet haben.  Das erste Wunder geschah unmittelbar nach der Ermordung des Bischofs in Form der Bestrafung des MÃ¶rders. Als er sich die MÃ¼tze vom Kopf nehmen wollte, blieben sein Skalp und seine Kopfhaut an dieser hÃ¤ngen und wurden so von seinem Kopf gerissen. Diese Beschreibung war Vorbild fÃ¼r das in spÃ¤teren Darstellungen Heinrichs verwendete Heiligenattribut: Der Bischof wurde regelmÃ¤ÃŸig stehend gezeigt, den glatzkÃ¶pfigen MÃ¶rder zu seinen FÃ¼ÃŸen liegend. Der abgetrennte, beringte Finger wurde im Jahr 1618 zum Symbol des Bistums Turku.  Die verbleibenden Wunder beschreiben zwei Auferweckungen von den Toten, fÃ¼nf Heilungen von Krankheiten, eine Rettung aus Seenot sowie eine Bestrafung eines Zweiflers.  Mehrere ErwÃ¤hnungen in den beiden Hauptquellen, der Legende und der Todesballade, lassen einen ausgeprÃ¤gten Reliquienkult bereits zum Zeitpunkt ihres Entstehens erkennen. SpÃ¤teren mittelalterlichen Quellen, insbesondere der Bischofschronik von Turku zufolge wurde Heinrich zunÃ¤chst in Nousiainen begraben und spÃ¤ter nach Turku gebracht. Der genaue Zeitpunkt der ÃœberfÃ¼hrung ist unbekannt, ein Zusammenfallen mit der Weihung des Doms von Turku zum Bischofssitz wird aber fÃ¼r wahrscheinlich gehalten. Ebenso wahrscheinlich ist es, dass ein Teil der Gebeine in der Stammkirche Heinrichs in Nousiainen verblieben ist. Der Sarkophag Heinrichs in der Kirche von Nousiainen wurde noch bis ins 15. Jahrhundert hinein prachtvoll verziert.[9]  In heutiger Zeit sind eine Reihe von Reliquien bekannt, von denen angenommen wird, dass sie von Heinrich stammen. Deren Echtheit konnte in keinem Fall mit wissenschaftlicher Sicherheit nachgewiesen werden. Aufsehen erregte ein Fund, den man 1924 bei Restaurierungsarbeiten des Doms von Turku machte. In einem vernagelten Wandschrank der Sakristei fanden sich, in Stoff eingewickelt, ein SchÃ¤del und zwei Armknochen. In der mittelalterlichen Bischofschronik war berichtet worden, dass Bischof Maunu II. Schreine fÃ¼r Heinrichs SchÃ¤del und Arme habe herstellen lassen. In der Ã–ffentlichkeit wurde vielfach der Schluss gezogen, der SchÃ¤del Heinrichs von Uppsala sei gefunden worden.  In den heutigen Heiligenkalendern wird angegeben, dass die Kanonisation, also die Heiligsprechung Heinrichs im Jahr 1158 durch seinen GefÃ¤hrten Papst Hadrian IV. erfolgt sei. Diese Angabe ist jedoch durch Quellen nicht belegbar. Sie beruht auf Spekulationen, die erst in der Neuzeit durch Forscher angestellt wurden. Ãœber die tatsÃ¤chliche Kanonisation gibt keine der ursprÃ¼nglichen Quellen Aufschluss. Es wird heute fÃ¼r ebenso mÃ¶glich gehalten, dass eine pÃ¤pstliche Heiligsprechung Heinrichs nie erfolgt ist, da die Kanonisation erst 1234 zum alleinigen Recht des Papstes erklÃ¤rt wurde.  Der estnische Komponist Veljo Tormis schrieb 1992 Piispa ja pakana (Der Bischof und der Heide) fÃ¼r MÃ¤nnerchor und Solisten unter Verwendung einer lateinischen Sequenz und finnischer Folklore.
English Bio:
Heinrich von Uppsala (  1156 in Kšyliš , Finland ), called Bishop Henrik in Finland , is a Catholic saint . According to tradition, he took part in a crusade to Finland in the middle of the 12th century as bishop of Uppsala and worked as a missionary and first bishop of Finland, but was soon killed by a Finnish farmer.

Henry was revered as the Finnish patron saint until the Reformation and as the only "own" saint of Finland has until today an important position in the religious life of the country. From a historical point of view, there are considerable uncertainties about Heinrich and his surviving life.

The tradition of the life of Henry of Uppsala is based on two different, partly contradictory sources. Contemporary sources for the life of Henry are unknown.

The oldest written source is the Latin legend of St. Henry . This text written for the liturgical purposes of the veneration of saints probably dates from the last decades of the thirteenth century, at least not before 1270. It is also the oldest surviving written work in Finnish history. As a canonical legend of the saints , the text is divided into a vita section on the life of Heinrich and a miracula section on the miracles he has created.

In contrast to this source is the folk song in Finnish language handed down death ballad of Bishop Henry . Origin and date of origin of this over centuries exclusively orally transmitted work are unknown. Mostly it is considered to be a little younger than the legend . Only in modern times was the death ballad also recorded in writing, the first known records date from the 17th century. The death ballad only deals with the time from the arrival of Henry in Finland until his death, but adds many details to the legend .

According to tradition, Henry came from England. Further information about his life until his arrival in Sweden is not available. Around the year 1152 Henry was sent to Scandinavia as a companion of the papal legate Nicholas of Albano, later Pope Hadrian IV , to organize the church organization in the Nordic countries. Heinrich to the legend before his trip to Finland, according to the Bishop of Uppsala have been.

Heinrich finally came as a participant in the so-called first crusade of the Swedish King Erik IX. to southwest Finland. The legend reports that the Finnish people at that time was barbaric and pagan and wreaking great damage from raids by Sweden. In the course of the successful crusade Erik forced the Finns to Christianity. Before Erik returned to Sweden, Henry was appointed the first Bishop of Finland and remained in Finland to organize the church. His first office was in Nousiainen .

Henry, however, already found in the following winter, according to legend , on January 20 , a violent death by a Finnish peasant. Regarding the details, the sources diverge. The legend says that the bishop a baptized in the legend had occupied nameless farmers for murder with an ecclesiastical penalty and was then struck by this in anger. On the other hand, the ballad of death tells that Henry was in the house of the farmer Lalliin the absence of the host requested catering. At Lalli's return, his wife declared that the bishop had refused payment. The ballad explains this to be a lie, although gratuitous hospitality according to ecclesiastical understanding would have belonged to episcopal taxation right. In any case, Lalli, angered by this incident, followed the bishop and killed him on the ice of Lake Kšyliš .

About Heinrich von Uppsala are no known contemporary sources. The earliest written source, the legend , not only arose at least a century after Henry's death, but as a saint legend had no purpose of accurate historiography. The second main source, the death ballad , was created in the environment of the cult of the saints around Henry and therefore can only be used with caution for historical research. The correctness of the tradition concerning Henry is therefore in all aspects doubtful and controversial from a historical point of view.

The fact that Heinrich actually existed as a historical person has been a matter of course in Finnish historiography for centuries. This was seriously questioned in the 20th century. Some researchers, especially Stjerna [1] and Schmid [2] considered the legend of Henry to be an invention for the purpose of embellishing the legend of the saints around King Erik. Today, however, historians also generally assume that Heinrich was an historical person. Virrankoski considers this finding obviously, [3] grants during HeikkilŠ one remaining doubt, but a direct connection with the Erik legend due to the origins of the legend holds unlikely.[4]

The tradition that Henry was Bishop of Uppsala before his departure to Finland today for implausible [5] or at least very doubtful [3] held. On the one hand, there are no references to Henry as bishop in the otherwise complete documents in Uppsala, on the other hand it would be unusual to assume that the bishop leaves his bishopric for a journey of several years abroad.

The so-called first crusade Erik IX. is still the subject of historical strife. [6] The very question of whether Erik undertook any kind of train to Finland is unclear, but is affirmed by a majority of historians today. Opinions about the nature of the procession cover a broad spectrum, from a classic crusade of missionary character to a military campaign for the purpose of strengthening the position against Russia to an ordinary raid. At any rate, it is certain that Christianity in south-western Finland, where Heinrich von Uppsala worked, had already gained a foothold since the middle of the eleventh century and was already in the majority until Erik's assumed crusade. [7] However, there was no church organization until Heinrich's arrival.

Also open is the question in which year Heinrich came to Finland. According to research today, the most probable dates are 1155, 1157 or 1158. Accordingly, the year of Heinrich's death - the winter following the "crusade" - has not been clarified. The uncertainties of dating are also reflected in the anniversary celebrations of the Finnish Church, which sees the arrival of Henry as her birth. Their 700th anniversary was celebrated in 1857, while the 850th anniversary was celebrated in 2005.

As far as Henry is recognized as a historical person, one assumes that the worship of Henry as a saint already began very soon after his death. However, evidence of the cult's existence does not exist until the second half of the 13th century. Towards the end of the century, Henry was included in the Finnish church calendar. His liturgy was dedicated to his recorded death, January 20. The saint legend of Henry was probably also written during this period, between 1270 and 1290.

The bones of Henry were buried at his main site in the church of Nousiainen . This church was the starting point of Henry's veneration and the first center of the Finnish church. The episcopal see was moved after 1229 first to Koroinen and around the turn of the century finally a few miles further south to Turku. At this time, Henry was also appointed patron saint of the cathedral at Turku and his relics were solemnly brought here. Henry was thus the patron saint of the entire diocese , which encompassed the entire then Finland.

As the only "own" saint of the diocese, Henry enjoyed a special position in Finland. His worship, however, extended geographically to the Swedish mainland. However, his name day was moved outside of Finland to the 19th of January, because January 20 was occupied by the perceived as more important Saints Sebastian and Fabian . In Finland, the calendar was adapted only at the end of the 17th century. Outside of the then Sweden Henry did not gain significant importance as a saint.

With the Reformation, the veneration of saints was ended as such in Sweden and Finland. However, the memory of Bishop Heinrich also remained an identity-forming part of the Finnish Church in the Lutheran period. There is also an evangelical remembrance of Henry outside of Finland: The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America has set up a memorial day for him on 19 January . [8] Today, Heinrich patron saint of the Catholic cathedral in Helsinki, in which some of the relics of saints are located.

According to legend, eleven miracles are attributed to St. Henry, all of which occurred after his death.

The first miracle happened immediately after the murder of the bishop in the form of the punishment of the murderer. The latter took the cap from the slain Heinrich, turned it over himself, and mocked the bishop at home. When he wanted to remove the cap from his head, his scalp and scalp stuck to it and were torn from his head. This description was a model for the saint's attribute used in later depictions of Henry : The bishop was regularly shown standing, lying the bald-headed murderer at his feet.

The second miracle also had lasting significance for Henry's worship. In the spring after his murder, after the ice had already melted, the finger of Henry, severed by the murder, is said to have been washed ashore together with his ring on an ice floe, on which a raven croaked. The severed, ringed finger became the symbol of the diocese of Turku in 1618.

The remaining miracles describe two resurrections from the dead, five healings of illnesses, a rescue from distress and a punishment of a doubter.

Several mentions in the two main sources, the legend and the death ballad , reveal a distinct cult of relics already at the time of their creation. Later medieval sources, especially the bishop chronicle of Turku according to Henry was first buried in Nousiainen and later brought to Turku. The exact date of the transfer is unknown, but a coincidence with the dedication of the Turku Cathedral to the Episcopal see is considered probable. It is equally probable that a part of the bones remained in the ancestral church of Henry in Nousiainen. The sarcophagus of Henry in the church of Nousiainen was magnificently decorated until the 15th century.[9]

At present, a number of relics are known that are believed to have come from Henry. Their authenticity could not be proven in any case with scientific certainty. A find, which was made in 1924 during restoration work of the Turku Cathedral, caused a sensation. In a nailed-down closet in the sacristy , wrapped in cloth, was a skull and two arm bones. In medieval episcopal chronicle it was reported that Bishop Maunu II had made shrines for Henry's skull and arms. The public has often concluded that the skull of Henry of Uppsala has been found.

In today's calendar of saints is stated that the canonization, ie the canonization of Henry in 1158 was done by his companion Pope Hadrian IV. However, this information can not be substantiated by sources. It is based on speculations that were made only in modern times by researchers. The actual canonization does not reveal any of the original sources. It is considered just as possible today that a papal canonization of Henry never occurred, since the canonization was declared in 1234 the sole right of the Pope.

English Bio:
Thomas (  1248 in Visby ) was Bishop of Turku in Finland .

He was Canon in Uppsala and then became Bishop of Turku in the late 1220s. He is considered the fourth bishop of Finland. During his term, Sweden extended its influence strongly to the east. The expansion was accompanied by the establishment of a feudal church system. In 1237 an insurrection broke out in largely pagan HŠme . With the backing of the Pope [1] the rebellion was crushed in the course of a crusade . At the same time, efforts were made to push back the Eastern Orthodox Church, a policy supported by Thomas. The defeat of the Swedish army against NovgorodTroops under Alexander Nevsky in 1240 at the mouth of the Neva in the Battle of the Neva failed further expansion of the East. The boundary of the influence zones ran since then through Karelia .

In 1245, Thomas resigned as bishop for torturing a man to death and forging a letter from the Pope. The farewell document was signed by Pope Innocent IV . Thomas retired to a Dominican convent in Visby, Gotland .

He left the Dominican monastery in Sigtuna a significant library , which is now in the University Library Uppsala .

So verbot er den Priestern, Kinder im Haus zu haben; offenkundig waren die Regelungen des ZÃ¶libats zu diesem Zeitpunkt noch nicht durchgesetzt. DarÃ¼ber hinaus fÃ¼hrte er in Finnland den Zehnt ein. Er lieÃŸ Kirchen errichten und den Dom von Turku ausbauen. Hemming galt als fromm.  In der Mitte der 1340er Jahre lernte er die spÃ¤ter heiliggesprochene Birgitta von Schweden kennen und wurde zu einem ihrer AnhÃ¤nger. Insbesondere unterstÃ¼tzte er sie in ihren BemÃ¼hungen zur Erneuerung der katholischen Kirche. Birgitta benannte Hemming in ihren Offenbarungen und schilderte ihn als furchtlos, wahrheitsliebend und stets vorwÃ¤rtsstrebend. 1348 reiste er mit dem Beichtvater Birgittas zu Papst Clemens VI. nach Avignon. Ziel der Reise war es, den Papst dazu zu bewegen, den Sitz des Heiligen Stuhls wieder nach Rom zu verlegen.  Ende des 14. Jahrhunderts begannen Versuche einer Kanonisierung Hemmings. 1514 erfolgte seine Seligsprechung. Seine Gebeine wurden zusammen mit anderen Reliquien im Dom von Turku in einem Schrein aufgestellt. English Bio:
Hemming (* 1290,   May 21, 1366 in Turku ) was Bishop of Turku in Finland .

Hemming was a native Swede . He probably studied in Paris . In 1329 he became canon in Turku. In 1338 he was elected Bishop of Turku by acclamation . He held office until his death. As a bishop, he endeavored to enforce Canon Law . So he forbade the priests to have children in the house; Apparently, the rules of celibacy were not yet enforced at this time. He also introduced tithing in Finland . He had churches built and the Turku Cathedral expanded. Hemming was considered religious.

In the middle of the 1340s, he met the later canonized Birgitta of Sweden and became one of her followers. In particular, he supported them in their efforts to renew the Catholic Church. Birgitta called Hemming in her revelations, describing him as fearless, truth-loving, and always forward-thinking. In 1348 he traveled with the confessor Birgittas to Pope Clement VI. to Avignon . The aim of the trip was to persuade the Pope to relocate the seat of the Holy See to Rome.

At the end of the 14th century, attempts were made to armor Hemmings. 1514 was his beatification . His bones, along with other relics, were set up in a shrine in Turku Cathedral . The intended canonization was no longer achieved by the beginning of the 1520s in Finland Reformation .

English Bio:
Maunu Olavinpoika Tavast (* 1357 in MynŠmŠki ,   March 9, 1452 in Naantali ), Swedish Magnus Tavast, was a Finnish clergyman and scholar. From 1412 to 1450 he was Bishop of Turku . He initiated several alterations to the local cathedral , which gave it its current appearance, and donated eight altars. He also expanded the - built at that time of wood - castle Kuusisto , but burned down to the ground under Bishop Konrad Bitz .

Maunu Tavast was appointed on October 21, 1412 Bishop of Turku. He acted as advisor to three kings and pacified u. a. an uprising that had broken out in Satakunta . It was thanks to his influence that the establishment of judges strengthened the jurisdiction in Finland. The episcopal chronicle of Paul Juusten reports that the bishop was a man of deep and deep piety, who personally led every hour of prayer in his chapel and always encouraged his chaplains to sing the Mass . He "misplaced" the monks and nuns of the Birgitt order of Vadstena after Naantali in a monastery, to which he himself sacristy and principal choir had donated.

In 1450, after a 38-year episcopate, he resigned from the episcopate and retired to a house he had built near his monastery in Naantali. There he died two years later.

Magni wurde dann, noch wÃ¤hrend er sich in Paris aufhielt, zum Archidiakon und Dompropst der DiÃ¶zese Turku gewÃ¤hlt. Im Jahr 1450 wurde er dann Bischof von Turku. English Bio:
Olaus Magni ( Finnish : Olavi Maununpoika ) (* 1405 in Piikkiš ,   February 24, 1460 in Turku ) was a scholar and bishop of Turku in Finland .

Magni lived in Paris from about the middle of the 1420s and finished there in 1428 his exam as a master. He then taught Aristotelian Ethics at the Sorbonne . He became procurator and receptor of the Anglo-German nation at the university. From 1435 to 1436 he was finally her rector . He was a sociology college member of Socius, a bachelor of theology and a teacher of theology.

In 1436 the Sorbonne sent him to King Charles VII to Bourges . He was there to reassure the king of the remorse and submission of the university. The university had in the past for a condemnation Jeanne d'Arcs , a follower of Charles, pronounced. After Karl had emerged victorious from the Hundred Years War , they saw themselves induced to such a remorse.

In 1437 Olaus Magni took part in the council of Basel as a representative of his nation.

Magni was then elected Archdeacon and Dean of the Diocese of Turku while still in Paris . In 1450 he became Bishop of Turku. He followed with his relative Magnus Tavast . The office he provided until his death in 1460.

His tomb is located in the Turku Cathedral .

English Bio:
Konrad Bitz (also Kort Bitz ,   March 13, 1489 in Kusto ) was from 1460 until his death Bishop of Turku in Finland .

Konrad Bitz was the son of Henrik Bitz and Anna Klausdotter Diekn. His first documentary mention can be found in sources from the year 1433, more precisely: on the occasion of his studies at the University of Leipzig , founded in 1409 , the second oldest since its founding without interruption working University (after the Ruprecht-Karls-University Heidelberg , 1386) in the field of Federal Republic of Germany . After successfully completing his Masters degree, he began studying Canon Law at the University of Bologna ten years later, the first university on European soil. With this training and his aristocratic status as a basis, he was able to enter the career ladder for higher ecclesiastical offices. After Olaus Magnus was appointed bishop of Turku in 1450, Bitz followed him in his previous office as dean and, after his death in February 1460, succeeded him as bishop a good six months later on 4 July. It was followed by a visit from Bitz at the Roman Curia, which is also mentioned in a document, and then in Siena the consecration as bishop . [1] [2]

Bishop Bitz commissioned the textbook Missale Aboense printed in 1488 at Bartholomew Ghotan in LŸbeck . The name of the book refers to the Swedish name of the city, bo. The work is the only incunabula in Finland. This first book, ever printed for Finland, is considered as the national shrine. As a textbook it picks up Finnish peculiarities, such as the legend of Heinrich von Uppsala . [3] [4] Of the work duplicated in 1488 in LŸbeck around 120 copies were produced cumulatively for both variants on paper and parchment. The missale comprises 226 folio-sized folios and although it is written in Latin as a liturgical work, it contains in Finnish a foreword by Bitz and a calendar of the diocese. [5] On the cover are located in the center of the image Bishop Henry , who was appointed after his MŠyrtertod the patron saint of the Church of Turku and all Finland, and at whose feet that farmer who is said to have killed him. In addition, Bishop Konrad Bitz was immortalized on the right and on the left the then cathedral provost Maunu Niilonpoika SŠrkilahti(  1500, Bishop), who later Bitz should follow as Bishop of Turku. [6]

In addition, Bitz also made a leap in development at the level of art. Specifically: While the medieval churches in Finland outwardly from a "austere and strict thrift of jewelry and outline" showed, they were in the early 15th century with chalk paintings in the al-secco technique, ie water colors on a dry limestone, with an "unusual rich, sparkling painting decorated". Leading here were next to Bitz, for a "fantastic animation of the interiors, which still seems to be fed by the Nordic animal ornaments", also art-loving Bishop Magnus Olofson Tavast (1408-50) and the Dominican Order, who had monasteries in Turku and Wiipuri , [7]At the instigation of Bitz, for example, Peter Henriksson came from Sweden in 1470 to paint the church of Kalanti. [8th]

Outside his sphere of influence was the loss of valuable documents, as his pontificates in 1485 burned down the Turku bishopric Kuusisto and with it a large part of the church archives. [9] [10]

Die Existenz des ABC-Kiria wurde erst wieder 1851 durch die Entdeckung eines Titelblattes in der UniversitÃ¤tsbibliothek von Uppsala bekannt, weitere Teile wurden 1904 im schwedischen Staatsarchiv und 1966 in der DiÃ¶zesanbibliothek von VÃ¤sterÃ¥s entdeckt.  1544 verÃ¶ffentlichte Agricola in Stockholm als NÃ¤chstes Rucouskiria Bibliasta, ein Gebetbuch nach Texten der Bibel. Der Beginn dieser Ãœbersetzungsarbeit lÃ¤sst sich anhand handschriftlicher Glossen in seinen BÃ¼chern bis in die Zeit in Turku vor dem Beginn seiner Wittenberger Studien zurÃ¼ckverfolgen. 1543 war sie vollendet, 1548 wurde sie in Stockholm publiziert. Seine Ãœbersetzung folgte dem griechischen Urtext, zog aber besonders noch die lateinische Ãœbertragung von Erasmus, die deutsche Martin Luthers und die schwedische von Olaus Petri heran.  1549 erschien seine finnische Bearbeitung der Messliturgie (Messu eli Herran Echtolinen), die im Unterschied zur dÃ¤nisch-norwegischen (1537/42) und islÃ¤ndischen (1594) nicht dem von Bugenhagen etablierten Typ angehÃ¶rt, sondern als Bearbeitung der schwedischen Messe von Olaus Petri (1531) einer 1524/25 in NÃ¼rnberg entstandenen Tradition folgt, die Ã¼ber eine in Rostock gebrauchte niederdeutsche Fassung der NÃ¼rnberger Spitalmesse Andreas DÃ¶bers nach Schweden vermittelt worden war.[2]  1551 publizierte er eine Ãœbersetzung der Psalmen (Dauidin Psalttari), der 1551 und 1552 noch weitere Ãœbersetzungen aus dem Alten Testament folgten. Jahrhundert ist. English Bio:
Mikael Agricola ( listen to ? / I , actually Mikael Olavinpoika , "son of Olav"; * 1509 in PernŒ (Finnish Pernaja),   April 9, 1557 in Uusikirkko / Nykyrka ), was a Finnish theologian and reformer and is considered a father the Finnish literary language .

Agricola was the son of a farmer and was born in the southern Finnish parish of Pernaja , probably in the village of Torsby. He grew up bilingually in both Swedish and Finnish, and according to Simo Heininen's findings, Swedish is considered his mother tongue. [1]

Agricola visited in Viipuri (black Wiborg or Viborg) the Latin School with Johannes Erasmus and came there for the first time in contact with ideas of humanism and the Reformation . In 1528 he was ordained and went to Turku (black bo) as secretary to Bishop Martin Skytte . In Turku he made the acquaintance of Peter SŠrkilax , a disciple of Erasmus and Luther . In Turku it was also where he 1531 in place of his surname Olavinpoika the Latin nickname Agricola ("Bauer") increased.

Bishop Skytte sent Agricola in 1536 to study at the University of Wittenberg . There he became a pupil of Melanchthon , Bugenhagen and Luther, of whom he had already acquired in 1531 in Turku a copy of the Enarrationes seu postillae in lectiones , published in Strasburg the previous year . Agricola graduated in 1539 with a master's degree and returned to Finland .

After returning to Turku, he became a canon in the cathedral chapter and rector of the Latin School of Turku, which he ran until 1548. In 1548 he was first coadjutor Bishop Skyttes and after his death in 1550 without papal approval of his successor. More determined than his predecessor, he sat down in this office for the interests of the Reformation.

Agricola was not only a major theological author and translator, but also a prudent administrator: his handwritten notes on the income of the chapter and the pastorate in Turku were issued by Jyrki Knuutila and Anneli MŠkelŠ-Alitalo 2007 on the occasion of the Agricola Year. He also worked as a politician and diplomat. In 1557 he was involved in the peace negotiations between Sweden and Russia as a member of an embassy of the Swedish king at the court of Ivan the Terrible . On the return journey from Russia Agricola died in Finland, probably in Uusikirkko. He was buried in the cathedral of Viipuri / Wiborg. The exact tomb in the cathedral is no longer known.

Agricola married in 1549 or 1550 Birgitta OlavintytŠr (= daughter of Olav,   1595). His only son Christian Agricola (born December 11, 1550,   February 19, 1586) was consecrated in 1583 in the cathedral of Uppsala Bishop of Reval ( Tallinn ). Christian Agricola was married to the nobleman Elin Pedersdotter Fleming (died 1608) and had a daughter with her. The male line of Michael Agricolas descendants went out with the death of his son.

Agricola is considered - comparable to Luther - to be the father of Finnish literary language, based on the Turku dialect , expanded by elements from other Finnish dialects and borrowed especially from German, Swedish and Latin, and by Agricola and his successors by numerous new formations was expanded for the theological and scientific needs.

With the turn of Sweden and Finland to the Reformation, there was also the task of communicating the faith to the people in their own language. There were also sermons and prayers in Finnish before Agricola, but it was he who programmatically substantiated and put into practice the Reformation concern for the Finnish language. His first printed work was also the first printed in Finnish language book, the ABC-kirja (ABC book), which was written between 1537 and 1543 and probably first printed in 1543, 1551 in a second edition and 1559 in a posthumous third Issue appeared. This is not a catechismfor beginners, but a collection of basic Christian texts that u. a. oriented to Luther's Small Catechism and Philipp Melanchthon's Catechism. The ABC Kiria contains u. a. the Creed , the Lord's Prayer , as well as statements of baptism and the Lord's Supper . The existence of the ABC Kiria became known again in 1851 by the discovery of a title page in the University Library of Uppsala, other parts were discovered in 1904 in the Swedish State Archives and in 1966 in the diocesan library of VŠsterŒs .

In 1544, Agricola next published in Stockholm Rucouskiria Bibliasta , a textbook of texts from the Bible. His most significant achievement, however, was the translation of the New Testament ( Se Wsi Testamenti ). The beginning of this translation work can be traced back to the time in Turku before the beginning of his Wittenberg studies by handwritten glosses in his books. In 1543 it was completed, in 1548 it was published in Stockholm. His translation followed the original Greek text, but especially drew the Latin translation of Erasmus, the German Martin Luther and the Swedish by Olaus Petri .

1549 appeared his Finnish processing of Messliturgie ( Messu eli Herran Echtolinen ), which in contrast to the Danish-Norwegian (1537/42) and Icelandic (1594) does not belong to the type established by Bugenhagen, but as processing the Swedish Mass of Olaus Petri (1531 ) followed in Nuremberg in 1524/25, which had been conveyed to Sweden via a Low German version of the Nuremberg hospital fair Andreas Dšbers used in Rostock . [2]

In 1551 he published a translation of the Psalms ( Dauidin Psalttari ), which followed in 1551 and 1552 still further translations from the Old Testament . In the introduction to his translation of psalms, he also offered a metric listing of indigenous pagan deities of Hare and Karelia , which is the most important source of Finnish mythology and folk tradition in the sixteenth century. In addition, in his prefaces he also occasionally added rhyming poems, which are written in three- or four-footed Iambian rhyming couplets and are based on the model of the German doggerel .

By Mikael Agricola no contemporary pictorial representations are handed down. The various statues (eg in the cathedral of Helsinki , in and in front of the cathedral in Turku) and pictorial representations of the Finnish reformer (eg the picture of Albert Edelfelt ) are inventions of the 19th and 20th century. In Wittenberg, two panels (a bronze plaque at the Luther House and an enamel panel at the former university building) are reminiscent of Agricola's studies in this city. [3]

The well-known Finnish poet and playwright Paavo Haavikko put Agricola in the center of his play Agricola ja kettu ("Agricola and the fox") in 1968, which allows Agricola to stand up for the rights of Finland in the power struggle between Sweden and Russia and in a more general sense the involvement of the Intellectuals in the political intrigues of his time represents. The premiere in Helsinki aroused particular attention by the fact that the director Kalle Holmberg had the performer Ivan the Terrible costumed after the example of Josef Stalin to underline the references to the current political situation of Finland in the conflict situation between East and West .

English Bio:
Paulus Juusten (* about 1516 in Juustila at Wiborg ,   August 22, 1575 in Turku ) was Bishop of Wiborg and Turku in Finland . He is considered one of the most important Finnish church leaders of the Reformation .

Juusten was born as a child of a middle-class family from Wiborg. Around 1540 he was ordained a priest. He worked as a house preacher at Bishop Martin Skytte and worked in Wiborg as a school principal. In 1543 he traveled to Wittenberg in Germany and studied at the University of Wittenberg embossed by the Reformation theology and was one of the few Finnish students at the university. The lectures were mainly given by Philipp Melanchton . Melanchton gave Juusten after completing his studies in 1546 then a letter of recommendation to the King Gustav I Vasa and the cathedral chapter Turku . [1]

He returned to Finland and became rector of Turku Cathedral School, where Finnish priestly formation took place. In 1554 Juusten became the first bishop of the newly created diocese of Wiborg after the division of the Finnish diocese . In 1563 he became Bishop of Turku. He held this office until his death.

Around 1565, he compiled a collection and adaptation of older Finnish bishop chronicles titled Catalogus et ordinaria successio episcoporum Finlandensium . [2] It was completed and annotated more than a century later by Henrik Gabriel Porthan . The work led to Juusten as the father of Finnish historiography is considered. [3]

In 1574 he published a catechism in Finnish . 1575 was followed by a Finnish Missal .
