German Bio: Johannes Gezelius der Ã„ltere (* 3. Februar 1615 in Romfartuna, VÃ¤stmanland; â€  20. Januar 1690 in Turku (Ã…bo)) war ein schwedisch-finnischer lutherischer Theologe.  Gezelius, Sohn eines Bauern, studierte nach dem Besuch des Gymnasiums in VÃ¤sterÃ¥s an den  UniversitÃ¤ten Uppsala und Dorpat Evangelische Theologie. 1638 erwarb er den Titel eines Magisters, wurde 1641 Professor fÃ¼r Biblische Sprachen und 1643 auÃŸerordentlicher Professor der Theologie in Dorpat. Im Auftrag von KÃ¶nigin Christina nahm er an verschiedenen Projekten zur VersÃ¶hnung der Konfessionen teil, unter anderem am Thorner ReligionsgesprÃ¤ch von 1645. Hier lernte er wohl auch Johann Amos Comenius kennen, dessen pÃ¤dagogische Ideen er spÃ¤ter zu verwirklichen suchte. Als die schwedische Kirchenpolitik jedoch zu einer strengeren Orthodoxie umschwenkte, wurde Gezelius 1649 nach Schweden zurÃ¼ckberufen und trat eine Pfarrstelle in Stora Skedvi, Dalarna, an. 1660 Ã¼bernahm er die Stelle des Superintendenten von Livland mit Sitz in Riga. 1664 wurde er zum Bischof von Turku gewÃ¤hlt und blieb in diesem Amt bis zu seinem Tod. Sein gleichnamiger Sohn Johannes Gezelius der JÃ¼ngere wurde sein Nachfolger.  Gezelius setzte sich besonders fÃ¼r die Verbesserung der theologischen Ausbildung ein. Dabei legte er grÃ¶ÃŸtes Gewicht auf die Predigt, die klar und verstÃ¤ndlich sein sollte. Alle Pfarrer mussten sich regelmÃ¤ÃŸig weiterbilden. Die Kirchengemeinden verpflichtete er, BÃ¼cher zu kaufen und Bibliotheken aufzubauen. Um sie mit guter Literatur zu versorgen, grÃ¼ndete er selbst eine Druckerei. Ferner reformierte er die stÃ¤dtischen Schulen und verpflichtete sie auf das didaktische Programm des Comenius.[1] Der 1666 von ihm verfasste finnische Katechismus Yxi paras lasten tawara (Der beste Schatz der Kinder)[2] war bis ins 19. Jahrhundert im Gebrauch.  Gezelius ambitiÃ¶sestes Werk war eine mehrbÃ¤ndige kommentierte Bibelausgabe, das sogenannte Bibelwerk, die er mit seinem Sohn herausgeben wollte. Die Arbeit zog sich aber lange hin. Erst 1711 und 1713 konnte das Neue Testament in zwei Teilen erscheinen. Die Ausgabe des Alten Testaments wurde erst von seinem Enkel Johannes Gezelius dem JÃ¼ngsten (1686â€“1733) vollendet.
English Bio:
Johannes Gezelius the Elder (born February 3, 1615 in Romfartuna , VŠstmanland ,   January 20, 1690 in Turku (bo) ) was a Swedish - Finnish Lutheran theologian.

Gezelius, son of a farmer, studied after the attendance of the high school in VŠsterŒs at the universities Uppsala and Dorpat Protestant theology . In 1638 he earned the title of Master , 1641 Professor of Biblical Languages __and 1643 associate professor of theology in Dorpat. On behalf of Queen Christina , he took part in various projects for the reconciliation of denominations, including the Thorner Religious Discourse of 1645. Here he probably got to know Johann Amos Comenius , whose educational ideas he later sought to realize. However, as the Swedish church policy to a stricterTurned Orthodoxy back , Gezelius was recalled to Sweden in 1649 and became a pastor in Stora Skedvi , Dalarna . In 1660 he took over the post of the Superintendent of Livonia based in Riga . In 1664 he was elected bishop of Turku and remained in office until his death. His eponymous son Johannes Gezelius the Younger became his successor.

Gezelius was particularly committed to the improvement of theological education. He put the greatest emphasis on the sermon , which should be clear and understandable. All pastors had to continue their education regularly. He obligated the parishes to buy books and build libraries. To provide her with good literature, he founded a printing house himself. He also reformed the municipal schools and committed them to the didactic program of Comenius. [1] The 1666 authored by him Finnish Catechism YXI paras loads Tawara (The best treasure of children) [2] was to the 19th century in use.

Gezelius most ambitious work was a multi-volume annotated Bible edition , the so-called Bible work, which he wanted to publish with his son. The work took a long time. It was not until 1711 and 1713 that the New Testament appeared in two parts. The edition of the Old Testament was only completed by his grandson Johannes Gezelius the Youngest (1686-1733).

Name: Johannes Gezelius der JÃ¼ngere
German Bio:
Johannes Gezelius der JŸngere (* 6. September 1647 in Dorpat, Estland;   10. April 1718 in Viggbyholm bei TŠby, Uppland) war ein schwedisch-finnischer lutherischer Theologe.

Gezelius, ein Sohn des damaligen Professors fŸr Griechisch an der schwedischen UniversitŠt Dorpat und spŠteren Bischofs Johannes Gezelius des €lteren, wuchs Ÿberwiegend in Dalarna, Schweden auf und studierte ab 1661 in Uppsala und Turku (bo). Anschlie§end machte er von 1670 bis 1674 eine Studienreise zur Vervollkommnung in der biblischen und orientalischen Philologie nach Deutschland (Studium bei Matthias Wasmuth in Kiel und bei Esdras Edzardus in Hamburg; Aufenthalt bei Philipp Jacob Spener in Frankfurt am Main, mit dem er lange korrespondierte), Holland, England (1671 Studien in Oxford und Cambridge, u. a. bei Edward Pococke und John Lightfoot), Frankreich (u. a. bei Richard Simon in Paris) und in die Schweiz. 1675 wurde er in Turku zum Lizenziaten der Theologie promoviert und gleich zum au§erordentlichen Professor berufen. 1676 folgte die Promotion zum Doktor der Theologie und die Berufung zum ordentlichen Professor sowie zum Pfarrer der St.-Marien-Gemeinde. 1681 wechselte er als Superintendent fŸr Ingermanland nach Narva. Hier versuchte er erfolglos, die russisch-orthodoxen Ingrier zum Luthertum zu bekehren. 1689 kehrte er nach Finnland zurŸck, um seinem greisen Vater zu assistieren, mit der Aussicht, dessen Nachfolge als Bischof des Erzbistums bo anzutreten. Nach dessen Tod 1690 wurde Gezelius Bischof und behielt diesen Titel bis zu seinem Tod. 1713 musste er jedoch sein Bistum verlassen, als Finnland im Gro§en Nordischen Krieg von den Russen besetzt wurde. Er starb auf seinem Landgut nšrdlich von Stockholm.

Gezelius war ein bedeutender Prediger und Organisator. Seine grš§ten Leistungen liegen jedoch auf den Gebieten der Hymnologie und der biblischen Philologie. Er fšrderte das Finnische als Kirchensprache gegenŸber dem fast nur von der Oberschicht gesprochenen Schwedisch. So gab er das (sogenannte alte) finnische Gesangbuch von 1701 (Uusi Suomenkielinen Wirsi-Kirja Niiden Cappalden canssa, jotca siihen tulevat) heraus, das auf dem offiziellen schwedischen Gesangbuch von 1695 basierte. Schon in diesem Gesangbuch waren mehrere Lieder Gezelius' enthalten, von denen eins, die schwedische Nachdichtung von Herr Jesu Christ, dich zu uns wend, noch im aktuellen schwedischen Gesangbuch von 1986 enthalten ist. Ferner fŸhrte er die Arbeiten seines Vaters an einer kommentierten Bibelausgabe, dem sogenannten Bibelwerk, fort, die sich aber lange hinzogen. 1711 und 1713 konnte das Neue Testament in zwei Teilen erscheinen. Die Ausgabe des Alten Testaments wurde erst nach Gezelius' Tod von seinem Sohn Johannes Gezelius dem JŸngsten (1686Ð1733) vollendet.

Nach seiner Begegnung mit Philipp Jacob Spener und Johann Jakob SchŸtz stand Gezelius zunŠchst dem Pietismus nahe. Er Ÿbersetzte sogar SchŸtz' Christliches GedenkbŸchlein zur Befšrderung eines anfangenden neuen Lebens ins Schwedische, wandte sich aber spŠter vom Pietismus ab, als dessen radikale Tendenzen deutlich wurden. Als Bischof war er ein entschiedener Vertreter der Lutherischen Orthodoxie und bekŠmpfte die frŸhen finnischen Pietisten wie Lars Ulstadius. Auch als Prokanzler der Akademie verteidigte er die orthodoxe Lehre gegen alle Neuerungen. Mit seinem DrŠngen auf ein philologisch genaues VerstŠndnis der Bibel, das auch zur Korrektur der offiziellen †bersetzungen fŸhren mŸsse, geriet er aber immer wieder selbst in Konflikte mit der Orthodoxie.
English Bio:
Johannes Gezelius the Younger (born September 6, 1647 in Dorpat , Estonia ,   April 10, 1718 in Viggbyholm at TŠby , Uppland ) was a Swedish - Finnish Lutheran theologian.

Gezelius, a son of the then professor of Greek at the Swedish University of Dorpat and later Bishop Johannes Gezelius the Elder , grew up mainly in Dalarna , Sweden and studied from 1661 in Uppsala and Turku (bo) . From 1670 to 1674 he made a study trip to perfection in biblical and oriental philology to Germany (studies with Matthias Wasmuth in Kiel and with Esdras Edzardus in Hamburg , with Philipp Jacob Spener in Frankfurt am Mainwith whom he corresponded for a long time), Holland, England (1671 studies in Oxford and Cambridge , inter alia, Edward Pococke and John Lightfoot ), France (including Richard Simon in Paris ) and Switzerland. In 1675 he received his doctorate in Turku licentiate theology and immediately appointed associate professor. 1676 followed the doctorate of theology and the appointment as a full professor and pastor of St. Mary's Church. In 1681 he moved as Superintendent for Ingermanland to Narva . Here he tried unsuccessfully, the to convert Russian Orthodox Ingrier to Lutheranism. In 1689 he returned to Finland to assist his aged father, with the prospect of succeeding him as Bishop of the Archdiocese of bo . After his death in 1690 Gezelius became a bishop and retained this title until his death. In 1713, however, he had to leave his diocese when Finland was occupied by the Russians in the Great Northern War . He died on his estate north of Stockholm.

Gezelius was a major preacher and organizer. His greatest achievements, however, are in the fields of hymnology and biblical philology. He promoted Finnish as the language of the church in relation to the Swedish spoken almost exclusively by the upper classes. So he published the (so-called old ) Finnish hymnal of 1701 ( Uusi Suomenkielinen Wirsi-Kirja Niiden Cappalden canssa, jotca siihen tulevat ), which was based on the official Swedish hymnal of 1695. Already in this hymnbook were contained several songs of Gezelius, one of which, the Swedish poetry of Lord Jesus Christ, turns you to us, still contained in the current Swedish hymnal of 1986. He also continued his father's work on a commented Bible edition , the so-called Bible work, but dragged on for a long time. In 1711 and 1713, the New Testament appeared in two parts. The edition of the Old Testament was completed only after Gezelius' death by his son Johannes Gezelius the Youngest (1686-1733).

After his meeting with Philipp Jacob Spener and Johann Jakob SchŸtz Gezelius was initially close to Pietism . He even translated SchŸtz's Christian Memorial Book to promote a new life into Swedish, but later turned away from Pietism when its radical tendencies became apparent. As a bishop, he was a staunch representative of Lutheran Orthodoxy and opposed the early Finnish pietists such as Lars Ulstadius . Also as ProkanzlerAt the academy he defended the orthodox doctrine against all innovations. With his insistence on a philologically accurate understanding of the Bible, which must also lead to the correction of the official translations, he came again and again in conflicts with Orthodoxy.

English Bio:
Benedict of Kefalonia (  after 1239) was from 1207 to 1239 the first Latin bishop of Kefalonia .

He was a relative of Count Maio, who ruled the island at that time. In Benedict's more than 37-year tenure, the transition from a Greek to a Latin episcopate in Franconian Greece, the reorganization of the Church after the Fourth Lateran Council , the changing affiliations of secular powers and finally the problems of the often uneducated and scandalous clergy Benedict was accused of simony , ignorance, negligence and sexual misconduct during the first decades after the Fourth Crusade .

English Bio:
Michael Akominatos (* 1138 in Chonai ,   1222 Keos ), after his birthplace called Choniates , was Greek Orthodox Metropolitan of Athens . He was the older brother of historian Niketas Choniates .

Born around 1138 in Chonai, ancient Kolossai , Michael received his education in the capital Constantinople . He was first employed by the Patriarch in 1182 Metropolitan of Athens. When the Crusaders conquered Constantinople in 1204 and established a Latin hierarchy, Choniates retired to the island of Keos, where he died about 1222.

Er starb 1564.
English Bio:
Lorenzo Campeggi (* 1474 in Milan ,   July 25, 1539 in Rome ), less correct sometimes also Campeggio , was an Italian lawyer and cardinal .

The eldest son of the famous lawyer Giovanni Zaccaria Campeggi studied the rights in Padua , taught in Venice from 1496 to 1499 and became professor at the University of Bologna in 1500 , in the same year he married Francesca Guastavillani . The marriage came from three sons and two daughters, born in 1504 Alessandro was also bishop of Bologna and cardinal. After the death of his wife in 1509 Lorenzo entered the spiritual state and was first Pope Julius II , who had helped the family Campeggi to rule over Bologna, the auditor of the RotaHe was appointed, but half a year later, as nuncio to Maximilian I , where he found the support of Gurk Bishop Matthew Lang . In 1512 Campeggi was appointed Bishop of Feltre and sent as nuncio first to Milan , then in 1513 again in the kingdom. Pope Leo X. created him in 1517 cardinal and appointed him in 1518 the cardinal priest of the titular church of San Tommaso in Parione , 1519 of Sant'Anastasia . Clement VII transferred him in 1528 to Santa Maria in Trastevere, In 1534 he was admitted to the class of cardinal bishops by Clement VII .

In 1519 he went as a papal legate against the initial resistance of Cardinal Wolsey to England, where Henry VIII gave him an exspect on the diocese of Salisbury and gave a palace in Rome [1] . Henry VIII. Appointed him in 1523 to the cardinal protector of England [2] . The new Pope Clement VII transferred him in 1523 to the diocese of Bologna , which was to remain family property until 1563. Campeggi's most famous broadcast is the one to the Reichstag of Nuremberg1524, where he skillfully avoided the resolute demands of the estates after a church reform, while he won at the same time at the Regensburg Convention some German princes for a permanent connection to the Pope. A new mission to England to dissuade Henry VIII from divorce or to persuade Catherine to renounce voluntarily was unsuccessful (1528). After attending the coronation of Charles V in Bologna, he accompanied the Emperor in 1530 to the Diet of Augsburg , where he urged him to be intransigent against the Protestants and, in an emergency, to use violence. After he was elected in 1534 for the election of Paul III. he had died diligently in 1539.

His brother Tommaso Campeggi accompanied him on several missions, followed him as bishop of Feltre, took part as papal nuncio at the Worms religious dialogue (1540/41) and was papal legate in the first time of the Trent Council . He died in 1564.

Sein GroÃŸonkel war der Kardinal Bernardo Navagero, sein Onkel Kardinal Agostino Valier. Der Familie entstammten mit Bertuccio Valier und Silvestro Valier zwei Dogen des 17. Jahrhunderts.  Ab 1605 lebte Pietro Valier im Apostolischen Palast. 1607 wurde er Referendar bei den GerichtshÃ¶fen der Apostolischen Signatur, 1609 war er Gouverneur von San Severino, 1610 Gouverneur von Todi und von 1610 bis 1614 Gouverneur von Orvieto. Januar und die Titelkirche San Salvatore in Lauro am 3. MÃ¤rz desselben Jahres. Er nahm am Konklave 1621 teil, das Papst Gregor XV. wÃ¤hlte. Oktober 1623 wurde er mit dem persÃ¶nlichen Titel eines Erzbischofs auf den Bischofssitz von Ceneda (Vittorio Veneto) transferiert. Am 18. MÃ¤rz 1624 optierte er fÃ¼r die Titelkirche San Marco. English Bio:
Pietro Valier (also Pietro Valerio , Pietro Valiero and Pietro Valieri * 1574 in Venice ,   5 April or 9 April [1] 1629 in Padua ) was an Italian cardinal of the Roman Church .

He was the second of six children of the Venetian patrician Giovanni Luigi Valier and his wife Laura Bernardo. His great-uncle was Cardinal Bernardo Navagero , his uncle Cardinal Agostino Valier . The family came with Bertuccio Valier and Silvestro Valier two doge of the 17th century.

From 1605 Pietro Valier lived in the Apostolic Palace . In 1607 he was a clerk at the courts of the Apostolic Signatura , 1609 he was Governor of San Severino , 1610 Governor of Todi and 1610-1614 Governor of Orvieto . He was also a canon of the cathedral chapter of Padua.

On May 18, 1611 Pietro Valier was appointed Titular Bishop of Famagusta . He was governor of Spoleto from 28 February 1614 to 1616 , then to about 1621 nuncio in Tuscany. On May 18, 1620 he was raised to the Archbishop of Candia (Crete) and received on June 1 of the same year, the pallium .

In the consistory of January 11, 1621 Pope Paul V. Pietro Valier created the cardinal priest . The red hat he received on 14 January and the titular church of San Salvatore in Lauro on 3 March of the same year. He participated in the conclave in 1621 , the Pope Gregory XV. elected. He was appointed a member of the Congregation Propaganda Fide in 1622. Pietro Valier was a participant in the conclave in 1623 , emerged from the Urban VIII as Pope. On October 2, 1623 he was with the personal title of archbishop on the bishopric of Ceneda(Vittorio Veneto) transferred. On 18 March 1624 he opted for the titular church of San Marco . He was transferred to the bishopric of Padua on 18 August 1625.

Pietro Valier died on 5 or 9 April 1629 and was buried in the Cathedral of Padua , where a cenotaph was erected in his honor .

German Bio: Marino Grimani (* 1488/1489 in Venedig; â€  28. September 1546 in Orvieto) war ein italienischer Kardinal und Patriarch.  Die Grimani gehÃ¶rten zu den "Case Nuove" des Patriziats von Venedig, der handeltreibenden Oberschicht der Republik Venedig. Marino war das dritte von acht Kindern des Gerolamo Grimani und dessen Ehefrau Elena Priuli. Sein Onkel Domenico Grimani war 1493 Kardinal geworden.  Er wurde 1508 Bischof des Bistums Ceneda. 1517 wurde er Patriarch von Aquileia. Papst Clemens VII. kreierte ihn im Konsistorium vom 3. Mai 1527 zum Kardinalpriester und verlieh ihm am 7. Februar 1528 die Titelkirche San Vitale. Danach war Kardinal Grimani Bischof der BistÃ¼mer Concordia (1533), CittÃ  di Castello (1534) und Saint-Pons-de-ThomiÃ¨res (1534). September 1543 wechselte Grimani auf den suburbikarischen Bischofssitz von Porto und Santa Rufina, zugleich wurde er Kardinalsubdekan. Er wurde am 23. MÃ¤rz 1545 Lateinischer Patriarch von Konstantinopel, was er bis zu seinem Tode blieb.  Marino Grimani starb 1546 in Orvieto und wurde in der dortigen Kathedrale beigesetzt.  Ein spÃ¤ter lebender Verwandter war Vincenzo Grimani, der 1697 zum Kardinal erhoben wurde.
English Bio:
Marino Grimani (* 1488/1489 in Venice ,   September 28, 1546 in Orvieto ) was an Italian cardinal and patriarch .

The Grimani were among the "Case Nuove" of the patriciate of Venice , the trading upper class of the Republic of Venice . Marino was the third of eight children of Gerolamo Grimani and his wife Elena Priuli. His uncle Domenico Grimani became cardinal in 1493.

He was bishop of the diocese of Ceneda in 1508 . In 1517 he became Patriarch of Aquileia . Pope Clement VII created him in the Consistory of May 3, 1527 cardinal priest and awarded him on 7 February 1528, the titular church of San Vitale . Then Cardinal Grimani was bishop of the dioceses of Concordia (1533), Cittˆ di Castello (1534) and Saint-Pons-de-Thomires (1534). Between 1535 and 1541 he was appointed as Papal Legate of Paul III.entrusted with various missions. On March 13, 1541, his elevation to the cardinal bishop of Frascati . On September 24, 1543 Grimani moved to the suburbicarian bishopric of Porto and Santa Rufina , at the same time he became Cardinal Sub-Dean . He became Latin Patriarch of Constantinople on March 23, 1545 , which he remained until his death.

Marino Grimani died in 1546 in Orvieto and was buried in the cathedral there.

A later living relative was Vincenzo Grimani , who was raised in 1697 cardinal.

English Bio:
Francesco degli Atti (* in Todi ,   August 25 or September 4, 1361 in Pont de Sorgues , today in the Vaucluse , France ) was a cardinal of the Roman Church and Bishop of Florence .

After studying canon law , he was elected bishop of Corfu in May 1348 , and in September of the same year Pope Clement VI. transferred to Chiusi . In 1351 he was a member of the Arbitration Commission, the peace between Amadeus VI. of Savoy and the Dauphin Charles of Vienne. On June 15, 1353, he was bishop of Cassino , which he left in 1355 Angelo Acciaiuoli and was his successor in Florence. Degli Atti was founded by Pope Innocent VI. on December 23, 1356 cardinal priest of San Marcoappointed. He left Florence and went to Avignon , where he worked among other things as Gro§pšnitentiar . In 1359 he formulated the papal judgment against the Teutonic Order in its dispute with the Archdiocese of Riga . From his time as bishop of Chiusi the treaty comes De quarta canonica piorum legatorum debita episcopo [1] , in which he tried to justify the claims of the bishop to a quarter of pious legacies. Contemporaries like Baldus took a critical look at his arguments.

German Bio: Mieszko von Beuthen (auch Mestko/Mesko von Beuthen; polnisch Mieszko bytomski; tschechisch MÄ›Å¡ek Bytomsko-KoselskÃ½ ; * 1295/1300; â€  1344 in VeszprÃ©m) war Herzog von Beuthen. 1328â€“1334 war er Bischof von Neutra und 1334â€“1344 Bischof von VeszprÃ©m sowie Prior der ungarischen Johanniterprovinz. Da der Widerstand des Neutraer Domkapitels gegen ihn auch in den nachfolgenden Jahren anhielt, gelangte er auf Empfehlung der ungarischen KÃ¶nigin Elisabeth 1334 auf den Bischofsstuhl von VeszprÃ©m. English Bio:
Mieszko von Beuthen (also Mestko / Mesko of Beuthen , Polish Mieszko bytomski , Czech M__ek Bytomsko - Koselsk_ , * 1295/1300,   1344 in VeszprŽm ) was Duke of Beuthen . 1328-1334 he was Bishop of Neutra and 1334-1344 Bishop of VeszprŽm and Prior of the Hungarian Johanniterprovinz. He was also Chancellor of the Hungarian Queen Elizabeth . He came from the Beuthener branch of the Silesian Piast .

Mieszko was the youngest son of the Duke of Beuthen Kasimir II and the Helena, whose origin is unknown. They appointed him for the spiritual career. After the death of his father in 1312 his older brothers kept the possessions that were transferred to them during his lifetime of the father: Boleslaus was Duke of Tost , Wladislaus was Duke of Cosel , later also by Beuthen and Ziemowit was first Duke of Beuthen and from 1337 Duke of Gliwice . Mieszko, who probably got the Duchy of Sewerien , was already a member of the Knights of St. John in 1313 and became two years laterPrior of the Hungarian Province of the Hospitallers.

Since Mieszko's sister Mary was married to the Hungarian King Charles I Robert , her brothers also maintained good relations with the Hungarian royal court, with which they remained connected after Mary's death in 1317. Mieszko's brother Boleslaus probably lived since 1315 at the Hungarian royal court and was appointed in 1321 Archbishop of Gran . Shortly before his death in 1328, he succeeded in enforcing Mieszko on the episcopal see of Neutra , although the local cathedral chapterwas against it. Presumably in the same year Mieszko renounced the office of Johanniterpriors and in favor of his brother Wladislaus on the Duchy of Sewerien. Since the resistance of the Neutra cathedral chapter continued against him in the following years, he came on recommendation of the Hungarian Queen Elizabeth in 1334 to the episcopal see of VeszprŽm . In the same year he was appointed Chancellor of Queen Elizabeth. 1342 he participated in the coronation of the Hungarian king Louis I. part. His body was buried in the Cathedral of VeszprŽm .

Er zeichnete sich durch humanistische Gelehrsamkeit, Redegabe, diplomatisches Geschick und kirchlichen Reformeifer aus; zugleich tat er sich als Freund und MÃ¤zen von Wissenschaft und Kunst hervor.  Er studierte in Pavia Zivil- und Kirchenrecht und schloss seine Studien mit dem Doktor beider Rechte ab. Seine religiÃ¶se Entwicklung wurde durch die bÃ¶hmische Devotio moderna beeinflusst, als in den neunziger Jahren fÃ¼hrende Vertreter dieser Reformrichtung nach Italien kamen; hierbei lernte er wohl auch Gedanken des Reformpredigers Konrad von Waldhausen (1325â€“1369) kennen.  Seit 1389 kam er in diplomatischer Mission im Auftrag von Gian Galeazzo Visconti mit dem Papst in Kontakt. 1404 wurde er Bischof von Piacenza, 1409 allerdings von Gregor XII. abgesetzt. 1412 wurde er Bischof und Graf von VeszprÃ©m (WeiÃŸenbrunn/Ungarn). Seit 1411 Kardinalpriester von San Clemente, war er pÃ¤pstlicher Legat in Ungarn (seit 1410) und in Germanien (ab 1413). Im Gefolge KÃ¶nig Sigismunds reiste er viel in Deutschland, Ungarn und Polen. Er nahm auch an den Konzilien von Pisa (1409), Konstanz (1414â€“1418) und Basel (1431â€“1445) teil. Dabei ging es ihm immer wieder um die Einheit der Christenheit, sowohl in Hinblick auf das pÃ¤pstliche Schisma als auch auf die Ostkirche. Er war die treibende Kraft hinter den KreuzzÃ¼gen gegen die Hussiten und ernannte Nikolaus von DinkelsbÃ¼hl 1421 zum offiziellen Hussitenkreuzzugs-Prediger. 1421 zum Reformator generalis fÃ¼r ganz Deutschland ernannt, erstrebte er eine Reform des Klerus und der religiÃ¶sen LebensfÃ¼hrung. Kardinal Branda entwarf Reformstatuten, die Grundlage fÃ¼r Kirchen- und Klosterreformen sein konnten (wie sie dann etwa im Kloster Pillenreuth realisiert wurden).   Im Alter von Ã¼ber 70 Jahren  begann er 1423 mit einer regen BautÃ¤tigkeit in seinem Heimatort Castiglione, wozu er bedeutende KÃ¼nstler heranzog. Castiglione ist bis heute davon geprÃ¤gt. Zugleich engagierte er sich fÃ¼r Bildung sowie soziale FÃ¶rderung durch GrÃ¼ndung des Collegio Branda an der UniversitÃ¤t Pavia und durch die Errichtung von Schulen und Armenhilfen in seinem Heimatort. Am 14. MÃ¤rz 1431 wurde er zum Kardinalbischof des suburbikarischen Bistums Porto-Santa Rufina ernannt. Im Jahr 1433 saÃŸ er einem Partikularkonzil vor, das der Herzog von Mailand einberufen hatte. Am 29. Januar 1440 wechselte er auf den suburbikarischen Bischofssitz von Sabina, den er bis zu seinem Tode innehatte.  Kardinal Branda starb 1443 hochbetagt und wurde in der Kirche von Castiglione beigesetzt, wo sein Grabmal Ã¼berdauert hat.
English Bio:
Branda Castiglione , sometimes Castiglioni (* before 1360 in Milan ,   February 3, 1443 in Castiglione Olona ) was an Italian humanist , cardinal and papal legate, who was active in much of Europe in the first half of the 15th century. He distinguished himself by humanistic erudition, Redegabe, diplomatic skill and ecclesiastical reform zeal; at the same time he was a friend and patron of science and art.

He studied civil and ecclesiastical law in Pavia and completed his studies with the doctor of both rights . Its religious development was influenced by the Bohemian devotio moderna , as in the nineties leading representatives of this reform direction came to Italy; Here he probably got to know thoughts of the reform preacher Konrad von Waldhausen (1325-1369). Since 1389 he came in diplomatic mission on behalf of Gian Galeazzo Visconti in contact with the Pope. In 1404 he became bishop of Piacenza , but in 1409 by Gregory XII. discontinued. In 1412 he became bishop and Count of VeszprŽm (Wei§enbrunn / Hungary). Since 1411Cardinal priest of San Clemente , he was a papal legate in Hungary (since 1410) and in Germania (from 1413). In the wake of King Sigismund he traveled a lot in Germany, Hungary and Poland. He also participated in the councils of Pisa (1409), Constance (1414-1418) and Basel (1431-1445). He was always concerned with the unity of Christendom, both with regard to the papal schism and to the Eastern Church. He was the driving force behind the Crusades against the Hussites and appointed Nikolaus von DinkelsbŸhl 1421 officialHussite Crusade-Preacher. Appointed general reformer for the whole of Germany in 1421 , he sought to reform the clergy and religious life. Cardinal Branda drafted reform statutes, which could be the basis for church and monastery reforms (as they were then realized in the monastery Pillenreuth ).

At the age of 70 he began in 1423 with a busy construction in his hometown of Castiglione, to which he drew important artists. Castiglione is still shaped by this. At the same time, he was involved in education and social promotion by founding the Collegio Branda at the University of Pavia and by setting up schools and aid to poor people in his hometown. On March 14, 1431 he was appointed Cardinal Bishop of the suburbicarian diocese of Porto-Santa Rufina . In 1433 he presided over a Particulate Council convened by the Duke of Milan. On January 29, 1440 he moved to the suburbicari bishopric of Sabinahe held until his death.

Cardinal Branda died very old in 1443 and was buried in the church of Castiglione, where his tomb survived.

German Bio:
Johann VitŽz (  1499) war Bischof von Sirmium, ernannter Administrator von OlmŸtz, Bischof von VeszprŽm und Administrator von Wien.

Johann VitŽz war der Neffe des gleichnamigen Erzbischofs Johann VitŽz von Gran. Er studierte vermutlich in Paris und wurde spŠter Kanzler und Legat des ungarischen Kšnigs Matthias Corvinus. Dieser nominierte am 31. MŠrz 1482 Johann VitŽz zum Bischof von Sirmium.

1487 wurde VitŽz vom Papst zum Administrator des Bistums OlmŸtz ernannt, konnte sich dort jedoch nicht durchsetzen, da Johann Filipec noch im Amt war. Wohl deshalb transferierte der Papst Johann VitŽz am 3. Juni 1489 nach VeszprŽm.

Nach dem Tod von Matthias Corvinus nominierte der Kaisersohn Maximilian am 3. November 1490 Johann VitŽz zum Administrator des Bistums Wien. Da die Nominierung ohne Zustimmung von Maximilians Vater Friedrich III. erfolgt war, legte Johann VitŽz am 9. Februar 1492 den Treueeid vor dem Kaiser ab, der danach der Nominierung zustimmte. Obwohl VitŽz das Bistum VeszprŽm weiterhin behielt, erfolgte die pŠpstliche Translation nach Wien am 8. Februar 1493.

Die von Konrad Celtis gegrŸndete Gelehrtengesellschaft ãSodalitas literaria DanubiaÒ wŠhlte Johann VitŽz zu ihrem Vorsitzenden.
English Bio:
John VitŽz (  1499 ) was Bishop of Sirmium , appointed administrator of Olomouc , Bishop of VeszprŽm and administrator of Vienna .

Johann VitŽz was the nephew of the eponymous archbishop Johann VitŽz of Gran . He probably studied in Paris and later became chancellor and legate of the Hungarian King Matthias Corvinus . This nominated on 31 March 1482 Johann VitŽz to the Bishop of Sirmium .

1487 VitŽz was appointed by the Pope administrator of the Diocese of Olomouc, but could not prevail there, as Johann Filipec was still in office. Probably because of this the pope transferred Johann VitŽz on 3 June 1489 to VeszprŽm.

After the death of Matthias Corvinus nominated the Emperor's son Maximilian on November 3, 1490 Johann VitŽz administrator of the diocese of Vienna. Since the nomination without the consent of Maximilian father Friedrich III. was done, put on January 9, 1492 Johann VitŽz the oath of allegiance to the emperor, who then agreed to the nomination. Although VitŽz continued to retain the diocese of VeszprŽm, the papal translation to Vienna took place on 8 February 1493.

The scholar society "Sodalitas literaria Danubia", founded by Konrad Celtis , elected Johann VitŽz as its chairman.

English Bio:
Istv‡n B‡ncsa (* in Hungary ,   July 9, 1270 [1] in Rome ) was Archbishop of Esztergom and the first Hungarian cardinal of the Roman Church . He is also performed as Stefan V‡ncza and Stephanus de Vancsa ; his last name is also written V‡ncsa , V‡ncha , Vanca or B‡nca .

He was first Provost in V‡c and from 1238 to 1240 Chancellor of the Hungarian King BŽla IV. In 1241 he went to Rome and was elected in the same year the Bishop of V‡c . On 7 July 1243 he was appointed Archbishop of Esztergom. On July 19, 1251 he became a legate in Croatia and Dalmatia.

In the Consistory of December 1251 Pope Innocent IV made him Cardinal-Bishop of Palestrina . On May 5, 1253 he was appointed legate in Hungary and Slavonia. He participated in the papal election in 1254 , from which Alexander IV emerged as Pope. In the papal election in 1261 with the election of Urban IV , he could not attend because he was at that time in Hungary. His name can be found again among the pope voters of 1264-1265 , who elected Clement IV in the Papal Office; He was also involved in the papal election 1268-1271 , but died during the Sedisvakanz,

He was buried in the church of Santa Balbina in Rome.

Obwohl seine Erfolge nicht belegt sind und groÃŸe Siege nicht zu verzeichnen waren, verbreiteten sich Legenden, die aus ihm einen groÃŸen Feldherrn machten und die ihm den Beinamen Der Eiserne einbrachten. Die Werke von John Wyclif, Jan Hus und Jakobellus von Mies durften weder gelesen noch verbreitet werden, lobende Ã„uÃŸerungen Ã¼ber Jan Hus und Hieronymus von Prag waren verboten. Die Prediger benÃ¶tigten fÃ¼r ihr Tun eine bischÃ¶fliche Genehmigung.  Im MÃ¤rz und Juni 1429 nahm Johann in PreÃŸburg an wichtigen Verhandlungen mit KÃ¶nig Sigismund teil. Dieser ernannte ihn nach dem Tod des Bischofs Nikolas von Salgo 1430 zum Administrator von Waitzen. Nach dem im selben Jahr erfolgten Tod wurde er in der dortigen Franziskanerkirche bestattet.  Johann war ein groÃŸer BÃ¼cherliebhaber; davon zeugt vor allem sein prunkvolles Gebetbuch (Stams, Stiftsbibliothek, Cod. 12). Er verfasste auch Schriften zur BekÃ¤mpfung der Ketzerei. English Bio:
John of Bucca (also: John the Iron , John de Bucca , John of Prague , according to the bishops list of Leitomischl: John IV of Bucca, the Iron , after the list of bishops of Olomouc: John XII of Bucca, the Iron , czech Jan _elezn_ * probably Prague ,   October 9, 1430 in Gran or Bratislava ) was bishop of Leitomischl and Olomouc , administrator of Prague and Waitzen as wellCardinal .

Johann came from the Prague branch of the noble family of Beneschau . His father H‡na the Younger was 1379-1381 councilor of the Old Town of Prague . His mother also came from a Prague patrician family. After training in Prague Johann was probably some time in service with King Wenceslas IV. In addition, he should have been a master in law school and canon of Prague and provost at the collegiate St. Apollinaris .

After the transfer of Leitomischler Bishop John III. Sob_slav in 1387 to the Patriarch of Aquileia appointed Pope Urban VI. 1388 Johann von Bucca as his successor. In the same year, John settled a dispute between the Prague Archbishop Johann von Jenstein and the royal servant Dietrich von Makov. In 1391 he appointed a Czech preacher for his cathedral. In the political power dispute between the king and John of Jenstein, he stood on the side of Jenstein. After the death of the Prague General Vicar John of Nepomuk , John of Bucca rose to the spokesman for the Bohemian clergyon. In early 1395 he joined the opposition nobility party. In 1398 he issued for the Leitomischler chapter statutes with which the diocese foundation could be completed.

In 1399 Johann made friends with King Sigismund of Hungary, who stayed with Johann for some time. During the imprisonment of King Wenceslas, John belonged to the government appointed by Sigismund. In the same year Sigismund tried to occupy the vacant Prague Archbishop's chair with John of Bucca. Since he could not prevail with it, there were fights in which Johann occupied the archiepiscopal castle Raudnitz . As a result , Zbynko Zaj’c of Hasenburg, John of Bucca, who was ordained a bishop of Prague in November 1402 and only elected by the cathedral chapter in September 1403, excommunicated him . After a conciliation of the dispute by Heinrich von Rosenberg the excommunication was not lifted until October 1405.

In the religious battles Johann ran an anti-Hussite policy. On behalf of the king, whose trust he obviously had again, he and the then Olomouc Bishop Konrad von Vechta 1413 should convene a synod on the measures against the heretics should be taken. Since members of the Prague University , who were on the side of the Hussites, were loaded, Johann did not take part in the synod.

The antipope John XXIII. instructed Johann to intervene against Jan Hus . Probably because of this Johann was appointed to the extraordinary synod of 1414 as the head of the Bohemian representation for the Council of Constance . There he was commissioned with the restoration of ecclesiastical order and returned in 1415 to Bohemia. Since he had little success with his mission in Bohemia, he went to Moravia and concluded a contract with the Olomouc bishop for the fight against the Hussites. The contract was followed by the two cathedral chapters of Prague and Olomouc.

Despite his political activities, Johann also took care of his diocese. For a regular administrative procedure he ordered vicars and officials . In 1393, with papal approval, he transferred the Landskron Abbey to the Marienkirche in the town, and in 1397 the Tr_ek Charterhouse dedicated to "Maria Dornbusch" , for which Bishop Albrecht von Sternberg donated the Episcopal estate Tr_ek, moved to Dolany in Moravia. In 1401 Johann held a diocesan synod from, in 1406 he visited his parish.

After the death of Olomouc administrator Wenzel Gerard von Burenitz elected on 21 September 1416, the majority of the present canons John of Bucca as his successor. However, the then absent members voted on October 3, the Vy_ehrad dean Albrecht von B_ez’ . King Wenceslas and the Prague Archbishop confirmed the election of Albrecht, whose opponents should be captured. After Albrecht attended the Mass of a Hussite priest a few days after his inauguration, a revolt broke out in Olomouc. Albrecht fled to the episcopal city of Kremsier .

Thereupon ordered on 14 December 1416 the Konstanzer council Johann von Bucca to the administrator of OlmŸtz. Nevertheless, the king and the archbishop refused to confirm Johann in office. Albrecht was also unwilling to give up. That is why Johann began to take over the episcopal castles and estates. On February 14, 1418 confirmed the newly elected Pope Martin V. Johann von Bucca as Bishop of Olomouc. Although Albrecht continued to refuse a transfer, Johann prevailed. Immediately he took measures against Hussitism, which included the ban on the Chalice Communion .

After the Prague Bishop Konrad von Vechta accepted the Four Articles of Prague in April 1421 , he effectively became the head of the Hussite Church. This was the beginning of the sedate vacancy of the Prague archdiocese. Therefore, the Pope John of Bucca appointed administrator of the Catholic part of the Archdiocese of Prague. The office of Olomouc bishop continued to keep Johann.

As a follower of King Sigismund, Johann was involved in all significant political events in the next few years. During the absence of Sigismund, he received extensive powers, with which he was also able to depose captains and appoint city councils.

Despite his advanced age, Johann took part in the campaign of Olomouc and Austrians against the Hussite camp near Nedakonice and other military campaigns. Although his successes are not proven and large victories were not recorded, spread legends that made him a great general and earned him the nickname The Iron .

Because of his merits, the Pope John in 1426 appointed cardinal priest of S. Ciriaco. A year later Johann issued further prohibitions. The works of John Wyclif , Jan Hus and Jakobellus of Mies could not be read or disseminated, and praising remarks about Jan Hus and Jerome of Prague were forbidden. The preachers needed an episcopal permit for their work.

In March and June 1429, Johann participated in important negotiations with King Sigismund in Bratislava. This appointed him after the death of Bishop Nikolas of Salgo 1430 administrator of Waitzen. After the death in the same year he was buried in the local Franciscan church.

Johann was a great book lover; This is especially evident in his splendid prayer book ( Stams, Abbey Library, Cod. 12 ). He also wrote writings to combat heresy. The treatises are known :

Liber salutis and
Specimen salutis .

German Bio:
Nicolaus B‡thory (ungarisch Mikl—s B‡thory, * um 1435;   1506) war ein ungarischer Bischof.

Er studierte in Bologna bei dem bekannten Historiker und Humanisten Galeotto Marzio, der auch Chronist am Hof von Matthias Corvinus war. 
1475 wurde er Bischof von V‡c. Unter dem Eindruck seiner Studienjahre in Italien lie§ er die Burgen in V‡c und N—gr‡d im Renaissancestil ausbauen.

Er fŸhrte einen regen Briefwechsel mit Marsilio Ficino und anderen bedeutenden italienischen Humanisten.
English Bio:
Nicolaus B‡thory ( Hungarian Mikl—s B‡thory, * 1435,   1506 ) was a Hungarian bishop .

He studied in Bologna with the well-known historian and humanist Galeotto Marzio , who was also a chronicler at the court of Matthias Corvinus . 
In 1475 he became bishop of V‡c . Under the impression of his years of study in Italy, he had the castles in V‡c and N—gr‡d built in the Renaissance style.

He had a lively correspondence with Marsilio Ficino and other important Italian humanists .

Hl. Gerhard
German Bio:
Gerhard von Csan‡d, auch Giorgio di Sagredo, Gerhard Sagredo oder ung. GellŽrt (* um 980 in Venedig oder Venetien;   24. September 1046 in Buda) war der erste Bischof von Csan‡d. Er wird in der ršmisch-katholischen Kirche als Heiliger verehrt und ist Stadtpatron von Budapest.

Gerhard wurde in eine wohlhabende Adelsfamilie in Venedig geboren, war langobardischer Herkunft und stammte aus der Familie Sagredo. Der †berlieferung zufolge soll er als Kind schwer krank gewesen sein. Seine Eltern brachten ihn in ein Benediktinerkloster und versprachen ihn dort dem Mšnchtum, sollte er wieder gesunden. So wurde Gerhard Novize bei den Benediktinern[1] Gerhard studierte in Bologna. Nach dem Tod des Abtes wurde er 1012 zum Abt des Benediktinerstiftes gewŠhlt.

Sein Vater Gerhard fiel auf einem Kreuzzug, woraufhin Giorgio sich nach ihm benannte und es ihm darin gleichtun wollte, die Moslems zu bekehren. So brach er im Jahre 1015 auch ins Heilige Land auf. Auf dieser Reise lernte er Rasia, den Abt des kŸrzlich gegrŸndeten ungarischen Klosters Pannonhalma kennen, der ihn nach Ungarn einlud, und GellŽrt folgte der Einladung.[2]

Der erste christliche Kšnig Ungarns, der hl. Stephan I., war von Gerhards Predigten so beeindruckt, dass er ihm die Erziehung seines achtjŠhrigen Sohnes Imre (Emmerich) anvertraute. Gerhard sollte sieben Jahre dessen Lehrer bleiben. Anschlie§end widmete sich Gerhard der †berlieferung zufolge weitere sieben Jahre dem Studium der Schrift und dem Verfassen eines Bibelkommentars. Bei der Deliberatio handelt es sich wahrscheinlich um den ersten in Ungarn entstandenen Bibelkommentar.[1]

Kšnig Stefan I. schenkte dem Oberfeldherrn Csan‡d fŸr seine Tapferkeit im Krieg gegen seinen Erzrivalen Achtwin 1028 die Maroschburg (Urbs Morisena) und die ausgedehnten Liegenschaften Achtwins dazu. Fortan wurde die Stadt nicht mehr Maroschburg, sondern Csan‡d genannt, wie auch die ganze Provinz.[1] Den Namen Csan‡d trug spŠter auch das hier gegrŸndete Bistum, dessen Oberhirte der heilige Gerhard wurde. Die Bischofsweihe des Heiligen im Jahre 1030 ist zugleich der Zeitpunkt der Errichtung der Dišzese Csan‡d.[1] In Csan‡d errichtete Gerhard die Domschule, an deren Spitze Walter und Henricus Teutonicus standen und die Studenten aus Bšhmen, Polen und Deutschland besuchten. Als Doctor decretorum und Magister sacrae theologiae war Gerhard auch ein fruchtbarer Schriftsteller.[2]

Der Bischof von Csan‡d spielte bei der Bekehrung der Heiden in Ungarn und in SiebenbŸrgen eine entscheidende Rolle. AnlŠsslich eines Heidenaufstands erlitt Gerhard in Buda, am heute nach ihm benannten Gellertberg, zusammen mit den Bischšfen Buldus und Bystr’k den MŠrtyrertod am 24. September 1046. Der Legende nach wurde er in einem Fass, das mit NŠgeln gespickt war, den HŸgel in die Donau hinuntergerollt und dort ertrŠnkt.[1]

Die Reliquien des hl. Gerhard wurden 1053 von seinem Nachfolger Maurus und Abt Philipp in den Csan‡der Dom ŸberfŸhrt und in einen einfachen, aus Stein gemei§elten und bis heute erhaltenen Sarkophag gelegt[3], der heute den Altar der ršmisch-katholischen Kirche bildet. Teile seiner Reliquien kamen in die Domkirche nach Stuhlwei§enburg (SzŽkesfehŽrv‡r), aber auch nach Venedig und in die Kirche des Priesterseminars zu Budapest.[2]

Gerhard wurde gemeinsam mit Kšnig Stephan 1083 von Papst Gregor VII. heiliggesprochen und ist heute Schutzpatron Budapests und einer der Patrone Ungarns.Dem heiligen Gerhard werden die folgenden Werke zugeschrieben:[4][5]

De laudibus B.M. Virginis
Sermomum quadragesimalium
Homiliarum de solemnitatibus totius anni
Au§er der Deliberatio sind keine Werke erhalten.
English Bio:
Gerhard von Csan‡d , also Giorgio di Sagredo , Gerhard Sagredo or ung. GellŽrt (* 980 in Venice or Veneto ,   24 September 1046 in Buda ) was the first bishop of Csan‡d . He is revered as a saint in the Roman Catholic Church and is the patron saint of Budapest .

Gerhard was born into a wealthy noble family in Venice , was of Longobard origin and came from the family Sagredo . According to tradition, he was said to have been seriously ill as a child. His parents took him to a Benedictine monastery and promised him monasticism there should he recover. Gerhard was a novice at the Benedictine monks [1] Gerhard studied in Bologna . After the death of the abbot he was elected in 1012 the abbot of the Benedictine monastery.

His father Gerhard fell on a crusade , whereupon Giorgio called himself after him and it would be like him to convert the Muslims. So in 1015 he also set out for the Holy Land . On this trip, he met Rasia, the abbot of the recently founded Hungarian monastery Pannonhalma , who invited him to Hungary, and GellŽrt accepted the invitation. [2]

The first Christian king of Hungary, the hl. Stephen I was so impressed by Gerhard's sermons that he entrusted him with the education of his eight-year-old son Imre (Emmerich) . Gerhard was to remain his teacher for seven years. Subsequently, Gerhard devoted himself to the tradition of another seven years studying the Scriptures and writing a Bible commentary. The Deliberatio is probably the first Bible commentary written in Hungary. [1]

King Stefan I gave the commander in chief Csan‡d for his bravery in the war against his arch rival Achtwin 1028 the Maroschburg ( Urbs Morisena ) and the extensive properties Achtwins to. From then on, the city was no longer called Maroschburg, but Csan‡d, as well as the whole province. [1] The name Csan‡d later was also founded here diocese whose chief shepherd of the holy Gerhard was. The episcopal ordination of the saint in 1030 is also the date of the establishment of the diocese of Csan‡d . [1]In Csan‡d Gerhard built the cathedral school, headed by Walter and Henricus Teutonicus and the students from Bohemia, Poland and Germany visited. As Doctor decretorum and Master sacrae theologiae Gerhard was also a prolific writer. [2]

The Bishop of Csan‡d played a crucial role in the conversion of the pagans in Hungary and Transylvania . On the occasion of a pagan uprising, Gerhard was martyred on June 24, 1046 in Buda, today named after him Gellertberg , together with the bishops Buldus and Bystr’k. According to legend, he was in a barrel, which was peppered with nails, the hill in the Danube rolled down and drowned there. [1]

The relics of St. Gerhard were in 1053 by his successor Maurus and Abbot Philip in the Csan‡d cathedral transferred and placed in a plain, carved in stone and preserved by the present sarcophagus [3] , which today serves as the altar of the Roman Catholic Church. Parts of his relics came to the cathedral after Stuhlwei§enburg ( SzŽkesfehŽrv‡r ), but also to Venice and the church of the seminary in Budapest . [2]

Gerhard was canonized together with King Stephen in 1083 by Pope Gregory VII and is today the patron saint of Budapest and one of the patrons of Hungary .

The following works are attributed to Saint Gerhard: [4] [5]

De laudibus BM Virginis
Sermomum quadragesimalium
Homiliarum de solemnitatibus totius anni
Apart from the Deliberatio no works have been preserved.

English Bio:
Andreas Dudith of Horehowicza , also Andreas Dudith Sbardellati , Andreas Duditius de Sbardellatus , Andreas Dudelius de Stardelaccis (Croatian Andrija Dudi_ , Hungarian Andr‡s Dudith , Czech Ond_ej Dudi_ z Horehovic , Polish Andrzej Dudycz ; * February 5, 1533 in Ofen ,   February 2 1589 in Breslau ) was a Hungarian humanist , bishop , imperial diplomat and reformed Protestant,

Dudith was born in Hungary and came from a Croatian noble family. His mother, from whom came his surname Sbardellatus , was a Venetian of the Sbardellati family. [1] He studied among others in Venice and Padua . He was titular prophet of FelhŽv’z ( îbuda ), Auxiliary Bishop in the Archdiocese of Gran and was ordained in 1560 Bishop of Tina (southern Croatia). From 1562 to 1563 Dudith was bishop of Csan‡d . At the Council of Trent Dudith in 1562 was one of the proponents of the lifting of the ban on the Chalicefor laymen and later demanded the abolition of celibacy . Between 1563 and 1567 he worked as bishop of FŸnfkirchen . In diplomatic service Emperor Maximilian II Dudith was in 1566 Polish royal court in Krakow , where he secretly engaged with a court lady. In 1567 he submitted his resignation from the episcopate, converted to Protestantism , married and moved to Krakow. Pope Pius V. cast a spell on him and publicly burned his picture in Rome. When his wife died after seven years of marriage, Dudith made a second marriage in 1574 to El_bieta Zborowska, the widow of Count Jan Tarnowski.

In Krakow, Dudith sat for the election of Maximilian II on the Polish throne and left after the coronation Stephan B‡thorys Poland. By Rudolf II Dudith was raised to the Moravian baron and bought in 1578 the rule Paskau in Moravia . Since he did not like the life in the remote town and the management of the goods, he sold Paskau in 1579 and moved to Breslau, where he turned back to scientific work and a Calvinistic-humanistic circle of scholars gathered around him. Dudith's Epitaph is located in the Wroc_aw Elisabeth Church . His daughter Regina married after his death in 1595 the Polish nobles and unitariansJerome Moscorzowski .

Dort verÃ¶ffentlichte er 1616 eine Abhandlung Ã¼ber Logik und einen groÃŸen Band seiner Machinae novae. Von seiner Krankheit an der Weiterreise gehindert starb er am 20. Januar 1617 in Venedig.[1]  Er wurde auf seinen ausdrÃ¼cklichen Wunsch hin in der Kirche Sveta Marija u Luci auf der Insel PrviÄ‡ bestattet.  Das bekannteste Werk von Fausto Veranzio sind wohl seine Machinae Novae, von denen nur wenige Exemplare erhalten sind. Es besteht aus der Titelseite, 49 Tafeln mit Abbildungen und ErlÃ¤uterungen in fÃ¼nf Sprachen (Latein, Italienisch, Spanisch, FranzÃ¶sisch und Deutsch). Die erhaltenen Exemplare sind nicht vollkommen identisch. Da einige seiner Freunde ihm im Juli 1616 fÃ¼r das Buch dankten, kann angenommen werden, dass es Anfang 1616 gedruckt wurde.  Veranzio befasste sich mit hydrologischen Problemen wie zum Beispiel der MÃ¶glichkeit, Ãœberflutungen durch den Tiber zu verhindern oder Venedig mit Trinkwasser zu versorgen. Andere Darstellungen betreffen Sonnenuhren, Wind-, Wasser- und GezeitenmÃ¼hlen, eine Seilbahn, eine KettenbrÃ¼cke und einen Fallschirm. Eine der Tafeln zeigt eine hÃ¶lzerne, massive SegmentbogenbrÃ¼cke aus Balken mit Nut-Feder-Verbindungen, eine BogenbrÃ¼cke mit einem unechten Bogen mit der als Zugband dienenden  untenliegenden Fahrbahn und mit Fachwerkstreben als Versteifung, sowie eine linsenfÃ¶rmige BogenbrÃ¼cke, die die von Isambard Kingdom Brunel 1859 gebaute Royal Albert Bridge in Saltash, Cornwall, vorwegnimmt. Manche dieser Ideen waren nicht absolut neu, aber erschienen erstmals in gedruckter Form, andere waren ihrer Zeit weit voraus.    Weit verbreiteten Angaben zufolge soll Veranzio 1617 den Fallschirm persÃ¶nlich getestet haben, indem er, je nach Quelle, vom Campanile di San Marco in Venedig oder vom Glockenturm des 86 m hohen St. Martinsdoms in Bratislava oder von einer BrÃ¼cke in Venedig sprang. Er gilt daher vielen als erster Mensch, der einen Fallschirm bis zum Stadium eines tatsÃ¤chlichen Einsatzes entwickelt habe. Als Beleg wird angefÃ¼hrt, dass sein Sprung in dem 30 Jahre spÃ¤ter erschienenen Werk Mathematical Magick or, The wonders that may by performed by mechanichal geometry von John Wilkins dokumentiert sei.[6]  Es erscheint aber mehr als zweifelhaft, dass der 65 Jahre alte, schwer kranke Veranzio sich auf solch ein Abenteuer eingelassen habe, und dass der immer noch sehr kleine Fallschirm einen Fall genÃ¼gend gebremst haben kÃ¶nnte. Es wird auch nicht diskutiert, wie jemand von einem Turm aus den Rahmen des Fallschirms in waagerechter Lage in die Luft und sich selbst unter diesen Rahmen bringen kÃ¶nnte.  TatsÃ¤chlich befasst sich John Wilkins in dem  Werk Mathematical Magick unter anderem mit der MÃ¶glichkeit zu fliegen, aber in keiner Weise mit einem Fallschirm oder sonstigen MÃ¶glichkeiten, den Fall eines Menschen zu bremsen. Auch Veranzio wird in dem Werk  Ã¼berhaupt nicht erwÃ¤hnt, auch kein Ereignis aus dem Jahr 1617. Offensichtlich wurde mit dieser Geschichte eine frÃ¼he, moderne Sage in die Welt gesetzt.
English Bio:
Fausto Veranzio (also Faustus Verantius , Serbo-Croatian  Faust Vran_i_ / _____ _______ , Hungarian Verancsics Faustus ) (* 1551 in Sibenik , Republic of Venice ;   20th January 1617 in Venice ) [1] [2] [3] was a diplomat , minister , Universal scholar and inventor , who became known to posterity especially through his work Machinae Novae .

Born from the marriage of diplomat and poet Michele Vran_i_ and his wife Catherine Dobroevi_, Veranzio came from a noble family that lived in _ibenik but had a summer residence in _epurine on the nearby island of Prvi_ . The family included various church dignitaries. His uncle Antun Vran_i_ (Antonius Verantius), an influential statesman, acquaintance of Philipp Melanchthon and Erasmus of Rotterdam and later Primate of Hungary and Archbishop of Esztergom , took care of his education and sent him to study philosophy andJurassic to Padua (1568-1570). [1] [4] Fausto Veranzio was also very interested in the fortress and supervised construction of the fortress in Eger in Hungary.

In 1579 Veranzio was commander of the fortress of VeszprŽm in Hungary, but was summoned two years later by Rudolph II , Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire , Archduke of Austria and King of Hungary and Croatia , as a secretary on the Hradschin in Prague . Veranzio, both fluent command of seven languages, [5] was thus 1581-1594 diplomat in the service of the Emperor in Prague as well as the Archduke Ernst in Vienna. As far as his obligations permitted, he studied mathematics and mechanics. [1]

During this time he also worked on his dictionary of the five most noble languages __of Europe ( Dictionarium quinque nobilissimarum Europeae linguarum, Latinae , Italicae , Germanicae , Dalmaticae et Hungaricae ), which was printed in 1595 in Venice. It contains about 5000 terms in the five languages __and is considered one of the first and most important dictionaries of the Dalmatian (Serbo-Croatian) and the Hungarian language as well as precursor to many other dictionaries that inspired him.

In 1594 Veranzio left the court and lived until 1598 in Dalmatia and Italy, mainly in Venice. In 1598 he was appointed bishop of Csan‡d , an honorary title, since Csan‡d was then occupied by the Ottoman Empire . At the same time he worked as an adviser for Hungarian and Transylvanian affairs for Rudolph II, but left the court in Prague in 1605 and joined the Pauline Barnabites in Rome .

In Rome, he certainly had the opportunity to see many of the technical drawings of Leonardo da Vinci . [1] He made at this time a number of drawings and engravings on new machines to. Although he received 1614 and 1615 permits to publish a book on the machines, but he did not succeed due to a serious illness. On the advice of his doctors, he left Rome to return to _ibenik, but interrupted the journey in Venice. There he published in 1616 a treatise on logic and a large volume of his Machinae novae . Hindered from his illness by the onward journey he died on January 20, 1617 in Venice. [1]

He was buried at Sveta Marija u Luci on the island of Prvi_ at his express wish .

The most famous work of Fausto Veranzio are probably his Machinae Novae , of which only a few copies are preserved. It consists of the title page, 49 panels with illustrations and explanations in five languages __(Latin, Italian, Spanish, French and German). The preserved specimens are not completely identical. Since some of his friends thanked him for the book in July 1616, it can be assumed that it was printed in early 1616.

Veranzio addressed hydrological issues such as the possibility of flooding the Tiber or supplying drinking water to Venice . Other illustrations include sundials , wind , water and tidal mills , a cable car , a chain bridge and a parachute . One of the panels shows a wooden, massive segmental arch bridge made of beams with tongue and groove connections , an arched bridge with a false archwith the underlying trackway and truss struts as stiffening, as well as a lenticular arch bridge anticipating the Royal Albert Bridge built by Isambard Kingdom Brunel in 1859 in Saltash, Cornwall. Some of these ideas were not completely new, but first appeared in print, others were far ahead of their time.

According to widespread information Veranzio 1617 personally tested the parachute by jumping, depending on the source of the Campanile di San Marco in Venice or the belfry of the 86 -meter St. Martin's Cathedral in Bratislava or by a bridge in Venice. He is therefore regarded by many as the first person who has developed a parachute to the stage of an actual use. As evidence it is stated that his leap was documented in the work of Mathematical Magick, published 30 years later, by John Wilkins . [6]

But it seems more than doubtful that the 65-year-old, seriously ill Veranzio had embarked on such an adventure, and that the still very small parachute could have braked a case sufficiently. It is also not discussed how someone from a tower could bring the frame of the parachute in a horizontal position in the air and himself under these frames.

In fact, in the book Mathematical Magick , John Wilkins deals, among other things, with the possibility of flying, but in no way with a parachute or other means to slow down the fall of a human being. Also Veranzio is not mentioned in the work, not even an event from the year 1617. Obviously, this story was an early, modern legend in the world.

German Bio:
B‡lint Als‡ni, auch Valentin dÕAlsan oder Valentino de Alsan (* um 1330 in Als‡n;   19. November 1408 in PŽcs) war ein Kardinal der Ršmischen Kirche.

Er war der Sohn des Gouverneurs des heute in Serbien gelegen Ma_va (ungarisch Macs—i), Janos Als‡ni. B‡lint Als‡ni studierte in Frankreich und Italien und wurde zum Doctor iuris utriusque promoviert. Danach wurde er Professor in Esztergom. Von 1352 (oder 1353) an bis zu seiner Bischofswahl war er Kanoniker in PŽcs, VeszprŽm und Esztergom.

Als‡ni wurde am 21. Juli 1374 zum Bischof von PŽcs erwŠhlt. Seine Bischofsweihe fand vor dem 25. Oktober 1374 statt. 1373 (oder 1376) war er Vizekanzler von Kšnig Lajos I. von Ungarn; 1381 findet er sich als ungarischer Botschafter in Italien (Padua, Venedig und Rom). Papst Urban VI. ernannte ihn im Konsistorium vom 17. Dezember 1384 zum Kardinalpriester. Am 9. Februar 1385 wurde ihm Santa Sabina als Titelkirche verliehen, wobei er den Bischofssitz von PŽcs weiter innehatte. Am Konklave 1389, das Papst Bonifaz IX. wŠhlte, nahm er nicht teil. Von 1397 oder 1398 bis zu seinem Tod war er Kardinalprotopriester. An den Konklaven von 1404 und 1406, an denen jeweils Innozenz VII. und Gregor XII. gewŠhlt wurden, war er ebenfalls nicht beteiligt. Am 22. August 1407 erreichte er den pŠpstlichen Hof in Viterbo, musste jedoch aufgrund einer Erkrankung von Siena Ÿber Venedig nach Ungarn zurŸckkehren.

Er starb im November des Folgejahres und wurde in PŽcs beigesetzt.
English Bio:
B‡lint Als‡ni , also Valentin d'Alsan or Valentino de Alsan (* 1330 in Als‡n ,   November 19, 1408 in PŽcs ) was a cardinal of the Roman Church .

He was the son of the Governor of Ma_va ( Hungarian Macs—i ), Janos Als‡ni , who is now in Serbia . B‡lint Als‡ni studied in France and Italy and received his doctorate for Doctor iuris utriusque . He then became a professor in Esztergom . From 1352 (or 1353) until his election to the bishop, he was a canon in PŽcs, VeszprŽm and Esztergom.

Als‡ni was elected on 21 July 1374 Bishop of PŽcs . His episcopal ordination took place before 25 October 1374. In 1373 (or 1376) he was vice-chancellor of King Lajos I of Hungary ; In 1381 he finds himself a Hungarian ambassador to Italy (Padua, Venice and Rome). Pope Urban VI. appointed him in the consistory of December 17, 1384 cardinal priest . On February 9, 1385 Santa Sabina was awarded as a titular church , where he continued to hold the bishopric of PŽcs. At the conclave in 1389 , Pope Boniface IX.he chose not to participate. From 1397 or 1398 until his death he was Cardinal Protopriester . At the conclaves of 1404 and 1406 , in each of which Innocent VII and Gregory XII. he was also not involved. On August 22, 1407, he reached the papal court in Viterbo, but had to return because of an illness from Siena via Venice to Hungary.

He died in November of the following year and was buried in PŽcs.

English Bio:
Janus Pannonius (Croatian Ivan _esmi_ki , Hungarian Csezmiczei J‡nos German Johannes Csezmiczei , Ivan or J‡nos of _azma after his northern Croatian birthplace; * 29. August 1434 in _azma ;   27. March 1472 in Castle Medvedgrad in Zagreb ) was a scholar, humanist , diplomat and bishop.

J‡nos of _azma was probably the son of a Croatian nobleman. Little is known about his childhood. His mother Borb‡la VitŽz [pronunciation: "Witehs"] (  1463) was a sister of Bishop John VitŽz , since 1465 Primate of Hungary . After his father's death in 1447, the latter sent him to the school of Guarino da Verona at the court of Margrave Leonello d'Este in Ferrara, which was then praised as the center of humanist art and culture . From 1454 to 1458 he studied law in Padua and returned to Hungary after his doctorate in 'canon law', where he made a career quickly, first as a canon with his uncle in Wardein, then as a Hungarian poet at the court of the Hungarian King Matthias Corvinus . He did not want to miss his experience in Italy and gave him a job in the royal chancellery. On 5 November 1459 he was made Bishop of PŽcs , whereby the Archbishop of Gran became his mentor. On February 16, 1460 he received the bishopric from Pius II. In 1465 he went on behalf of the Hungarian king as ambassador to Rome to get papal support in the fight against the Ottomans.

With his uncle, he joined in 1471 a conspiracy against the king because of its autocratic government style and tried in vain to bring King Casimir of Poland on the Hungarian throne. He had to flee to Croatia, where he died in 1472 at the age of 38 (his uncle died four months later in house arrest in Gran).

Janus Pannonius, as he called himself as a humanist, wrote numerous poems and epigrams and made his mark as a translator of ancient authors. The teachings of Plotinus had particularly affected him. He wrote in Latin . Janus Pannonius designed his own grave inscription (translation): "Janus rests allhier who first the laurel decorated Muses of Helikon heights at the shore of domestic Nonoba has brought." [1] A bronze statue is located below the castle in Pecs. The biographer Vespasian da Bisticci explained that the Hungarian humanist was distinguished both by his virtues, as well as his erudition [2] .

English Bio:
Antun Vran_i_ (also Anton Wranczy , Latin Antonius Verantius , Hungarian Antal Verancsics ) (born May 29, 1504 in _ibenik , Dalmatia ,   June 15, 1573 in Eperjes ( slow Pre_ov ), S‡ros county , Upper Hungary , today Slovakia ) was a Roman Catholic archbishop , scientist and diplomat.

Vran_i_ was born in 1504 in _ibenik and came from a Croatian noble family. His cousin, the Croatian Ban Petar Berislavi_, took care of his education . Vran_i_ himself also took care of his nephew, later Bishop Faust Vran_i_ .

The study time spent Antun Vran_i_ in Padua , Vienna and Krakow . At the age of 26, Vran_i_ became secretary to the Transylvanian Prince Johann Z‡polya . His diplomatic career began after Z‡polya's death at the Habsburg court . For Ferdinand I and Maximilian II , Vran_i_ represented Habsburg at the Holy See , at the Sublime Porte , in France, Poland, in the Republic of Venice , as well as in England and Italy. In 1530 he became dean of Buda .

During his four-year stay in the Ottoman Empire , Vran_i_, together with the diplomat Ogier Ghislain de Busbecq , made the archaeological discovery of the Augustinian account " Res gestae divi Augusti ". On August 3, 1554 Vran_i_ was appointed bishop of PŽcs , on July 17, 1557 he was appointed bishop of Eger .

The ceremonial episcopal ordination took place on 21 September 1561. One of his greatest diplomatic achievements was the Peace Treaty of Adrianople , which was closed in 1568. For this merit he was appointed Primate of Hungary . On his many diplomatic trips Vran_i_ came into contact with Philipp Melanchthon , Erasmus of Rotterdam and Paolo Giovio . On September 25, 1570 he was appointed Archbishop of Esztergom . On June 5, 1573, Pope Gregory XIII appointed him . to the cardinal, The news from Rome did not reach Vran_i_, he died on 15 June 1573 in Pre_ov . His resting place is, at his own request, in the church of St. Nicholas in Tyrnau (slow Trnava ).

English Bio:
Juraj II Dra_kovi_ of Trako__an. , Hungarian Gyšrgy Draskovics (* 5 February 1515 [1] on Castle Bilina in Croatia region Bukovica (west of the city of Knin );   21st January 1587 in Vienna ) was a Croatian nobleman, archbishop and cardinal , From 1567 to 1576 he was Ban (viceroy) of Croatia .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ came from the Croatian noble family Dra_kovi_ . His father was Bartol Dra_kovi_ (* 1500,   1538), a small nobleman from the south of Croatia. His mother Ana, born. Utje_inovi_, born in Kami_ak , was a sister of the cardinal and statesman Juraj Utje_inovi_ , better known as Georg Martinuzzi .

He studied in Krakow , Vienna , Bologna and Rome , received in 1539 [1] the priesthood and was canon to Oradea , abbot Lelesz , infulierter provost of the collegiate church of St. Martin to Bratislava , King and Emperor Ferdinand I advice and confessor, and 1557 Bishop of five churches .

In 1561 he translated Vinzenz von LŽrin's book "Against the heretics" ( Commonitorium fidei ). He participated for Croatia and Hungary in the Trento Council , where he performed in the interest of the emperor. Ferdinand appointed him for the Bishop of Agram (Zagreb) in 1565 , and his successor Maximilian II to the Real Privy Council , and 1567 to the Ban of Croatia , Dalmatia and Slavonia . In 1573 he became archbishop of Kalocsa .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ became ingloriously known in his power position secured by the authorities, by the oppression and exploitation of the Croatian farmers entrusted to him. As Ban he was instrumental in the ruthless crushing of the Croatian peasant uprising of 1573. The leader of the uprising, the peasant king Matija Gubec , who was proclaimed by the Croatian peasants , was tortured and then executed at the Agrarian Mark Square (Markov Trg) .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ organized the defense against the Turks , where he was relatively successful. In 1578 Emperor Rudolf II granted him the dignity of a Hungarian court chancellor in 1578 and in addition to his other benefices in 1578 gave him the diocese of Raab . In 1584, the Emperor gave him the castle Trako__an , which remained until 1945 in the possession of the family. On December 18, 1585, Cardinal Pope Sixtus V. became cardinal priest and Emperor Rudolf governor of Hungary, he died on January 21, 1587. [2]

German Bio: Andreas Dudith von Horehowicza, auch Andreas Dudith Sbardellati,  Andreas Duditius de Sbardellatus, Andreas Dudelius de Stardelaccis (kroatisch Andrija DudiÄ‡, ungarisch AndrÃ¡s Dudith, tschechisch OndÅ™ej DudiÄ z Horehovic, polnisch Andrzej Dudycz; * 5. Februar 1533 in Ofen; â€  2. Februar 1589 in Breslau) war ein ungarischer Humanist, Bischof, kaiserlicher Diplomat und reformierter Protestant.  Dudith wurde in Ungarn geboren und entstammte einem kroatischen Adelsgeschlecht. Seine Mutter, von der sein Beiname Sbardellatus stammt, war eine Venetianerin aus dem Geschlecht der Sbardellati.[1] Er studierte unter anderem in Venedig und Padua. Er war Titularpropst von FelhÃ©vÃ­z (bei Ã“buda), Weihbischof im Erzbistum Gran und wurde 1560 zum Bischof von Tina (SÃ¼dkroatien) geweiht. Von 1562 bis 1563 war Dudith Bischof von CsanÃ¡d. Auf dem Konzil von Trient gehÃ¶rte Dudith 1562 zu den BefÃ¼rwortern der Aufhebung des Verbotes der Kelchkommunion fÃ¼r Laien und forderte spÃ¤ter auch die Abschaffung des ZÃ¶libates. Zwischen 1563 und 1567 wirkte er als Bischof von FÃ¼nfkirchen. In diplomatischen Diensten Kaiser Maximilians II. weilte Dudith am 1566 polnischen KÃ¶nigshof in Krakau, wo er sich heimlich mit einer Hofdame verlobte. 1567 reichte er seine Demission von Bischofsamt ein, trat zum Protestantismus Ã¼ber, heiratete und zog nach Krakau. In Krakau setzte sich Dudith fÃ¼r die Wahl Maximilians II. auf den polnischen Thron ein und verlieÃŸ nach der KrÃ¶nung Stephan BÃ¡thorys Polen. Von Rudolf II. wurde Dudith in den mÃ¤hrischen Freiherrnstand erhoben und kaufte 1578 die Herrschaft Paskau in MÃ¤hren. Da ihm das Leben in dem abgelegenen StÃ¤dtchen und die Bewirtschaftung der GÃ¼ter nicht behagte, verkaufte er Paskau 1579 und zog nach Breslau, wo er sich wieder wissenschaftlichen Arbeiten zuwandte und einen calvinistisch-humanistischen Gelehrtenkreis um sich versammelte. Dudiths Epitaph befindet sich in der Breslauer Elisabethkirche. Seine Tochter Regina heiratete nach seinem Tod 1595 den polnischen Adligen und Unitarier Hieronymus Moskorzowski.
English Bio:
Andreas Dudith of Horehowicza , also Andreas Dudith Sbardellati , Andreas Duditius de Sbardellatus , Andreas Dudelius de Stardelaccis (Croatian Andrija Dudi_ , Hungarian Andr‡s Dudith , Czech Ond_ej Dudi_ z Horehovic , Polish Andrzej Dudycz ; * February 5, 1533 in Ofen ,   February 2 1589 in Breslau ) was a Hungarian humanist , bishop , imperial diplomat and reformed Protestant,

Dudith was born in Hungary and came from a Croatian noble family. His mother, from whom came his surname Sbardellatus , was a Venetian of the Sbardellati family. [1] He studied among others in Venice and Padua . He was titular prophet of FelhŽv’z ( îbuda ), Auxiliary Bishop in the Archdiocese of Gran and was ordained in 1560 Bishop of Tina (southern Croatia). From 1562 to 1563 Dudith was bishop of Csan‡d . At the Council of Trent Dudith in 1562 was one of the proponents of the lifting of the ban on the Chalicefor laymen and later demanded the abolition of celibacy . Between 1563 and 1567 he worked as bishop of FŸnfkirchen . In diplomatic service Emperor Maximilian II Dudith was in 1566 Polish royal court in Krakow , where he secretly engaged with a court lady. In 1567 he submitted his resignation from the episcopate, converted to Protestantism , married and moved to Krakow. Pope Pius V. cast a spell on him and publicly burned his picture in Rome. When his wife died after seven years of marriage, Dudith made a second marriage in 1574 to El_bieta Zborowska, the widow of Count Jan Tarnowski.

In Krakow, Dudith sat for the election of Maximilian II on the Polish throne and left after the coronation Stephan B‡thorys Poland. By Rudolf II Dudith was raised to the Moravian baron and bought in 1578 the rule Paskau in Moravia . Since he did not like the life in the remote town and the management of the goods, he sold Paskau in 1579 and moved to Breslau, where he turned back to scientific work and a Calvinistic-humanistic circle of scholars gathered around him. Dudith's Epitaph is located in the Wroc_aw Elisabeth Church . His daughter Regina married after his death in 1595 the Polish nobles and unitariansJerome Moscorzowski .

English Bio:
Astrik ( Hungarian spelling Asztrik ; and Anastasius , Astricus or ash Rich ,   1037 ) was a priest of unknown origin, 993 abbot of the pin B_evnov in Prague and in 1006 the first Archbishop of Gran (ung. Esztergom ) was. He paved the way for the royal coronation of St. Stephen of Hungary and created the foundations of the Hungarian church organization. He often becomes "Apostle of Hungary" called. The details of his biography, however, are uncertain and sometimes contradictory handed down. [1]

There are different assumptions about the origin of Astrik. A German or French-Burgundian origin is suspected. Other sources suggest Czech origin. Astrik was a student of St. Adalbert of Prague , whom he accompanied to Rome in 993, and to Poland in 996/997.

The first written record dates back to 993. At that time, Astrik became the first abbot of the B_evnov Abbey. According to the memorandum, he received from Pope John XV. the right to wear episcopal insignia . After the extinction of Slavn’kovci the monks left the monastery and fled to Poland . For the Benedictines from B_evnov and other Czech monasteries, Bishop Adalbert of Prague donated an abbey in Meseritz, Poland, and ordered his companion Astrik to be abbot. Later, in Subottin, whose location is unknown today, he received episcopal ordination and even the pallium of an archbishop.

After the Battle of Libice (September 28, 995) Astrik came by invitation Radlas with some monks to Hungary . Later he contacted the Hungarian court and traveled to Rome in 1000/1001 to seek papal approval for the coronation of Stephen and the establishment of the Hungarian bishoprics. As abbot of PŽcsv‡rad and since about 1006 as archbishop of Gran and Kalocsa , he was the most important church employee Stephans.

Nach seiner RÃ¼ckkehr aus Italien wurde Berthold 1209 zum Ban von Kroatien, Dalmatien und Slavonien ernannt. 1212 wurde Berthold sogar zum Woiwoden von SiebenbÃ¼rgen und zum Stellvertreter des KÃ¶nigs ernannt.   Der ungarische Adel, der Ã¼ber die Bevorzugung Bertholds und anderer deutscher GÃ¼nstlinge durch den ungarischen KÃ¶nig empÃ¶rt war, zettelte 1213 eine VerschwÃ¶rung an. Der einheimische Adel nutzte die Abwesenheit Andreas', der sich auf einem Feldzug in Halytsch befand, um das Gefolge von KÃ¶nigin Gertrud zu Ã¼berfallen, das gerade eine Jagd veranstaltete. WÃ¤hrend Gertrud und einige ihrer AnhÃ¤nger ermordet wurden, konnte Berthold verletzt entkommen.   Als der Patriarch von Aquileia Wolfger von Erla starb, wurde Berthold am 10. Februar 1218 von Papst Honorius III. zu dessen Nachfolger ernannt. 1238 verlegte er den Sitz des Patriarchenstaats von Cividale del Friuli nach Udine und initiierte um 1245 den Bau der heutigen Kathedrale von Udine. Berthold betrieb wÃ¤hrend seiner Amtszeit eine intensive Territorialpolitik und festigte die Macht des Patriarchenstaats. Bei seinen Bestrebungen wurde er vom rÃ¶misch-deutschen Kaiser Friedrich II. unterstÃ¼tzt, der in ihm einen VerbÃ¼ndeten gegen die feindlichen lombardischen StÃ¤dte sah.   Als es zum Konflikt zwischen Papst Gregor IX. und Friedrich II. kam, der 1239 vom Papst gebannt wurde, wurde Berthold aufgrund seiner Kaisertreue zunÃ¤chst ebenfalls exkommuniziert. Erst nach der Intervention von KÃ¶nig Andreas II. von Ungarn wurde die Exkommunikation Bertholds 1241 aufgehoben. Berthold trat in Folge vermehrt als Vermittler zwischen Kaiser und Papst auf.   Mit Bertholds Tod am 23. Mai 1251 endete die langjÃ¤hrige Zeit, in der deutsche Adelige das Amt des Patriarchen von Aquileia bekleideten. Ebenso erlosch mit seinem Tod das Haus Andechs-Meranien im Mannesstamm.
English Bio:
Berthold V. of Andechs or Berthold of Aquileia (* 1180 in Bamberg ,   May 23, 1251 ) was Count of Andechs-Meranien , Archbishop of Kalocsa and Patriarch of Aquileia .

Berthold was born around 1180 as the son of Berthold IV of Andechs and his wife Agnes von Rochlitz . He came from the noble family Andechs . Among his siblings were St. Hedwig of Andechs , Queen Gertrude of Hungary and Bishop Eckbert von Bamberg .

In 1203 Berthold began his spiritual career and became a provost in Bamberg . At the instigation of his sister Gertrud von Andechs , who had married the later King Andrew II of Hungary , Berthold gained great influence at the court of his brother-in-law. So he was appointed in 1206 by Andrew Archbishop of Kalocsa in southern Hungary. Pope Innocent III. However, the election was only confirmed in 1212, because Berthold had neither the prescribed age nor the required experience. Presumably for this reason, Berthold went to Vicenza for further study . After his return from Italy Berthold 1209 became the Ban of Croatia, Dalmatia and Slavonia . In 1212 Berthold was even appointed Voivode of Transylvania and Deputy King.

The Hungarian nobility, who was outraged by the favor of Berthold and other German favorites by the Hungarian king, instigated a conspiracy in 1213. The local nobility took advantage of the absence of Andrew, who was on a campaign in Halychensk to raid the entourage of Queen Gertrude, who was in the process of hunting. While Gertrud and some of her followers were murdered, Berthold escaped injured.

When the Patriarch of Aquileia Wolfger von Erla died, Berthold was on 10 February 1218 by Pope Honorius III. appointed as his successor. In 1238 he moved the seat of the Patriarchate of Cividale del Friuli to Udine and initiated in 1245 the construction of the present Cathedral of Udine . During his term of office, Berthold pursued an intensive territorial policy and consolidated the power of the patriarchal state. In his efforts, he was supported by the Roman-German Emperor Frederick II , who saw him as an ally against the hostile Lombard cities.

When it came to the conflict between Pope Gregory IX. and Frederick II came, who was banned by the pope in 1239, Berthold was initially also excommunicated because of his loyalty to the emperor. Only after the intervention of King Andrew II of Hungary was Berthold's excommunication repealed in 1241. As a result, Berthold increasingly appeared as mediator between the emperor and the pope.

With Berthold's death on May 23, 1251 ended the long time, in which German nobles held the office of Patriarch of Aquileia. Also died with his death, the house Andechs-Meranien in the male line.

English Bio:
Andreas dei Benzi (* 1360 in Gualdo Tadino ,   April 17, 1437 in Sion ) was Prince-Bishop of Sion .

He was the son of Pietro di Gionta dei Benzi and studied theology in Rome . In 1408 he became Vicar General of the Diocese of Erlau (Eger) in Hungary and in the same year archdeacon of Zala and papal collector in the church provinces of Kalocsa and Esztergom , as well as 1409 Grosspšnitentiar of Hungary. He was a follower of King Sigismund of Luxembourg and his representative at the Council of Constance , which in 1418 appointed him administrator of the diocese of Sion. In 1431 he became bishop of Sion. He was a participant in the Basel Council (1431-1449) and founder of the Andreas altar in the cathedral of Sion,
