Mitte 1520 teilte er sein VermÃ¶gen unter den Verwandten auf und trat dem Franziskanerorden bei. Als 1521 ein erneuter Krieg zwischen den Ungarn und den Osmanen ausbrach, weigerte er sich trotz vielfacher Bitten, ein Kommando auf Seiten der Ungarn zu Ã¼bernehmen, zunÃ¤chst das Kloster in Esztergom zu verlassen, in dem er als MÃ¶nch lebte.  Erst 1523 nahm er auf ausdrÃ¼ckliche Anweisung des Papstes das Amt des Erzbischofs von Kalocsa an und Ã¼bernahm zugleich die Position des Hauptkommandanten der sÃ¼dlichen Verteidigungslinie gegen die Osmanen. English Bio:
P‡l Tomori (* 1475 , _ August 29, 1526 at Moh‡cs ) was a Hungarian officer and archbishop of Kalocsa . In 1526 against the Ottomans out battle of Moh‡cs he was the main commander of the Hungarian army.

The offspring of a small-noble family began his military career as a feudal lord of J‡nos Bornemisza . Later he became a castellan of the castles of Fogarasch and Munk‡cs and captain of the castle of Buda . He was also on the suppression of the of Gyšrgy D—zsa led peasant uprising involved.

In mid-1520 he divided his fortune among the relatives and joined the Franciscan Order . In 1521, a renewed war broke out between the Hungarians and the Ottomans, he refused despite many requests to take command of the Hungarians, first to leave the monastery in Esztergom , where he lived as a monk.

It was not until 1523, on the express instructions of the Pope, that he assumed the office of archbishop of Kalocsa and at the same time assumed the position of chief commander of the southern defensive line against the Ottomans.

Shortly before the Battle of Moh‡cs in 1526 he was elected chief commander of the Hungarian army, as Johann Z‡polya , the actual commander, was not on site and therefore could not intervene in the fighting.

Tomori fell in the battle in which the Hungarian squad was crushed by the Ottomans.

Januar 1543 in Pressburg) war ein Angehšriger des Geschlechts der Frankopan. Er war Erzbischof von Kalocsa und von 1538 bis 1543 Bischof von Agria. Er war Sprecher des Kšnigs Johann Z‡polya (Johannes) von Ungarn.

Franz Johann Frankopan war Sohn des Bernardin Frankopan und der Luisa Marzano.[1]

Nach der Niederlage der Ungarn bei Moh‡cs (1526) gegen die TŸrken breiteten sich diese immer mehr Ÿber das Territorium des Kšnigreichs Ungarn aus. Auch die Habsburger hatten AnsprŸche auf Ungarn. Infolge des am 10. Juni 1538 in Wratislauia (Breslau) abgeschlossenen Vertrags zwischen Kšnig Johannes Z‡polya von Ungarn und Kšnig Ferdinand von Habsburg, der auf einen Interessenausgleich bezŸglich der gegenseitigen Territorial- und ErbansprŸche hinausging, schreibt Kaiser Karl V. aus Toledo Kšnig Johann, dass er die Botschaft des Sprechers von Johannes, Franciscus de Fragepanibus, Erzbischof von Kalotscha und Bischof von Agria, entgegengenommen und die Friedensbestrebungen zwischen seinem Bruder Ferdinand und Kšnig Johannes ãmit grš§ter GenugtuungÒ vernommen habe.[2][3]
English Bio:
Franz Johann Frankopan ( Franciscus de question bus, Ivan Franjo Frankapan, Ferenc J‡nos Frankopan , * 1490 ,   January 22 or January 28, 1543 in Bratislava ) was a member of the family of Frankopan . He was Archbishop of Kalocsa and from 1538 to 1543 Bishop of Agria . He was spokesman for King John Z‡polya (John) of Hungary.

Franz Johann Frankopan was the son of Bernardin Frankopan and Luisa Marzano. [1]

After the defeat of the Hungarians at Moh‡cs (1526) against the Turks, they spread more and more over the territory of the Kingdom of Hungary. The Habsburgs also had claims to Hungary. As a result of the concluded on 10 June 1538 in Wratislauia ( Wroclaw ) Treaty between King Johannes Z‡polya of Hungary and King Ferdinand of Habsburg , which was based on a reconciliation of interests in the mutual territorial and hereditary claims, writes Emperor Charles V of Toledo King John that he received the message of the spokesman of John, Franciscus de question busArchbishop of Kalocha and Bishop of Agria, who received the peace efforts between his brother Ferdinand and King John "with the utmost satisfaction". [2] [3]

English Bio:
Juraj II Dra_kovi_ of Trako__an. , Hungarian Gyšrgy Draskovics (* 5 February 1515 [1] on Castle Bilina in Croatia region Bukovica (west of the city of Knin );   21st January 1587 in Vienna ) was a Croatian nobleman, archbishop and cardinal , From 1567 to 1576 he was Ban (viceroy) of Croatia .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ came from the Croatian noble family Dra_kovi_ . His father was Bartol Dra_kovi_ (* 1500,   1538), a small nobleman from the south of Croatia. His mother Ana, born. Utje_inovi_, born in Kami_ak , was a sister of the cardinal and statesman Juraj Utje_inovi_ , better known as Georg Martinuzzi .

He studied in Krakow , Vienna , Bologna and Rome , received in 1539 [1] the priesthood and was canon to Oradea , abbot Lelesz , infulierter provost of the collegiate church of St. Martin to Bratislava , King and Emperor Ferdinand I advice and confessor, and 1557 Bishop of five churches .

In 1561 he translated Vinzenz von LŽrin's book "Against the heretics" ( Commonitorium fidei ). He participated for Croatia and Hungary in the Trento Council , where he performed in the interest of the emperor. Ferdinand appointed him for the Bishop of Agram (Zagreb) in 1565 , and his successor Maximilian II to the Real Privy Council , and 1567 to the Ban of Croatia , Dalmatia and Slavonia . In 1573 he became archbishop of Kalocsa .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ became ingloriously known in his power position secured by the authorities, by the oppression and exploitation of the Croatian farmers entrusted to him. As Ban he was instrumental in the ruthless crushing of the Croatian peasant uprising of 1573. The leader of the uprising, the peasant king Matija Gubec , who was proclaimed by the Croatian peasants , was tortured and then executed at the Agrarian Mark Square (Markov Trg) .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ organized the defense against the Turks , where he was relatively successful. In 1578 Emperor Rudolf II granted him the dignity of a Hungarian court chancellor in 1578 and in addition to his other benefices in 1578 gave him the diocese of Raab . In 1584, the Emperor gave him the castle Trako__an , which remained until 1945 in the possession of the family. On December 18, 1585, Cardinal Pope Sixtus V. became cardinal priest and Emperor Rudolf governor of Hungary, he died on January 21, 1587. [2]

Februar 1594 im Alter von 19 Jahren in Esztergom zum Priester geweiht. Mit 35 Jahren wurde er am 27. Januar 1610 von Papst Paul V. zum Bischof von Bosnien ernannt. Konsekriert wurde er am 25. September 1611 in Rom durch Roberto Francesco Romolo Kardinal Bellarmino, SJ, Kardinalpriester von San Matteo in Merulana. Mitkonsekratoren waren Antonio d'Aquino, Bischof von Sarno, und Giulio Sansedoni, der emeritierte Bischof von Grosseto. Von 1613 bis 1619 war er Bischof von Oradea Mare. Im MÃ¤rz 1619 ernannte ihn Papst Paul V. zum Bischof von Nitra. 1624 resignierte er, Papst Urban VII. ernannte ihn zum Erzbischof von Kalocsa und setzte ihn auch als Bischof von Nitra wieder ein.  JÃ¡nos Telegdy verstarb 1647 im Alter von 72 Jahren, nach fast 53 Priesterjahren und 35 Jahren im Bischofsamt[1][2] und wurde in Kalocsa beigesetzt.
English Bio:
J‡nos Telegdy (* 1575 in NovŽ Z‡mky,   1647 in Kalocsa , Hungary ) was a Hungarian Roman Catholic archbishop .

Telegdy was born on 10 February 1594 at the age of 19 years in Esztergom for priests ordained. At the age of 35 he was appointed bishop of Bosnia by Pope Paul V on January 27, 1610 . He was consecrated on September 25, 1611 in Rome by Roberto Francesco Romolo Cardinal Bellarmino , SJ , cardinal priest of San Matteo in Merulana . Co- consecrators were Antonio d'Aquino , Bishop of Sarno , and Giulio Sansedoni , the emeritus Bishop of Grosseto, From 1613 to 1619 he was Bishop of Oradea Mare . In March 1619, Pope Paul V appointed him Bishop of Nitra . In 1624 he resigned, Pope Urban VII appointed him Archbishop of Kalocsa and also reinstated him as Bishop of Nitra.

J‡nos Telegdy died in 1647 at the age of 72 years, after nearly 53 years a priest and 35 years in the episcopate [1] [2] and was buried in Kalocsa.

Name: Juraj IV. SzelepcsÃ©nyi de Pohronc
German Bio:
Georg SzelepcsŽnyi (* 24. April 1595 in Szelepcseny, Kšnigreich Ungarn;   24. April 1685 in Lettowitz, Kšnigreich Bšhmen) war katholischer Priester und Erzbischof von Gran. Er war auch publizistisch tŠtig und ein bedeutender Vertreter der Gegenreformation.

Georg SzlepcsŽnyi war eines von mehreren Kindern slowakischer Leibeigener, seine Mutter hie§ Zsuzsanna und war eine geborene GyŸrky. Getauft wurde er in der Kirche von Barskisfalud (slow. Vieska nad _itavou)[1] einem kleinen Dorf etwa 10 km von Goldmorawitz entfernt, im Komitat Bars. Beide Eltern sollen infolge der TŸrkenkriege von TŸrken erschlagen worden sein[2]. Als Waise verdingte er sich als Schweinehirt um Ÿberleben zu kšnnen. Danach kam er in die Obhut eines entfernten Verwandten, Ladislaus SzelepcsŽnyi der den Kleinadel angehšrte. Dr Junge Ÿbernahm auch dessen Namen, Wappen und das AdelsprŠdikat.

Erzbischof PŽter P‡zm‡ny lernte den talentierten jungen Mann wŠhrend einer kanonischen Visitation im Komitat Bars im Jahre 1617 kennen. Er erkannte das Talent des JŸnglings und nahm ihm mit nach Tyrnau, wo er im dortigen Jesuiten-Gymnasium eine Weiterbildung ermšglichte. 1618 schickte ihm P‡zm‡ny zu weiteren Studien an das Priesterseminar Pontificium Collegium Germanium et Hungaricum nach Rom, wo er nach seinem Studien in Theologie und Philosophie promovierte und zwei Doktortitel erhielt. Im Jahre 1627 wurde er zum Priester geweiht.

Nach seiner RŸckkehr in die Heimat machte er als Priester, jedoch auch als Diplomat eine steile Karriere. Zuerst wirkte er als Priester in Wartberg (ung. Szenc), 1536 wurde er Kanoniker in Tyrnau. Bei der feierlichen Bestattung seines Gšnners und Freundes Peter P‡zmany im Jahre 1637 leitete er die Trauerfeierlichkeiten und hielt auch die Traueransprache.

Am 18. April 1648 wurde er zum Bischof von Neutra und 1657 zum Erzbischof von Kalocsa ernannt. Nach dem Tode von Gyšrgy Lippay[3] wurde er am 15. Januar 1666 zum Erzbischof von Gran und Primas von Ungarn ernannt. Er war einer der engsten Vertrauten und Berater von Kaiser Leopold I. Neben seiner TŠtigkeit als KirchenfŸrst war er auch an RegierungsgeschŠften beteiligt. Ab 1644 war er Chef der Ungarischen Hofkanzlei die damals noch in Pre§burg angesiedelt war, bevor sie 1690 nach Wien umzog. Er war dreimal in diplomatischer Mission im Auftrag des Kaisers bei der Hohen Pforte in Konstantinopel (dem heutigen Istanbul). Zwischen 1670 und 1681 war er kšniglicher Statthalter fŸr das Kšnigreich Ungarn, was die hšchste WŸrde nach dem Kšnig darstellte.

Bei der Aufdeckung der Magnatenverschwšrung im Kšnigreich Ungarn spielte SzelepcsŽnyi eine entscheidende Rolle. L‡szl— Fekete Ð Iv‡nyi[4] (ung. Iv‡nyi-Fekete L‡szl—) verriet die Verschwšrer an den Erzbischof, der diese Informationen an den Wiener Kaiserhof weitergab.

Wegen seiner Verdiente aber auch Dank seiner geschŠftlichen FŠhigkeiten erwarb er sich ein riesiges Vermšgen. Dieses Vermšgen nutzte er vor allem jedoch zum Wohl der Allgemeinheit. Er grŸndete Schulen und lie§ zahlreiche Kirchen auf seine eigenen Kosten erbauen. Finanziell unterstŸtzte er viele Pfarreien und katholische Ordensgemeinschaften. In Tyrnau grŸndete er ein Priesterseminar und unterstŸtzte die UniversitŠt mit bedeutenden finanziellen Mitteln.

SzelepcsŽnyi erreichte fŸr die damalige Zeit ein hohes Lebensalter. Am Ende seines Lebens erkrankte er und zog sich auf seine GŸter in Lettowitz in MŠhren zurŸck. Aber auch von hier aus leitete er schriftlich seine Graner Erzdišzese und unterhielt eine rege Korrespondenz mit dem Kaiser und den Wiener Hof. Er starb am 15. Januar 1685 auf seinem Gut in Lettowitz. GemŠ§ seinem eigenen Wunsch, den er auch testamentarisch bekrŠftigte, fand er in der Wallfahrtskirche von Mariazell seine letzte RuhestŠtte. Er wurde in der dortigen Kapelle des Hl. Ladislaus beigesetzt, die er selber errichten lie§.

Als Trauerdekade des Protestantismus in Ungarn darf das Jahrzehnt zwischen 1671 und 1681 bezeichnet werden. Wenn es nach dem Willen der von Gyšrgy SzelepcsŽnyi gefŸhrten Jesuitenpartei innerhalb des Ršmischen Kirche gegangen wŠre, so hŠtte der Protestantismus in Ungarn in dieser Zeit mit seiner gŠnzlichen Vernichtung rechnen mŸssen.[5] SzelepcsŽnyi war als Ð ein von Jesuiten erzogener Ÿberzeugter Katholik Ð ein Verfechter der Gegenreformation. Er war bereit den zwischenzeitlich auch in Kšnigreich Ungarn etablierten Protestantismus Ð mit Hilfe des katholischen habsburgischen Kaisers auch gewaltsam zurŸckzudrŠngen. Leopold I. konstituierte ein "Sondergericht", das unter dem Vorsitz von SzelepcsŽnyi (in seiner Eigenschaft als Erzbischof von Gran) stand. Unter der Leitung von SzelepcsŽnyi und seines Nachfolgers Leopold Kollonich (damals in seiner Eigenschaft als PrŠsident der Ungarischen Hofkammer) wurden in den Jahren 1673/74 "Schauprozesse" in Tyrnau (slow. Trnava, ung. Nagyszombat) inszeniert, in welchen die Protestanten Ð Lutheraner und Calviner gleicherma§en- massenweise vorgefŸhrt und verurteilt wurden. Damit hofften die katholischen WŸrdentrŠger die lutherischen und calvinistischen "HŠretiker" ein fŸr allemal auszurotten.[5]

Bereits am 25. September 1673 wurden 33 evangelische Prediger und zahlreiche Schullehrer vor dieses Gericht zitiert und wegen "MajestŠtsbeleidigung" und Zusammenarbeit mit den (als evangelisch geltenden) Kuruzen angeklagt. Au§erdem wurden sie der Kollaboration mit den Osmanen beschuldigt.

Einige von ihnen wurden zum Tode verurteilt. man legte ihnen zur verbindlichen Unterschrift ein Reversal vor, wonach sie

entweder das Land verlassen mussten oder
ihre TŠtigkeit als evangelische Prediger aufgeben
und zum Katholizismus konvertieren
Jene welche bereit waren dieses Reversal zu unterzeichnen sollten freigelassen werden. Von den Vorgeladenen haben die meisten unterschrieben. Nach diesem 'Erfolg' wurden am 5. MŠrz 1674 weitere 730 protestantische Prediger und Lehrer vor das Sondergericht vorgeladen. Die Anschuldigungen waren dieselben, wie im vergangenen Jahr. Es gab jedoch mehrere Prediger, die nicht bereit waren das Reversal zu unterzeichnen. Die wurden am 4. April 1674 zum Tode verurteilt. Ein Aufschrei der Empšrung brauste durch das protestantische Europa!

Der kaiserliche Hof in Wien konnte diese radikale Position des katholischen Klerus nicht hinnehmen. RŸcksichtnahmen auf die protestantischen FŸrsten im Deutschen Reich, sowie seiner protestantischen Bundesgenossen England und Holland, die er im Kampf gegen den tŸrkischen Sultan und Frankreich brauchte, zwangen Kaiser Leopold I. einen liberaleren Standpunkt einzunehmen.[5]

Daraufhin wurden die Todesurteile in schwere drakonische Kerkerstrafen umgewandelt. 1675 wurden die betroffenen als GaleerenstrŠflinge in die Sklaverei nach Neapel verkauft.

Szelepcsenyi war ein entschlossener Gegner des Islam. Seinem diplomatischen Geschick ist es zu verdanken, dass sich in Europa eine antitŸrkische Union bildete. Er prophezeite die Belagerung Wiens und deshalb begab er sich in diplomatischer Mission im Auftrag des Kaisers nach Polen, wo er um die Teilnahme der polnischen und litauischen StreitkrŠfte warb.

Als Reaktion auf die osmanischen Kriegsvorbereitungen und auf DrŠngen von SzelepcsŽnyi, das auch von Papst Innozenz XI. unterstŸtzt wurde, ging der damalige Kšnig von Polen Johann III. Sobieski am 1. April 1683 ein DefensivbŸndnis mit Kaiser Leopold I. ein. Sobald den Kšnig die Nachricht von dem tŸrkischen Feldzug Richtung Wien erreichte, erlie§ er das allgemeine Adelsaufgebot und machte sich auf den Weg, um die bedrohte Reichshauptstadt zu befreien. Damit griff er entscheidend in die Geschichte Europas ein. Seine polnische Armee schlug mit seinen VerbŸndeten 1683 das osmanische Heer in de Schlacht am Kahlenberg entscheidend.

Bereits Anfang Mai 1683 kam SzelepcsŽnyi nach Pre§burg wo er eine Heilige Messe vor den versammelten Truppen zelebrierte und den Verteidigern Wiens seinen Segen erteilte. Im Sommer 1683 unterstŸtzte er die christlichen Heere mit 493 Tausend Gulden aus seiner Privatschatulle. Au§erdem unterstŸtzte er die christlichen Heere mit Lebensmitteln aus seinen bšhmischen und mŠhrischen GŸtern im geschŠtzten Wert von rd. 170 Tausend Gulden.

Am 12. September 1683 besiegten die christlichen Heere die tŸrkische †bermacht. Als Erinnerung an diesen Sieg[6] erhob Papst Innozenz XI. diesen Tag zum Fest MariŠ Namen das auch heute noch in katholischen Gebieten als Feiertag gehalten wird.

Erzbischof SzelepcsŽnyi erwarb sich wegen seines geistigen Beistandes, sowie seiner finanziellen und materiellen Hilfe den Ehrentitel "Retter Wiens".
English Bio:
Georg SzelepcsŽnyi (born April 24, 1595 in Szelepcseny , Kingdom of Hungary ,   April 24, 1685 in Lettowitz , Kingdom of Bohemia ) was a Catholic priest and Archbishop of Gran . He was also a journalist and an important representative of the Counter-Reformation .

Georg SzlepcsŽnyi was one of several children of Slovak serfs , his mother's name was Zsuzsanna and he was a born GyŸrky. It was baptized in the church of Barskisfalud ( slow Vieska nad _itavou) [1] a small village about 10 km from Goldmorawitz away, in the county bars . Both parents are a result of the Turkish wars were killed by Turks be [2] . As an orphan , he worked as a swineherd to survive. Then he came into the care of a distant relative, Ladislaus SzelepcsŽnyi who belonged to the nobility. Dr Junge also took over his name, coat of arms and the nobility predicate .

Archbishop PŽter P‡zm‡ny became acquainted with the talented young man during a canonical visit to Bars County in 1617. He recognized the talent of the young man and took him to Trnava , where he in the local Jesuit - School enabled training. In 1618 P‡zm‡ny sent him to further studies at the seminary Pontificium Collegium Germanium et Hungaricum to Rome , where he received his doctorate after his studies in theology and philosophy and received two doctorates. In 1627 he was ordained a priest.

After his return home, he made a steep career as a priest, but also as a diplomat . First he worked as a priest in Wartberg ( ung Szenc), 1536 he became a canon in Tyrnau. At the solemn funeral of his patron and friend Peter P‡zmany in 1637, he led the funeral and held the funeral address.

On April 18, 1648 he was appointed Bishop of Neutra and 1657 Archbishop of Kalocsa . After the death of Gyšrgy Lippay [3] he was appointed by Hungary on 15 January 1666 Archbishop of Esztergom and Primate. He was one of the closest confidants and advisers of Emperor Leopold I. In addition to his work as a church prince he was also involved in government business. From 1644 he was head of the Hungarian Court Chancellery, which at that time was still located in Bratislava , before moving to Vienna in 1690 . He was on diplomatic mission three times on behalf of the Emperor at the Sublime Porte inConstantinople (today's Istanbul ). Between 1670 and 1681 he was royal governor for the Kingdom of Hungary, which represented the highest dignity after the king.

SzelepcsŽnyi played a crucial role in uncovering the magnate plot in the Kingdom of Hungary. L‡szl— Fekete - Iv‡nyi [4] ( . Ung Iv‡nyi Fekete L‡szl—) betrayed the conspirators to the Archbishop, who passed on this information to the Imperial Court in Vienna.

Because of his merit but also thanks to his business skills, he acquired a huge fortune. Above all, he used this fortune for the common good. He founded schools and built numerous churches at his own expense. He financially supported many parishes and Catholic religious communities . In Tyrnau he founded a seminary and supported the university with significant financial resources.

SzelepcsŽnyi reached a high age for the time. At the end of his life he fell ill and retired to his estates in Lettowitz in Moravia . But also from here he wrote in writing his Graner archdiocese and maintained a lively correspondence with the emperor and the court of Vienna. He died on January 15, 1685 on his estate in Lettowitz. According to his own wish, which he also affirmed in his will, he found his final resting place in the pilgrimage church of Mariazell . He was buried in the local chapel of St. Ladislaus , which he had himself built.

The decade between 1671 and 1681 may be described as the funeral decade of Protestantism in Hungary. If, according to the wishes of the Jesuit party led by Gyšrgy SzelepcsŽnyi, it had been within the Roman Church, Protestantism in Hungary would have had to reckon with its total annihilation at that time. [5] SzelepcsŽnyi was as - a trained by Jesuits devout Catholic - a supporter of the Counter-Reformation, He was ready to forcibly replace Protestantism established in the Kingdom of Hungary with the help of the Catholic Habsburg Emperor. Leopold I constituted a "special court" chaired by SzelepcsŽnyi (in his capacity as Archbishop of Gran). Under the direction of SzelepcsŽnyi and his successor Leopold Kollonich (then in his capacity as President of the Hungarian Court Chamber), "show trials" were staged in Tyrnau (Slow Trnava, Nagyszombat) in 1673-74, in which the Protestants - Lutherans and Calvinians were presented and condemned in equal measure. The Catholic dignitaries hoped that Lutheran and Calvinist "Heretics "once and for all. [5]

Already on 25 September 1673, 33 Protestant preachers and numerous school teachers were cited before this court and charged with " lese majeste " and co-operation with the (as evangelical) Kuruzen . In addition, they were charged with collaborating with the Ottomans .

Some of them were sentenced to death. they were presented with a reversal to the binding signature , according to which they

either had to leave the country or
abandon her work as a Protestant preacher
and convert to Catholicism
Those ready to sign this reversal should be released. Most of those who were summoned signed. After this 'success' on 5 March 1674 another 730 Protestant preachers and teachers were summoned before the Special Court. The allegations were the same as last year. However, there were several preachers who were unwilling to sign the reversal. They were sentenced to death on April 4, 1674. An outcry of outrage roared through Protestant Europe!

The imperial court in Vienna could not tolerate this radical position of the Catholic clergy. Considerations to the Protestant princes in the German Reich , as well as his Protestant allies England and Holland , which he needed in the fight against the Turkish Sultan and France , forced Emperor Leopold I to take a more liberal position. [5]

As a result, the death sentences were turned into serious draconian jail sentences. In 1675 the victims were sold as galley prisoners into slavery in Naples .

Szelepcsenyi was a determined opponent of Islam . It is thanks to his diplomatic skills that an anti-Turkish Union was formed in Europe. He prophesied the siege of Vienna and therefore he went on a diplomatic mission on behalf of the Emperor to Poland , where he campaigned for the participation of the Polish and Lithuanian armed forces.

In response to the Ottoman war preparations and at the insistence of SzelepcsŽnyi, also by Pope Innocent XI. was supported, went the then king of Poland Johann III. Sobieski on 1 April 1683 a defensive alliance with Emperor Leopold I. a. As soon as the king reached the news of the Turkish campaign in the direction of Vienna, he issued the general nobility and set out to liberate the threatened imperial capital. He made a decisive contribution to the history of Europe. His Polish army struck with his allies in 1683 the Ottoman army in the Battle of Kahlenberg crucial.

Already at the beginning of May 1683 SzelepcsŽnyi came to Bratislava where he celebrated a Mass in front of the assembled troops and gave his blessing to the defenders of Vienna. In the summer of 1683 he supported the Christian armies with 493 thousand guilders from his private casket. In addition, he supported the Christian armies with food from his Bohemian and Moravian estates valued at approx. 170 thousand guilders.

On 12 September 1683, the Christian armies defeated the Turkish supremacy. As a reminder of this victory [6] , Pope Innocent XI. this day for the Feast of the Name of Mary, which is still held today in Catholic areas as a holiday.

Archbishop SzelepcsŽnyi earned the honorary title of "Savior of Vienna" for his spiritual assistance and financial and material support.

Name: Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch
German Bio:
Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch, auch: Kollonich, Collonicz, Kollonitz (* 26. Oktober 1631 in Komorn;   20. JŠnner 1707 in Wien) war ršmisch-katholischer Erzbischof der Erzdišzese Gran (Esztergom), Primas des Kšnigreiches Ungarn und Kardinal.

Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch stammte aus der Adelsfamilie Kollonitz von Kollograd, er war der Sohn des Grafen Ernst von Kollonitsch, des Befehlshabers der Festung Komorn. Er nahm 1651 als Kandidat des Malteserordens bei der Verteidigung von Kandia (Kreta) gegen die TŸrken und 1655 an den KŠmpfen in den Dardanellen teil. Als Malteserritter war er ab 1658 Prior der Ordensniederlassungen der Kommende Mailberg und spŠter von Eger in Bšhmen.

1659 ernannte ihn Kaiser Leopold I. zum Kammerherrn und schlug ihn als Bischof von Neutra (heute Slowakei) vor. Erst danach begann Kollonitsch mit dem Theologiestudium und empfing 1668 die Priesterweihe. Die Bischofsweihe spendete ihm am 26. August 1668 in Wien Erzbischof Antonio Pignatelli, der spŠtere Papst Innozenz XII.; Mitkonsekratoren waren Ferenc Szegedy, Bischof von V‡c, und Lorenz Aidinger, Bischof von Wiener Neustadt. 1669 trat er das Bischofsamt an, verzichtete aber wegen Kritik in Ungarn darauf und wurde 1670 Bischof von Wiener Neustadt. Von 1672 bis 1681 war er PrŠsident der ungarischen Hofkammer.

Gemeinsam mit Juraj SelepcŽni Pohronec (Gyšrgy SzelepcsŽny) war er beim 1673Ð1674 stattfindenden Sondergericht von Pressburg fŸr die Verurteilung und Ausweisung von 278 Protestanten aus der jetzigen Slowakei verantwortlich.

Bei der Zweiten Wiener TŸrkenbelagerung im Jahr 1683 begab er sich in die belagerte Stadt, sorgte fŸr die Besoldung der Truppen und richtete in Klšstern NotspitŠler ein. Nach der Befreiung Wiens am 12. September durch die Schlacht am Kahlenberg organisierte er die Betreuung von etwa 500 Waisenkindern auf Schloss Mailberg, deren Eltern bei der Zerstšrung der VorstŠdte ums Leben gekommen waren. In den Folgejahren grŸndete er hinter den nach Osten vorrŸckenden Truppen die ersten MilitŠrspitŠler. Dadurch erfreute er sich bei der Wiener Bevšlkerung gro§er Beliebtheit.

1685 wurde er Bischof des Bistums Raab und 1686 Kardinal; 1688 wurde er zusŠtzlich noch Erzbischof von Kalocsa. 1692 ernannte ihn der Kaiser zum Staats- und Konferenzminister, in dieser Funktion war er fŸr die Neuordnung der eroberten ungarischen Gebiete verantwortlich.

Im Jahr 1695 wurde er schlie§lich Erzbischof von Gran und Primas von Ungarn. Er konnte Ÿber 100.000 Orthodoxe Christen fŸr eine Union mit Rom gewinnen.

Unter Kollonitsch begann auch die Ansiedlung der Kapuziner in Pressburg. So wurde 1708 der Grundstein fŸr das Kapuzinerkloster mit der danebenliegenden Klosterkirche gelegt.[1]

Vor dem Wiener Rathaus steht sein Denkmal von Vincenz Pilz. Im Jahr 1862 wurde in Wien Landstra§e (3. Bezirk) die Kolonitzgasse und 1873 der Kolonitzplatz nach ihm benannt.
English Bio:
Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch , also: Kollonich , Collonicz , Kollonitz (born October 26, 1631 in Komorn ,   January 20, 1707 in Vienna ) was Roman Catholic Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Gran (Esztergom), Primate of the Kingdom of Hungary and Cardinal.

Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch came from the noble family Kollonitz von Kollograd , he was the son of Count Ernst von Kollonitsch, the commander of the fortress Komorn. He participated in 1651 as a candidate of the Order of Malta in the defense of Kandia ( Crete ) against the Turks and 1655 in the fighting in the Dardanelles in part. As a Knight of the Order of Malta, he was from 1658 Prior of the orders of the upcoming Mailberg and later of Eger in Bohemia .

1659 Emperor named him Leopold I to Chamberlain and hit him as Bishop of Neutra (now Slovakia before). Only then did Kollonitsch begin the study of theology and in 1668 he was ordained a priest . The episcopal consecration gave him on August 26, 1668 in Vienna Archbishop Antonio Pignatelli , the later Pope Innocent XII .; Co- consecrators were Ferenc Szegedy , Bishop of V‡c , and Lorenz Aidinger , Bishop of Wiener Neustadt, In 1669 he took up the episcopate, but renounced it because of criticism in Hungary and 1670 Bishop of Wiener Neustadt. From 1672 to 1681 he was president of the Hungarian Court Chamber.

Together with Juraj SelepcŽni Pohronec (Gyšrgy SzelepcsŽny), he was responsible for the sentencing and expulsion of 278 Protestants from present-day Slovakia at the 1673-1674 special court in Bratislava .

At the Second Viennese Turkish siege in 1683, he went to the besieged city, provided for the salaries of the troops and established emergency hospitals in monasteries. After the liberation of Vienna on 12 September by the Battle of Kahlenberg , he organized the care of about 500 orphans at Castle Mailberg , whose parents had died in the destruction of the suburbs. In the following years he founded behind the eastward advancing troops, the first military hospitals. As a result, he enjoyed great popularity among the Viennese population.

In 1685 he became bishop of the diocese of Raab and 1686 cardinal ; In 1688 he was also Archbishop of Kalocsa . In 1692, the Emperor appointed him Minister of State and Conference, in this role he was responsible for the reorganization of the conquered Hungarian territories.

In 1695 he finally became Archbishop of Gran and Primate of Hungary. He was able to win over 100,000 Orthodox Christians for a union with Rome .

Under Kollonitsch also began the settlement of the Capuchins in Bratislava . Thus, in 1708, the foundation stone was laid for the Capuchin monastery with the adjoining monastery church. [1]

In front of the Vienna City Hall stands his monument by Vincenz Pilz . In 1862, in Vienna Landstrasse (3rd district) Kolonitzgasse and 1873 Kolonitzplatz named after him.

Weiters war er Bischof von Raab und Erlau. Von 1488 bis 1490 war er Administrator des Bistums Wien.[1]  Urban DÃ³czi wurde in Nagy-Luche, nahe der Insel SchÃ¼tt in Ungarn geboren.  Matthias Corvinus ernannte den Diplomaten zum kÃ¶niglichen Schatzmeister, KronhÃ¼ter und 1481 zum Statthalter. Matthias nominierte ihn 1483 zum Bischof von Raab und 1486 von Erlau. DÃ³czi half Matthias bei kriegerischen Unternehmungen wie der Belagerung von Hainburg mit 5000 Mann und hohen Geldsummen sowie bei der Einnahme von Wien und Wiener Neustadt. 1470 kam es zu Meinungsverschiedenheiten zwischen Kaiser Friedrich III. und Matthias Corvinus, die 1477 in eine formelle KriegserklÃ¤rung mÃ¼ndeten. Der TÃ¼rkenkrieg beschÃ¤ftigte ihn jedoch bis zum Tod Sultan Mehmeds II. im Jahre 1481. Matthias schloss 1483 mit den Osmanen einen Waffenstillstand und begann den Kampf um Wien. Aus dem Wirken DÃ³czis in seinem neuen Bistum Wien ist nur eine Verordnung aus dem Jahre 1489 bekannt, die das Fest der Unbefleckten EmpfÃ¤ngnis Mariens zum Feiertag erklÃ¤rte. Dieser Tag war bisher nur im Chor des Stephansdoms und von der UniversitÃ¤t Wien gefeiert worden. Nach dem Tod seines Protektors KÃ¶nig Matthias am 6. April 1490 â€“ Dienstag der Karwoche â€“ mit 46 Jahren gab DÃ³czi seine Wiener Administratur nach nur zwei Jahren wieder auf und ging nach Ungarn zurÃ¼ck, wo er 1493 in seinem Bistum Erlau starb.
English Bio:
Orb‡n of Nagylœcse or Urban D—czi (* 15th century in Nagy-Luche , Hungary ,   1493 in Erlau ) was royal treasurer, guardian and governor of Hungary. He was also bishop of Raab and Erlau. From 1488 to 1490 he was administrator of the diocese of Vienna . [1]

Urban D—czi was born in Nagy-Luche, near the island of SchŸtt in Hungary.

Matthias Corvinus appointed the diplomat to the royal treasurer, KronhŸter and 1481 governor. Matthias nominated him in 1483 as Bishop of Raab and 1486 of Erlau . D—czi helped Matthias in military operations such as the siege of Hainburg with 5000 men and large sums of money and in the capture of Vienna and Wiener Neustadt . In 1470 there were differences of opinion between Emperor Frederick III. and Matthias Corvinus, who in 1477 ended in a formal declaration of war. The Turkish War , however, employed him until the death of Sultan Mehmed II.in 1481. Matthias concluded a truce with the Ottomans in 1483 and began the fight for Vienna. In the autumn of 1482 Vienna was besieged by the Hungarians. In 1484 the Hungarians took Bruck an der Leitha and besieged Korneuburg . In 1483, the Viennese paid tribute to the Hungarians in order to be able to bring in the grapes harvest undisturbed. The citizens of Vienna concluded without the consent of Emperor Friedrich III. together with the University of Vienna on May 21, 1485 a truce with Matthias. According to a report by the humanist Wolfgang Lazius , Matthias had the intention to lift the Vienna diocese. In 1485 or 1486 he is said to have entered the cathedral chapter with this request .

After the death of the administrator Bernhard von Rohr , he changed his mind and ordered the Bishop of Erlau Urban D—czi to the new administrator of Vienna. Pope Innocent VIII confirmed him by a bull published on April 20, 1488 in Vienna . From the work of D—czi in his new diocese of Vienna, only a decree from 1489 is known, which declared the feast of the Immaculate Conception of Mary as a holiday. This day was previously only in the choir of St. Stephen's Cathedral and the University of Viennabeen celebrated. After the death of his protector King Matthias on April 6, 1490 - Tuesday of the Holy Week - at age 46, D—czi resigned after only two years and returned to Hungary, where he died in 1493 in his diocese of Erlau.

Mit den Vorbereitungen fÃ¼r den Kreuzzug beauftragte er den Szekler GyÃ¶rgy DÃ³zsa. Diese Entscheidung mÃ¼ndete in einen verheerenden Bauernaufstand.  Nach dem Tod von Vladislav II. (1516) verlor er an politischem Einfluss. Die letzten Jahre seines Lebens war er so krank, dass er sein Haus nicht mehr verlassen konnte. Als er am 15. English Bio:
Tam‡s Bak—cz ( Croatian Toma Baka_ [1] * 1442 in Erd_dy ,   June 15, 1521 in Esztergom ) was a Hungarian cardinal and politician.

Bak—cz came from a family of the Hungarian nobility and was born on the estate Erd_d in Szatm‡r county . He was adopted by his uncle B‡lint B‡kocz, who enabled him to become a priest . Tam‡s Bak—cz studied law in Wroclaw and at the University of Padua . Later he became one of the secretaries of Matthias Corvinus , who in 1486 appointed him Bishop of Gy_r . In 1490 he became a member of the Privy Council and Chancellor. He then became bishop of Zagreb .

Under Vladislav II he received as Bishop of Eger one of the richest dioceses in Hungary. In 1497 he became archbishop of Esztergom and thus primate of Hungary. From 1490 until his death in 1521 he was Chancellor of the Kingdom of Hungary and responsible for the foreign policy of the country. He served as a writer Lazarus Secretarius .

1500 raised him Alexander VI. the Cardinal and appointed him cardinal priest of San Martino ai Monti . Since 1507 Cardinal Bak—cz was also titular patriarch of Constantinople Opel . After the death of Julius II , he participated in the conclave October 1503 for the election of the new pope. He used his great political influence, including his wealth, to influence the election in his favor, but was unable to prevail against the eventually elected Pope Julius II.

He returned to Hungary as a papal legate , with a cop from Leo X. for a crusade against the Turks. He commissioned Szekler Gyšrgy D—zsa to prepare for the crusade . This decision resulted in a devastating peasant uprising .

After the death of Vladislav II (1516) he lost political influence. The last years of his life he was so ill that he could not leave his house. When he died on 15 June 1521, he left his relatives (who called himself Count Erd_dy after his birthplace) a million worth.

Juraj DraÅ¡koviÄ‡ entstammte der kroatischen Adelsfamilie DraÅ¡koviÄ‡. Sein Vater war Bartol DraÅ¡koviÄ‡ (* ca. 1500; â€  1538), ein Kleinadliger aus dem SÃ¼den Kroatiens. Seine Mutter Ana geb. Als Ban war er maÃŸgeblich an der rÃ¼cksichtslosen Niederschlagung des kroatischen Bauernaufstands von 1573 beteiligt. Den FÃ¼hrer des Aufstands, den von den kroatischen Bauern ausgerufenen BauernkÃ¶nig Matija Gubec, lieÃŸ er auf dem Agramer Markusplatz (Markov Trg) foltern und anschlieÃŸend hinrichten.  Juraj DraÅ¡koviÄ‡ organisierte die Verteidigung gegen die TÃ¼rken, wobei er relativ erfolgreich war. DafÃ¼r verlieh ihm Kaiser Rudolf II. 1578 die WÃ¼rde eines ungarischen Hofkanzlers und gab ihm zusÃ¤tzlich zu seinen anderen PfrÃ¼nden 1578 das Bistum Raab. Im Jahre 1584 Ã¼berlieÃŸ der Kaiser ihm das Schloss TrakoÅ¡Ä‡an, das bis 1945 im Besitz der Familie blieb. Von Papst Sixtus V. am 18. Dezember 1585 zum Kardinalpriester und von Kaiser Rudolf zum Statthalter Ungarns erhoben, starb er am 21. Januar 1587.[2]
English Bio:
Juraj II Dra_kovi_ of Trako__an. , Hungarian Gyšrgy Draskovics (* 5 February 1515 [1] on Castle Bilina in Croatia region Bukovica (west of the city of Knin );   21st January 1587 in Vienna ) was a Croatian nobleman, archbishop and cardinal , From 1567 to 1576 he was Ban (viceroy) of Croatia .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ came from the Croatian noble family Dra_kovi_ . His father was Bartol Dra_kovi_ (* 1500,   1538), a small nobleman from the south of Croatia. His mother Ana, born. Utje_inovi_, born in Kami_ak , was a sister of the cardinal and statesman Juraj Utje_inovi_ , better known as Georg Martinuzzi .

He studied in Krakow , Vienna , Bologna and Rome , received in 1539 [1] the priesthood and was canon to Oradea , abbot Lelesz , infulierter provost of the collegiate church of St. Martin to Bratislava , King and Emperor Ferdinand I advice and confessor, and 1557 Bishop of five churches .

In 1561 he translated Vinzenz von LŽrin's book "Against the heretics" ( Commonitorium fidei ). He participated for Croatia and Hungary in the Trento Council , where he performed in the interest of the emperor. Ferdinand appointed him for the Bishop of Agram (Zagreb) in 1565 , and his successor Maximilian II to the Real Privy Council , and 1567 to the Ban of Croatia , Dalmatia and Slavonia . In 1573 he became archbishop of Kalocsa .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ became ingloriously known in his power position secured by the authorities, by the oppression and exploitation of the Croatian farmers entrusted to him. As Ban he was instrumental in the ruthless crushing of the Croatian peasant uprising of 1573. The leader of the uprising, the peasant king Matija Gubec , who was proclaimed by the Croatian peasants , was tortured and then executed at the Agrarian Mark Square (Markov Trg) .

Juraj Dra_kovi_ organized the defense against the Turks , where he was relatively successful. In 1578 Emperor Rudolf II granted him the dignity of a Hungarian court chancellor in 1578 and in addition to his other benefices in 1578 gave him the diocese of Raab . In 1584, the Emperor gave him the castle Trako__an , which remained until 1945 in the possession of the family. On December 18, 1585, Cardinal Pope Sixtus V. became cardinal priest and Emperor Rudolf governor of Hungary, he died on January 21, 1587. [2]

Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch stammte aus der Adelsfamilie Kollonitz von Kollograd, er war der Sohn des Grafen Ernst von Kollonitsch, des Befehlshabers der Festung Komorn. Er nahm 1651 als Kandidat des Malteserordens bei der Verteidigung von Kandia (Kreta) gegen die TÃ¼rken und 1655 an den KÃ¤mpfen in den Dardanellen teil. Erst danach begann Kollonitsch mit dem Theologiestudium und empfing 1668 die Priesterweihe. Die Bischofsweihe spendete ihm am 26. August 1668 in Wien Erzbischof Antonio Pignatelli, der spÃ¤tere Papst Innozenz XII.; Mitkonsekratoren waren Ferenc Szegedy, Bischof von VÃ¡c, und Lorenz Aidinger, Bischof von Wiener Neustadt. 1669 trat er das Bischofsamt an, verzichtete aber wegen Kritik in Ungarn darauf und wurde 1670 Bischof von Wiener Neustadt. Von 1672 bis 1681 war er PrÃ¤sident der ungarischen Hofkammer.  Gemeinsam mit Juraj SelepcÃ©ni Pohronec (GyÃ¶rgy SzelepcsÃ©ny) war er beim 1673â€“1674 stattfindenden Sondergericht von Pressburg fÃ¼r die Verurteilung und Ausweisung von 278 Protestanten aus der jetzigen Slowakei verantwortlich.  Bei der Zweiten Wiener TÃ¼rkenbelagerung im Jahr 1683 begab er sich in die belagerte Stadt, sorgte fÃ¼r die Besoldung der Truppen und richtete in KlÃ¶stern NotspitÃ¤ler ein. Nach der Befreiung Wiens am 12. September durch die Schlacht am Kahlenberg organisierte er die Betreuung von etwa 500 Waisenkindern auf Schloss Mailberg, deren Eltern bei der ZerstÃ¶rung der VorstÃ¤dte ums Leben gekommen waren. In den Folgejahren grÃ¼ndete er hinter den nach Osten vorrÃ¼ckenden Truppen die ersten MilitÃ¤rspitÃ¤ler. Dadurch erfreute er sich bei der Wiener BevÃ¶lkerung groÃŸer Beliebtheit.  1685 wurde er Bischof des Bistums Raab und 1686 Kardinal; 1688 wurde er zusÃ¤tzlich noch Erzbischof von Kalocsa. 1692 ernannte ihn der Kaiser zum Staats- und Konferenzminister, in dieser Funktion war er fÃ¼r die Neuordnung der eroberten ungarischen Gebiete verantwortlich.  Im Jahr 1695 wurde er schlieÃŸlich Erzbischof von Gran und Primas von Ungarn. Er konnte Ã¼ber 100.000 Orthodoxe Christen fÃ¼r eine Union mit Rom gewinnen.  Unter Kollonitsch begann auch die Ansiedlung der Kapuziner in Pressburg. So wurde 1708 der Grundstein fÃ¼r das Kapuzinerkloster mit der danebenliegenden Klosterkirche gelegt.[1]  Vor dem Wiener Rathaus steht sein Denkmal von Vincenz Pilz. Michael Altkind (Administrator)Â | Petrus EngelprechtÂ | Augustin KiebingerÂ | Theoderich KammererÂ | Johann FabriÂ (Koadjutor)Â | Gregor AngererÂ | Heinrich MuelichÂ | Christoph WertweinÂ (Administrator)Â | Franz AbstemiusÂ | Martin DurlacherÂ | Kaspar von LogauÂ | Christian NapponÃ¤usÂ | Lambert GruterÂ | Martin RadwigerÂ | Melchior KhleslÂ (Administrator)Â | Matthias GeiÃŸlerÂ | Johann ThuanusÂ | Laurenz AidingerÂ | Leopold Karl von KollonitschÂ | Christoph de Royas y SpinolaÂ | Franz Anton von BucheimÂ | Ignaz von LovinaÂ | Joseph Ignaz della RovereÂ | Johann Moritz Gustav von Manderscheid-BlankenheimÂ | Franz Anton von KhevenhÃ¼llerÂ | Ferdinand von HallweilÂ | Johann Heinrich von Kerens (dann Bischof von St. PÃ¶lten)
English Bio:
Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch , also: Kollonich , Collonicz , Kollonitz (born October 26, 1631 in Komorn ,   January 20, 1707 in Vienna ) was Roman Catholic Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Gran (Esztergom), Primate of the Kingdom of Hungary and Cardinal.

Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch came from the noble family Kollonitz von Kollograd , he was the son of Count Ernst von Kollonitsch, the commander of the fortress Komorn. He participated in 1651 as a candidate of the Order of Malta in the defense of Kandia ( Crete ) against the Turks and 1655 in the fighting in the Dardanelles in part. As a Knight of the Order of Malta, he was from 1658 Prior of the orders of the upcoming Mailberg and later of Eger in Bohemia .

1659 Emperor named him Leopold I to Chamberlain and hit him as Bishop of Neutra (now Slovakia before). Only then did Kollonitsch begin the study of theology and in 1668 he was ordained a priest . The episcopal consecration gave him on August 26, 1668 in Vienna Archbishop Antonio Pignatelli , the later Pope Innocent XII .; Co- consecrators were Ferenc Szegedy , Bishop of V‡c , and Lorenz Aidinger , Bishop of Wiener Neustadt, In 1669 he took up the episcopate, but renounced it because of criticism in Hungary and 1670 Bishop of Wiener Neustadt. From 1672 to 1681 he was president of the Hungarian Court Chamber.

Together with Juraj SelepcŽni Pohronec (Gyšrgy SzelepcsŽny), he was responsible for the sentencing and expulsion of 278 Protestants from present-day Slovakia at the 1673-1674 special court in Bratislava .

At the Second Viennese Turkish siege in 1683, he went to the besieged city, provided for the salaries of the troops and established emergency hospitals in monasteries. After the liberation of Vienna on 12 September by the Battle of Kahlenberg , he organized the care of about 500 orphans at Castle Mailberg , whose parents had died in the destruction of the suburbs. In the following years he founded behind the eastward advancing troops, the first military hospitals. As a result, he enjoyed great popularity among the Viennese population.

In 1685 he became bishop of the diocese of Raab and 1686 cardinal ; In 1688 he was also Archbishop of Kalocsa . In 1692, the Emperor appointed him Minister of State and Conference, in this role he was responsible for the reorganization of the conquered Hungarian territories.

In 1695 he finally became Archbishop of Gran and Primate of Hungary. He was able to win over 100,000 Orthodox Christians for a union with Rome .

Under Kollonitsch also began the settlement of the Capuchins in Bratislava . Thus, in 1708, the foundation stone was laid for the Capuchin monastery with the adjoining monastery church. [1]

In front of the Vienna City Hall stands his monument by Vincenz Pilz . In 1862, in Vienna Landstrasse (3rd district) Kolonitzgasse and 1873 Kolonitzplatz named after him.

Name: Kardinal Christian August von Sachsen-Zeitz auch Erzbischof von Gran
German Bio:
Christian August von Sachsen-Zeitz (* 9. Oktober 1666 auf Schloss Moritzburg in Zeitz;   23. August 1725 in Regensburg) war Prinz von Sachsen-Zeitz, Kardinal-Erzbischof von Gran sowie Kaiserlicher Prinzipalkommissar.

Der Sohn des Herzogs Moritz von Sachsen-Zeitz und der Dorothea Maria von Sachsen-Weimar war Ritter im Deutschen Orden, konvertierte 1693 zum Katholizismus und wurde Domherr sowie 1695 Dompropst von Kšln und am 18. Juni 1696 zudem Bischof von Raab (Gy_r) in Ungarn. Am 24. Januar 1701 wurde er Koadjutor des Erzbischofs von Gran (Esztergom) und durch Papst Clemens XI. am 17. Mai 1706 schlie§lich Kardinal[1]. Am 20. Januar 1707 wurde er Erzbischof von Gran und damit Primas von Ungarn (ungarisch KeresztŽly çgost genannt)[2]. 1714 wurden er und seine Nachfolger als Erzbischšfe von Gran vom Kaiser zu ReichsfŸrsten erhoben. Christian August bekleidete ab 1716 das Amt des kaiserlichen Prinzipalkommissars beim ImmerwŠhrenden Reichstag zu Regensburg und prŠsidierte damit de facto als Stellvertreter des Kaisers dem Reichstag. Hier starb er am 23. August 1725.

Um Kšnig von Polen zu werden, musste sein Verwandter August der Starke zum ršmisch-katholischen Glauben Ÿbertreten. Christian August unterrichtete ihn heimlich in diesem Glauben und am 1. Juni 1697 trat August in der katholischen Hofkapelle zu Baden bei Wien heimlich, dann in Deutsch-Piekar (Oberschlesien) šffentlich, feierlich zum ršmisch-katholischen Glauben Ÿber, indem er das vorgeschriebene Apostolische Glaubensbekenntnis vor seinem Gro§cousin Christian August ablegte. †ber die erfolgte Konversion August des Starken stellte Christian August eine Bescheinigung aus, die vom pŠpstlichen Internuntius beglaubigt wurde.

AnlŠsslich des Sieges Ÿber die TŸrken in Belgrad 1717 veranstaltete Christian August, ReprŠsentant von Karl VI. am Reichstag, auf Veranlassung des Kaisers ein prŠchtiges Fest. Zum Festessen am 26. Oktober wurde in den Rittersaal von St. Emmeram geladen.
English Bio:
Christian August of Saxe-Zeitz (* 9. October 1666 at Castle Moritzburg in Zeitz ,   23. August 1725 in Regensburg ) was Prince of Saxe-Zeitz , Cardinal - Archbishop of Gran and Imperial principal commissioner.

The son of Duke Moritz of Saxe- Zeitz and Dorothea Maria of Saxe- Weimar was knight in the Teutonic Knights , converted to Catholicism in 1693 and became a canon and 1695 cathedral dean of Cologne and on June 18, 1696 Bishop of Raab (Gy_r) in Hungary , On January 24, 1701, he became coadjutor of the Archbishop of Gran (Esztergom) and by Pope Clement XI. on May 17, 1706 finally cardinal [1], On 20 January 1707 he became Archbishop of Esztergom and Primate of Hungary ( Hungarian called KeresztŽly çgost) [2] . In 1714, he and his successors were elevated from emperor to imperial prince as archbishops of Gran . Starting in 1716, Christian August held the office of Imperial Princely Commissioner at the Permanent German Reichstag in Regensburg, thereby de facto presiding as deputy of the Emperor for the Reichstag. Here he died on 23 August 1725.

To become King of Poland, his relative Augustus the Strong had to convert to the Roman Catholic faith. Christian August secretly taught him this belief, and on June 1, 1697, August secretly joined the Catholic court orchestra at Baden near Vienna , then publicly in Deutsch-Piekar (Upper Silesia), solemnly converting to the Roman Catholic faith by complying with the prescribed Apostles' Creed before his grand cousin Christian August took off. On the conversion of August the Strong, Christian August issued a certificate, which was certified by the papal Internuntius.

On the occasion of the victory over the Turks in Belgrade 1717 organized Christian August, representative of Charles VI. at the Reichstag, at the instigation of the Emperor a splendid festival. For the feast on October 26th was invited to the Knight's Hall of St. Emmeram .

Um 1000/02 wurde ein Dominicus in einer BestÃ¤tigungsurkunde fÃ¼r das erste ungarische Kloster auf dem Martinsberg (Pannonhalma) als Vizekanzler und MÃ¶nch aufgefÃ¼hrt. 1037 wurde ein Erzbischof Dominicus genannt, mÃ¶glicherweise fÃ¼r eine zurÃ¼ckliegende Zeit.[1]  Die ungarische Forschung nimmt heute an, dass Dominicus der erste Erzbischof des 1001 gegrÃ¼ndeten Erzbistums Gran war.[2]
English Bio:
Dominicus (Hungarian Domonkos ,   after 1001) was Archbishop of Gran (Esztergom) in Hungary.

There is hardly any historical information about him. Around 1000/02 a Dominicus was listed in a confirmation of the first Hungarian monastery on the Martinsberg (Pannonhalma) as vice-chancellor and monk. In 1037, an archbishop named Dominicus, possibly for a time in the past. [1]

Hungarian research today assumes that Dominicus was the first archbishop of the archdiocese of Gran founded in 1001. [2]

Name: Sebastian
German Bio: Sebastian (ungarisch SebestyÃ©n; â€  nach 1007) war wahrscheinlich Erzbischof von Gran (Esztergom).  Er wird nur in der Legenda Sancti Stephani des Bischofs Hartwich im spÃ¤ten 11. Jahrhundert erwÃ¤hnt, nicht jedoch in der Ã¤lteren Legenda maior. Nach drei Jahren erblindete er und wurde durch Bischof Astrik von Kalocsa abgelÃ¶st. Nach seiner Genesung kehrte er wieder in das Amt zurÃ¼ck, wÃ¤hrend Astrik nach Kalocsa zurÃ¼ckging, aber die ErzbischofswÃ¼rde behielt.[1]  Dieser Bericht widerspricht der Legenda maior, nach der Astrik erster Bischof von Gran gewesen sein soll. Die neuere ungarische Geschichtsforschung reiht Sebastian als zweiten Erzbischof von Gran nach Dominicus ein.
English Bio:
Sebastian (Hungarian SebestyŽn ,   after 1007) was probably Archbishop of Gran (Esztergom).

He is mentioned only in the Legenda Sancti Stephani of Bishop Hartwich in the late 11th century, but not in the older legenda maior . According to Sebastian Sebastian was in the Benedictine abbey on the Martinsberg (Pannonhalma) and was appointed by King Stephen for the first Archbishop of Gran. After three years, he went blind and was replaced by Bishop Astrik Kalocsa . After his recovery, he returned to office, while Astrik went back to Kalocsa, but kept the archbishop's dignity. [1]

This report contradicts the Legenda maior , according to which Astrik was said to be the first bishop of Gran. The recent Hungarian historical research ranked Sebastian as the second archbishop of Gran to Dominicus .

German Bio: Astrik  (ungarische Schreibung Asztrik; auch Anastasius, Astricus oder Ascherich; â€  1037) war ein Geistlicher unbekannter Herkunft, der 993 Abt des Stifts BÅ™evnov bei Prag und 1006 erster Erzbischof von Gran (ung. Esztergom) wurde. Er bahnte der KÃ¶nigskrÃ¶nung des heiligen Stephan von Ungarn den Weg und schuf die Grundlagen der ungarischen Kirchenorganisation. Vielfach wird er â€žApostel Ungarnsâ€œ genannt. English Bio:
Astrik ( Hungarian spelling Asztrik ; and Anastasius , Astricus or ash Rich ,   1037 ) was a priest of unknown origin, 993 abbot of the pin B_evnov in Prague and in 1006 the first Archbishop of Gran (ung. Esztergom ) was. He paved the way for the royal coronation of St. Stephen of Hungary and created the foundations of the Hungarian church organization. He often becomes "Apostle of Hungary" called. The details of his biography, however, are uncertain and sometimes contradictory handed down. [1]

There are different assumptions about the origin of Astrik. A German or French-Burgundian origin is suspected. Other sources suggest Czech origin. Astrik was a student of St. Adalbert of Prague , whom he accompanied to Rome in 993, and to Poland in 996/997.

The first written record dates back to 993. At that time, Astrik became the first abbot of the B_evnov Abbey. According to the memorandum, he received from Pope John XV. the right to wear episcopal insignia . After the extinction of Slavn’kovci the monks left the monastery and fled to Poland . For the Benedictines from B_evnov and other Czech monasteries, Bishop Adalbert of Prague donated an abbey in Meseritz, Poland, and ordered his companion Astrik to be abbot. Later, in Subottin, whose location is unknown today, he received episcopal ordination and even the pallium of an archbishop.

After the Battle of Libice (September 28, 995) Astrik came by invitation Radlas with some monks to Hungary . Later he contacted the Hungarian court and traveled to Rome in 1000/1001 to seek papal approval for the coronation of Stephen and the establishment of the Hungarian bishoprics. As abbot of PŽcsv‡rad and since about 1006 as archbishop of Gran and Kalocsa , he was the most important church employee Stephans.

English Bio:
Benedict (Latin Benedictus , Hungarian Benedek , probably also Beneta ,   after 1055 ) was archbishop in Hungary .

Some Hungarian historians consider it possible that he may have been Bishop of Kalocsa in 1035. In 1046, a Bishop Beneta was present at the violent raid on the GellŽrt Hill near Buda , as a result of which the bishops Gerhard (GellŽrt), Bystr’k and Buldus were killed. Beneta was the only one to escape the bishops. His diocese was not mentioned, it could have been Gran (Esztergom). 1055 was in the founding document of the monastery Tihany an Archbishop Benedictuscalled as the first witness. Since only Gran is known as an archdiocese in Hungary at this time, he was probably there archbishop. Further mentions of his person have not been received.

English Bio:
Istv‡n B‡ncsa (* in Hungary ,   July 9, 1270 [1] in Rome ) was Archbishop of Esztergom and the first Hungarian cardinal of the Roman Church . He is also performed as Stefan V‡ncza and Stephanus de Vancsa ; his last name is also written V‡ncsa , V‡ncha , Vanca or B‡nca .

He was first Provost in V‡c and from 1238 to 1240 Chancellor of the Hungarian King BŽla IV. In 1241 he went to Rome and was elected in the same year the Bishop of V‡c . On 7 July 1243 he was appointed Archbishop of Esztergom. On July 19, 1251 he became a legate in Croatia and Dalmatia.

In the Consistory of December 1251 Pope Innocent IV made him Cardinal-Bishop of Palestrina . On May 5, 1253 he was appointed legate in Hungary and Slavonia. He participated in the papal election in 1254 , from which Alexander IV emerged as Pope. In the papal election in 1261 with the election of Urban IV , he could not attend because he was at that time in Hungary. His name can be found again among the pope voters of 1264-1265 , who elected Clement IV in the Papal Office; He was also involved in the papal election 1268-1271 , but died during the Sedisvakanz,

He was buried in the church of Santa Balbina in Rome.

English Bio:
Boleslaus of Tost (also Boleslaus / Boleslaw II of Beuthen and Tost , Polish Boles_aw toszecki , Czech Boleslav Bytomsko - Koselsk_ , * 1280,   1328 or 1329) was Duke of the Upper Silesian Duchy of Beuthen and since 1304 Duke of the Duchy of Tost . In 1321 he became archbishop of Gran .

Boleslaus / Boleslaw was the eldest son of the Duke of Beuthen Kasimir II and the Helena, whose origin is not known. They appointed him for the spiritual career. He was first mentioned on January 10, 1289, when, together with his father and his younger brother Wladislaus, he paid homage to the Bohemian King Wenceslas II and took his oath of allegiance. For the year 1294 he is a scholar of Krakow and three years later a canon of the Wroc_aw cathedral chapter . During the lifetime of his father, who died in 1312, was for him the area of Tostspun off as its duke he held for the first time in 1304 uncertificated and the rule of rights, when he and other accessories to Peter Ratay sold the Scholtisei the village Giegowicz at Tost [1] . In a document issued in Wroc_aw on 5 April 1306 , in which he is mentioned as a witness, he is referred to as Duke of Tost and Scholastikus of Krakow . In a document written on March 6, 1309, he testified that his knight Scarbimir had sold the estate Keltsch to the knights Jasco and Florian.

Around 1315 Boleslaus went to the court of the Hungarian King Charles Robert of Anjou , who was married to Boleslaus sister Maria , who died in 1317. In 1320 he was sent by the king to the court of Krak—w, where he made the marriage of his daughter Elisabeth with King Charles Robert of Anjou with King W_adys_aw I. Ellenlang . Presumably, therefore, he was appointed on October 2, 1321 Archbishop of Gran .

Shortly before his death, he managed to give his younger brother Mieszko the bishop's chair of Neutra . After his death in 1328 Boleslaus was buried in the Cathedral of Gran . The area of __Tost inherited his brother Wladislaus , who in turn connected it with the Duchy of Beuthen.

English Bio:
Georg Count of Hohenlohe (* 1350,   August 3, 1423 in Gran ) was from 1390 to 1423 prince-bishop in the diocese of Passau and from 1418 to 1423 administrator of the Archdiocese of Gran .

The member of the House Hohenlohe came from the Franconian nobility . He was in 1387 against Ruprecht von Berg Elekt of the Diocese of Passau, but his election was made by the cathedral chapter against the resistance of the Passau citizenship, which denied him access to the city. There were armed conflicts.

Duke Albrecht III. from Austria reached that Pope Urban VI. declared him Bishop of Passau in 1389. Ruprecht, who knew except the Passau citizenship and the Wittelsbacher behind, but remained in Passau and ruled from there, the Bavarian part of the diocese, while Georg dominated the Austrian part in Sankt Pšlten .

In 1390, Pope Boniface IX. Ruprecht to the bishop of Paderborn , but the citizens of Passau denied Georg the recognition, so that he still did not get to Passau. Only in 1393, after Ruprecht had renounced Passau, Georg procured violently his entry into the city.

Since the citizenship still resisted, he had their rights restricted. In 1394 he rebuilt a former country estate into Eggendobl Castle . 1391 and again 1395 to 1398 he was pursued especially in Steyr by the Inquisitor Petrus Zwicker the Waldenses .

On May 7, 1407, he laid the foundation stone for the new late-Gothic cathedral of St. Stephen , from which today still preserved the choir built by Hans Krumenauer . In 1409 he built the defensive walls on the Inn and Ilzstadt . He also began the construction of a moated castle in Obernzell , which his successor Leonhard von Laiming completed in 1426.

On the occasion of the Council of Constance (1414-1418) Georg appeared in early 1415 with a hundred horses in Constance . He surrounded himself with professors from the University of Vienna , and at the council he advised and represented King Sigismund , whose chancellor he was from 1421.

In 1418 he became administrator of the Archdiocese of Gran. In 1419 he convened a diocesan synod to carry out the decisions of the Council. In addition to monastery visations, he carried out several diplomatic missions for the Habsburgs . Pope Martin V last awarded him the pallium and granted, but only for his person, the exemption of the Diocese of Passau from the Archdiocese of Salzburg .

English Bio:
Johann von Borsnitz (also Johann von Borschnitz ,   after 27 March 1420 in Lebus ) was from 1397 to 1420 Bishop of Lubusz and 1420 Bishop of Gran .

Johann von Borsnitz came from Silesia and was canon in Prague . Around 1378 he studied at the Charles University in Prague , where he graduated with a Ph.D. decrecrete acquired. He was then papal chaplain and auditor of Rota .

After the death of the Lebus Bishop John III. Frost he was elected by the cathedral chapter to his successor and on September 24, 1397 by Pope Boniface IX. approved. The episcopal ordination took place after 16 June 1398 in Rome.

During his tenure, he founded a collegiate chapter in the Marian shrine Gšritz . In 1405 he arranged for the creation of the Lubusz Collegiate Registry "Lubusz diocesis", which lists the 166 parishes, villages and revenues as well as possessions in Rothreu§en , Greater and Lesser Poland . In 1409 he took part in the Council of Pisa , from which he became Pope Gregory XII. he was to be invited to the council. Between 1414 and 1418 he is repeatedly occupied as a participant in the Council of Constance .

On March 27, 1420 he was transferred to the archbishopric of Gran Pope Martin V , but could not take office because he probably died before in Lebus.

English Bio:
DŽnes SzŽcsi (* 1400 [1] or 1410 in Eger , Hungary ,   February 1, 1465 in Esztergom ) was a Hungarian cardinal and first primate of Hungary.

DŽnes Mikl—s SzŽcsi, (Desiderius SzŽchy, Dionysius) also Zech, Zecho or Zechus was born as the sixth of eight children of the Hungarian aristocrat Mikl—s SzŽchy de Fels›lendva [2] (magister tavernicorum) and his wife Ilona Garai. He studied in 1426 at the University of Vienna and 1433 at the University of Bologna where he received his doctorate in 1434 ( canon law ). Another study at the University of Padua joined.

On August 21, 1438, he was appointed bishop of Nitra . On 5 June 1439 he was appointed Bishop of Eger . In the consistory of December 18, 1439 he was selected by Pope Eugene IV. Created cardinal. On February 15, 1440 Cardinal SzŽcsi was appointed Archbishop and Metropolitan of Esztergom . He took part in the conclave in 1447, in which Cardinal Tommaso Parentucelli was elected Pope Nicholas V , who gave him the title of "Primate of Hungary" and is still associated with the archiepiscopal chair Esztergom.

In the provincial synod in 1450 in Esztergom he campaigned for the restoration of monastic discipline and encouraged the observance of celibacy . He rebuilt the basilica in Esztergom in 1453.

He died on February 1, 1465 and was buried in the Cathedral of Esztergom.

Johann Vitez (* 1408 in Sredna at Kri_evci , Croatia;   9. August 1472 in Esztergom , Hungary; Croat Ivan Vitez od Sredne , Hungarian Janos Vitez de Zredna ) was a Croatian Humanist , from 1445 bishop of Oradea (now Oradea , Romania ) and from 1465 Archbishop of Gran (today: Esztergom, Hungary ). His father was DŽnes of the Zredna (Croatian Dionizije od Sredne ) in the Slavonian Bjelovar-Kri_evci county . His nephew was Janus Pannonius .

Johann Vitez visited in 1434 the University of Zagreb and later the University of Vienna . He first worked as a clerk in the secret chancery of the Hungarian King Sigismund and rose there to the assessor . In 1438 he was custodian of Zagreb. In 1440 he belonged to the Legation, which Wladyslaw I submitted in Krakow the election conditions.

In 1443 he became provost in Wardein (now Oradea ). As a relative of Johann Hunyadi he took over the education of his children during his reign. In 1445 he became a bishop to Wardein. As Chancellor of the Regent and later King Matthias Corvinus he was entrusted with numerous diplomatic tasks. In 1465 he became archbishop of Esztergom (Gran).

In the same year he founded the Universitas Istropolitana in Pre§burg at the behest of Matthias Corvinus, King of Hungary . He had his nephew Janus Pannonius studied in Italy. He then promoted him to the Episcopal See of PŽcs.

In 1471 he joined the conspiracy against King Matthias and became one of its leaders. Matthias forgave him first, but then had him imprisoned in the castle of Visegr‡d and held him in Esztergom under house arrest, where he died in the summer of 1472.

English Bio:
Johann Beckenschlager , also Johann Beckensloer , Johann Pfluger or Johann Peckensloer , (* 1435 in Wroclaw ,   December 15, 1489 in Salzburg ) was Archbishop of Gran and as John III. Archbishop of Salzburg .

Johann Beckenschlager is said to be the son of a blacksmith . Matthias Corvinus made him the provost of five churches and on May 17, 1465 Bishop of Oradea . In 1468 he became Bishop of Eger and 1473 Archbishop of Gran (Hungarian Esztergom ) and Primate of Hungary . Because he lost the favor of the Hungarian king more and more, he left Hungary on February 13, 1476 and joined the Emperor Frederick III. whose advisor and financier he became. Beckenschlager was from March 22, 1477 coadjutorfor the seriously ill Bishop of Vienna, Leo von Spaur , and from 1480 also administrator of the Diocese of Vienna , but renounced this office, since he was on 14 January 1482 as Johann III. first administrator of the (nominally ruling) archbishop of Salzburg and 1487 archbishop.

Johann was more secular warlord than spiritual leader and archbishop. He liked to show himself in full armor and personally went into the field. His extraordinary physical strength was especially praised. This archbishop, like his predecessor and successor, loved the bodily pleasures without regard to ecclesiastical office and frequently used the secret passage of his predecessor as his concubine. Beckenschlager was not popular among the population. She gave him substantial blame for many acts of war and the misery involved.

Most of his reign was Johann Beckenschlager as a diplomat of Emperor Frederick III. working abroad. Already in 1483 the emperor had appointed the archbishop governor of Styria . The year 1481 and the winter half-years 1483/84 he was in the Netherlands . On June 21, 1486, the emperor appointed him governor of Austria (Upper and Lower Austria), Styria, Carinthia , Carniola , Istria and the Karst. Since May 1486 he was responsible for the recruitment of imperial mercenaries in the war against the Hungarian king Matthias Corvinus .

The Regency in Salzburg took over during his long absences substantially the Salzburg Hofkanzler Bishop Georg Altdorfer von Chiemsee. The last year of his life was spent by the already ill archbishop at Hohensalzburg Fortress , whom he had purposefully expanded. Above all, he built here the high floor as a princely residence and built SchŸttkasten (temporarily used as a living space) and workhouse.

Name: Hippolyt Este

Bereits als SiebenjŠhriger wurde er von Kšnig Matthias Corvinus zum Erzbischof von Gran ernannt, als 14-JŠhriger (1493) zum Kardinal, und als 17-JŠhriger zum Erzbischof von Mailand. Er tauschte mit Tam‡s Bak—cz seinen Erzbischofsstuhl von Gran und wurde dafŸr Bischof von Erlau (1497Ð1520). Er war auch Erzbischof von Capua (ab 1502) sowie Bischof von Ferrara (ab 1503).

Ippolito I. dÕEste ist Ludovico Ariostos Werk Orlando Furioso gewidmet.
English Bio:
Ippolito I. d'Este (born March 20, 1479 in Ferrara ,   September 3, 1520 ibid) was a son of Ercole I d'Este , Duke of Ferrara, Modena and Reggio, and brother of Isabella d'Este (1474 -1539), Beatrice d'Este (1475-1497) and Alfonso I d'Este (1476-1534).

Already as a seven -year-old he was appointed Archbishop of Gran by King Matthias Corvinus , as a 14-year-old (1493) Cardinal , and as Archbishop of Milan at the age of 17 . He exchanged his archbishop's chair of Gran with Tam‡s Bak—cz and became Bishop of Erlau (1497-1520). He was also Archbishop of Capua (from 1502) and Bishop of Ferrara (from 1503).

Ippolito I d'Este is dedicated to Ludovico Ariosto 's Orlando Furioso .

English Bio:
Tam‡s Bak—cz ( Croatian Toma Baka_ [1] * 1442 in Erd_dy ,   June 15, 1521 in Esztergom ) was a Hungarian cardinal and politician.

Bak—cz came from a family of the Hungarian nobility and was born on the estate Erd_d in Szatm‡r county . He was adopted by his uncle B‡lint B‡kocz, who enabled him to become a priest . Tam‡s Bak—cz studied law in Wroclaw and at the University of Padua . Later he became one of the secretaries of Matthias Corvinus , who in 1486 appointed him Bishop of Gy_r . In 1490 he became a member of the Privy Council and Chancellor. He then became bishop of Zagreb .

Under Vladislav II he received as Bishop of Eger one of the richest dioceses in Hungary. In 1497 he became archbishop of Esztergom and thus primate of Hungary. From 1490 until his death in 1521 he was Chancellor of the Kingdom of Hungary and responsible for the foreign policy of the country. He served as a writer Lazarus Secretarius .

1500 raised him Alexander VI. the Cardinal and appointed him cardinal priest of San Martino ai Monti . Since 1507 Cardinal Bak—cz was also titular patriarch of Constantinople Opel . After the death of Julius II , he participated in the conclave October 1503 for the election of the new pope. He used his great political influence, including his wealth, to influence the election in his favor, but was unable to prevail against the eventually elected Pope Julius II.

He returned to Hungary as a papal legate , with a cop from Leo X. for a crusade against the Turks. He commissioned Szekler Gyšrgy D—zsa to prepare for the crusade . This decision resulted in a devastating peasant uprising .

After the death of Vladislav II (1516) he lost political influence. The last years of his life he was so ill that he could not leave his house. When he died on 15 June 1521, he left his relatives (who called himself Count Erd_dy after his birthplace) a million worth.

English Bio:
Georg Kardinal Martinuzzi OSPPE ( Hungarian Gyšrgy Utje_enovic , also known as Frater Gyšrgy , brother Georg ; * 1482 in Kamicac , Dalmatia ,   December 17, 1551 at Winzendorf Castle ) was a Hungarian cleric and statesman at the time of the Renaissance .

He was the son of the Croatian landowner Gregor Utje-_enovic, who fell in the fight against the Turks, his mother was a Venetian from the patrician family of Martinuzzi; his uncle was Giacomo Martinuzzi , Bishop of Skradin in Dalmatia . In memory of her, he adopted the surname Martinuzzi. His first name is also given as Juraj ; his last name is given as Utiesenovic, Utyeszenics, Utissenoviski, Utje_inovic, Wisenowiski or Martinuzius ( Latin ). He himself usually depicted Fr. Georgius as a Frater Gyšrgy in Hungarian historiographyor briefly referred to as the Frater .

At the age of eight he came in 1490 to the court of Duke J‡nos Corvin and became the first page and valet of the Duke. He remained there for twelve years until he entered the service of the Z‡polya family and fought under Johann Z‡polya for a short time . A monk of the Paulines had taught him reading and writing, so he gave up military career and joined in 1510 in the monastery of St. Lawrence near Buda this order, later he studied philosophy and theology .

Georg Martinuzzi was prior of the Pauline monastery in Czestochowa , later he was the monastery in Sajolad near Erlau in northern Hungary. In 1527, the newly crowned King of Hungary J‡nos Z‡polya visited him in this monastery when he fled to Poland after his defeat of King Ferdinand of Bohemia , and asked him for help. Frater Gyšrgy gathered the supporters of King John, reached financial support by the great ones of the kingdom and set up an army, which in 1529 under the command of General Ravay defeated Ferdinand's troops. The king appointed him as royal advisor and treasurer in the same year.

In 1534 Georg Martinuzzi was appointed by King J‡nos Bishop of Nagyv‡rad . Since he was preconized by the Pope only five years later , he led the bishopric by auxiliary bishops. In 1536 he became bishop of Csan‡d . In 1538 he concluded with King Ferdinand the Treaty of Nagyv‡rad, by the J‡nos the title of king and the rule was granted to the greater part of Hungary, with Ferdinand was appointed to his successor.

On May 30, 1539 he took over the bishopric of Nagyv‡rad. King J‡nos died on 21 July 1540 and recanted on the deathbed the Treaty of Nagyv‡rad, at the same time he bequeathed the crown of Hungary to his only nine-day-old son Johann Sigismund Z‡polya ; In the will of the deceased king Georg Martinuzzi and Peter Petrovich were appointed guardians of the infant. The two proclaimed J‡nos Zsigmond as king. Sultan Suleiman I promised to recognize the young king. However, in 1541 the Sultan conquered Buda, the capital of Hungary. Bishop Martinuzzi, guardian of the young king and regent, succeeded Transylvania as an independent principality under the suzeraintyof the Ottoman Empire. He then changed his policy and tried in 1545 to establish a common front against the Turks with Ferdinand. The contract was confirmed at the Diet of Cluj in 1551, after Georg Martinuzzi had convinced the Queen Mother Isabella and the young king to resign; and led to the reunification of Hungary under the Habsburgs . For Martinuzzi, this brought the metropolitan seat of Esztergom and the cardinal title . The episcopal ordination he had already received in 1548 by Franciscus Josephich , the bishop of Senj .

On October 12, 1551 Georg Martinuzzi by Pope Julius III. elevated to the cardinal priest and obtained permission to wear his white habit instead of the purple of the cardinals who were world priests ; he died, however, before he could receive the cardinal's hat and a titular church . In 1551 the Turks captured Csan‡d and other places. Then Cardinal Martinuzzi and the imperial generals Giovanni Battista Castaldo , Marquess of Cassiano, and Sforza Pallavicini united their troops against the common enemy. A letter from the Cardinal, which emphasized the danger of the Turks, was published in theConsistory of November 16, 1551 read. To delay an attack by the Turks, Martinuzzi secretly proposed in December 1551 the payment of tribute to the Sultan . His secret contacts, however, aroused the distrust of Castaldo, who accused him of high treason against King Ferdinand [1] and asked for permission to eliminate the cardinal, if necessary. [2] The king agreed. Martinuzzi's secretary Marco Aurelio Ferrari was recruited for this purpose. On December 17, 1551 in Schloss Winzendorfthe secretary stabbed his master as he read a letter; however, the 69-year-old was still able to defend himself, so he was eventually killed by Pallavicini and his soldiers.

His grave is located in the Catholic Cathedral in Alba Iulia . In 1553, a trial was held in Vienna for the murder of Georg Martinuzzi, led by Nunzius Girolamo Martinengo . The doctor Giorgio Biandrata , who had been working in Transylvania, was called to testify to this process. [3]

Name: Nicolaus Olaho auch Erzbischof von Eger und Bischof von Agram
German Bio:
Mikl—s Ol‡h (auch Nicolaus Ol‡h, Nikola Olah, Nicolaus Olahus oder Nikolaus Olahus, * 10. Januar 1493 in Hermannstadt;   15. Januar 1568 in Nagyszombat) war ein ungarischer Erzbischof, Schriftsteller, Politiker und Theologe.

1543 wurde er von Ferdinand I. zum kšniglichen Kanzler und Bischof von Zagreb (Agram) ernannt. 1548 wurde er Erzbischof von Erlau, 1554 Erzbischof von Gran, der 1563 Maximilian zum Kšnig von Ungarn kršnte.[1] Ol‡h war der erste Gegenreformator in Ungarn.
English Bio:

English Bio:
Antun Vran_i_ (also Anton Wranczy , Latin Antonius Verantius , Hungarian Antal Verancsics ) (born May 29, 1504 in _ibenik , Dalmatia ,   June 15, 1573 in Eperjes ( slow Pre_ov ), S‡ros county , Upper Hungary , today Slovakia ) was a Roman Catholic archbishop , scientist and diplomat.

Vran_i_ was born in 1504 in _ibenik and came from a Croatian noble family. His cousin, the Croatian Ban Petar Berislavi_, took care of his education . Vran_i_ himself also took care of his nephew, later Bishop Faust Vran_i_ .

The study time spent Antun Vran_i_ in Padua , Vienna and Krakow . At the age of 26, Vran_i_ became secretary to the Transylvanian Prince Johann Z‡polya . His diplomatic career began after Z‡polya's death at the Habsburg court . For Ferdinand I and Maximilian II , Vran_i_ represented Habsburg at the Holy See , at the Sublime Porte , in France, Poland, in the Republic of Venice , as well as in England and Italy. In 1530 he became dean of Buda .

During his four-year stay in the Ottoman Empire , Vran_i_, together with the diplomat Ogier Ghislain de Busbecq , made the archaeological discovery of the Augustinian account " Res gestae divi Augusti ". On August 3, 1554 Vran_i_ was appointed bishop of PŽcs , on July 17, 1557 he was appointed bishop of Eger .

The ceremonial episcopal ordination took place on 21 September 1561. One of his greatest diplomatic achievements was the Peace Treaty of Adrianople , which was closed in 1568. For this merit he was appointed Primate of Hungary . On his many diplomatic trips Vran_i_ came into contact with Philipp Melanchthon , Erasmus of Rotterdam and Paolo Giovio . On September 25, 1570 he was appointed Archbishop of Esztergom . On June 5, 1573, Pope Gregory XIII appointed him . to the cardinal, The news from Rome did not reach Vran_i_, he died on 15 June 1573 in Pre_ov . His resting place is, at his own request, in the church of St. Nicholas in Tyrnau (slow Trnava ).
