English Bio:
PŽter P‡zm‡ny de Panasz [ pe_t_r pa_zma__ ] ( latin Peter Pazmanus , German and Peter Pazman , Slovak Peter Pazman ; * 4. October 1570 in Oradea (German Oradea , Hungarian Nagyv‡rad ), Transylvania , now Romania ;   19th March 1637 in Bratislava ( today Bratislava , Hungarian Pozsony ), Royal Hungary , today Slovakia ) was oneHungarian philosopher and Catholic theologian . Born in a Calvinist family in Transylvania, the convert first became a Jesuit , later Archbishop of Gran, and thus Primate of Hungary. P‡zm‡ny was the main figure of the Counter-Reformation in royal Hungary of his time (largely in the area of __today's Slovakia).

PŽter P‡zm‡ny, son of Calvinist parents, took on the Catholic faith in 1583 under the influence of his Catholic stepmother and the Jesuit Istv‡n Sz‡nt— 1583 and entered the Jesuit College to Cluj (German Klausenburg , Hungarian Kolozsv‡r ). In 1583 he entered the Order of the Jesuits. During the novitiate he was in Krakow and Vienna, where he studied at the Faculty of Philosophy, and 1593-1597 he studied theology in Rome. In Rome he also became a priest and doctor of theology. He also met Robert Bellarmin , the famous "fighter" of Giordano Bruno, P‡zm‡ny's views and recatholicization efforts came about during this time.

After completing his studies, he came to Graz on appeal to Archduke Karl . There he was first from 1597 to 1601 professor of philosophy (he taught logic , ethics and science ), later for theology (1603-06). One of his theology students in Graz was St. Marko of Kri_evci . In 1601 he was sent as a missionary preacher to his homeland, where he worked in _a_a , later in Ko_ice (German Kaschau , Hungarian Kassa ). 1607-1616 he was in the service of Ferenc Forg‡chs , the Archbishop of Esztergom (GermanGran ) [1] . On his initiative P‡zm‡ny was freed from the religious vows of the Jesuits and appointed on 25 April 1616 by the Pope for provost of the Turz . Since Forg‡ch died in the same year, P‡zm‡ny 1616 was appointed Archbishop of Gran and Prince Primate of Hungary. In addition, P‡zm‡ny received in the consistory of November 19, 1629 by Pope Urban VIII, the cardinal sword.

He died on 19 March 1637 in Bratislava and was buried there in the Martinsdom . [2]

The grave of Peter P‡zm‡ny was rediscovered on September 12, 1859 during restoration work on the Pressburg Cathedral by the Catholic priest Ferdinand Knauz . His remains were very well preserved, even his hair under the Jesuit hat and his beard hair were still there. He was dressed in a red cassock with simple leather shoes on his feet. [3] 

PŽter P‡zm‡ny was the most important representative of the Catholic restoration in royal Hungary. His opponent was the Protestant Istv‡n Magyari , who saw all mischief in Royal Hungary as a divine punishment for "Catholic idolatry" in the country.

In 1619 P‡zm‡ny founded in Trnava an educational institution for Catholics, in 1623 in Vienna the Pazmaneum , which was temporarily relocated to Trnava in 1761, and in Trnava the Adalbertinum as a seminary. In Bratislava he founded for the Jesuits a theological school with dormitory and in NovŽ Z‡mky (NeuhŠusl) and Kremnica (Kremnitz) monasteries for the Franciscans . In 1635 he founded in Tyrnau / Trnava / Nagyszombat an important university, which was relocated to Budapest in 1777 : today's Eštvšs Lor‡nd University and the Catholic PŽter P‡zm‡ny University .

P‡zm‡ny is considered the founder of Hungarian-language Baroque literature . He wrote several scriptures against the ideas of the Calvinists, whom he knew well, but also many sermons and catechetical writings. He also dealt with the translation of Latin religious and prayer books; Among other things, he transferred The following of Christ into Hungarian. In his works, written in pictorial, powerful language, he contrasts the glory of God with human imperfection and calls for humility. The most important of his writings is the Isteni igazs‡gra vezŽrl_ kalauz ("Guide to Divine Truth").

In 1992, the Catholic University was reactivated in Budapest , bearing PŽter P‡zm‡ny's name. His seminary, Pazmaneum, in Vienna's Alsergrund district , today serves as the study and guesthouse of the Archdiocese of Esztergom-Budapest . In the Leopoldstadt district of Vienna Pazmanitengasse is named after the seminarians of the Pazmaneum ("Pazmaniten").

English Bio:
Georg SzelepcsŽnyi (born April 24, 1595 in Szelepcseny , Kingdom of Hungary ,   April 24, 1685 in Lettowitz , Kingdom of Bohemia ) was a Catholic priest and Archbishop of Gran . He was also a journalist and an important representative of the Counter-Reformation .

Georg SzlepcsŽnyi was one of several children of Slovak serfs , his mother's name was Zsuzsanna and he was a born GyŸrky. It was baptized in the church of Barskisfalud ( slow Vieska nad _itavou) [1] a small village about 10 km from Goldmorawitz away, in the county bars . Both parents are a result of the Turkish wars were killed by Turks be [2] . As an orphan , he worked as a swineherd to survive. Then he came into the care of a distant relative, Ladislaus SzelepcsŽnyi who belonged to the nobility. Dr Junge also took over his name, coat of arms and the nobility predicate .

Archbishop PŽter P‡zm‡ny became acquainted with the talented young man during a canonical visit to Bars County in 1617. He recognized the talent of the young man and took him to Trnava , where he in the local Jesuit - School enabled training. In 1618 P‡zm‡ny sent him to further studies at the seminary Pontificium Collegium Germanium et Hungaricum to Rome , where he received his doctorate after his studies in theology and philosophy and received two doctorates. In 1627 he was ordained a priest.

After his return home, he made a steep career as a priest, but also as a diplomat . First he worked as a priest in Wartberg ( ung Szenc), 1536 he became a canon in Tyrnau. At the solemn funeral of his patron and friend Peter P‡zmany in 1637, he led the funeral and held the funeral address.

On April 18, 1648 he was appointed Bishop of Neutra and 1657 Archbishop of Kalocsa . After the death of Gyšrgy Lippay [3] he was appointed by Hungary on 15 January 1666 Archbishop of Esztergom and Primate. He was one of the closest confidants and advisers of Emperor Leopold I. In addition to his work as a church prince he was also involved in government business. From 1644 he was head of the Hungarian Court Chancellery, which at that time was still located in Bratislava , before moving to Vienna in 1690 . He was on diplomatic mission three times on behalf of the Emperor at the Sublime Porte inConstantinople (today's Istanbul ). Between 1670 and 1681 he was royal governor for the Kingdom of Hungary, which represented the highest dignity after the king.

SzelepcsŽnyi played a crucial role in uncovering the magnate plot in the Kingdom of Hungary. L‡szl— Fekete - Iv‡nyi [4] ( . Ung Iv‡nyi Fekete L‡szl—) betrayed the conspirators to the Archbishop, who passed on this information to the Imperial Court in Vienna.

Because of his merit but also thanks to his business skills, he acquired a huge fortune. Above all, he used this fortune for the common good. He founded schools and built numerous churches at his own expense. He financially supported many parishes and Catholic religious communities . In Tyrnau he founded a seminary and supported the university with significant financial resources.

SzelepcsŽnyi reached a high age for the time. At the end of his life he fell ill and retired to his estates in Lettowitz in Moravia . But also from here he wrote in writing his Graner archdiocese and maintained a lively correspondence with the emperor and the court of Vienna. He died on January 15, 1685 on his estate in Lettowitz. According to his own wish, which he also affirmed in his will, he found his final resting place in the pilgrimage church of Mariazell . He was buried in the local chapel of St. Ladislaus , which he had himself built.

The decade between 1671 and 1681 may be described as the funeral decade of Protestantism in Hungary. If, according to the wishes of the Jesuit party led by Gyšrgy SzelepcsŽnyi, it had been within the Roman Church, Protestantism in Hungary would have had to reckon with its total annihilation at that time. [5] SzelepcsŽnyi was as - a trained by Jesuits devout Catholic - a supporter of the Counter-Reformation, He was ready to forcibly replace Protestantism established in the Kingdom of Hungary with the help of the Catholic Habsburg Emperor. Leopold I constituted a "special court" chaired by SzelepcsŽnyi (in his capacity as Archbishop of Gran). Under the direction of SzelepcsŽnyi and his successor Leopold Kollonich (then in his capacity as President of the Hungarian Court Chamber), "show trials" were staged in Tyrnau (Slow Trnava, Nagyszombat) in 1673-74, in which the Protestants - Lutherans and Calvinians were presented and condemned in equal measure. The Catholic dignitaries hoped that Lutheran and Calvinist "Heretics "once and for all. [5]

Already on 25 September 1673, 33 Protestant preachers and numerous school teachers were cited before this court and charged with " lese majeste " and co-operation with the (as evangelical) Kuruzen . In addition, they were charged with collaborating with the Ottomans .

Some of them were sentenced to death. they were presented with a reversal to the binding signature , according to which they

either had to leave the country or
abandon her work as a Protestant preacher
and convert to Catholicism
Those ready to sign this reversal should be released. Most of those who were summoned signed. After this 'success' on 5 March 1674 another 730 Protestant preachers and teachers were summoned before the Special Court. The allegations were the same as last year. However, there were several preachers who were unwilling to sign the reversal. They were sentenced to death on April 4, 1674. An outcry of outrage roared through Protestant Europe!

The imperial court in Vienna could not tolerate this radical position of the Catholic clergy. Considerations to the Protestant princes in the German Reich , as well as his Protestant allies England and Holland , which he needed in the fight against the Turkish Sultan and France , forced Emperor Leopold I to take a more liberal position. [5]

As a result, the death sentences were turned into serious draconian jail sentences. In 1675 the victims were sold as galley prisoners into slavery in Naples .

Szelepcsenyi was a determined opponent of Islam . It is thanks to his diplomatic skills that an anti-Turkish Union was formed in Europe. He prophesied the siege of Vienna and therefore he went on a diplomatic mission on behalf of the Emperor to Poland , where he campaigned for the participation of the Polish and Lithuanian armed forces.

In response to the Ottoman war preparations and at the insistence of SzelepcsŽnyi, also by Pope Innocent XI. was supported, went the then king of Poland Johann III. Sobieski on 1 April 1683 a defensive alliance with Emperor Leopold I. a. As soon as the king reached the news of the Turkish campaign in the direction of Vienna, he issued the general nobility and set out to liberate the threatened imperial capital. He made a decisive contribution to the history of Europe. His Polish army struck with his allies in 1683 the Ottoman army in the Battle of Kahlenberg crucial.

Already at the beginning of May 1683 SzelepcsŽnyi came to Bratislava where he celebrated a Mass in front of the assembled troops and gave his blessing to the defenders of Vienna. In the summer of 1683 he supported the Christian armies with 493 thousand guilders from his private casket. In addition, he supported the Christian armies with food from his Bohemian and Moravian estates valued at approx. 170 thousand guilders.

On 12 September 1683, the Christian armies defeated the Turkish supremacy. As a reminder of this victory [6] , Pope Innocent XI. this day for the Feast of the Name of Mary, which is still held today in Catholic areas as a holiday.

Archbishop SzelepcsŽnyi earned the honorary title of "Savior of Vienna" for his spiritual assistance and financial and material support.

English Bio:
Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch , also: Kollonich , Collonicz , Kollonitz (born October 26, 1631 in Komorn ,   January 20, 1707 in Vienna ) was Roman Catholic Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Gran (Esztergom), Primate of the Kingdom of Hungary and Cardinal.

Leopold Karl von Kollonitsch came from the noble family Kollonitz von Kollograd , he was the son of Count Ernst von Kollonitsch, the commander of the fortress Komorn. He participated in 1651 as a candidate of the Order of Malta in the defense of Kandia ( Crete ) against the Turks and 1655 in the fighting in the Dardanelles in part. As a Knight of the Order of Malta, he was from 1658 Prior of the orders of the upcoming Mailberg and later of Eger in Bohemia .

1659 Emperor named him Leopold I to Chamberlain and hit him as Bishop of Neutra (now Slovakia before). Only then did Kollonitsch begin the study of theology and in 1668 he was ordained a priest . The episcopal consecration gave him on August 26, 1668 in Vienna Archbishop Antonio Pignatelli , the later Pope Innocent XII .; Co- consecrators were Ferenc Szegedy , Bishop of V‡c , and Lorenz Aidinger , Bishop of Wiener Neustadt, In 1669 he took up the episcopate, but renounced it because of criticism in Hungary and 1670 Bishop of Wiener Neustadt. From 1672 to 1681 he was president of the Hungarian Court Chamber.

Together with Juraj SelepcŽni Pohronec (Gyšrgy SzelepcsŽny), he was responsible for the sentencing and expulsion of 278 Protestants from present-day Slovakia at the 1673-1674 special court in Bratislava .

At the Second Viennese Turkish siege in 1683, he went to the besieged city, provided for the salaries of the troops and established emergency hospitals in monasteries. After the liberation of Vienna on 12 September by the Battle of Kahlenberg , he organized the care of about 500 orphans at Castle Mailberg , whose parents had died in the destruction of the suburbs. In the following years he founded behind the eastward advancing troops, the first military hospitals. As a result, he enjoyed great popularity among the Viennese population.

In 1685 he became bishop of the diocese of Raab and 1686 cardinal ; In 1688 he was also Archbishop of Kalocsa . In 1692, the Emperor appointed him Minister of State and Conference, in this role he was responsible for the reorganization of the conquered Hungarian territories.

In 1695 he finally became Archbishop of Gran and Primate of Hungary. He was able to win over 100,000 Orthodox Christians for a union with Rome .

Under Kollonitsch also began the settlement of the Capuchins in Bratislava . Thus, in 1708, the foundation stone was laid for the Capuchin monastery with the adjoining monastery church. [1]

In front of the Vienna City Hall stands his monument by Vincenz Pilz . In 1862, in Vienna Landstrasse (3rd district) Kolonitzgasse and 1873 Kolonitzplatz named after him.

English Bio:
DŽnes SzŽcsi (* 1400 [1] or 1410 in Eger , Hungary ,   February 1, 1465 in Esztergom ) was a Hungarian cardinal and first primate of Hungary.

DŽnes Mikl—s SzŽcsi, (Desiderius SzŽchy, Dionysius) also Zech, Zecho or Zechus was born as the sixth of eight children of the Hungarian aristocrat Mikl—s SzŽchy de Fels›lendva [2] (magister tavernicorum) and his wife Ilona Garai. He studied in 1426 at the University of Vienna and 1433 at the University of Bologna where he received his doctorate in 1434 ( canon law ). Another study at the University of Padua joined.

On August 21, 1438, he was appointed bishop of Nitra . On 5 June 1439 he was appointed Bishop of Eger . In the consistory of December 18, 1439 he was selected by Pope Eugene IV. Created cardinal. On February 15, 1440 Cardinal SzŽcsi was appointed Archbishop and Metropolitan of Esztergom . He took part in the conclave in 1447, in which Cardinal Tommaso Parentucelli was elected Pope Nicholas V , who gave him the title of "Primate of Hungary" and is still associated with the archiepiscopal chair Esztergom.

In the provincial synod in 1450 in Esztergom he campaigned for the restoration of monastic discipline and encouraged the observance of celibacy . He rebuilt the basilica in Esztergom in 1453.

He died on February 1, 1465 and was buried in the Cathedral of Esztergom.

Name: Ascagnio Sforza bis
German Bio:
Ascanio Maria Sforza (* 3. MŠrz 1455 in Mailand;   28. Mai 1505 in Rom) aus der Familie Sforza war Kardinal und der sechste Sohn von Francesco I. Sforza, Herzog von Mailand und Herzogin Bianca Maria Visconti. Seine BrŸder waren die MailŠnder Herzšge Galeazzo Maria Sforza und Ludovico Sforza, genannt ãil MoroÒ.

Ascanio Maria Sforza war Bischof von Eger und wurde im Jahr 1484 von Papst Sixtus IV. zum Kardinal mit der Titeldiakonie Santi Vito, Modesto e Crescenzia erhoben. Als Kardinal sah er es als seine Aufgabe an, die Macht der Sforza auszubauen und zu erhalten. Vor 1499 gehšrte das Herzogtum von Mailand, das von seinem Bruder Ludovico Sforza usurpiert worden war, zu den einflussreichsten in Italien. Mailand allerdings war ein Lehen des Heiligen Ršmischen Reiches und unterstand damit nominell dem Kaiser Ð zunŠchst Friedrich III., ab 1493 dessen Sohn Maximilian I. Ludovicos Situation war vor allem deswegen prekŠr, weil er den rechtmŠ§igen Erben des MailŠnder Throns, Galeazzo Maria Sforza (der Ÿberdies mit Isabella von Aragon (1470Ð1524), einer Enkelin des neapolitanischen Kšnigs Ferrante verheiratet war) von der Herrschaft zu verdrŠngen suchte. Solange Kaiser Friedrich lebte, hatte er Ÿberdies keine Mšglichkeit, mit dem Herzogshut rechtmŠ§ig belehnt zu werden Ð der Habsburger lehnte den Abkšmmling des Condottiere Muzio Attendolo schlichtweg als Parvenue ab. Daher befanden sich die Sforza Ð wie Ÿbrigens alle italienischen HerrscherhŠuser Ð unter stŠndigem existentiellen Druck und waren gezwungen, laufend wechselnde BŸndnisse einzugehen.

Die Sforza hatten zunŠchst die Wahl Rodrigo de Borgias zum Papst unterstŸtzt, ursprŸnglich in der Hoffnung, dieser werde sich Šhnlich am GŠngelband fŸhren lassen, wie es Giuliano della Rovere mit seinem VorgŠnger Innozenz VIII. vorgefŸhrt hatte. Ascanio wollte eigentlich selbst nach dem Tode Innozenz im Juli 1492 Papst werden, aber mit seinen 37 Jahren war er nicht nur zu jung, sondern auch durch seine Familie zu stark politisch exponiert. Schon im Konklave zog Ascanio alle Register: ausgestattet mit einer Vollmacht seines Bruders zum Stimmenkauf und den zahlreichen PfrŸnden des Vizekanzlers der Kurie, Rodrigo Borgia, als Handelsware wurde der Papstthron regelrecht verkauft. Wie der SekretŠr des Kardinals Barbo, Giovanni Lorenzi, schon vor dem Konklave festgehalten hatte, hatten die beiden den Weltkreis unter sich aufgeteilt: der Vizekanzler wird Papst, Ascanio aber †ber-Papst.

Doch Alexander VI. (so der Papstname Rodrigo de Borgias), der Ð wie bereits sein Onkel Kalixt III. Ð in Neapel eine mšgliche Borgia-Herrschaft sah, spielte sein eigenes Spiel. Dadurch sah sich Ludovico Sforza gezwungen, Frankreich um UnterstŸtzung zu bitten; Karl VIII. betrachtete sich ohnehin als rechtmŠ§iger Erbe des Kšnigreiches Neapel und hatte Ð nach dem eben gegen Maximilian I. verlorenen Erbfolgekrieg um Burgund nicht nur beide HŠnde frei, sondern strebte Ÿberdies danach, sich endlich mit Ruhm zu bedecken. Der franzšsische Kšnig sollte Ÿberdies nicht nur Ferrante ausschalten, sondern auch ein Konzil erzwingen, um den in den Augen der Sforza unbotmŠ§igen Papst abzusetzen Ð natŸrlich mit dem Hintergedanken, dass Ascanio endlich selbst nach der Tiara greifen konnte. (Alexander hatte in der Zwischenzeit mit den Neapolitanern verhandelt Ð Neapel war immerhin ein pŠpstliches Lehen Ð und hatte eine Hochzeitsverbindung mit den Aragonesen ins Auge gefasst.)

Der folgende Italienfeldzug Karls VIII. war zwar siegreich, aber lediglich, was Neapel anbelangte Ð denn der Kšnig verzichtete auf ein Konzil, und Alexander konnte seinen Kopf in Verhandlungen aus der Schlinge ziehen.

Die franzšsischen Truppen in Italien wurden immer mehr zur Gefahr fŸr das europŠische Gleichgewicht Ð und vor allem von den italienischen Stadtstaaten und Territorialherren als Bedrohung empfunden. Die Sforza sahen sich unter dem Druck der italienischen VerhŠltnisse gezwungen, wieder einmal ihre BŸndnispartner zu wechseln. Gemeinsam mit Spanien, dem Kaiser, Venedig und dem Papst bildeten sie eine Liga gegen Frankreich und vertrieben am 6. Juli 1495 in der Schlacht bei Fornovo die franzšsischen Truppen aus Italien.

Ascanio war jetzt an der Kurie zwischen die Fronten geraten, und drohte zwischen Giuliano della Rovere (der zunŠchst nach dem Konklave ins franzšsische Exil gegangen war und dort den Kšnig zu einem Konzil gegen Alexander gewinnen wollte, sich jetzt aber auf Wunsch des Kšnigs mit dem Papst Ð vorŸbergehend Ð ausgesšhnt hatte) und den Borgia aufgerieben zu werden. Als Karl VIII. 1497 starb Ð er war in seinem Schloss in Amboise gegen einen Balken gelaufen und hatte infolge der Kopfverletzung offensichtlich einen Schlaganfall erlitten Ð wurde Ludwig XII. aus dem Hause OrlŽans franzšsischer Kšnig. War Karl noch ein VerbŸndeter Ludovicos gewesen, so Šnderte sich die Lage grundlegend: denn die OrlŽans waren mit den Visconti verwandt Ð und ebendiese waren durch die Sforza aus Mailand vertrieben worden. Somit streckte der neue franzšsische Herrscher seine HŠnde nach Mailand aus.

Im Jahre 1500 hatten franzšsische Truppen schlie§lich die Residenzstadt Mailand der Sforza-Familie besetzt. Kardinal Ascanio Sforza unterstŸtzte seinen Bruder Ð der mit seiner Familie zwischenzeitlich nach …sterreich ins Exil gegangen war (Bianca Maria Sforza war mit dem ršmisch-deutschen Kšnig und spŠteren Kaiser Maximilian I. verheiratet) Ð bei den KŠmpfen um die RŸckeroberung der Stadt. Als Ludovico Sforza jedoch seine Schweizer Sšldner nicht mehr bezahlen konnte, wurde er von diesen im April 1500 an die Franzosen ausgeliefert. Ludovico sollte 1508 in franzšsischer Gefangenschaft sterben. Kardinal Ascanio Sforza wurde Ð ebenfalls 1500 Ð von Venedig an die Franzosen ausgeliefert. Anders als sein Bruder wurde er jedoch nicht in einen Kerker geworfen, sondern erhielt lediglich Hausarrest und wurde 1502 unter der Auflage freigelassen, Frankreich nicht zu verlassen. Kardinal Ascanio Sforza wurde sogar an den franzšsischen Kšnigshof unter Ludwig XII. gerufen und zŠhlte bald zu den stŠndigen Jagdbegleitern des franzšsischen Kšnigs. Aufsehen erregte er, als er der franzšsischen Kšnigin eine ungewšhnlich gro§e Perle Ÿberreichen lie§, die frŸher sein Bruder Ludovico trug.

Im August 1503 gestattete Ludwig XII. dem Kardinal die RŸckkehr nach Rom. Papst Alexander VI. war gestorben, und Kardinal Ascanio Sforza sicherte dem franzšsischen Kšnig zu, seine Stimme dem franzšsischen Kardinal Georges d'Amboise zu geben. Die Politik, die der Kardinal betrieb, war jedoch immer noch auf die Rehabilitation seiner Familie, die Wiedereinsetzung seines in franzšsischer Haft eingekerkerten Bruders Ludovico als Duca in Mailand und die Vertreibung der Franzosen aus der Lombardei gerichtet. Entsprechend seiner Zusage gegenŸber dem franzšsischen Kšnig wŠhlte Kardinal Sforza tatsŠchlich den vom franzšsischen Hof favorisierten Kardinal, sorgte jedoch dafŸr, dass im Konklave schlie§lich Francesco Nanni Todeschini-Piccolomini als Pius III. zum Papst gewŠhlt wurde. Pius III., der vor allem Giuliano della Rovere verhindern sollte, erwies sich jedoch nur als ein †bergangskandidat Ð er starb bereits vier Wochen nach seiner Wahl. Damit war endgŸltig der Weg fŸr Giuliano della Rovere frei, der als Julius II. auf den Stuhl Petri gelangte.

Wenn Papst Julius II. auch einer den Sforzas nicht wohlgesinnten italienischen Herrscherfamilie angehšrte, einte sie jedoch das Ziel, Frankreichs Einfluss in Italien zu beenden. Die Politik Julius eskalierte 1510 schlie§lich in einem offenen Kampf gegen die in Norditalien befindlichen franzšsischen Truppen. Kardinal Ascanio Sforza erlebte dies allerdings nicht mehr. Er starb im 50. Lebensjahr am 28. Mai 1505.

Ascanio Maria Sforzas Grabmal, das von Julius II. trotz der Gegnerschaft an Andrea Sansovino (um 1467Ð1529) in Auftrag gegeben wurde, steht in der Kirche Santa Maria del Popolo in Rom in der ãCappella MaggioreÒ. Es ist das erste dreiachsige Triumphbogengrab, das in Rom errichtet wurde, und trŠgt die Inschrift:

Ascanio Maria Sforza...der sich im GlŸck ma§voll, im UnglŸck von hšchster Standhaftigkeit erwies, von Papst Julius II., der sich der Ÿberaus respektablen Tugenden des Verewigten erinnerte, die Streitigkeiten mit ihm aber verga§. (zit. n. Zitzlsperger, S. 27f)
Diese ungewšhnlich erscheinende Geste Julius II. hat einen realpolitischen Hintergrund. FŸr Julius II. war die Familie der Sforza als legitime Herzšge von Mailand wichtige BŸndnispartner im Kampf gegen die franzšsischen Truppen. Mit dem Grabmal dokumentierte der Papst aus der Rovere-Familie, dass er ihre Herrschaft Ÿber Mailand anerkannte.

Nach Ascanio Sforzas Einzug in Rom berief er vermutlich den Komponisten Josquin Desprez (um 1450/55Ð1521) in die pŠpstliche SŠngerkapelle. Die Beziehung zwischen Ascanio Sforza und Desprez war so eng, dass einige Kompositionen Josquins unter der Autorenangabe ãJosquin DascanioÒ Ÿberliefert sind.
English Bio:
Ascanio Maria Sforza (born March 3, 1455 in Milan ,   May 28, 1505 in Rome ) from the family Sforza was Cardinal and the sixth son of Francesco I Sforza , Duke of Milan and Duchess Bianca Maria Visconti . His brothers were the Milanese dukes Galeazzo Maria Sforza and Ludovico Sforza , called "il Moro".

Ascanio Maria Sforza was Bishop of Eger and was raised in 1484 by Cardinal Sixtus IV to cardinal with the head dia. Santi Vito, Modesto e Crescenzia . As a cardinal, he saw it as his task to develop and maintain the power of the Sforza. Before 1499, the Duchy of Milan , which had been usurped by his brother Ludovico Sforza , was one of the most influential in Italy. Milan, however, was a fief of the Holy Roman Empire and thus subordinate nominally to the emperor - initially Frederick III. , from 1493 his son Maximilian I.Ludovico's situation was precarious mainly because he sought to oust the rightful heir of the Milanese throne, Galeazzo Maria Sforza (who was also married to Isabella of Aragon (1470-1524), a granddaughter of the Neapolitan king Ferrante ) from the rule. Moreover, as long as Emperor Frederick lived, he had no opportunity to be lawfully entrusted with the Duke's hat - the Habsburgs simply rejected the descendant of the Condottiere Muzio Attendolo as a Parvenue. As a result, the Sforza, like all Italian rulers, were under constant existential pressure and forced to make ever-changing alliances.

The Sforza had initially supported Rodrigo de Borgia's election to the pope, originally in the hope that this would be similar lead on the strap, as Giuliano della Rovere with his predecessor Innocent VIII.had demonstrated. Ascanio actually wanted to become pope even after Innocent's death in July 1492, but at the age of 37 he was not only too young, but also too politically exposed by his family. Even in the conclave Ascanio pulled out all the stops: equipped with a power of attorney from his brother to vote and the numerous benefices of the vice-chancellor of the Curia, Rodrigo Borgia, as a commodity, the Pope's throne was downright sold. As the secretary of Cardinal Barbo, Giovanni Lorenzi, had held before the conclave, the two had divided the world circle among themselves: the vice-chancellor will be Pope, Ascanio but over-pope .

But Alexander VI. (as the pope's name Rodrigo de Borgias), who - like his uncle Kalixt III. - saw in Naples a possible Borgia rule, played his own game. As a result, Ludovico Sforza was forced to ask France for support; In any case, Charles VIII regarded himself as the rightful heir of the Kingdom of Naples and, after the succession war that had just been lost to Maximilian I, had to do with Burgundynot only freeing both hands, but also striving to finally cover himself with glory. Moreover, the French king was not only to eliminate Ferrante, but also force a council to depose the pope who was unbearable in the eyes of the Sforza - with the ulterior motive, of course, that Ascanio himself finally reached for the tiara. (Alexander had meanwhile negotiated with the Neapolitans - Naples was after all a papal fief - and had made a wedding connection with the Aragonese in the eye.)

The following Italian campaign of Charles VIII was indeed victorious, but only in terms of Naples - because the king renounced a council, and Alexander could pull his head in negotiations from the noose.

The French troops in Italy became more and more a threat to the European balance - and were perceived as a threat, especially by the Italian city-states and territorial rulers. Under the pressure of Italian conditions, the Sforza were forced to change their allies again. Together with Spain, the Emperor, Venice and the Pope, they formed a league against France and expelled on July 6, 1495 in the Battle of Fornovo, the French troops from Italy.

Ascanio had now come between the fronts at the Curia, and threatened between Giuliano della Rovere (who had first gone into exile in France after the conclave and there wanted to win the king to a council against Alexander, but now at the request of the king with the Pope - temporarily - reconciled) and the Borgia to be wiped out. When Charles VIII died in 1497 - he had run in his castle in Amboise against a beam and had suffered a stroke as a result of head injury - Louis XII. from the House of Orleans French King. If Charles had been an ally of Ludovico, the situation changed fundamentally: for the OrlŽans were with the Viscontirelated - and these were expelled by the Sforza from Milan. Thus, the new French ruler extended his hands to Milan.

In 1500, French troops finally occupied the royal capital Milan of the Sforza family. Cardinal Ascanio Sforza supported his brother - who had gone into exile with his family in the meantime to Austria ( Bianca Maria Sforza was with the Roman-German king and later Emperor Maximilian I.married) - in the fighting for the reconquest of the city. However, when Ludovico Sforza could no longer pay his Swiss mercenaries, he was extradited by them in April 1500 to the French. Ludovico was to die in 1508 in French captivity. Cardinal Ascanio Sforza was also delivered from Venice to the French, also in 1500. Unlike his brother, however, he was not thrown into a dungeon, but received only house arrest and was released in 1502 under the condition not to leave France. Cardinal Ascanio Sforza was even sent to the French royal court under Louis XII. was called and soon counted among the constant hunting companions of the French king. He caused a sensation when he gave the French queen an unusually large pearl, which used to carry his brother Ludovico.

In August 1503, Louis XII allowed. Cardinal returning to Rome. Pope Alexander VI. died and Cardinal Ascanio Sforza assured the French king to give his vote to the French Cardinal Georges d'Amboise . The cardinal's policy, however, was still directed at the rehabilitation of his family, the reinstatement of his imprisoned brother Ludovico as Duca in Milan and the expulsion of the French from Lombardy . According to his commitment to the French king cardinal Sforza actually chose the cardinal favored by the French court, but ensured that in the conclave finally Francesco Nanni Todeschini - Piccolomini as Pius III.was elected pope. However, Pius III, who was mainly to prevent Giuliano della Rovere, proved to be only a transitional candidate - he died four weeks after his election. This finally cleared the way for Giuliano della Rovere , who arrived in the chair of Peter as Julius II .

However, if Pope Julius II also belonged to an Italian ruling family who did not approve of Sforzas, they were united by the goal of ending France's influence in Italy. The policy Julius finally escalated in 1510 in an open fight against the French troops in northern Italy. Cardinal Ascanio Sforza, however, did not experience this anymore. He died in his 50th year on May 28, 1505.
Ascanio Maria Sforza's tomb, commissioned by Julius II despite the opposition to Andrea Sansovino (c. 1467-1529), stands in the church of Santa Maria del Popolo in Rome in the "Cappella Maggiore". It is the first tri-axial triumphal arch tomb erected in Rome and bears the inscription:

Ascanio Maria Sforza ... who in moderation, in calamity, proved himself most steadfast, by Pope Julius II, who remembered the exceedingly respectable virtues of the immortal, but forgot his quarrels with him. (cited by Zitzlsperger, p. 27f)
This unusually appearing gesture Julius II has a realpolitical background. For Julius II, the Sforza family, legitimate dukes of Milan, were important allies in the fight against French troops. With the tomb documented the Pope from the Rovere family that he recognized her rule over Milan.

After Ascanio Sforza's entry into Rome, he probably called the composer Josquin Desprez (about 1450 / 55-1521) in the papal singer band. The relationship between Ascanio Sforza and Desprez was so close that some of Josquin's compositions are narrated under the author's name "Josquin Dascanio".

English Bio:
Johann Beckenschlager , also Johann Beckensloer , Johann Pfluger or Johann Peckensloer , (* 1435 in Wroclaw ,   December 15, 1489 in Salzburg ) was Archbishop of Gran and as John III. Archbishop of Salzburg .

Johann Beckenschlager is said to be the son of a blacksmith . Matthias Corvinus made him the provost of five churches and on May 17, 1465 Bishop of Oradea . In 1468 he became Bishop of Eger and 1473 Archbishop of Gran (Hungarian Esztergom ) and Primate of Hungary . Because he lost the favor of the Hungarian king more and more, he left Hungary on February 13, 1476 and joined the Emperor Frederick III. whose advisor and financier he became. Beckenschlager was from March 22, 1477 coadjutorfor the seriously ill Bishop of Vienna, Leo von Spaur , and from 1480 also administrator of the Diocese of Vienna , but renounced this office, since he was on 14 January 1482 as Johann III. first administrator of the (nominally ruling) archbishop of Salzburg and 1487 archbishop.

Johann was more secular warlord than spiritual leader and archbishop. He liked to show himself in full armor and personally went into the field. His extraordinary physical strength was especially praised. This archbishop, like his predecessor and successor, loved the bodily pleasures without regard to ecclesiastical office and frequently used the secret passage of his predecessor as his concubine. Beckenschlager was not popular among the population. She gave him substantial blame for many acts of war and the misery involved.

Most of his reign was Johann Beckenschlager as a diplomat of Emperor Frederick III. working abroad. Already in 1483 the emperor had appointed the archbishop governor of Styria . The year 1481 and the winter half-years 1483/84 he was in the Netherlands . On June 21, 1486, the emperor appointed him governor of Austria (Upper and Lower Austria), Styria, Carinthia , Carniola , Istria and the Karst. Since May 1486 he was responsible for the recruitment of imperial mercenaries in the war against the Hungarian king Matthias Corvinus .

The Regency in Salzburg took over during his long absences substantially the Salzburg Hofkanzler Bishop Georg Altdorfer von Chiemsee. The last year of his life was spent by the already ill archbishop at Hohensalzburg Fortress , whom he had purposefully expanded. Above all, he built here the high floor as a princely residence and built SchŸttkasten (temporarily used as a living space) and workhouse.

English Bio:
Orb‡n of Nagylœcse or Urban D—czi (* 15th century in Nagy-Luche , Hungary ,   1493 in Erlau ) was royal treasurer, guardian and governor of Hungary. He was also bishop of Raab and Erlau. From 1488 to 1490 he was administrator of the diocese of Vienna . [1]

Urban D—czi was born in Nagy-Luche, near the island of SchŸtt in Hungary.

Matthias Corvinus appointed the diplomat to the royal treasurer, KronhŸter and 1481 governor. Matthias nominated him in 1483 as Bishop of Raab and 1486 of Erlau . D—czi helped Matthias in military operations such as the siege of Hainburg with 5000 men and large sums of money and in the capture of Vienna and Wiener Neustadt . In 1470 there were differences of opinion between Emperor Frederick III. and Matthias Corvinus, who in 1477 ended in a formal declaration of war. The Turkish War , however, employed him until the death of Sultan Mehmed II.in 1481. Matthias concluded a truce with the Ottomans in 1483 and began the fight for Vienna. In the autumn of 1482 Vienna was besieged by the Hungarians. In 1484 the Hungarians took Bruck an der Leitha and besieged Korneuburg . In 1483, the Viennese paid tribute to the Hungarians in order to be able to bring in the grapes harvest undisturbed. The citizens of Vienna concluded without the consent of Emperor Friedrich III. together with the University of Vienna on May 21, 1485 a truce with Matthias. According to a report by the humanist Wolfgang Lazius , Matthias had the intention to lift the Vienna diocese. In 1485 or 1486 he is said to have entered the cathedral chapter with this request .

After the death of the administrator Bernhard von Rohr , he changed his mind and ordered the Bishop of Erlau Urban D—czi to the new administrator of Vienna. Pope Innocent VIII confirmed him by a bull published on April 20, 1488 in Vienna . From the work of D—czi in his new diocese of Vienna, only a decree from 1489 is known, which declared the feast of the Immaculate Conception of Mary as a holiday. This day was previously only in the choir of St. Stephen's Cathedral and the University of Viennabeen celebrated. After the death of his protector King Matthias on April 6, 1490 - Tuesday of the Holy Week - at age 46, D—czi resigned after only two years and returned to Hungary, where he died in 1493 in his diocese of Erlau.

English Bio:
Tam‡s Bak—cz ( Croatian Toma Baka_ [1] * 1442 in Erd_dy ,   June 15, 1521 in Esztergom ) was a Hungarian cardinal and politician.

Bak—cz came from a family of the Hungarian nobility and was born on the estate Erd_d in Szatm‡r county . He was adopted by his uncle B‡lint B‡kocz, who enabled him to become a priest . Tam‡s Bak—cz studied law in Wroclaw and at the University of Padua . Later he became one of the secretaries of Matthias Corvinus , who in 1486 appointed him Bishop of Gy_r . In 1490 he became a member of the Privy Council and Chancellor. He then became bishop of Zagreb .

Under Vladislav II he received as Bishop of Eger one of the richest dioceses in Hungary. In 1497 he became archbishop of Esztergom and thus primate of Hungary. From 1490 until his death in 1521 he was Chancellor of the Kingdom of Hungary and responsible for the foreign policy of the country. He served as a writer Lazarus Secretarius .

1500 raised him Alexander VI. the Cardinal and appointed him cardinal priest of San Martino ai Monti . Since 1507 Cardinal Bak—cz was also titular patriarch of Constantinople Opel . After the death of Julius II , he participated in the conclave October 1503 for the election of the new pope. He used his great political influence, including his wealth, to influence the election in his favor, but was unable to prevail against the eventually elected Pope Julius II.

He returned to Hungary as a papal legate , with a cop from Leo X. for a crusade against the Turks. He commissioned Szekler Gyšrgy D—zsa to prepare for the crusade . This decision resulted in a devastating peasant uprising .

After the death of Vladislav II (1516) he lost political influence. The last years of his life he was so ill that he could not leave his house. When he died on 15 June 1521, he left his relatives (who called himself Count Erd_dy after his birthplace) a million worth.

German Bio:
Ippolito I. dÕEste (* 20. MŠrz 1479 in Ferrara;   3. September 1520 ebenda) war ein Sohn des Ercole I. dÕEste, Herzog von Ferrara, Modena und Reggio, und Bruder von Isabella dÕEste (1474Ð1539), Beatrice dÕEste (1475Ð1497) und Alfonso I. dÕEste (1476Ð1534).

Bereits als SiebenjŠhriger wurde er von Kšnig Matthias Corvinus zum Erzbischof von Gran ernannt, als 14-JŠhriger (1493) zum Kardinal, und als 17-JŠhriger zum Erzbischof von Mailand. Er tauschte mit Tam‡s Bak—cz seinen Erzbischofsstuhl von Gran und wurde dafŸr Bischof von Erlau (1497Ð1520). Er war auch Erzbischof von Capua (ab 1502) sowie Bischof von Ferrara (ab 1503).

Ippolito I. dÕEste ist Ludovico Ariostos Werk Orlando Furioso gewidmet.
English Bio:
Ippolito I. d'Este (born March 20, 1479 in Ferrara ,   September 3, 1520 ibid) was a son of Ercole I d'Este , Duke of Ferrara, Modena and Reggio, and brother of Isabella d'Este (1474 -1539), Beatrice d'Este (1475-1497) and Alfonso I d'Este (1476-1534).

Already as a seven -year-old he was appointed Archbishop of Gran by King Matthias Corvinus , as a 14-year-old (1493) Cardinal , and as Archbishop of Milan at the age of 17 . He exchanged his archbishop's chair of Gran with Tam‡s Bak—cz and became Bishop of Erlau (1497-1520). He was also Archbishop of Capua (from 1502) and Bishop of Ferrara (from 1503).

Ippolito I d'Este is dedicated to Ludovico Ariosto 's Orlando Furioso .

Ferenc Frangepan

Er war Sprecher des KÃ¶nigs Johann ZÃ¡polya (Johannes) von Ungarn. Auch die Habsburger hatten AnsprÃ¼che auf Ungarn. Infolge des am 10. Juni 1538 in Wratislauia (Breslau) abgeschlossenen Vertrags zwischen KÃ¶nig Johannes ZÃ¡polya von Ungarn und KÃ¶nig Ferdinand von Habsburg, der auf einen Interessenausgleich bezÃ¼glich der gegenseitigen Territorial- und ErbansprÃ¼che hinausging, schreibt Kaiser Karl V. aus Toledo KÃ¶nig Johann, dass er die Botschaft des Sprechers von Johannes, Franciscus de Fragepanibus, Erzbischof von Kalotscha und Bischof von Agria, entgegengenommen und die Friedensbestrebungen zwischen seinem Bruder Ferdinand und KÃ¶nig Johannes â€žmit grÃ¶ÃŸter Genugtuungâ€œ vernommen habe.[2][3]
English Bio:
Franz Johann Frankopan ( Franciscus de question bus, Ivan Franjo Frankapan, Ferenc J‡nos Frankopan , * 1490 ,   January 22 or January 28, 1543 in Bratislava ) was a member of the family of Frankopan . He was Archbishop of Kalocsa and from 1538 to 1543 Bishop of Agria . He was spokesman for King John Z‡polya (John) of Hungary.

Franz Johann Frankopan was the son of Bernardin Frankopan and Luisa Marzano. [1]

After the defeat of the Hungarians at Moh‡cs (1526) against the Turks, they spread more and more over the territory of the Kingdom of Hungary. The Habsburgs also had claims to Hungary. English Bio:
Antun Vran_i_ (also Anton Wranczy , Latin Antonius Verantius , Hungarian Antal Verancsics ) (born May 29, 1504 in _ibenik , Dalmatia ,   June 15, 1573 in Eperjes ( slow Pre_ov ), S‡ros county , Upper Hungary , today Slovakia ) was a Roman Catholic archbishop , scientist and diplomat.

Vran_i_ was born in 1504 in _ibenik and came from a Croatian noble family. His cousin, the Croatian Ban Petar Berislavi_, took care of his education . Vran_i_ himself also took care of his nephew, later Bishop Faust Vran_i_ .

The study time spent Antun Vran_i_ in Padua , Vienna and Krakow . At the age of 26, Vran_i_ became secretary to the Transylvanian Prince Johann Z‡polya . His diplomatic career began after Z‡polya's death at the Habsburg court . For Ferdinand I and Maximilian II , Vran_i_ represented Habsburg at the Holy See , at the Sublime Porte , in France, Poland, in the Republic of Venice , as well as in England and Italy. In 1530 he became dean of Buda .

During his four-year stay in the Ottoman Empire , Vran_i_, together with the diplomat Ogier Ghislain de Busbecq , made the archaeological discovery of the Augustinian account " Res gestae divi Augusti ". On August 3, 1554 Vran_i_ was appointed bishop of PŽcs , on July 17, 1557 he was appointed bishop of Eger .

The ceremonial episcopal ordination took place on 21 September 1561. One of his greatest diplomatic achievements was the Peace Treaty of Adrianople , which was closed in 1568. For this merit he was appointed Primate of Hungary . On his many diplomatic trips Vran_i_ came into contact with Philipp Melanchthon , Erasmus of Rotterdam and Paolo Giovio . On September 25, 1570 he was appointed Archbishop of Esztergom . On June 5, 1573, Pope Gregory XIII appointed him . to the cardinal, The news from Rome did not reach Vran_i_, he died on 15 June 1573 in Pre_ov . His resting place is, at his own request, in the church of St. Nicholas in Tyrnau (slow Trnava ).

Gissur êsleifsson (* 1042 ,   1118 ) was, after the takeover of Christianity by the Icelanders in 1000, the second bishop of Iceland . From 1106 he was bishop in the diocese of Sk‡lholt in the south of the island. This year, the northern Icelandic diocese H—lar was founded.

Gissur is described as tall, strong and good natured. [1]

The father of Gissur was êsleifur Gissurarson , Bishop of Iceland.

Like this, Gissur studied in Saxony in the pen Herford and was ordained there at a young age as a priest. [2]

After he had returned from there, he married Steinunn _orgr’msd—ttir (about 1042 - after 1118), who had been married in the first marriage with _—rir Skegg - Broddason of Hof in Vopnafjšr_ur . There, the couple also lived first.

The couple traveled a lot, among other things made pilgrimages to Rome. When his father, Bishop Isleifur Gissurason, died in 1080, Gissur overseas, but then traveled to Iceland in the summer and was elected bishop.

The bishop consecration, however, succeeded only after a few random walks.

Gissur first drove to Saxony, because actually the competent archbishop of Bremen should have consecrated him. He had just been removed from office. Gissur then continued his journey towards Rome. Pope Gregory VII sent him to Magdeburg after an encounter, where he was consecrated by Archbishop Hartwig in 1082 as Bishop of Iceland. [3]

When he returned to Iceland, he settled like his father in Sk‡lholt and after the death of his mother, he gave the land of the church. [4]

Gissur was the strictest proponent of the inclusion of the church tithes in Iceland, and this was sanctioned by parliament in 1097. He also had the first census in Iceland for the purpose. [5]

Gissur died in Sk‡lholt in 1118, after having served as bishop for 36 years. [6]

English Bio:
_orl‡kur _—rhallsson (German Thorlak Thorhallson ) (* 1133 in Flj—tshl’_ ,   December 23, 1193 ) was a bishop at the Icelandic bishopric in Sk‡lholt .

_orl‡kur _—rhallsson was the son of _—rhall _orl‡ksson in Hli_arendi , Flj—tshl’_ , and his wife Halla Steinad—ttir.

He received his education from a priest in Oddi in Rang‡rvellir. In 1152 he was ordained a priest. He probably married. [1] He probably studied from 1153 to 1159 at the School of St. Victor in Paris and at the Augustinian cathedral chapter in Lincoln . [2]

After his return he should have decided for the monastic life and have solved his marriage. [3] He lived for six years as a teacher in Kirkjub¾r (South Iceland).

Around 1168 he founded with Bishop Kl¾ngur _orsteinsson (Klongr Thorsteinsson) of Sk‡lholt the first Augustinian monastery in Iceland in _ykkvab¾jarklaustur . He led it first as Prior , from about 1171 as abbot .

In 1176 he was chosen by Kl¾ngur to Bishop of Sk‡lholt. On July 1, 1178, he was consecrated by Archbishop ¯ystein Erlendsson in Nidaros (Trondheim) and held his office until his death.

In Thorlak's term in 1186 the Benedictine monastery in Kirkjub¾r ( Kirkjub¾jarklaustur ) was founded. He issued rules on Lent and reformed the church. Above all, he turned against the immorality and the habit of influential gentlemen to keep second women ( Kebsen ).

In the summer of 1179 he traveled through his diocese and persuaded many peasants in the Ostfjorden to transfer their farms to the church and then receive them from the church as a fief . The advantage for the farmers was that they to the Church With continuing with the delivery of their farms owned this before accessing a Goden could protect or another powerful.

Upon his return, he came into fierce dispute with the Goden J—n Loftsson in Oddi , one of the most powerful men in the country, over the sovereignty over the church property, which belonged to the own church manor according to the traditional Eigenkirchenwesen .

This was a reflection of the investiture dispute that was simultaneously smoldering between the emperor and the pope . [4]

His successor P‡ll J—nsson had his bones raised on July 20, 1198 on the altar ( Translatio ). A papal confirmation was initially not obtained. [5]

His death, the 23rd of December, was declared his holiday on the Althing the following year. Bishop P‡ll had a shrine made for the corpse placed on the high altar of Sk‡lholt. The shrine was made of gold, silver and precious stones.

His grave became one of Iceland's most important places of pilgrimage; his persona programmatically stood for the freedom of the church of laical influence; In addition, the Thorlak Diet received a national rating when Iceland in 1262 had to submit to the Norwegian kingship. " [6] .

In 1237, the 20th of July was also declared the day of the Translatio. He was ordained 56 churches in Iceland.

On January 14, 1984, Pope John Paul II confirmed him as the patron saint of Iceland.

On the 23rd of December the _orl‡ksmessa (Thorlak Mass) is celebrated in Iceland in memory of him , as well as in Norway , in the Faroe Islands where he was also venerated and since the 18th century also in Sweden, u. a. also called Torlaksmesse , Tollesmesse , Sjursmesse or Lilla julafton .

English Bio:
P‡ll J—nsson (* 1155 ,   November 29, 1211 ) was Bishop of Sk‡lholt in southern Iceland .

He was an illegitimate child of the influential Goden J—n Loftsson and grew up together with his foster son Snorri Sturluson in Oddi . Later, he continued his studies in England and then became a farmer on the farm Skar_ in the district of Landsveit in southern Iceland.

In 1195 he was consecrated Bishop of Sk‡lholt. He gained notoriety above all as an esthete who would decorate both the church there and make treasures for himself and as gifts for influential friends.

Among these works of art was an ornately decorated stone sarcophagus , an unprecedented treasure in Iceland.

As a very educated person he commissioned the production of manuscripts .

Finally, he caused the canonization of his predecessors in the Office _orl‡kur _—rhallsson , Bishop of Sk‡lholt, and J—n helgi , Bishop of H—lar in northern Iceland.

English Bio:
Sigvar_ur _Žttmarsson (  1268 ) was from 1238 Bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland .

Sigvar_ur _Žttmarsson came from Norway . There he was first abbot in Selje (today's province Sogn og Fjordane ).

He was the first of a series of bishops of foreign descent on Icelandic bishoprics. This was due not least to the changed political situation in Iceland. In the thirteenth century, the country was in a civil war-like state, and the kings of Norway sought to seize it.

After both were orphaned at about the same time, the Icelanders, according to their custom, had elected new bishops in Parliament and sent them to the archbishop responsible for the consecration in Nidaros , Norway. However, none of these men was ordained a bishop. The Norwegian King HŒkon the Old wanted to increase his influence in Iceland and consequently moved the archbishop to occupy both bishop's chairs with him agreeable Norwegians.

Sigvar_ur took office as Bishop of Sk‡lholt in 1238.

He was promptly involved in various disputes of Sturlungen -Zeit. The incident became famous when fighting between îr¾kja Snorrason , who wanted to avenge the death of his father Snorri Sturluson , and Gissur _orvaldsson , who had fled to Sk‡lholt, into the bishop's church and front yard and the bishop stopped this activity by he appeared in full regalia on the threshold and imposed the church ban on îr¾kja Snorrason. Gissur _orvaldsson had led the men in 1241, who had killed on the orders of the Norwegian king Snorri Sturluson. [1]

In the years 1250 to 1254 the bishop stayed abroad and Brandur J—nsson represented him in office.

When, in 1267, Jšrundur _orsteinsson elected a new bishop from H—lar , he was appointed bishop over all of Iceland at short notice because Sigvar_ur had become too lax to be able to take office.

çrni _orl‡ksson was now sent to Sk‡lholt to take office on behalf of, and after the death of Sigvar_ur the following year he took over the episcopal see.

English Bio:
çrni _orl‡ksson (* 1237 ,   April 17, 1298 in Bergen ) was from 1269 [1] -1298 Icelandic bishop in Sk‡lholt .

He came from one of the most powerful families in the country. His parents were _orl‡kur Gu_mundsson gr’s and Halld—ra Ormsd—ttir. He was versed on his grandfather Gu_mundur gr’s with the powerful clans of Sv’nfellinga, the chiefs of Haukadal, H’tadal and Skar_verja. S¾mundur fr—_i was one of his ancestors through his mother . [2]

He participated in the rewriting of Icelandic law after the annexation of Iceland to Norway in 1262. He wrote a new Christian law with Archbishop Jon Raude , which was adopted in 1275 at the Althing . [3] In his tenure falls acceptance of J—nsb—k 1,281th

He fought for the observance of the celibacy of the priests and against the patronage law , based on the newly introduced Christian law. [4] He demanded that no layman could have a church or church property, and thus fell into a long and bitter struggle with the powerful Icelandic church owners, especially with the chief Rafn Oddson still in the tradition of private church being understood. In this concern, he did not even bow to King Erik Magnusson , whom he certainly supported in secular areas. It came to a conflict with Lodin Lepp , the envoy of the king. [5]Bishop Arne was therefore badly regarded at the court of King Erik. [6] But outside Norway but he was in such high regard that even King Erik Menved of Denmark asked him, King Erik of Norway to move to cease its military trips to Denmark. [7] The dispute over church property was in 1297 by comparing ¯gvaldsnes (now Avaldsnes ) settled between King Erik and Bishop çrni. [8th]

His life is in çrni saga biskups , a biography that was written immediately after his death in Sk‡lholt presented. She describes his life and work until the year 1291, when she suddenly breaks off. It is believed that it was written by his nephew, Bishop çrni Helgason (bishop from 1304 to 1320). [9] In any case, the author used the episcopal archive and had has detailed knowledge of its actions, as can be seen from the many letters cited. She is the most important source for his life.

English Bio:
J—n Gerreksson (* 1378 ?   July 20, 1433 ) was a bishop of Sk‡lholt in southern Iceland . He had the office from 1426 held.

His exact lineage is unknown, but he was obviously of good family and had found in Erich of Pomerania an influential patron, who caused J—n Gerreksson in 1408 Archbishop of Uppsala in Sweden . There he earned himself a rather dubious reputation, above all because of his cleric barely adequate life course. In 1422, the pope declared him unfit for the priesthood because of numerous celibacy violations . [1]

In 1426, however, sources call him a member of the papal guard, the forerunner of today's Swiss Guard , in Rome .

Under Pope Martin V he rose again in the church and received in 1426 the diocese of Sk‡lholt awarded, for which he paid quite a lot of money. Presumably his patron Erich von Pommern, who was also King of Denmark, had his hand in the game. The latter may have wanted to counterbalance Iceland's considerable political and economic influence in the country, as the English had succeeded in having one of their own, J—n Vilhj‡lmsson Craxton, bishop of H—lar in the north of the country.

J—n Gerreksson first traveled to Iceland in 1430, after a stopover in England. He used his own ship and led his own mercenary troop with him.

Initially, the new bishop was welcomed. However, his men acquired in the shortest possible time a conceivable bad reputation, which quickly rubbed off on the bishop himself.

The clashes ended with the Al beschlossening 1431's decision to expel the mercenaries of the bishop of the country. The bishop, however, did nothing like that. [2]

In 1432 it came to an assumption to some clashes with the Englishmen, who did not want to spoil their business, which the people of Gerreksson, however, mostly failed.

The exact history of the events can not be reconstructed from the historical sources, however, it is reported that the great interest of the leader of the mercenary troupe for some MargrŽt Vigfœsd—ttir was related to it. The woman rejected the mercenary leader. He then rode with his men to their brother's farm, where she lived, with the intention of burning down the Kirkjub—l farm with all the inhabitants. Significantly, her brother, êvar, had stood up for the banishment of mercenaries at the parliamentary session. êvar died in the altercations, but MargrŽt fled to Eyjafjšr_ur , where she allegedly made a vow to marry the one who would avenge her brother's death.

The most significant opponents of the bishop were at the time Teitur r’ki Gunnlaugsso n of Bjarnanes in Hornafjšr_ur and _orvar_ur Loftsson of Mš_ruvellir . The bishop had both arrested, brought to Sk‡lholt and forced labor there. _orvar_ur escaped captivity in the fall of 1432, Teitur only in the following spring. _orvar_ur, Teitur and çrni Einarsson Dalskeggur assembled a team and appeared on July 20, 1433 in Sk‡lholt. There they killed all the mercenaries who could get hold of them, finally pulled the bishop out of the church himself, put him in a sack and drowned him in the nearby river Brœar‡, [3] This was done in such a way that no one could claim that they had shed blood of the bishop. As far as known, the crime was not punished. _orvar_ur and MargrŽt married in 1436, lived in Mš_ruvellir and were considered in Iceland as the richest couple of their time.

The historian Bjšrn _orsteinsson has championed the thesis that the murder is a political attack on the English. The historian also saw a connection with J—n Craxton, the bishop of H—lar , whose zealous supporters were Loftor Guttormsson , the father of _orvar_ur. [4]

In any case, this is certain that the brother in law of J—n Gerreksson in H—lar did not move a finger to punish the crime.

English Bio:
Gissur Einarsson , also Gizur Einarsson, (* 1512,   March 24, 1548 in Sk‡lholt ) was from 1540 Bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland and also the first Lutheran bishop in the country.

Gissur Einarsson himself had been educated in the school of Sk‡lholt with his predecessor …gmundur P‡lsson , who held a lot of him. For further education, he went to Hamburg and came there in contact with the Reformation .

In 1538 he returned to Iceland and was ordained a priest. Like some other young theologians, including Oddur Gottsk‡lksson , the translator of the New Testament into Icelandic, he remained a follower of the Reformation.

…gmundur chose the young theologian as his successor in 1538, but it remains uncertain whether he knew of his inclination for the Reformation. The king confirmed this election. After Gissur had returned home, he took over the bishopric and revealed openly that he had become Lutheran. Thereupon …gmundur regretted his choice and wanted to sell him again.

However, this prevented Christian III. , the king of Denmark, for whom this was not least a question of power, by sending troops under Christofer Huitfeld Iceland and Ogmundur brought to Denmark, where he died. Christian III. He had adopted Lutheran Christianity for himself and his subjects in his empire, and wanted to do so in remote Iceland, which at the time belonged to the Danish kingdom. However, strong opposition was made in Iceland by Catholic circles around J—n Arason , Bishop of H—lar .

In autumn 1542 Gissur Einarsson was ordained a bishop in Copenhagen .

As a result, Gissur Einarsson translated the church laws of Christian III. from Denmark to Icelandic and supported the Danish king with the ultimate goal of enforcing Lutheran Christianity as the state religion in Iceland.

However, this lasted for some years and initially you had to agree on a compromise. In 1542, a pact was signed with J—n Arason, preventing military clashes until 1550. The country was divided during that epoch into a Lutheran south and a Catholic north.

Gissur tried in his sphere of influence to combat Catholic customs and let u. a. to take down a cross in Kalda_arnes , to which miracles were attributed.

He died in 1548. He left behind his wife Katrin Eggertsd—ttir.

English Bio:
Marteinn Einarsson (  7 October 1576 ) was an evangelical bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland .

In 1548 he took over the episcopate after his predecessor Gissur Einarsson . He was the second bishop of Sk‡lholt, who belonged to Evangelical Lutheran Christianity .

Marteinn Einarsson came from a family from Sta_asta_ur on the peninsula Sn¾fellsnes , where many members were pastors.

His father Einar Snorrason z. For example, there was pastor from 1500 to 1538, the brother of the mother, Ingir’_ur J—nsd—ttir , Stefan J—nsson , was also a bishop of Sk‡lholt and predecessor of Marteinn in office. A half-brother of Marteinn was pastor of Hjar_arholt in Borgarfjšr_ur .

One of his sisters was married in England and so Marteinn received his education there.

After nine years abroad, he returned to Iceland and worked as a merchant in Grindav’k .

In 1533 he took over as pastor's office of his father in Sta_asta_ur.

In 1548 he was elected bishop of Sk‡lholt.

As a result, he fell in the middle of the fire of the current smoldering conflicts over Iceland's membership in Catholic or Lutheran Christianity. This was for Christian III. of Denmark, who had just converted to Martin Luther's Reformation and held secular sovereignty over Iceland, not least a power issue.

While Marteinn Einarsson was in Denmark in 1548 to receive the ordination as Evangelical Lutheran bishop, the Catholic Bishop in northern Iceland, J—n Arason , sent the Abbot of _ykkvab¾r Sigvar_ur Halld—rsson to Sk‡lholt. He wanted to take advantage of the opportunity quickly and occupy the vacant bishop's chair again for the side of the Catholic faction. However, this could not prevent Marteinn Einarsson was ordained on April 7, 1549 in Denmark to (Protestant) bishop and sent by the Danish king back to Iceland.

There, however, he fell into enemy hands. Bjšrn J—nsson and Ari J—nsson, the sons of J—n Arason, detained him for about a year. Most of the time he spent in Mš_rufell, the court of Ari J—nsson. J—n Arason himself even wrote a mocking poem on the incidents.

However, the joy of the Catholics was short-lived: In 1550 J—n Arason was captured with his sons and executed in 1551.

Then Marteinn Einarsson was reinstated in his office in Sk‡lholt.

Martein Einarsson held this until 1557, when he himself resigned from the episcopate. As a reason for his resignation in 1557 he said that the king in his opinion went too far in the expropriation and disempowerment of the church.

From 1557 to 1569 he was again pastor in Sta_asta_ur, but finally renounced this office and spent his last years in çlftanes ‡ M_rum.

He emerged in the publication and constitution of psalm collections and was u. a. also as a good painter.

Einarsson was married and had many children.

English Bio:
G’sli J—nsson (* 1515,   September 3, 1587 ) was an evangelical bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland .

G’sli J—nsson was the son of the priest J—n G’slason of Hraunger_i in the district of Fl—i in the south of Iceland. He first received his education from …gmundur P‡lsson in Sk‡lholt. For further education he traveled to Germany, where he became acquainted with the Evangelical Lutheran Christianity and its followers.

From 1538 he worked as a pastor in Sk‡lholt and represented there the Reformation . From 1546 he is found as pastor of Sel‡rdalur in Arnarfjšr_ur .

Because of clashes with J—n Arason , the Catholic bishop of H—lar , who accused him in the course of the Counter-Reformation of blasphemy , the spread of false beliefs and the resistance to church laws, J—nsson fled to Denmark.

In 1551, after the execution of J—n Arason, he returned to Iceland and Sel‡rdalur. In 1556 he was elected Bishop of Sk‡lholt and consecrated in 1558 .

G’sli was a zealous advocate of Lutheran Christianity and translated numerous texts to further its spread in Iceland. He published a psalm book in 1558 .

His wife was Krist’n Eyj—lfsd—ttir. With her, he had numerous children, some of whom were pastors. Stef‡n, who received the rich parish of Oddi .

English Bio:
Oddur Einarsson (born August 31, 1559 ,   December 28, 1630 ) was an evangelical bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland .

His father Einar Sigur_sson ’ Eydšlum was pastor in Nes in the A_aldalur not far from Lake M_vatn in Northern Iceland.

When Oddur Einarsson was born, his father worked as an assistant pastor in Mš_ruvellir and there Oddur was born. Later, his father was pastor at M_vatn and then in Nes. Although his parents were poor and full of children - his father had other children with his second wife after the death of Oddur's mother - Oddur and one of his brothers received a good education at the H—lar school .

Then Oddur drove like most of his colleagues to further education to Copenhagen , where he spent two years studying at the local university (1585-87). Among other things, he took mathematics and astronomy and in this way he came into contact with Tycho Brahe , whom he also visited in his castle Uranienborg.

First, Oddur became headmaster of the H—lar School. In 1588 he was sent by Gu_brandur _orl‡ksson , the very weighed Bishop of H—lar, to Parliament Althing to promote his election as Bishop of Sk‡lholt. After Oddur had been elected, he went to Denmark, where he spent the winter and was ordained a bishop at the young age of 30 years.

Oddur Einarsson was considered a strict bishop. He turned against popular customs such as the Vikivaki balls and the consumption of horse meat on Sundays and public holidays.

He also campaigned for the persecution and the ban of so-called magicians.

On the other hand, he cared for his relatives, brought the non-wealthy parents and siblings to Sk‡lholt and handed over his father Eydalir in Brei_dalur in eastern Iceland, which was then considered one of the richest parishes in the country

The bishop was considered very educated and was probably the first to collect medieval manuscripts in Iceland. However, his collection burned in the fire of 1630, which severely damaged the bishopric Sk‡lholt. Some remains of the valuable collection were taken over by çrni Magnœsson .

Oddur Einarsson himself wrote much, especially historical treatises on the bishops of Sk‡lholt and H—lar, including J—n Arason . He also encouraged other authors to do the same, so wrote with his support J—n Egilsson the Biskupaann‡l (German bishop annals ).

Today Oddur Einarsson is known not least as a (presumable) author of a Latin- speaking description of his country ( Qualiscunque descriptio Islandiae ), which was considered lost, but emerged as a manuscript in a Hamburg library at the beginning of the 20th century . Presumably, the book was not launched at the time, because at the same time çrngr’mur J—nsson had also written a description of Iceland and this was in print.

His wife was Helga J—nsd—ttir, who came from the rich farm Grund in Eyjafjšr_ur . She had a comparatively bad reputation as a very tough woman towards the poor.

After his death in 1630, his son G’sli Oddsson succeeded him as bishop.

English Bio:
G’sli Oddsson (* 1593 ,   July 2, 1638 ) was an evangelical bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland .

He took office from 1632 until his death.

His father was Oddur Einarsson , at the same time his predecessor in office.

G’sli Oddson attended the school in Sk‡lholt. He then traveled to Copenhagen in 1613 following Icelandic customs to continue his studies there.

In 1616 he became a priest in Sk‡lholt and 1621 rector of the local school.

In 1629 he was formally appointed as a personal employee of his father, after his death the provost (governor of the episcopal see).

In 1632, Parliament Althing elected him Bishop of Sk‡lholt.

In 1622 he married Gu_rœn Bjšrnsd—ttir. The marriage remained childless.

Like his father, G’sli Oddsson wrote a treatise on his homeland in Latin. The work was titled De mirabilibus Islandi¾ ( Eng About the Wonders of Iceland ). In this work, the incipient empiricism mingles with the people (but) believe the Icelanders of his epoch.

English Bio:
Brynj—lfur Sveinsson (born September 14, 1605 in Holt ( …nundarfjšr_ur ),   August 5, 1675 ) was one of the 16 Lutheran bishops of Sk‡lholt .

The Icelandic 1000-kroner banknote shows a portrait of him.

After attending Sk‡lh—lt's school, Brynj—lfur went to Copenhagen, where he studied classical philology and philosophy: a study choice that shaped his critical view of the witch huntings of his time. There he also made contacts with the most outstanding thinkers of the North, such as Ole Worm . He then worked for six years as a Vice President at the School of Roskilde .

In 1638 he was about to leave for a study trip to the Netherlands, when he was unexpectedly elected to the episcopal see of Sk‡lh—lt. His letter of resignation was not accepted by Christian IV . So he was ordained a bishop in May 1639 in the Frauenkirche of Copenhagen.

Of the children from the marriage with MargrŽt Halld—rsd—ttir survived only one daughter, Ragnhei_ur, and a son, Halld—r, who died in England in 1666.

Brynj—lfur Sveinsson died on 5 August 1675 without his heirs.

The name of the bishop, especially because of three well-known texts that passed through his hands, is closely linked to medieval manuscripts .

In 1643, a composite manuscript containing Old Norse mythological and heroic poetry became the property of the clergyman. He gave her the name "S¾mundar Edda ". Brynj—lfur attributed this manuscript to S¾mundr Sigfœsson (inn fr—_i) by combining and reinterpreting the hypotheses of an "older" Edda as precursors of Snorra-Edda , and of S¾mundr as the author of the latter. However, modern research agrees that the creator of the work (whether in the sense of "author" or "compiler") could not have been S¾mundr. Rather, it is also called Codex Regiusdescribed manuscript based on a variety of sources; the manuscript contains texts of very different age groups and is otherwise quite uneven in terms of content and style. The life data of the author adopted by Brynj—lfur and the probable date of origin of the manuscript (around 1270) also do not match, so that authorship is excluded.

Also, a manuscript of the Old Norse Snorra Edda , the so-called Codex Upsaliensis , got into the hands of the Icelandic clergyman, before he passed it in 1639 to the Danish historian Stephanius .

Finally, he also found a manuscript of the Icelandic book (êslendingab—k), which was copied by one of his priests, but lost shortly thereafter.

Brynj—lfur Sveinsson, who served as bishop from 1639 to 1675, was less well known poet and wrote hymns and psalms. He promoted Hallgr’mur PŽtursson , Iceland's most famous psalm-poet and helped him to pastoral posts.

Brynj—lfur Sveinsson is one of the main characters in the opera Ragnhei_ur by the Icelandic composer Gunnar _—r_arson , which was performed with great success in 2013/2014 and deals with the fate of Brynj—lfur's daughter Ragnhei_ur.

English Bio:
_—r_ur _orl‡ksson (German Thordur Thorlaksson ) (born August 14, 1637 ,   March 17, 1697 in Sk‡lholt ) was an evangelical bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland .

He took office from 1674 until his death.

_—r_ur _orl‡ksson was the son of lorl‡kur Skœlason , Bishop of H—lar . Therefore, he first went to the prestigious school of H—lar. Like most of his evangelical predecessors, he later traveled to Denmark and completed his studies at the University of Copenhagen .

After an interlude in Iceland he pursued further studies abroad from 1663, first at the universities of Rostock [1] and Wittenberg . He then stayed in Paris , in Belgium and Holland . In 1669 he is found in Stangerland in Norway .

From 1660 to 1663 he was rector of the school of H—lar.

In 1772 he was ordained a bishop and took over the office in Sk‡lholt Brynj—lfur Sveinsson .

Bishop _—r_ur was a good musician, but he was particularly passionate about science, not least geography and agricultural science. [2]

He also stood in the tradition of other bishops of Sk‡lholt [3] , to publish a Latin-language description of Iceland. The title was Dissertatio chorographico-historica de Islandia . The treatise was published in 1666 in Wittemberg . He also drew maps of Iceland and Greenland .

In addition, he initiated trial breeding of wheat species in Sk‡lholt.

He ordered the transfer of the episcopal printing house from H—lar to Sk‡lholt and was the first in Iceland to print medieval works. a. the first printed edition of the Landnahmebuch (1688). He is also said to have introduced technical innovations in the printing house.

His wife was Gu_r’_ur G’slad—ttir (1651-1707).

One of his sons was farmer in Hl’_arendi , Flj—tshl’_ , the court known by the Nj‡lssaga .

English Bio:
J—n _orkelsson V’dal’n (born March 21, 1666 ,   August 30, 1720 ) was an evangelical bishop of Sk‡lholt in the south of Iceland .

He was considered an outstanding preacher and one of the best poets in Latin in his country.

J—n V’dal’n came from a family from Gar_ar (çlftanes) on the peninsula çlftanes .

His father _orkell Arngr’msson was pastor there. One of his sisters was married to the vicar of _ingvellir .

J—n V’dal’n went to school with a relative, P‡ll Bjšrnsson in Sel‡rdalur in the Westfjords . Afterwards, like many Icelandic priests of the time, he went to Copenhagen to study theology at the university there. A classmate of his was çrni Magnœsson , who later founded the famous collection of medieval manuscripts .

After graduating in theology, J—n V’dal’n initially went to the Royal Navy in the hope of making a career there quickly. After this failed, his mother bought him.

In 1691 he returned to Iceland, reportedly relatively destitute. In 1692 he became a teacher in the school of Sk‡lholt and in 1693 he took over the office of the local pastor. After an interlude as a priest in Gar_ar he was finally elected in 1697 Bishop of Sk‡lholt and consecrated in 1698.

J—n V’dal’n gained a good reputation as a theologian and scholar.

Until well into the 20th century, his book V’dal’nspostille , a booklet with sermons for every holiday of the year, enjoyed great popularity. The influence of this book in the following two centuries on faith, but also culture and literature in the country is not to be underestimated.

Together with the psalmist Hallgr’mur PŽtursson , he is considered to be the most famous representative of pietism in Iceland.

About J—n V’dal’n contradictory is reported. On the one hand, he was considered very generous to the poor and needy, on the other hand, but also reckless in the financial sector.

He was open to innovations in the agricultural sector and made experiments with vegetable growing (various types of cabbage). He also recommended the Icelandic animals the reindeer breeding. The country was already very poor at that time, it came to famine again and again, although the hardest test, the outbreaks of Laki only in the 1780s, should be long after his death.

As a shadow side of his character his tendency to drunkenness is mentioned. There are also numerous anecdotes about it. In addition, he seems to have been choleric disposition and was for example always in dispute with the legal scholar Oddur Sigur_sson .

His wife was Sigr’_ur the Younger (1677-1730), a daughter of J—n Vigfœsson , Bishop of H—lar . She was considered extraordinarily educated for the time and even taught Latin herself.

His death on the Kaldidalur / Uxahryggur inland road in the late summer of 1720 is famous. According to a well-known quote, he foreshadowed it and expressed his fear of the Kaldidalur before the trip. [1] He was returning from the funeral of a relative when he suddenly became ill and died.

A cross reminds as a memorial to his place of death on the slope, which was then called Biskupsbrekka (German Bishop's slope ).

English Bio:
J—n …gmundsson (* 1052 ,   April 23, 1121 ) was an Icelandic bishop .

In 1106 he founded a bishopric in H—lar in the north of Iceland and served there until his death as a bishop.

J—n was the son of …gmundur _orkelsson and _orger_ur Egilsd—ttir from Brei_ab—lsta_ur in Flj—tshl’_ .

J—n was later married twice, but had no children.

At the beginning J—n learned at êsleifur Gissurarson in Sk‡lholt and later went on to further studies in Denmark and Norway.

S¾mundur fr—_i was his traveling companion when he returned home after completing his studies.

J—n lived in his homeland, when he was appointed Bishop of H—lar, probably with the support of the Bishop of Sk‡lholt, Gissur êsleifsson . The future bishop first went to Rome, where he met the Pope, who caused him to be ordained a bishop. This happened on April 29, 1106.

J—n …gmundsson became an influential bishop. He also founded a school in H—lar, the u. a. Teachers from abroad employed.

J—n made it his mission to eradicate the remains of ancient Norse pagan religion. This involved changing the names of the days of the week. Thus, from —_insdagr , the day of Odin , the name mi_vikudagr became the day of the midweek; the days of T_r and Thor were renamed "third day" and "fifth day".

To date, these designations of the weekdays have been preserved in Iceland. Overall, however, J—ns reform efforts appear to have succeeded only on an external level. He did not succeed in dispelling the memory of the pagan gods.

Thus, more than a century after his death, the Snorra-Edda and the Liederedda , both of which have preserved mythical paganism and mythical lyricism.

J—n was appointed a local saint by a bishop's decree at Althing in 1200. It is therefore called in Iceland as J—n helgi (German St. J—n ).

A saga, J—ns saga H—labiskups or J—ns saga helga , tells of his actions and life in his time in H—lar.
