English Bio:
J—n Arason (* 1484 in Gr_ta , North Iceland,   November 7, 1550 in Sk‡lholt ) was bishop of H—lar in northern Iceland from 1524 to 1550. He was the last Catholic bishop of the country until 1923, an Apostolic Prefecture was built.

In the 16th century , the Danish king Christian III. (1537-1559), under whose rule Iceland was located since 1380, endeavors to enforce the Reformation here, too. It was also about worldly power and wealth: He was able to bring church property such as those of the bishoprics and monasteries under his rule.

The king succeeded in occupying the important bishopric of Sk‡lholt in the south in 1541 with a reformation-friendly bishop, Gissur Einarsson . However, the Catholic bishop in the north of H—lar, J—n Arason, stubbornly resisted any attempt to reform this part of the country. He had the equally powerful bishopric since 1524 held.

Many Icelanders have identified, and still identify with, this man, who fought not only for the Catholic Church, but also, above all, for independence from Danish rule. On the other hand, he certainly also fought for his own interests: He is quite equal to the power and behavior of many mainland European bishops of the time. He married Helga Sigur_ard—ttir with purely secular marriage contract, as it was quite common in the local clergy, and had with her the daughter _—runn and the sons Sigur_ur, Ari and Bjšrn. He was also not too squeamish in enforcing his goals.

The southern bishopric, Sk‡lholt, took over the Reformation after a parliamentary resolution in 1541. But when in 1548 Gissur Einarsson died, J—n Arason intervened and there used a Catholic man of his confidence. The king did not tolerate this and put his own man in his place. This allowed J—n Arason capture. However, J—n Arason could not resist long against the superiority of the troops of the king and was executed without trial on November 7, 1550 together with the sons Ari and Bjšrn . [1]

J—n Arason has also acquired cultural merit: he was a good poet and writer himself and founded the first printing works in Iceland in H—lar . The Breviarum Holense (Book of H—lar) was the first printed book in Iceland, but no copy has survived . [2]

English Bio:
Gu_brandur _orl‡ksson (* 1541 ,   July 20, 1627 ) was an Icelandic humanist and bishop .

Gu_brandur studied at the Cathedral School H—lar and at the University of Copenhagen . Later he was a successful rector of the Sk‡lholter School, pastor in Brei_ab—lsta_ur and finally for 56 years - until his death - Bishop of H—lar .

He was one of the most learned men of his time and worked in addition to his ecclesiastical duties in the typically humanistic branches of mathematics , cartography and astronomy . During his episcopacy, he edited and published at least eighty books, including the first translation of the Bible into Icelandic - the so-called Gu_brandsbibl’a [1] - and a codification of Icelandic law. In addition, he created in 1590 as the first a comparatively accurate map of Iceland.

His daughter Steinunn Gu_brandsd—ttir (1571-1649), born to a house maid, Gu_rœn G’slad—ttir, became the mother of _orl‡kur Skœlason, the successor of Gu_brand as Bishop of H—lar.

Gu_brand's portrait adorns the Icelandic 50-crown banknote , which, however, is barely circulating .

English Bio:
John Leslie (also John Lesley , born September 29, 1527 in Kingussie , Scotland ,   May 31, 1596 in Guirtenburg, near Brussels ) was a Scottish clergyman and Bishop of Ross . He is especially known for his work for Maria Stuart and as a historian .

John Leslie was a son of the pastor Gavin Leslie. He studied at the University of Aberdeen and became a Magister Artium . In 1538 he received dispensation to hold a benefice, although he was illegitimate birth, became acolyte in the Cathedral of Aberdeen in June 1546 and later ebenda PrŠbendar. After he had later studied at Poitiers , to Toulouse and Paris , where he graduated in 1553 as a doctor of law, he taught from about 1554 Canon Law at King's College, Aberdeen . In 1558 he was ordained and Official (Deputy) of the Bishop of Aberdeen, He then received in 1559 the benefice and praising Oyne .

In the Reformation Leslie appeared on the side of Catholicism . In 1560 in Edinburgh , held disputation he defended the Roman Catholic Church ; John Knox and John Willock were two of his opponents. The following year he was one of the commissars sent to the young Queen Mary Stuart to bring her to Scotland for the purpose of her reign. He returned in their retinue and was appointed Privy Councilor. In 1565 he became senator of the judicial office and abbot of Lindores, 1566 Bishop of Ross and one of the 16 members of the Commission for the Revision of the Scottish Law, whereupon printed under his supervision, the collection of the Scottish Act of Parliament known as the Black Acts ( Actis and Constitutiounis of the Realm of Scotland from the Reigne of James I ) has been.

Bishop Leslie was one of Queen Mary's most faithful followers and worked hard for her cause during her imprisonment in England . He served in October 1568 as the most important Scottish commissioner during the unsuccessful conference at York with Commissioners of the English Queen Elizabeth Tudor . In 1569, he appeared as ambassador of Mary at the court of Elizabeth I, to appeal because of the injustice done to his queen. When he found no hearing, he made plans for Maria's escape. He finally participated in the conspiracy of Roberto di Ridolfi to overthrow Elizabeth and make Mary Queen of England. Here was the marriage of Mary withThomas Howard, 4th Duke of Norfolk . But in April / May 1571, the plot was uncovered and Lesley was first imprisoned on the Isle of Ely and later in the Tower of London . His confessions made in October and November 1571 were enough, along with other evidence, to have Norfolk executed in June 1572 as a traitor.

During his absence from Scotland, Leslie was deprived of his income from his bishopric, so that he fell into poverty. Meanwhile, during his captivity, he was gathering material for his story of Scotland. In 1572 he gave the last part of this work to Queen Maria for her entertainment in captivity, written in the Scottish dialect . He also wrote for their use Piae Consolationes , of which Maria translated a part into French verses.

In 1573 Leslie was released, but expelled from England. He went to continental Europe and implored the kings of France and Spain, the Pope and the German princes in vain, to do something serious to save his mistress. In 1578 he published in Rome his also particularly appreciated for the elegant Latin history of Scotland under the title De origine, moribus et rebus gestis Scotorum .

In 1579 Leslie traveled to France, where the Archbishop of Rouen, Charles de Bourbon , appointed him suffragan and vicar general. On the way to his diocese he was arrested on the way and had to pay a ransom of 3000 pistols to prevent his extradition to Elisabeth. During the remaining reign of Henry III. Leslie was not further bothered, but after the accession to the throne of the Protestant King Henry IV , he was again in tribulation. In 1590 he was imprisoned again and had to ransom again with the same ransom as before. In 1593 he was appointed by Clement VIII as Bishop of Coutances in Normandybut was unable to take possession of his chair. So he had the permission to remain Bishop of Ross, until a peaceful takeover of the Diocese of Coutances was possible. He never returned to Scotland. Finally, he retired to the Augustinian monastery Guirtenburg near Brussels, where he spent his last life and died on May 31, 1596 at the age of 68 years.

Most Leslie writings served the defense of his queen. His ten-volume history of Scotland describes events from 1436 to 1561. In its early parts, it is based essentially on the portrayals of Hector Boece and John Major , although many of the topographical data in it stem from Leslie's own experience. In the later parts of his History, Leslie gives a completely independent account from the Catholic point of view, offering a valuable complement and corrective to the writings of George Buchanan and John Knox. A Scottish translation of Leslie's work was written in 1596 by James Dalrymple from the Schottenkloster in Regensburg, It was printed in two volumes for the Scottish Text Society under the direction of EG Cody in the years 1888-1895. Thomas Thomson published the work in 1830 in Edinburgh for the Bannatyne Club as The History of Scotland, from the death of King James I in the year 1436 to the year 1561, according to an old manuscript owned by the Earl of Lewen and Melville.

German Bio: ThaddÃ¤us MacCarthy (* um 1455; â€  25. Oktober 1492 in Ivrea, auch ThaddÃ¤us Macher) war ein irischer Bischof. Er wurde am 26. Mai 1895 von Papst Leo XIII. seliggesprochen. Neben Oliver Plunkett ist er der einzige Ire, der in der Neuzeit seliggesprochen wurde.  MacCarthy wurde in Cork geboren und war Sohn des Lords von Muskerry. Seine Erziehung erfolgte im Kloster Kilcrea.  Papst Sixtus IV. weihte ihn im Jahr 1481 zum Bischof und wies ihm Ross als neue DiÃ¶zese zu. Er konnte die DiÃ¶zese aber nicht Ã¼bernehmen, da zu diesem Zeitpunkt der Bischof von Ross noch lebte. Also wurde er zum Bischof von Cork und Cloyne ernannt. In Irland sollen durch ihn vier Synoden einberufen worden sein, die 1480, 1486 und 1489 zusammentraten. Anfeindungen in der Heimat zwangen ihn 1492 zu einer erneuten Romreise, bei der er vom Papst eine BestÃ¤tigung als Bischof zu erhalten suchte. Auf der RÃ¼ckreise verstarb er in Ivrea nahe Turin.
English Bio:
Thaddeus MacCarthy (* 1455,   October 25, 1492 in Ivrea , also ThaddŠus Macher ) was an Irish bishop . He was on May 26, 1895 by Pope Leo XIII. Blessed . In addition to Oliver Plunkett he is the only Irishman who was beatified in modern times.

MacCarthy was born in Cork and was son of the Lord of Muskerry. His education took place in the monastery Kilcrea.

Pope Sixtus IV consecrated him bishop in 1481 and assigned Ross to him as a new diocese. He could not take over the diocese, because at that time the Bishop of Ross was still alive. So he was appointed Bishop of Cork and Cloyne. In Ireland four synods are said to have been convened by him in 1480, 1486 and 1489 together. Hostilities in his homeland in 1492 forced him to return to Rome, where he sought to obtain confirmation from the Pope as bishop. On the return journey he died in Ivrea near Turin .

German Bio: Dermot McGrath (auch Magrath, Mâ€™Grath, Creagh, irisch Diarmaid Mag Raith; * im 16. Jahrhundert; â€  im 17. Jahrhundert) war ein irischer rÃ¶misch-katholischer Geistlicher und ab 1580 Bischof von Cork und Cloyne.  Seit der LoslÃ¶sung der englischen Kirche von Rom durch Heinrich VIII. und Elisabeth I. war der Katholizismus im britischen Herrschaftsbereich als kÃ¶nigsfeindlich und hochverrÃ¤terisch verboten und wurde zum Teil blutig verfolgt. In Irland widersetzten sich Hierarchie und BevÃ¶lkerung mehrheitlich der Protestantisierung.  Dermot McGrath war ein GroÃŸneffe von Richard Creagh, dem katholischen Erzbischof von Armagh (â€  1588 im Tower of London),[1] und ein Cousin von Miler Magrath (â€  1622). Dieser, ursprÃ¼nglich Franziskaner-Minorit und ab 1565 katholischer Bischof von Down und Connor, spielte hinsichtlich der kÃ¶niglichen Kirchenpolitik ein doppeltes Spiel, wurde 1571 anglikanischer Erzbischof von Cashel, schÃ¼tzte aber gleichzeitig seinen â€žpapistischenâ€œ Cousin durch gezielte Informationen.[2]  Dermot McGrath studierte im Ausland Theologie, kehrte zur Zeit der zweiten Desmond-Rebellion[1] nach Irland zurÃ¼ck und wurde am 12. Oktober 1580 vom Papst gegen den entschieden protestantischen Bischof Matthew Sheyne (â€  1582, Nachfolger William Lyon) zum katholischen Bischof von Cork und Cloyne ernannt. Sein gegenreformatorischer Eifer fÃ¼hrte zur raschen Rekatholisierung Corks, so dass 1603 fÃ¼hrende BÃ¼rger protestantische Bibeln und GottesdienstbÃ¼cher verbrannten und versuchten, die katholische Messe in den Kirchen der Stadt wiederherzustellen. Er nutzte dazu die durch die Munster Plantation hervorgerufene Unzufriedenheit der BevÃ¶lkerung.[3]  McGrath entging mehrfach der Festnahme und Hinrichtung, so im November 1600, als ihn Soldaten des Earl of Thomond[1] in einem Versteck auf dem Lande aufspÃ¼rten, aber wegen seiner abgerissenen Kleidung und Ã„rmlichkeit nicht erkannten. Danach verliert sich seine Spur. 1614 ernannte der Heilige Stuhl einen Apostolischen Vikar fÃ¼r Cork und Cloyne; demzufolge war McGrath zu diesem Zeitpunkt verstorben.[4]  Im Jahr 1603 kam der Corker Priester Dermot McCarthy mit 40 GefÃ¤hrten nach Bordeaux und grÃ¼ndete dort, unterstÃ¼tzt von Erzbischof FranÃ§ois dâ€™Escoubleau de Sourdis, das Irische Kolleg.[5] Name und Zeitpunkt legen eine IdentitÃ¤t dieses Dermot McCarthy mit Dermot McGrath/Creagh nahe.
English Bio:
Dermot McGrath (also Magrath , M'Grath , Creagh , Irish Diarmaid Mag Raith ; * in the 16th century ,   in the 17th century ) was an Irish Roman Catholic clergyman and from 1580 bishop of Cork and Cloyne .

Since the separation of the English church from Rome by Henry VIII and Elizabeth I was the Catholicism in the British dominion prohibited as anti-royal and treasonable and was prosecuted in part bloody . In Ireland, the majority of the hierarchy and population opposed Protestantism.

Dermot McGrath was a great-nephew of Richard Creagh , the Catholic Archbishop of Armagh (  1588 in Tower of London ), [1] and a cousin of Miler Magrath (  1622). This, originally Franciscan minority and from 1565 Catholic bishop of Down and Connor , played a double role in the royal church policy , 1571 Anglican Archbishop of Cashel , but at the same time protected his " papist " cousin by specific information. [2]

Dermot McGrath studied abroad theology, returned at the time of the second Desmond rebellion [1] back to Ireland and was on 12 October 1580 by the Pope against the decision Protestant Bishop Matthew Sheyne (  1582 successor William Lyon ) to the Catholic Bishop of Cork and appointed Cloyne. His counter-Reformation zeal led to the rapid recatholicization of Cork, so that in 1603 leading citizens burned Protestant Bibles and books of worship and tried to restore the Catholic Mass in the churches of the city. He used the dissatisfaction of the population caused by the Munster Plantation .[3]

McGrath escaped arrest and execution on several occasions, including in November 1600, when soldiers of the Earl of Thomond [1] tracked him down in a rural retreat, but did not recognize him because of his tattered clothes and pettiness. After that, his track loses. In 1614, the Holy See appointed an Apostolic Vicar for Cork and Cloyne; As a result, McGrath had died at that time. [4]

In 1603, the Corker priest Dermot McCarthy came with 40 companions to Bordeaux and founded there, supported by Archbishop Franois d'Escoubleau de Sourdis , the Irish College. [5] name and time put an identity this Dermot McCarthy with Dermot McGrath / Creagh close.

German Bio: Malachias (irisch Maoileachlainn, englisch Malachy, * 1094/95 wahrscheinlich in Armagh; â€  2. English Bio:
Malachias ( Irish Maoileachlainn , Malachy English , * 1094/95 probably in Armagh ,   November 2, 1148 in Clairvaux , born as M‡el M‡edoc Ua Morgair or Maelmhaedhoc î Morgair ) was an Irish saint and Archbishop of Armagh . His name is associated with prophecies , but it is very doubtful whether they come from him. Within the Catholic Church he is worshiped as a saint. His memorial day is the 3rd of November.

Almost everything that is known about Malachi today is due to the hagiography [1] of Bernard of Clairvaux , thus laying the foundation for the canonization of Malachi by Pope Clement III. put on July 6, 1190. Malachi's significance is that at a time of upheaval in Ireland as Archbishop of Armagh, he initiated a reform that was largely realized by monasteries. He opened the way for the Augustinern , the order of Savigny and in particular the Cistercian order to Ireland.

According to Bernhard von Clairvaux , Malachias grew up in Armagh. His birthplace is also believed to be in Armagh or the surrounding area. Since Malachias was 53 years old at the time of his death, the year of birth is 1094 or 1095. His father was Mugr—n Ua Morgair , who is mentioned in the annals of Ulster as head of the school of Armagh. In addition to his father, he found in his youth an important teacher in Imar Ua h-Aedach‡in , who at that time as Abbot of the Abbey of Saints Peter and Paul in Armagh led an ascetic life. Malachias was known about him with the Archbishop Cellach Mac Aodh , who in 1117 or 1118 himDeacon consecrated. At the age of 25 (around 1119) Malachias was ordained a priest.

Shortly after the ordination Malachias was appointed by Cellach Vicar General and charged with the renewal of his diocese , while Archbishop Cellach himself began in 1120 his second trip to Munster . Malachias took this opportunity to introduce the Roman liturgy in Ireland and to promote confession . After the return of Archbishop Cellach Malachias traveled to Malchus ( M‡el êsu Ua hAinmere ), the bishop of the dioceses of Lismore and Waterford . After the death of the lay abbot Oenghus Ua Gorman of BangorIn 1123, under the influence of Archbishop Cellach and Imar Ua h-Aedach‡in Malachias was appointed as the new abbot. Malachy abandoned it on the extensive associated land and built by the raids of the Vikings destroyed Abbey Bangor again. According to his biographer Ailbe Luddy , it can be assumed that Malachi's introduced the rule of saint Comgall , the founding father of Bangor.

Saint Malachy was in a 1595 by a Belgian named Arnold Wion published work Lignum Vitae [2] a papal revelation from 112 short aphorisms attributed to all the popes of Celestine II (1143-1144) to the end of the papacy attributed. However, it is considered to be absolutely certain that this can not come from him, and as very likely that the holy Philipp Neri is the author of their last 41 prophetic propositions, while the first 71 senses are a forgery, which should serve to to make the public aware of this prophecy already done.

German Bio: Brendan (irisch BreandÃ¡n, lateinisch Brendanus; * etwa 484 eventuell in Annagh oder in Fenit auf der Dingle-Halbinsel im County Kerry unweit von Tralee; â€  577 im Kloster Annaghdown, County Galway) war ein irischer Heiliger. Auf dem Weg zu dieser Brendaninsel, die in mehreren mittelalterlichen Karten verzeichnet ist, erlebte er allerhand Abenteuer, von denen das bekannteste die Verwechslung des Fisches Jasconius mit einer Insel ist. English Bio:
Brendan ( Irish Breand‡n , Latin Brendanus ; * about 484 possibly in Annagh or in Fenit on the Dingle Peninsula in County Kerry near Tralee ,   577 in Annaghdown Abbey, County Galway) was an Irish saint .

Brendan probably became a priest in 512 and founded numerous monasteries. The various accounts of his life are almost all legendary . The only confirmed date is the foundation of the monastery Clonfert (in the county of Galway ) around 560th He is said to have been baptized by the Bishop of Ardfert "Erth of Cornwall" (also Erc ) in the Aries source (Tobar na Molt) .

He is known by the Navigatio Sancti Brendani , a very popular and widespread in the Middle Ages report on a voyage, which he said to have undertaken between 565 and 573 with twelve companions. The goal of this trip, which was undertaken with a curragh , was the "Terra Repromissionis sanctorum", a promised island in the west. On the way to this Brendan island , which is recorded in several medieval maps, he experienced all sorts of adventures, the most famous of which is the confusion of the fish Jasconius with an island.

The description of his journey led to expeditions to search for Brendan's island until the 18th century. Since the 19th century was also trying to adapt the descriptions of the various islands to real islands in the Atlantic. The assumptions range from the Canary Islands to Iceland to America , but can not be conclusively documented in any of the cases, which probably will never be possible given the mythical-religious character of the travelogue: The Navigatio Sancti Brendani is a Christianized Immram , a fixed one island- celtic narrative type that describes the journey into the Otherworld .

In 1976, however , Timothy Severin was indeed able to sail with a Curragh to America, which suggests that a discovery of America at least at that time would have been possible.

Brendan is the patron saint of boatmen . [1]

The St Brandan's Stanes in Scotland are named after him.

Saint Aidan (also Bishop of Lindisfarne )
German Bio:
Aidan von Lindisfarne, der Apostel von Northumbria (* wahrscheinlich in Connacht, Irland;   31. August 651 in Bamburgh) war der GrŸnder und erste Bischof des Klosters auf der Insel Lindisfarne[1] in Northumbria. Er war ein christlicher Missionar und Heiliger, der Northumbria, das ins Heidentum zurŸckgefallen war, rechristianisierte.

Aidan ist die anglisierte Namensform des altirischen Aodh‡n (ãkleines FeuerÒ).

Aidan wurde wahrscheinlich in Connacht (Irland) geboren. ZunŠchst studierte er als Mšnch bei St. Senan auf Iniscathay (Scattery Island), bevor er Bischof von Clogher wurde.

Im Jahre 630 legte er sein Bischofsamt nieder und ging im Zuge der Missionierung Schottlands zunŠchst wieder als Mšnch nach Iona.

Als Oswald von Northumbria nach langem Exil unter den christlichen Pikten und Iren 634 heimkehrte und sich der Herrschaft Ÿber die nšrdlichen Angeln bemŠchtigte, beschloss er, das ihm bekannt gewordene Christentum in seinem Land einzufŸhren, und wandte sich darum an den Abt Segene/Segenius.[2] Zuerst wurde Corm‡n als Missionar gesandt, der aber seine MissionstŠtigkeit bald ergebnislos aufgab und nach Iona zurŸckkehrte. Aidan tadelte dessen Methoden und wurde 635 selbst zum Bischof ernannt. Er lie§ sich auf der in Oswalds Stammland Bernicia gelegenen kleinen Insel Lindisfarne nahe der kšniglichen Burg Bamburgh nieder. Auf der Insel grŸndete Aidan mit 12 schottischen Mšnchen noch im selben Jahr ein Kloster als Bischofssitz und begann mit der Christianisierung von Northumbria. Aidan predigte anfangs in schottisch-gŠlischer Sprache und Kšnig Oswald Ÿbersetzte fŸr seinen anglischen Hof.[1]

Als Kšnig Oswald 642 starb, fŸhrte sein Nachfolger Oswine die Christianisierung fort. Zwischen den beiden MŠnnern entwickelte sich eine tiefe Freundschaft. Durch behutsame GesprŠche und mit gro§em EinfŸhlungsvermšgen brachten Aidan und seine Mšnche das Christentum in die Gemeinden Northumbrias.[2] Einer Legende nach schenkte der Kšnig Aidan ein Pferd, damit er nicht mehr zu Fu§ gehen musste. Aidan aber schenkte das Pferd einem Bettler. Der Theologe Beda Venerabilis rŸhmte Aidans Demut, Glauben, MŠ§igung und seinen Eifer bei der VerkŸndung des Glaubens. Beda hatte an Aidan nur auszusetzen, dass er an der keltischen Osterfeier im Gegensatz zu dem ršmischen Brauch festgehalten habe.

Das Kloster Lindisfarne blŸhte auf und wurde zu einem Zentrum der christlichen Kunst und Kultur. BerŸhmt war seine Schreibschule, in der begabte Jungen wie Eata von Hexham erzogen wurden, damit die christliche Elite des Landes kŸnftig aus Einheimischen gebildet wŸrde. Alle northumbrischen Kirchen und Klšster nahmen hier ihren Ursprung.[1]

Einer Legende zufolge griff Kšnig Penda von Mercia 651 Bamburgh an und versuchte die Befestigungsanlagen niederzubrennen. Aidan betete fŸr die Stadt, worauf der Wind drehte und den Feinden Rauch und Feuer entgegenblies. Penda zog daraufhin ab.

Aidan starb am 31. August 651[3] in Bamborough, 12 Tage nach der Ermordung seines Freundes Oswine, im 17. Jahr seiner Amtszeit als Bischof. Er wurde in Lindisfarne beerdigt.

Einige seiner Knochen wurden 664 von Coloman (Abt von Lindisfarne 661Ð664) nach Schottland ŸberfŸhrt. Die in Lindisfarne verbliebenen Knochen wurden von Bischof Eardulf von Lindisfarne 875 nach langer Irrfahrt vor den DŠnen im Sarg von St. Cuthbert nach Newfield (Chester-le-Street) in Sicherheit gebracht.

Gedenktag katholisch: 31. August (n.g. Gedenktag in England und Irland)
Gedenktag orthodox: 31. August (†bertragung der Gebeine: 8. Oktober)
Gedenktag evangelisch: 9. Juni (Evangelisch-Lutherische Kirche in Amerika)

Patron der Feuerwehrleute
Apostel von Northumbria
English Bio:
Aidan of Lindisfarne , the Apostle of Northumbria (* probably in Connacht , Ireland ;   August 31 651 in Bamburgh ) was the founder and first bishop of the monastery on the island of Lindisfarne [1] in Northumbria . He was a Christian missionary and saint who rechristianized Northumbria, which had fallen into paganism.

Aidan is the Anglicised name form of the Old Irish Aodh‡n ("small fire").

Aidan was probably in Connacht ( Ireland born). He first studied as a monk at St. Senan on Iniscathay ( Scattery Island ), before he became Bishop of Clogher .

In 630 he resigned his episcopate and went in the course of missionary Scotland first as a monk to Iona .

When Oswald of Northumbria, after a long exile under the Christian Picts and Irish, returned home and seized control of the northern foothills, he decided to introduce the Christianity known to him into his land, and therefore turned to the Abbot Blessing / Segenius. [2] First, Corman was sent as missionary but soon gave up his missionary work inconclusive and returned to Iona. Aidan rebuked its methods and was appointed bishop in 635. He settled on the small island of Lindisfarne, near the royal castle of Bamburgh, in Oswald's native Bernicialow. On the island Aidan founded with 12 Scottish monks in the same year a monastery as a bishopric and began the Christianization of Northumbria. Aidan initially preached in Scottish-Gaelic language and King Oswald translated for his Anglican court. [1]

When King Oswald died in 642, his successor Oswine continued the Christianization. Between the two men developed a deep friendship. Through careful discourse and empathy, Aidan and his monks brought Christianity to the communities of Northumbria. [2] Legend has it that King Aidan gave a horse so he would not have to walk anymore. But Aidan gave the horse to a beggar. The theologian Beda Venerabilis praised Aidan's humility, faith, moderation and zeal in proclaiming the faith. Beda had only to complain to Aidan that he had held on the Celtic Easter celebration in contrast to the Roman custom.

The Lindisfarne monastery flourished and became a center of Christian art and culture. Famous was his writing school, where talented boys such as Eata were educated by Hexham , so that the Christian elite of the country would in future be made up of locals. All Northumbrian churches and monasteries originated here. [1]

Legend has it that King Penda of Mercia attacked Bamburgh in 651 and tried to burn down the fortifications. Aidan prayed for the city, whereupon the wind turned and blew smoke and fire at the enemies. Penda left.

Aidan died on 31 August 651 [3] in Bamborough, 12 days after the assassination of his friend Oswine of Deira, in the 17th year of his tenure as bishop. He was buried in Lindisfarne.

Some of his bones were transferred to Scotland in 664 by Coloman (Abbot of Lindisfarne 661-664). The remains of Lindisfarne bones were brought by Bishop Eardulf of Lindisfarne in 875 after a long wandering in front of the Danes in the coffin of St. Cuthbert to Newfield (Chester -le-Street) to safety.

Remembrance Day Catholic: August 31 (Memorial Day in England and Ireland)
Remembrance day orthodox: 31st of August (transfer of the bones: 8th of October)
Remembrance Day: June 9 ( Evangelical Lutheran Church in America )
Remembrance day Anglican: 31st August
Patron of firefighters
Apostle of Northumbria

German Bio:
ƒimhear Mac Mathœna [_e_v__ m_k_mahu_n_] (Šltere irische Orthographie ƒimhear Mac Mathghamhna, anglisiert Heber MacMahon, latinisiert Emerus Matthaeus; * 1600 in Inniskeen (Inis Caoin), heutiges County Monaghan;   17. September 1650 in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh) war ršmisch-katholischer Bischof von Clogher und ein HeerfŸhrer der konfšderierten irischen Katholiken in Ulster.

Mac Mathœna war der Sohn von Toirdhealbhach (Turlough oder Tirlough MacMahon) und Aoife N’ NŽill (Eva OÕNeill). Er war ein Neffe von P‡draig Mac Airt Mac Mathœna (Sir Patrick MacArt MacMahon). Der Clan der Mac Mathœna stellte vom 13. bis 16. Jahrhundert die Kšnige von Airgialla (Oriel). Das letzte Oberhaupt der MacMahons und Teilnehmer des Einnahmeversuchs von Dublin am 23. Oktober 1641 zu Beginn der Rebellion von 1641, Aodh îg Mac Mathœna (Hugh Oge MacMahon), war sein Gro§onkel. Mac Mathœnas Vater verarmte durch Landkonfiszierungen nach der Flucht der Grafen und wurde aus dem heutigen County Monaghan nach Killybegs (Na Cealla Beaga) im County Donegal vertrieben.

Mac Mathœna begann seine Ausbildung im Franziskanerkonvent in Donegal. Als SiebzehnjŠhriger ging Mac Mathœna 1617 an das Irische Kolleg der UniversitŠt von Douai in den Spanischen Niederlanden. SpŠter setzte er seine Studien bei Aodh Mac Cathmhaoil am Collegium Pastorale Hibernicum in Lšwen fort.[1] 1625 wurde er zum Priester geweiht und war als Seelsorger im heimatlichen Bistum Clogher tŠtig. Am 17. November 1627 wurde er durch pŠpstliches Breve zum apostolischen Vikar des Bistums ernannt.[2]

15 Jahre spŠter, am 10. MŠrz 1643, wurde er auf Empfehlung des Erzbischofs von Armagh Aodh î Raghailligh (Hugh OÕReilly) als Bischof von Down und Connor eingesetzt.[2][3] Als Bischof von Down und Connor nahm er an der Provinzialsynode von Kells im MŠrz 1642, der Generalkongregation des Klerus in Kilkenny im Mai teil und hatte in der Folge eine fŸhrende Rolle im Obersten Rat der Irisch-Katholischen Konfšderation in Kilkenny.[3]

Bereits im Juni 1643, noch vor der Bischofsweihe, wurde er auf Wunsch der Konfšderation versetzt und Bischof des bedeutenderen, weil stŠrker katholisch besiedelten Bistums Clogher (Clochar).[2] Er arbeitete wŠhrend der 1640er Jahre eng mit Eoghan Rua î NŽill, den er bereits in Lšwen kennengelernt hatte, zusammen and stellte eine Verbindung zum pŠpstlichen Nuntius Giovanni Battista Rinuccini nach dessen Ankunft in Irland 1645 her. 1647 versuchten die Gegner Rinuccinis unter den Konfšderierten Mac Mathœna auszuschalten, indem sie ihn eine Reise nach Frankreich zu schicken, jedoch verweigerte er dies, in dem er unter anderem auf seine fehlenden Franzšsisch- und Englischkenntnisse verwies.[3] 1648 verurteilte er den Waffenstillstand mit Inchiquin als feindlich der Sache der Katholiken. Da seine BemŸhungen fruchtlos blieben, zog er sich mit Eoghan Rua î NŽill nach Ulster zurŸck, woraufhin sie als VerrŠter Irlands vom Obersten Rat der Konfšderation bezeichnet wurden. 1649 wurde er von Feidhlim Rua î NŽill gefangen genommen und in Charlemont (Achadh an D‡ Chora, Co. Armagh) inhaftiert, aber er entkam zwei Monate darauf. Im Oktober 1649 einigten sich Ormonde und Eoghan Rua î NŽill, um der Invasion Cromwells besser Widerstand leisten zu kšnnen.[1]

Nach dem Tode î NŽills kurz darauf im November 1649 versicherte er Ormonde des fortbestehenden BŸndnisses. Im Dezember organisierte er ein Treffen des Klerus in Clonmacnoise. Im MŠrz 1650 wurde dem militŠrisch unerfahrenen Bischof Mac Mathœna die FŸhrung der Ulster-Armee mit 5.000 Infanteristen und 600 Reitern durch Ormonde anvertraut. 1650 nahm Mac Mathœna Dungiven (Dœn Geimhin) ein und hatte einige weitere kleine Erfolge, die ihn ermutigten, schlie§lich den Kampf gegen Cromwells Truppen unter Charles Coote in der Schlacht von Scarrifholis (An Scairbh Sholais) nahe Letterkenny aufzunehmen, obwohl seine Offiziere dagegen waren. Coote besiegte ihn am 21. Juni 1650.

Obwohl er zunŠchst reitend entkommen konnte, wurde er zwei Tage spŠter bei Enniskillen gefangen genommen und am 17. September 1650 auf Befehl Cootes erhŠngt.[4][2] Er wurde zudem enthauptet und sein Kopf aufgespie§t auf Enniskillen Castle ausgestellt. Sein Kšrper wurde von Katholiken auf Devenish Island (Daimhinis) im Lower Lough Erne bestattet.[3]

Nach seinem Tode wurde 1651 Philip Crolly apostolischer Vikar in der Dišzese Clogher, der nŠchste Bischof wurde P‡draig î Dubhthaigh (Patrick Duffy) 1671.[2]
English Bio:
ƒimhear Mac Mathœna [ e_v__ m_kmahu_n_ ] (older Irish orthography ƒimhear Mac Mathghamhna , anglicised Heber MacMahon , Latinized Emerus Matthaeus ; 1600 in Inniskeen ( Inis Caoin ), today's County Monaghan ,   September 17, 1650 in Enniskillen , County Fermanagh ) was Roman Catholic Bishop of Clogher and a commander of Confederate Irish Catholics in Ulster.

Mac Mathœna was the son of Toirdhealbhach (Turlough or Tirlough MacMahon) and Aoife N’ NŽill (Eva O'Neill). He was a nephew of P‡draig Mac Airt Mac Mathœna (Sir Patrick MacArt MacMahon). The clan of Mac Mathœna represented the kings of Airgialla (Oriel) from the 13th to the 16th century . The last chief of the MacMahons and participants in the Dublin Attempt on 23 October 1641 at the start of the 1641 rebellion , Aodh îg Mac Mathœna (Hugh Oge MacMahon), was his great-uncle. Mac Mathœnas father impoverished by land confiscations after the flight of the count and was from what is now County Monaghan to Killybegs ( Na Cealla Beaga) in County Donegal .

Mac Mathœna began his education at the Franciscan Convent in Donegal . As a 17-year-old Mac Mathœna 1617 went to the Irish College of the University of Douai in the Spanish Netherlands . Later, he continued his studies with Aodh Mac Cathmhaoil at the Collegium Pastorale Hibernicum in Leuven . In 1625 he was ordained a priest and worked as a pastor in the native diocese of Clogher . On November 17, 1627, he was papal brief to the apostolic vicar appointed the diocese. [2]

15 years later, on March 10, 1643, he was bishop of Down and Connor at the recommendation of the Archbishop of Armagh Aodh î Raghailligh (Hugh O'Reilly) . [2] [3] As Bishop of Down and Connor, he participated in the Provincial Synod of Kells in March 1642 of the General Congregation of the Clergy in Kilkenny in May in part and had subsequently a leading role in the Supreme Council of the Irish Catholic Confederation in Kilkenny , [3]

Already in June 1643, before the episcopal consecration, he was transferred at the request of the Confederation and bishop of the more important, because more Catholic settled diocese Clogher ( Clochar ). [2] He worked during the 1640s closely with Eoghan Rua î NŽill , whom he had met in Leuven, together and provided a link to the Papal Nuncio Giovanni Battista Rinuccini after his arrival in Ireland in 1645 ago. In 1647 Rimini's opponents tried to eliminate Confederate MacMathœna by sending him on a trip to France, but he refused, pointing out, among other things, his lack of knowledge of French and English.In 1648 he condemned the truce with Inchiquin as hostile to the cause of the Catholics. Since his efforts were fruitless, he retired with Eoghan Rua î NŽill to Ulster, after which they were referred to as traitors of Ireland by the Supreme Council of the Confederation. In 1649, he was captured by Feidhlim Rua î NŽill and imprisoned in Charlemont ( Achadh to D‡ Chora , Co. Armagh), but escaped two months later. In October 1649, Ormonde and Eoghan Rua î NŽillagreed tobetter resistthe invasion of Cromwell . [1]

Shortly after the death of î NŽill in November 1649, he assured Ormonde of the continuing alliance. In December he organized a meeting of the clergy in Clonmacnoise . In March 1650, the militarily inexperienced Bishop Mac Mathœna was entrusted the leadership of the Ulster Army with 5,000 infantry and 600 horsemen by Ormonde. In 1650, Mac Mathœna Dungiven ( Dœn Geimhin ) took over and had several other minor successes that encouraged him to eventually take up the fight against Cromwell's forces under Charles Coote at the Battle of Scarrifholis ( An Scairbh Sholais ) near Letterkenny , although his officers opposed it. Coote defeated him on June 21, 1650.

Although he initially escaped riding, he was captured two days later at Enniskillen and hanged on 17 September 1650 on command Cootes. [4] [2] He was also beheaded and his head impaled on Enniskillen Castle issued. His body was buried by Catholics on Devenish Island ( Daimhinis ) in Lower Lough Erne . [3]

After his death in 1651 Philip Crolly apostolic vicar in the diocese of Clogher, the next bishop was was P‡draig î Dubhthaigh (Patrick Duffy) 1671. [2]

John of Ufford
German Bio:
John of Ufford (  nach 1289) war ein Bischof des irischen Bistums Annadown.

Ufford erhielt seinen Namen nach dem Dorf Ufford im englischen Suffolk, wo sein Šlterer Bruder Robert Ende des 13. Jahrhunderts Vasall der Bischšfe von Ely und der Earls of Norfolk war. Vermutlich hatte sein Bruder diese Besitzungen vor 1256 von ihrem Vater geerbt, wobei der Name und der Stand ihres Vaters unbekannt sind. John of Ufford schlug als jŸngerer Sohn eine geistliche Laufbahn ein. Vermutlich Ende 1280 oder zu Beginn 1281 kam er als Master John of Ufford nach Irland, wo sein Bruder zu dieser Zeit Justiciar und damit Stellvertreter des Kšnigs war. Durch den Einfluss seines Bruders wurde John Archidiakon von Annadown in Galway. Sein Bruder wurde im November 1281 abgelšst und kehrte nach England zurŸck. 1283 wurde John of Ufford zum Bischof von Annadown gewŠhlt. Die Temporalien dieses Bistums waren jedoch bereits in den 1230er Jahren dem Erzbistum Tuam Ÿbertragen worden. John reiste zum Papst nach Rom, um die GŸter fŸr sich zu beanspruchen, blieb jedoch auch dort erfolglos. Ohne sein Amt als Bischof je angetreten zu haben, verzichtete er um 1289 auf seinen Anspruch.[1] Erst 1306 wurde der aus Irland stammende Gilbert î Tigernaig zu seinem Nachfolger gewŠhlt.[2]
English Bio:
John of Ufford (  after 1289) was a bishop of the Irish diocese of Annadown .

Ufford was named after the village of Ufford in Suffolk , England , where his elder brother Robert was a vassal of the bishops of Ely and the Earls of Norfolk at the end of the 13th century. Presumably, his brother had inherited these possessions from their father before 1256, the name and state of their father being unknown. John of Ufford began a spiritual career as a younger son. Probably in late 1280 or early 1281, he came as Master John of Ufford to Ireland , where his brother at the time Justiciar and thus Deputy of the King was. Due to the influence of his brother, John Archdeacon of Annadown became Galway, His brother was relieved in November 1281 and returned to England. In 1283, John of Ufford was elected Bishop of Annadown. However, the temporalities of this diocese had already been transferred to the archbishopric of Tuam in the 1230s . John traveled to the Pope in Rome to claim the goods for himself, but was unsuccessful there. Without ever taking office as a bishop ever, he renounced his claim in 1289. [1] Only in 1306 was a native of Ireland Gilbert î Tigernaig elected his successor. [2]

English Bio:
Malachias ( Irish Maoileachlainn , Malachy English , * 1094/95 probably in Armagh ,   November 2, 1148 in Clairvaux , born as M‡el M‡edoc Ua Morgair or Maelmhaedhoc î Morgair ) was an Irish saint and Archbishop of Armagh . His name is associated with prophecies , but it is very doubtful whether they come from him. Within the Catholic Church he is worshiped as a saint. His memorial day is the 3rd of November.

Almost everything that is known about Malachi today is due to the hagiography [1] of Bernard of Clairvaux , thus laying the foundation for the canonization of Malachi by Pope Clement III. put on July 6, 1190. Malachi's significance is that at a time of upheaval in Ireland as Archbishop of Armagh, he initiated a reform that was largely realized by monasteries. He opened the way for the Augustinern , the order of Savigny and in particular the Cistercian order to Ireland.

According to Bernhard von Clairvaux , Malachias grew up in Armagh. His birthplace is also believed to be in Armagh or the surrounding area. Since Malachias was 53 years old at the time of his death, the year of birth is 1094 or 1095. His father was Mugr—n Ua Morgair , who is mentioned in the annals of Ulster as head of the school of Armagh. In addition to his father, he found in his youth an important teacher in Imar Ua h-Aedach‡in , who at that time as Abbot of the Abbey of Saints Peter and Paul in Armagh led an ascetic life. Malachias was known about him with the Archbishop Cellach Mac Aodh , who in 1117 or 1118 himDeacon consecrated. At the age of 25 (around 1119) Malachias was ordained a priest.

Shortly after the ordination Malachias was appointed by Cellach Vicar General and charged with the renewal of his diocese , while Archbishop Cellach himself began in 1120 his second trip to Munster . Malachias took this opportunity to introduce the Roman liturgy in Ireland and to promote confession . After the return of Archbishop Cellach Malachias traveled to Malchus ( M‡el êsu Ua hAinmere ), the bishop of the dioceses of Lismore and Waterford . After the death of the lay abbot Oenghus Ua Gorman of BangorIn 1123, under the influence of Archbishop Cellach and Imar Ua h-Aedach‡in Malachias was appointed as the new abbot. Malachy abandoned it on the extensive associated land and built by the raids of the Vikings destroyed Abbey Bangor again. According to his biographer Ailbe Luddy , it can be assumed that Malachi's introduced the rule of saint Comgall , the founding father of Bangor.

Saint Malachy was in a 1595 by a Belgian named Arnold Wion published work Lignum Vitae [2] a papal revelation from 112 short aphorisms attributed to all the popes of Celestine II (1143-1144) to the end of the papacy attributed. However, it is considered to be absolutely certain that this can not come from him, and as very likely that the holy Philipp Neri is the author of their last 41 prophetic propositions, while the first 71 senses are a forgery, which should serve to to make the public aware of this prophecy already done.

Die Inschrift nimmt konventionell auf den heiligen Patrick und die UnwÃ¼rdigkeit seines Nachfolgers Bezug, auÃŸerdem auf seine Treue zur englischen Herrschaft in kriegerischer Zeit. RÃ¤tselhaft und kaum Ã¼bersetzbar sind die darauf folgenden Zeilen, die wahrscheinlich die Trennung von KÃ¶rper und Seele meinen, jedoch auch auf einen anderweitigen Bestattungsort oder auf die doppelte kirchliche ZugehÃ¶rigkeit des Toten bezogen wurden:  Wie eine Verteidigung oder Entschuldigung klingen die biblischen Schlussworte â€žDer Herr ist es, der mich richtetâ€œ (1 Kor 4,4Â EU) und â€žWer steht, gebe acht, dass er nicht falleâ€œ (1 Kor 10,12Â EU).[3]
English Bio:
Miler Magrath (also Meiler , Myler , McGrath , eigtl Irish Maolmhuire Mag Raith (* 1522 in County Donegal ,   November 24, 1622 ) was an Irish bishop of the Elizabethan era . Because of his double play between Catholicism and Anglicanism and his unrestrained collecting of novelties and office sales , he went down in history as the Scoundrel of Cashel - "the scoundrel of Cashel". [1]

Magrath came from a family from Ulster who was hereditary with church property; It also produced bishops Richard Creagh and Dermot McGrath . It was the time of the English Reformation , which started from the royal house ( Suprematsakte ) and met in Ireland on national, feudal and religious resistance. This was Elizabeth I violently break.

Nothing is known about Miler Magrath's education. The biographical testimonies prove that he was literary and juristic and rhetorically skillful. The pilgrimage site Purgatorium of St. Patrick , which belonged to the administrative area of __his father, was perhaps a religious influence . In the 1540s he joined the Franciscan Conventuals in an unknown place . In 1549 he was ordained a priest , perhaps in the Netherlands or in Italy .

In 1565, Magrath stayed in Rome , when the controversial question of the reoccupation of the vacant bishopric of Down and Connor in Ulster was discussed. Pope Pius IV had personally become aware of Magrath; he appointed him and initiated his episcopal ordination , which took place on October 12, 1565 in Rome. Magrath also recommended a proposal to introduce the Inquisition in Ireland. However, the Latin writing remained without consequences.

When Magrath arrived in Ireland, his relative and metropolitan , the Archbishop of Armagh Richard Creagh, was in exile. In the summer of 1566, he returned to Ireland, and Magrath arranged a meeting between him and the most powerful clan chief of Ulster Shane O'Neill; It was about the question whether ecclesiastical loyalty to the Pope could be reconciled with recognition of the secular rule of the English Queen. Thereupon Creagh put his hopes while O'Neill vehemently refused. The conversation brought only a temporary rapprochement in which Magrath might have had no real interest. O'Neill has been declared a traitor by the British. His rebellion he financed u. a. from income of the bishopric Down and Connor, who thereby escaped Magrath.

On May 29, 1567, Miler Magrath declared his submission to the temporal and ecclesiastical rule of Elizabeth I, who welcomed the move by letter and expressed the hope that other bishops appointed by the Pope would follow suit and receive their bishoprics from their hands. Magrath's church loyalty remained unclear. In late 1567 he turned to Rome with a request to be transferred to Clogher . Archbishop Creagh, again prisoner in the Tower since April 1567 , warned the Pope by letter before this appointment. Magrath in turn sued Creagh in Rome for heresy, His evidence, however, were recognized as fakes. Then Magrath left Ireland in 1569 and traveled to London, where he was arrested and held until 1571. During this time he managed to win the appreciation of the queen. On February 3, 1571, he received the royal appointment as Archbishop of Cashel and Emly in Munster , while at the same time, according to papal law, Bishop of Down and Connor.

Magrath's "Protestantism" consisted mainly in material considerations. [2] He did nothing to take on the religious life of his flock influence. Instead, through his alliance with English rule and self-enrichment, he appropriated the hatred of the poor and the resistance of the local feudal lords. When the Anglican bishop of Down and Connor died, Magrath tried unsuccessfully to be transferred there - he would then have held the papal and the royal episcopal title at the same time. It was not until 1580 that Pope Gregory XIII withdrew . Magrath officially became the (Catholic) bishop of Down and Connor and excommunicated him.

During his fifty-year tenure at Cashel, Magrath was frequent and long-absent. His representatives, including his brother Niall, arranged for the collection of ever higher taxes and duties. He sold diocesan ministries to the highest bidders or left them unoccupied and seized their benefices themselves. He leased church land for the benefit of the lower clergy and the church buildings to his own advantage. From 1582 until the reassignment in 1588 he was also (Anglican) Bishop of Waterford and Lismore and used the title in the same way. As a bishop of the established church he was also a member of the royal provincial government of Munster; also this influence he used to his and his family's advantage.

In 1575 he married Amy O 'Meara from Toomevara . She was Catholic and remained so after the marriage. The marriage produced nine children who were baptized and confirmed Catholic . Catholic priests, religious and even bishops who "illegally" preached and gave sacraments in his diocese, allowed him to live and even live in his palace; but then he delivered them to Dublin Castle and thus gained further prestige in London.

Nevertheless, he had to answer in 1592 in front of the Privy Council , because the allegations against him from royal side were unmistakable. However, he managed deftly and defended the Irish situation in his favor, and the Queen's confidence was preserved. After his return, a new journalistic campaign was directed against him, which painted his excessiveness in the darkest colors. Again he traveled to London and presented the charges as a papist slander and the mistrust of the royal representatives against him as a papist seed. On the streets of his own diocese he was in mortal danger and could not go out unarmed. Again he managed to avert sanctions and consequences from the government.

In his long tenure, Magrath had a significant stake in the ruin of the established church in Munster. In 1607, a visitation led by the (Anglican) Archbishop of Dublin came to a scathing verdict, and a downsizing of Magrath's jurisdiction was decided. In the same year Magrath asked Pope Paul V for absolution and reconciliation, which did not happen. A second attempt in 1612 was answered by the Pope with an invitation to Rome, the 90-year-old could not or would not comply.

Miler Magrath died in 1622 at the age of 100 years. On his two-year sickbed he wrote his grave inscription, which is still to be read in his grave niche in the dilapidated old cathedral of Cashel; underneath lies the half relief figure of an archbishop with pallium , which is evidently a medieval spolia and not a portrait of Magrath. The inscription conventionally refers to Saint Patrickand the unworthiness of his successor, as well as his loyalty to English rule during the war. Enigmatic and hardly translatable are the following lines, which probably mean the separation of body and soul, but were also related to a different burial place or to the double ecclesiastical affiliation of the dead:

Hicubi sum positus non sum.
Sum non ubi non sum.
Sum nec in ambobus,
sum sed utroque loco.
Like a defense or apology, the biblical concluding words "The Lord is the one who judges me" ( 1 Cor 4 : 4  EU ) and "Whoever stands, be careful that he does not fall" sound ( 1 Cor 10:12  EU ). [3]

Name: Donat Gallagher, O.F.M. vorher Bischof von Killala
Seliger Conor Oâ€™Devany, O.F.M. Hanratty Apostolischer Vikar
Heber MacMahon danach Bischof von Clogher
German Bio:
ƒimhear Mac Mathœna [_e_v__ m_k_mahu_n_] (Šltere irische Orthographie ƒimhear Mac Mathghamhna, anglisiert Heber MacMahon, latinisiert Emerus Matthaeus; * 1600 in Inniskeen (Inis Caoin), heutiges County Monaghan;   17. September 1650 in Enniskillen, County Fermanagh) war ršmisch-katholischer Bischof von Clogher und ein HeerfŸhrer der konfšderierten irischen Katholiken in Ulster.

Mac Mathœna war der Sohn von Toirdhealbhach (Turlough oder Tirlough MacMahon) und Aoife N’ NŽill (Eva OÕNeill). Er war ein Neffe von P‡draig Mac Airt Mac Mathœna (Sir Patrick MacArt MacMahon). Der Clan der Mac Mathœna stellte vom 13. bis 16. Jahrhundert die Kšnige von Airgialla (Oriel). Das letzte Oberhaupt der MacMahons und Teilnehmer des Einnahmeversuchs von Dublin am 23. Oktober 1641 zu Beginn der Rebellion von 1641, Aodh îg Mac Mathœna (Hugh Oge MacMahon), war sein Gro§onkel. Mac Mathœnas Vater verarmte durch Landkonfiszierungen nach der Flucht der Grafen und wurde aus dem heutigen County Monaghan nach Killybegs (Na Cealla Beaga) im County Donegal vertrieben.

Mac Mathœna begann seine Ausbildung im Franziskanerkonvent in Donegal. Als SiebzehnjŠhriger ging Mac Mathœna 1617 an das Irische Kolleg der UniversitŠt von Douai in den Spanischen Niederlanden. SpŠter setzte er seine Studien bei Aodh Mac Cathmhaoil am Collegium Pastorale Hibernicum in Lšwen fort.[1] 1625 wurde er zum Priester geweiht und war als Seelsorger im heimatlichen Bistum Clogher tŠtig. Am 17. November 1627 wurde er durch pŠpstliches Breve zum apostolischen Vikar des Bistums ernannt.[2]

15 Jahre spŠter, am 10. MŠrz 1643, wurde er auf Empfehlung des Erzbischofs von Armagh Aodh î Raghailligh (Hugh OÕReilly) als Bischof von Down und Connor eingesetzt.[2][3] Als Bischof von Down und Connor nahm er an der Provinzialsynode von Kells im MŠrz 1642, der Generalkongregation des Klerus in Kilkenny im Mai teil und hatte in der Folge eine fŸhrende Rolle im Obersten Rat der Irisch-Katholischen Konfšderation in Kilkenny.[3]

Bereits im Juni 1643, noch vor der Bischofsweihe, wurde er auf Wunsch der Konfšderation versetzt und Bischof des bedeutenderen, weil stŠrker katholisch besiedelten Bistums Clogher (Clochar).[2] Er arbeitete wŠhrend der 1640er Jahre eng mit Eoghan Rua î NŽill, den er bereits in Lšwen kennengelernt hatte, zusammen and stellte eine Verbindung zum pŠpstlichen Nuntius Giovanni Battista Rinuccini nach dessen Ankunft in Irland 1645 her. 1647 versuchten die Gegner Rinuccinis unter den Konfšderierten Mac Mathœna auszuschalten, indem sie ihn eine Reise nach Frankreich zu schicken, jedoch verweigerte er dies, in dem er unter anderem auf seine fehlenden Franzšsisch- und Englischkenntnisse verwies.[3] 1648 verurteilte er den Waffenstillstand mit Inchiquin als feindlich der Sache der Katholiken. Da seine BemŸhungen fruchtlos blieben, zog er sich mit Eoghan Rua î NŽill nach Ulster zurŸck, woraufhin sie als VerrŠter Irlands vom Obersten Rat der Konfšderation bezeichnet wurden. 1649 wurde er von Feidhlim Rua î NŽill gefangen genommen und in Charlemont (Achadh an D‡ Chora, Co. Armagh) inhaftiert, aber er entkam zwei Monate darauf. Im Oktober 1649 einigten sich Ormonde und Eoghan Rua î NŽill, um der Invasion Cromwells besser Widerstand leisten zu kšnnen.[1]

Nach dem Tode î NŽills kurz darauf im November 1649 versicherte er Ormonde des fortbestehenden BŸndnisses. Im Dezember organisierte er ein Treffen des Klerus in Clonmacnoise. Im MŠrz 1650 wurde dem militŠrisch unerfahrenen Bischof Mac Mathœna die FŸhrung der Ulster-Armee mit 5.000 Infanteristen und 600 Reitern durch Ormonde anvertraut. 1650 nahm Mac Mathœna Dungiven (Dœn Geimhin) ein und hatte einige weitere kleine Erfolge, die ihn ermutigten, schlie§lich den Kampf gegen Cromwells Truppen unter Charles Coote in der Schlacht von Scarrifholis (An Scairbh Sholais) nahe Letterkenny aufzunehmen, obwohl seine Offiziere dagegen waren. Coote besiegte ihn am 21. Juni 1650.

Obwohl er zunŠchst reitend entkommen konnte, wurde er zwei Tage spŠter bei Enniskillen gefangen genommen und am 17. September 1650 auf Befehl Cootes erhŠngt.[4][2] Er wurde zudem enthauptet und sein Kopf aufgespie§t auf Enniskillen Castle ausgestellt. Sein Kšrper wurde von Katholiken auf Devenish Island (Daimhinis) im Lower Lough Erne bestattet.[3]

Nach seinem Tode wurde 1651 Philip Crolly apostolischer Vikar in der Dišzese Clogher, der nŠchste Bischof wurde P‡draig î Dubhthaigh (Patrick Duffy) 1671.[2]
English Bio:
ƒimhear Mac Mathœna [ e_v__ m_kmahu_n_ ] (older Irish orthography ƒimhear Mac Mathghamhna , anglicised Heber MacMahon , Latinized Emerus Matthaeus ; 1600 in Inniskeen ( Inis Caoin ), today's County Monaghan ,   September 17, 1650 in Enniskillen , County Fermanagh ) was Roman Catholic Bishop of Clogher and a commander of Confederate Irish Catholics in Ulster.

Mac Mathœna was the son of Toirdhealbhach (Turlough or Tirlough MacMahon) and Aoife N’ NŽill (Eva O'Neill). He was a nephew of P‡draig Mac Airt Mac Mathœna (Sir Patrick MacArt MacMahon). The clan of Mac Mathœna represented the kings of Airgialla (Oriel) from the 13th to the 16th century . The last chief of the MacMahons and participants in the Dublin Attempt on 23 October 1641 at the start of the 1641 rebellion , Aodh îg Mac Mathœna (Hugh Oge MacMahon), was his great-uncle. Mac Mathœnas father impoverished by land confiscations after the flight of the count and was from what is now County Monaghan to Killybegs ( Na Cealla Beaga) in County Donegal .

Mac Mathœna began his education at the Franciscan Convent in Donegal . As a 17-year-old Mac Mathœna 1617 went to the Irish College of the University of Douai in the Spanish Netherlands . Later, he continued his studies with Aodh Mac Cathmhaoil at the Collegium Pastorale Hibernicum in Leuven . In 1625 he was ordained a priest and worked as a pastor in the native diocese of Clogher . On November 17, 1627, he was papal brief to the apostolic vicar appointed the diocese. [2]

15 years later, on March 10, 1643, he was bishop of Down and Connor at the recommendation of the Archbishop of Armagh Aodh î Raghailligh (Hugh O'Reilly) . [2] [3] As Bishop of Down and Connor, he participated in the Provincial Synod of Kells in March 1642 of the General Congregation of the Clergy in Kilkenny in May in part and had subsequently a leading role in the Supreme Council of the Irish Catholic Confederation in Kilkenny , [3]

Already in June 1643, before the episcopal consecration, he was transferred at the request of the Confederation and bishop of the more important, because more Catholic settled diocese Clogher ( Clochar ). [2] He worked during the 1640s closely with Eoghan Rua î NŽill , whom he had met in Leuven, together and provided a link to the Papal Nuncio Giovanni Battista Rinuccini after his arrival in Ireland in 1645 ago. In 1647 Rimini's opponents tried to eliminate Confederate MacMathœna by sending him on a trip to France, but he refused, pointing out, among other things, his lack of knowledge of French and English.In 1648 he condemned the truce with Inchiquin as hostile to the cause of the Catholics. Since his efforts were fruitless, he retired with Eoghan Rua î NŽill to Ulster, after which they were referred to as traitors of Ireland by the Supreme Council of the Confederation. In 1649, he was captured by Feidhlim Rua î NŽill and imprisoned in Charlemont ( Achadh to D‡ Chora , Co. Armagh), but escaped two months later. In October 1649, Ormonde and Eoghan Rua î NŽillagreed tobetter resistthe invasion of Cromwell . [1]

Shortly after the death of î NŽill in November 1649, he assured Ormonde of the continuing alliance. In December he organized a meeting of the clergy in Clonmacnoise . In March 1650, the militarily inexperienced Bishop Mac Mathœna was entrusted the leadership of the Ulster Army with 5,000 infantry and 600 horsemen by Ormonde. In 1650, Mac Mathœna Dungiven ( Dœn Geimhin ) took over and had several other minor successes that encouraged him to eventually take up the fight against Cromwell's forces under Charles Coote at the Battle of Scarrifholis ( An Scairbh Sholais ) near Letterkenny , although his officers opposed it. Coote defeated him on June 21, 1650.

Although he initially escaped riding, he was captured two days later at Enniskillen and hanged on 17 September 1650 on command Cootes. [4] [2] He was also beheaded and his head impaled on Enniskillen Castle issued. His body was buried by Catholics on Devenish Island ( Daimhinis ) in Lower Lough Erne . [3]

After his death in 1651 Philip Crolly apostolic vicar in the diocese of Clogher, the next bishop was was P‡draig î Dubhthaigh (Patrick Duffy) 1671. [2]

English Bio:
Fulk of Sandford (also Fulk Basset ) (* before 1225,   before June 1271 ) was an archbishop of the Irish Archdiocese of Dublin .

Fulk of Sandford came from the English noble family Basset . His exact origin is not clear. He was a nephew of Sir Philip Basset , presumably he was either an illegitimate son of Fulk Basset , the bishop of London or his brother Gilbert Basset . In general, however, he is called Fulk of Sandford , nicknamed also his brother John .

In 1244 Fulk was appointed Archdeacon of Middlesex by Bishop Fulk Basset . For this office he had to have been under canon law at least 19 years old, which is why he was probably born before 1225. In addition, he held a benefice at St Paul's Cathedral in London, whose treasurer he was no later than 1252. In 1256 Fulk was at the Papal Curia in Rome. There, Pope Alexander IV rejected the election of Ralph de Norwichto the new Archbishop of Dublin, who had been elected by two cathedral chapters. Instead, the Pope on July 19, 1256 Fulk appointed new archbishop. Unlike his predecessors, who owed their appointment to the English kings, Fulk was thus under the influence of the Pope's Archbishop of Dublin.

With the acceptance of his new office Fulk gave up his previous office in England. In late October or early November 1256 Fulk arrived in Dublin , where he was probably soon after ordained archbishop. Fulk proved active clergyman who took his duties seriously. His first measure was a visitation to the ecclesiastical province of Dublin, This was possibly the first visitation undertaken by an archbishop, leading to a flood of complaints and trials. In contrast to his English predecessors, who were only occasionally present in Dublin, Fulk devoted himself entirely to his ministry. He proved to be a pugnacious clergyman, who continued to maintain good relations with the papal curia and represented the interests of the Roman Church in relation to the Irish Church, which still strongly from the Church of Irelandwas shaped. Presumably, during his term of office, most of the rules and diocesan statutes for the archbishopric were enacted, with which he wanted to teach the lower clergy, thus aligning the level of pastoral care with the general standards of the Roman Church. Fulk quickly realized that he made many enemies with his strict exercise of office. He therefore asked Pope Alexander IV., That he may choose a confessor , who may give him the absolution for a possibly imposed excommunication . This privilege was granted to Fulk in July 1257.

In 1259 Fulk had to return to Rome, where he conducted a lawsuit with the monks of the Cistercian monastery Baltinglass , who resisted his visitation. In Rome, Fulk also complained about the English officials, especially about William Dean , the royal Justiciar of Ireland , who would interfere with his spiritual work. Alexander IV then turned to the Irish clergy and asked them to defend the rights of the Archbishop of Dublin. Alexander's successor Urban IV turned in November 1261 to the English King Henry III. and to the heir apparent Lord EduardHe repeated the complaints of Fulk. The Pope turned to leading English clergy and asked them to intervene in favor of Fulk in Ireland. However, disputes between Fulk and royal officials continued in Dublin, leading to further complaints from the Pope.

Despite his tense relationship with the English officials, Fulk was asked by the British government in 1265 to take over the management of Ireland after the capture of then Justiciar Ralph de la Rochelle by Irish barons. In fact, he did this job for a short time, but this was the only secular office he took in Ireland.

Shortly thereafter, Fulk was involved in a serious dispute with the mayor and the citizens of Dublin complaining about the level of their charges to the archbishop. Citizens demanded that the jurisdiction of the Archbishop in spiritual matters be restricted to Dublin. As a result, Fulk in 1266 excommunicated the mayor and the citizens, imposed the interdict on the city and traveled to London to deal with the papal legate Ottobonoto discuss. The legate supported Fulk's stance and confirmed the spell. Presumably the interdict was abrogated when, in November 1267, John of Sandford, the lawyer and brother of Fulk, and the citizens concluded an agreement settling a number of issues. Among other things, it curtailed the Archbishop's right to impose a public penalty on the citizens, which was one of the main demands of the citizens.

Fulk had probably incurred considerable debt before his election to the archbishop during his long stay at the curia in Rome or for his renewed trip to Rome in 1259. For the repayment of loans he had to lease or even sell possessions of the archbishopric, even 1266 he paid an Italian businessman £ 100, another 550 marks .

After April 1267 Fulk undertook a pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela . During his absence, John represented him of Sandfort. At the latest in August 1270 Fulk was back in Ireland. He probably died in early 1271, at the latest before June 1271 and was buried in St Patrick's Cathedral in Dublin. Inside the cathedral is a funerary monument from the late 13th century created either for Fulk or for his brother John, who was also Archbishop of Dublin from 1286 to 1294.

Name: John Lech
German Bio: John Lech (auch Leek) (â€  10. August 1313) war ein englischer Geistlicher. Ab 1311 war er Erzbischof von Dublin.  John Lech stammte mÃ¶glicherweise aus Yorkshire, wo er Grundbesitz besaÃŸ.[1] Er wird erstmals 1307 als kÃ¶niglicher Beamter erwÃ¤hnt.[2] Da zu dieser Zeit das Erzbistum Dublin nach dem Tod von Erzbischof Richard de Ferings vakant war, konnte KÃ¶nig Eduard II. Ã¼ber die PfrÃ¼nden der DiÃ¶zese verfÃ¼gen. Am 12.Â September 1307 ernannte er Lech zum PrÃ¤zentor der St Patrickâ€™s Cathedral in Dublin.[3] Zu dieser Zeit hielt Lech bereits eine PfrÃ¼nde im schottischen Dunkeld.[4] 1309 diente Lech als Almosenier des KÃ¶nigs.  Als Bischof Matthew de Crambeth von Dunkeld 1309 starb, setzte EduardÂ II. seinen ganzen Einfluss bei der Kurie ein, damit Lech zum neuen Bischof der wichtigen schottischen DiÃ¶zese ernannt wurde. Angeblich hÃ¤tten der Dekan und das Kathedralkapitel von Dunkeld Lech bereits gewÃ¤hlt, und der KÃ¶nig bat nun den Papst, die Wahl zu bestÃ¤tigen, um so den Frieden und die englische Herrschaft in Schottland zu festigen.[5] Am 14.Â Dezember 1309 beauftragte der KÃ¶nig Lech, nach schottischer Gewohnheit die GewÃ¤nder, BÃ¼cher und das Messgeschirr des verstorbenen Bischofs zu Ã¼bernehmen. Wenig spÃ¤ter brach Lech offenbar nach Frankreich auf, um seine AnsprÃ¼che direkt bei der Kurie zu vertreten.[6] In Dunkeld hatte es jedoch mit William Sinclair einen schottischen Gegenkandidaten gegen Lech gegeben. Am 8.Â Februar 1312 stimmte der KÃ¶nig in einem Brief an den Papst schlieÃŸlich der Wahl von Sinclair zu.[7] Damit Lech die Kosten fÃ¼r seinen Aufenthalt bei der Kurie bezahlen konnte, erlaubte ihm Papst Clemens V. am 21.Â Februar 1311, einen Kredit in HÃ¶he von 800 Mark aufzunehmen.[8]  In Dublin war es nach dem Tod von Erzbischof Fering Ende 1306 oder Anfang 1307 zu einer Doppelwahl zwischen den Kathedralkapiteln der beiden rivalisierenden Kathedralen gegeben. English Bio:
John Lech (also Leek ) (  10 August 1313 ) was an English clergyman. From 1311 he was archbishop of Dublin .

John Lech probably came from Yorkshire , where he owned land. [1] It was first mentioned in 1307 as a royal official. [2] At this time, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Dublin after the death of Archbishop Richard de Ferings was vacant, King was Edward II. About the livings have the diocese. On September 12, 1307, he appointed Lech Precentor of St Patrick's Cathedral in Dublin . [3] held at this time Lech already living in the Scottish Dunkeld . In 1309 Lech served as almoner of the King.

When Bishop Matthew de Crambeth of Dunkeld died in 1309, Eduard II put all his influence into the curia to make Lech the new bishop of the important Scottish diocese. Allegedly, the dean and the cathedral chapter of Dunkeld Lech had already voted, and the king now asked the pope to confirm the election in order to consolidate peace and English rule in Scotland. [5] On December 14, 1309 King Lech commissioned by Scottish habit robes , books and measuring utensilsof the deceased bishop. A little later, Lech apparently set off for France to represent his claims directly with the Curia. [6] In Dunkeld, however, it had with William Sinclair given a Scottish rival candidates against Lech. In view of the successes of the Scots in the fight against English rule Lech could not prevail despite the support of the English king against this Scottish opposition candidate. On February 8, 1312, the king in a letter to the pope finally agreed to the election of Sinclair. [7] Thus, Lech could pay the cost of his stay with the Curia, allowed him to Pope Clement V on February 21, 1311, a loan of 800To pick up Mark . [8th]

In Dublin, it was after the death of Archbishop Fering in late 1306 or early 1307 given a double choice between the cathedral chapters of the two rival cathedrals. The chapter of the Holy Trinity Cathedral had Nicholas Butler , the chapter of St Patrick's Cathedral had chosen the royal official Richard de Havering as the new archbishop. The king wished Havering as archbishop and gave this on September 13, 1307 the temporalthe archdiocese, he previously transferred the office of Precentor to Lech. Although Havering accepted the income from the diocese, but made no move to be consecrated bishop. In November 1310 he finally rejected the election, after which in spring the two cathedral chapter of Dublin unanimously elected the royal official Alexander Bicknor to the new archbishop. However, the king had now apparently recognized that against the Scottish Resistance, the appointment of John Lech to the bishop of Dunkeld would not succeed. He then asked the Pope to appoint Lech as the new Archbishop of Dublin, which took place on 16 May 1311. On May 18, the pope commissioned three cardinals, Lech the palliumto hand over, but on the episcopal ordination of Lech is not known. On July 20, 1311 he was handed over the temporaries of the diocese. [9]

In the homage that Lech had to pay the king for the goods of the diocese, he was represented by William de Birston . Lech probably remained in France because he is considered a participant in the Council of Vienne , which was opened in October 1311 by the Pope. [10] Apparently, just before the conclusion of the Council in May 1312, Lech presented the pope with the proposal brought by an Irish delegation to found a university in Dublin. A little later he returned from Avignon to England. [11] On October 1, 1312, he appointed in London Walter Thornbury to his Vicar Generaland to his representative in Dublin during his absence. [12] On May 20, 1313 King Lech treasurer of Ireland appointed, but probably not broke Lech before his death to Ireland on. He was probably buried in Westminster Abbey . After the death of Lech, the king ordered on October 29, 1313, that the Sheriff of Yorkshire should confiscate the possessions of Lech in York to settle the remaining debt of Lech to the crown. [14]

English Bio:
Alexander Bicknor (also de Bicknor or Bykenore ) (* after 1260,   July 14, 1349 in Dublin ) was an English clergyman. From 1317 he was archbishop of Dublin .

Alexander Bicknor was probably born in the 1260s in Bicknor in Gloucestershire and named after the place. He probably studied at the University of Oxford and graduated as a master . Perhaps he was promoted at the beginning of his career in England and later in Wales by Joan de Valence , the Countess of Pembroke and Lady of Wexford. Goodrich Castle , which was one of their favorite residences, is located near Bicknor.

In 1291, Bicknor was first mentioned in the service of the Crown, when he was to check the weirs at the Severn . In 1301 and 1302 he levied taxes in Gloucestershire, and in 1305 accompanied John Wogan , the Justiciar of Ireland , on his journey to Ireland . Apparently, however, he had returned quickly to England, because 1306 he should again raise taxes in Gloucestershire. In June 1307 he was appointed as the administrator of fallen loans in Ireland and in October 1307 Treasurer of the Treasury of Dublin. In early 1311, he was the cathedral chapter of St. Patrick's and Holy Trinity CathedralIn Dublin elected as new Archbishop of the Archdiocese of Dublin . Pope Clement V , however, rejected the election in favor of John Lech , another royal official. In June 1311, King Eduard II appointed Bicknor as his representative at the Council of Vienne , but Bicknor did not attend the council, but served as treasurer in Ireland from 1311 to 1312. [1] In May 1313 King Archbishop Lech appointed as the new Treasurer. However, Lech died a few months later, before he could take office, so that Bicknor continued to exercise the office. [2]After the death of Archbishop Lech, Bicknor was re-elected archbishop by a majority of the cathedral chapter of St Patrick's Cathedral, while the chapter of Holy Trinity Cathedral elected Walter Thornbury , Chancellor of Ireland . Then Bicknor resigned on April 15, 1314 his office as Treasurer to represent his claim before the Curia in Avignon . He had the king's support, and his rival Thornbury was probably drowned in early 1314 when he wanted to travel by ship to France to the Curia. [3] As Bicknor but to June 1314 in AvignonPope Clement V died, so that the dispute over the recognition of the election could not be decided. With the approval of the king, Bicknor remained in Avignon, but the election of a new pope was delayed. An English embassy finally sat down in favor of Bicknor, among others. On this confirmed on August 20, 1317, the new Pope John XXII. the election of Bicknor, who was finally consecrated bishop in Avignon on 25 August by the Pope himself. [4]

In early autumn 1317 Bicknor had already returned to England, but he did not travel to Ireland in his diocese. Instead, in the fall he was a member of the delegation of English bishops who traveled to the Earl of Lancaster in Pontefract Castle . There they tried to mediate between the king and Lancaster, who was the King's leading domestic opponent. [5] In September, the delegation led Lancaster further talks in York . [6] In November 1317 Bicknor was in London's St Paul's Cathedral , where the papal bulls with the excommunication of Scottish King Robert Brucethen he traveled on behalf of the king again to Lancaster to Pontefract. [7] As of spring 1318 took part in Bicknor further, lengthy negotiations with the Earl of Lancaster. In the meantime, he led on June 2, 1318 together with Archbishop Reynolds , the Earl of Pembroke and Hugh le Despenser a royal council. [8] In August 1318 he witnessed the Treaty of Leake , who was to reconcile Lancaster with the king. [9]A few days later, Bicknor was named Justiciar of Ireland on 11 August. On October 9, 1318, he returned to Dublin, six years after his first election as archbishop. Bicknor stayed longer in Ireland, but already in March 1319 he was replaced by Roger Mortimer as Justiciar. In early 1320, he held a provincial synod, while the 23 statutes were decided. These included, among other things, the duty to pay tithing and the duty to honor the feast day of St. Patrickand other Irish saints. In February 1321, he founded a university affiliated with St Patrick's Cathedral, which had a law and a theology faculty. The statutes of the university had been modeled on the statutes of the University of Oxford, which had been approved in 1312 by Pope Clement V. [10] probably was involved later in the Bicknor due to financial problems and conflicts, but the university was only briefly. In early November 1319 Bicknor had been asked to submit his accounts as Treasurer of Ireland for consideration to the English Treasury. The exam finally began in October 1323 and lasted until June 1325. In March 1324, Bicknor was joined with the Earl of Kentsent to France to mediate in the dispute over Saint-Sardos . After the failure of the negotiations, he traveled with Kent in the Gascony , where it came to war with France. [12] In October 1324 was commissioned Bicknor, a marriage between the heir Edward and a daughter of King James II. Of Aragon to negotiate.

In May 1325, Eduard II asked Pope John XXII to suspend Bicknor . Bicknor was responsible for the conquest of La RŽole by French troops in September 1324, he allegedly accused the royal favorite Hugh le Despenser of betrayal and he had embezzled funds in Ireland. Although Bicknor's accounts were incomplete and partly false, he had clearly committed fraud and falsification, but the king's attack on the archbishop was clearly politically motivated. In October 1325 Bicknor appeared in the Treasury in Westminsterand pleaded guilty. As a result, his estates, livestock, and land were confiscated in England and Ireland in December, and the value of his possessions was estimated at £ 553. When in September 1326 Queen Isabelle landed with an army in England to overthrow the rule of her husband Edward II, her Bicknor immediately joined. [13] He is mentioned as the first of the prelates, as at October 26, 1326 a meeting of prelates and magnates in Bristol the heir to Edward Regent said in place of his father fled. But despite this support, the new government did not pardon Bicknor for his mismanagement as treasurer, as the new government did not want to set a precedent.[14] Instead Bicknor has now been prosecuted even for alleged irregularities during his brief tenure as Justiciar. The Treasury tried for several years to hold him responsible for his mismanagement before Eduard III. pardoned him in June 1344.

But Bicknor had other difficulties. Due to the lack of repayment of debt, which had partly still recorded his predecessor John Lech during his stay at the Curia, [15] the Pope excommunicated in 1325 Bicknor. True, Pope John XXII. apparently no further attempts to collect the debt, but his successor Benedict XII. asked for the outstanding debts in 1335, whereupon Bicknor refused to pay. [16] had a different, protracted dispute Bicknor with Richard Ledred , the Bishop of Ossory and a suffragan of Bicknor, over alleged witchcraft and heresy of the Irish FamilyUtlagh . Bicknor supported the family against Lendred's allegations after he returned to Ireland in 1328. The dispute was still not settled when Clement VI. 1342 was elected pope. When Bicknor refused to travel to Avignon for the curia, Archbishop FitzRalph of Armagh was commissioned in 1347 to review the status of the Archdiocese of Dublin. Between the archbishops of Armagh and Dublin there was an old dispute over primacy over Ireland. Bicknor had rekindled the quarrel when he arbitrarily claimed the title of Primate of Ireland. [17]Finally, FitzRalph was expelled from Dublin by Royal officials in April or May 1349 at the behest of Bicknor. The aged Bicknor died a little later, possibly of the plague raging in Ireland at the time.

Although Bicknor first served well during the reign of Edward II as a prelate and was considered a capable official, [18] he failed towards the end of the reign of the king. Perhaps he was too naive, not unscrupulous enough or incapable of surviving in the difficult political conditions of that time. Even after the fall of the king he was under Eduard III. never restore his position despite his long life.

Bicknor has delivered a sermon in which he denounced laziness and laziness and held it at Holy Trinity Cathedral, possibly at the Provincial Synod of 1320.

Name: John de St Paul auch Lordkanzler von Irland
German Bio: John de St Paul (* um 1295; â€  9. September 1362) war ein englischer Kleriker, Jurist und von 1349 bis 1362 Erzbischof von Dublin.  Geboren wurde St Paul als Sohn von Thomas St Paul aus Owston in Yorkshire. Die Familie stammt ursprÃ¼nglich wohl aus Guyenne und war mit den Grafen Saint-Pol verwandtschaftlich verbunden.
