Juni 1339 Ã¼bernahm er zudem die Aufsicht Ã¼ber das Domus Conversorum. Im selben Jahr hatte er kurzfristig das Amt des Lord Keeper of the Great Seal inne. 1340 wurde ihm die Ehre zuteil, die Sitzung des englischen Parlaments zu erÃ¶ffnen. In dieser Zeit war er auch als Rechtsanwalt fÃ¼r verschiedene AngehÃ¶rige des britischen Adels wie etwa Marie de Saint-Pol tÃ¤tig. Zugleich beriet er den Prior der Kathedrale von Canterbury. Ab 1326 wurden St Paul zahlreiche PfrÃ¼nden verliehen. 1340 hatte er das Amt des Propstes von Wells inne. Seine Karriere erhielt einen DÃ¤mpfer, als KÃ¶nig Edward III. rigoros gegen Korruption in seinem Verwaltungsapparat vorging und zahlreiche Angestellte entlieÃŸ. Infolgedessen verlor St Paul nicht nur den Posten des Master of the Rolls, sondern wurde auch verhaftet und eingesperrt. Durch das Einschreiten des Erzbischofs von Canterbury John Stratford wurde er wieder freigelassen. St Paul kehrte zunÃ¤chst als einfacher Angestellter in die Kanzlei zurÃ¼ck. 1343 und 1349 Ã¼bernahm er wieder kurzzeitig die Rolle des Lord Keeper of the Great Seal. Ab 1344 gelang es ihm wiederum, seine PfrÃ¼nden auszubauen. Zwei Jahre spÃ¤ter Ã¼bernahm er mit dem Archidiakonat in Canterbury wieder ein kirchliches Amt. 1349 erhob ihn Papst Clemens VI. zum Erzbischof von Dublin. In seine Amtszeit fiel ein Streit mit der DiÃ¶zese von Armagh Ã¼ber deren erzbischÃ¶fliche Rechte. Diese wurden 1349 vom KÃ¶nig aufgehoben. 1351 erhielt St Paul von Papst Clemens VI. den Auftrag, gegen Ketzer vorzugehen, die aus dem Bistum Ossory nach Dublin geflohen waren. Am 20. Juli 1350 wurde St Paul zum Lordkanzler von Irland ernannt. Als solcher hatte er den Auftrag, Untersuchungen zu Korruption und Misswirtschaft in der Verwaltung Irlands durchzufÃ¼hren. Aus diesem Grund verfasste er zwei Berichte und deckte 1355 eine Unterschlagung von Geldern durch den irischen Schatzkanzler auf. Sein Amt gab er im Juli 1356 im Rahmen der Neuorganisation der Verwaltung auf. Er blieb jedoch weiterhin als Berater fÃ¼r die Krone tÃ¤tig. Am 9. September 1362 verstarb St Paul und wurde in der Christ Church Cathedral in Dublin beigesetzt.
English Bio:
John de St Paul (* 1295,   September 9, 1362 ) was an English cleric, lawyer and from 1349 to 1362 Archbishop of Dublin .

St Paul was born to Thomas St Paul from Owston , Yorkshire . The family originally came from Guyenne and was related to the counts Saint-Pol . Since his parents secretly married, he was until 1339 as an illegitimate descendant of his parents. His brother was Robert de St Paul, Lord of Byram.

Already before 1318 St Paul worked as a law clerk . In 1329 he took a job as a pastor in Lincoln . From 1334 he represented the Lord Keeper of the Great Seal in his absence and was on April 28, 1337 by Edward III. appointed Master of the Rolls . Two years later, on June 7, 1339 he also took over the supervision of the Domus Conversorum . In the same year he held the post of Lord Keeper of the Great Seal. In 1340 he was honored to open the session of the English Parliament . During this time he was also a lawyer for various members of the British nobility such asMarie de Saint-Pol . He also advised the Prior of Canterbury Cathedral . From 1326 St Paul were awarded numerous benefices . In 1340 he held the office of the provost of Wells . His career got a damper when King Edward III. rigorously against corruption in his administrative apparatus and dismissed many employees. As a result, St Paul not only lost the post of Master of the Rolls, but was also arrested and imprisoned. By the intervention of the archbishop of Canterbury John Stratfordhe was released. St Paul initially returned to the firm as a simple clerk. In 1343 and 1349 he took over again briefly the role of Lord Keeper of the Great Seal. From 1344 he succeeded again to expand his benefices. Two years later, he took over again with the Archdeacon in Canterbury a church office. 1349 raised him Pope Clement VI. to the Archbishop of Dublin . In his term fell a dispute with the diocese of Armagh on their archiepiscopal rights. These were lifted in 1349 by the king. In 1351 St Paul received from Pope Clement VI. the order to act against heretics , from the diocese of Ossory to Dublinhad fled. On July 20, 1350, St Paul was appointed Lord Chancellor of Ireland . As such, he was charged with investigating corruption and mismanagement in the Irish administration. For this reason, he wrote two reports and revealed in 1355 a misappropriation of funds by the Irish Chancellor. He gave his office in July 1356 as part of the reorganization of the administration. He continued to serve as a consultant to the Crown. On September 9, 1362 St Paul died and was buried in the Christ Church Cathedral in Dublin.

German Bio: Robert Waldby (auch Waldeby) (* um 1335; â€  27. Dezember 1397) war ein englischer Geistlicher. Er war Bischof von vier DiÃ¶zesen, zuletzt Erzbischof von York.  Robert Waldby stammte wahrscheinlich aus Yorkshire. Er war mit dem Prediger John Waldby (â€  1372) verwandt, der vermutlich ein Onkel oder Cousin von ihm war. Sehr unwahrscheinlich ist dagegen die gelegentlich angenommene These, dass John Waldby sein Bruder war. Ãœber Roberts Jugend ist nichts bekannt. Er trat in den Augustinerorden ein und empfing zwischen MÃ¤rz 1361 und MÃ¤rz 1362 im Gebiet des Erzbistums York die Priesterweihe. Vermutlich hatte er zuvor in Oxford studiert. 1382 wurde Waldby als Tholosanus bezeichnet, was vermuten lÃ¤sst, dass er auch in Toulose studiert hat, wohin 1365 Papst Urban V. die MÃ¶nche des Augustinerordens zum Studium hin geschickt hatte. Nach Angaben auf Waldbys Grabdenkmal hatte er Beziehungen zur Augustinerniederlassung in Tickhill. 1383 wurde er als Master der Theologie und als Theologieprofessor bezeichnet. Nach seinem Grabdenkmal hatte er auch rÃ¶misches Recht sowie mÃ¶glicherweise auch Medizin studiert. Am 1.Â April 1383 gehÃ¶rte er einer englischen Gesandtschaft nach AragÃ³n an und am 20.Â August 1389 wurde er zum Siegelbewahrer des Seneschalls von Aquitanien ernannt. Gelegentlich wird er auch als Kanzler von Aquitanien bezeichnet, was jedoch wohl ein MissverstÃ¤ndnis ist. Am 4.Â Juni 1386 ernannte ihn Papst Urban VI. fÃ¼r seine Dienste zum Bischof von Aire. Zeitweise wurde er auch als Bischof von Aire und St QuittiÃ¨re und fÃ¤lschlicherweise als Bischof von Sodor bezeichnet. WÃ¤hrend des GroÃŸen Schismas unterstÃ¼tzte das englisch besetzte Aquitanien die PÃ¤pste in Rom, wÃ¤hrend das gegnerische Frankreich die GegenpÃ¤pste in Avignon unterstÃ¼tzte. Da das Bistum Aire keine wohlhabende DiÃ¶zese war, erwarb Waldby 1388 die EinkÃ¼nfte von verschiedenen PfrÃ¼nden in Frankreich, die von der englischen Krone wÃ¤hrend des Kriegs beschlagnahmt worden waren. Nach der Inschrift auf seinem Grabdenkmal war er vielleicht der Leibarzt des KÃ¶nigs, was jedoch nicht gesichert ist. Durch die FÃ¶rderung des KÃ¶nigs wurde Waldby am 14.Â November 1390 zum Erzbischof von Dublin ernannt. Waldby besuchte seine neue DiÃ¶zese jedoch nicht, sondern erhielt am 30.Â Oktober 1391 von RichardÂ II. die lebenslange Erlaubnis, nicht nach Irland reisen zu mÃ¼ssen. Dennoch wurde er im Februar 1392 zum Kanzler von Irland ernannt, was im Juli des Jahres bestÃ¤tigt wurde. Im MÃ¤rz 1394 wurde ihm erneut erlaubt, trotz seiner Ã„mter in England zu bleiben. Als RichardÂ II. jedoch im Herbst 1394 zu einem Feldzug nach Irland aufbrach, begleitete Waldby den KÃ¶nig. 1395 wurde er kurzzeitig Siegelbewahrer des GroÃŸsiegels von Irland. 1395 gehÃ¶rte er zu den Gesandten, die nach Frankreich reisten, um mit dem franzÃ¶sischen KÃ¶nig Karl VI. Ã¼ber eine Heirat von RichardÂ II. mit der franzÃ¶sischen Prinzessin Isabelle zu verhandeln. Am 3.Â November 1395 wechselte Waldby erneut die DiÃ¶zese und wurde Bischof von Chichester. Obwohl er damit vom Erzbischof zum Bischof herabgestuft wurde, konnte er durch den Wechsel in engerem Kontakt zum KÃ¶nig bleiben. Dazu hatte er aus der DiÃ¶zese Chichester grÃ¶ÃŸere EinkÃ¼nfte als aus der irischen ErzdiÃ¶zese. Bereits am 5.Â Oktober 1396 wechselte Waldby erneut seine DiÃ¶zese, als er Erzbischof von York wurde. Angeblich stimmte das Kathedralkapitel von York gegen seine Ernennung, was jedoch nicht sicher bewiesen ist, doch dafÃ¼r gab es VorwÃ¼rfe wegen Simonie. Soweit bekannt ist, kam er nie nach York, sondern Ã¼berlieÃŸ die Verwaltung der ErzdiÃ¶zese seinem Generalvikar. Bei seinem Tod befand er sich in finanziellen Schwierigkeiten. Der KÃ¶nig erlaubte, dass er in Westminster Abbey bestattet wurde.[1]  Waldby war ein gelehrter Theologe, der aktiv Ketzerei und HÃ¤resie bekÃ¤mpfte. In seiner BÃ¼chersammlung befand sich auch ein Buch, das sich gegen die Lehren von Wyclif wandte. 1382 nahm er als Theologe an der Earthquake Synod in London teil, die unter Leitung von Erzbischof William Courtenay die Ideen von Wyclif und den Lollarden verdammte. 1392 nahm er an einer Synode in Stamford teil. 1391 wurde ihm und den anderen irischen BischÃ¶fen die Erlaubnis gegeben, ketzerische Prediger zu verhaften, wobei sich diese Erlaubnis vermutlich weniger gegen AnhÃ¤nger Wyclifs als gegen AnhÃ¤nger des Gegenpapstes Clemens VII. richtete. Seine Spende zur UnterstÃ¼tzung des Neubaus der Kapelle von University College in Oxford wurde in einer Fensterinschrift gewÃ¼rdigt. English Bio:
Robert Waldby (also Waldeby ) (* 1335,   27 December 1397 ) was an English clergyman. He was bishop of four dioceses, most recently Archbishop of York .

Robert Waldby probably came from Yorkshire . He was related to the preacher John Waldby (  1372), who was probably an uncle or cousin of his. Very unlikely, however, is the occasional hypothesis that John Waldby was his brother. Nothing is known about Robert's youth. He entered the Augustinian order and received the ordination from March 1361 to March 1362 in the area of __the Archbishopric of York. He had probably studied at Oxford before . In 1382 Waldby was called Tholosanus , which suggests that he also studied in Toulose , where 1365 Pope Urban V.the monks of the Augustinian Order had sent to study. According to Waldby's grave monument , he had relations with the Augustine branch in Tickhill . In 1383 he was called Master of Theology and professor of theology. After his grave monument he had also studied Roman law and possibly also medicine.

Waldby apparently served during the Hundred Years War the Black Prince as an official in Aquitaine . On April 1, 1383, he was an English delegation to Arag—n and on August 20, 1389 he was appointed Seal Keeper of the Seneschal of Aquitaine . Occasionally, he is also referred to as Chancellor of Aquitaine, which is probably a misunderstanding. On June 4, 1386 appointed him Pope Urban VI. for his services to the Bishop of Aire . At times he was also bishop of Aire and St Quittire and falsely as Bishop of Sodordesignated. During the Great Schism , English-speaking Aquitaine supported the popes in Rome, while the opposing France supported the counter- popes in Avignon . Since the Diocese of Aire was not a wealthy diocese, Waldby acquired in 1388 the income of various benefices in France, which had been confiscated by the English crown during the war.

By the late 1380s, Waldby was one of the close supporters of King Richard II. According to the inscription on his grave monument, he was perhaps the personal physician of the king, but this is not certain. Through the promotion of the king Waldby was appointed on 14 November 1390 Archbishop of Dublin . However, Waldby did not visit his new diocese, but received on October 30, 1391 Richard II. The lifelong permission not to have to travel to Ireland. Nevertheless, he was in February 1392 Chancellor of Irelandappointed, which was confirmed in July of the year. He remained further away from Ireland, but due to his office, he participated in 1392 several times in meetings of the royal council. In March 1394 he was again allowed to remain in England despite his duties. However, when Richard II set out on a campaign to Ireland in the autumn of 1394, Waldby accompanied the king. In 1395 he was briefly Seal Keeper of the Seal of Ireland. In 1395 he was one of the ambassadors who traveled to France to meet with the French King Charles VI. to negotiate a marriage of Richard II with the French Princess Isabelle . On 3 November 1395 Waldby changed again the diocese and became Bishop of Chichester, Although he was thus downgraded by the archbishop to the bishop, he could remain by the change in closer contact with the king. For this he had from the Diocese of Chichester greater income than from the Irish Archdiocese. As early as October 5, 1396 Waldby changed again his diocese, when he became archbishop of York. Allegedly, the cathedral chapter of York voted against his appointment, which is not proven, but there were allegations of simony . As far as is known, he never came to York, but left the administration of the archdiocese to his vicar general . However, he died about a year later, probably in London, possibly in Gloucester, as a result of a shin fracture. At his death, he was in financial trouble. The king allowed him to be buried in Westminster Abbey . [1]

Waldby was a learned theologian who actively opposed heresy and heresy . There was also a book in his book collection that turned against the teachings of Wyclif . In 1382 he participated as a theologian in the Earthquake Synod in London, which condemned under the leadership of Archbishop William Courtenay the ideas of Wyclif and the Lollards . In 1392 he participated in a synod in Stamford. In 1391, he and the other Irish bishops were given permission to arrest heretical preachers, though this presumption was probably less against Wycliffe's supporters than against supporters of the antipope Clement VII.taught. His donation to support the construction of the new college chapel at University College , Oxford was honored in a window inscription. Since there are no scriptures preserved by Waldby, however, his influence on the English church of the late 14th century can not be proven.

English Bio:
M‡ed—c of Ferns (* presumably before 550 in Temple port , County Cavan ;   627 presumably in Ferns , County Wexford ) [2] is the founder of the convent in Ferns and is considered the first of the Bishop diocese Ferns . In the hagiographies from 1200 onwards , he is worshiped under the name M‡ed—g , a form of name derived from Aid‡n or çedh, prefixed by the adoring prefix mo (translated: "mine") and the diminutive —g as a suffixwhich emphasizes the youthfulness of the name bearer. [3] He is considered the patron of the diocese and of Ferns. [4] His feast day is January 31. [5]

In addition to the annals of the four masters , the Annals, which mention Aid‡n's death, also include the Annals of Ulster , [6] the Annals of Tigernach, [7] and the Chronicon Scotorum . [8] By confusion with M‡ed—g Clonmore emerged in the Annals of Tigernach and the Chronicon Scotorum However, entries that refer to a too late year of death. [9] Both the martyrology of Tallaght and the Martyriologie of Oengus , both originated from 828 to 833, [10] call Aidan for January 31.[11] [5] The martyrology of the Oengus has extensive glosses , which give Aid‡n information about his noble origin andidentifyhim as a disciple of David of Menevia . [12]

The earliest surviving hagiography of Aid‡n was written around 1200, which is probably a translation into Latin from an original Irish version, which is no longer preserved. At the time of origin of the Irish original version, there are different assumptions. Some assume that it was built in the 11th century during the reign of the then King of Leinster M‡el na mB— (1042-1072). [13] î Riain, however, recognizes in the text some Augustinian references and therefore dates this to the middle or second half of the 12th century. [14] The motivation for the text was probably in the interest of the importance of Ferns compared to rivals in Clonmore (now inCounty Carlow ). [15] To this effect also added, that one of the M‡ed—g Clonmore associated stories was incorporated into the Hagiografie for Aidan. [16] The earliest surviving text probably originated in Monmouth and Brecon in Wales as part of a collection of Welsh saint and is in the British Library held. [17]

From this Vita derived more texts. Are received u. a. a 13th-century text in Brussels, [18] a 15th-century manuscript in the Primate Marsh's Library , [19] a very similar text from Trinity College [20] , also from the same period, and two around 1350 and 1400 resulting manuscripts in Oxford . [21]

Aid‡n, son of Setna, belonged to the clan of U’ Meic Uais, one of the ruling families of the Oriel kingdom . [22] His mother Eithne came from the clan of the U’ Amalgai that in today for County Mayo were home belonging area. [23] He was born in Port Island in the community of Templeport , County Cavan . As usual with ruling families back then, he probably grew up with foster parents and then came to Menevia in southern Wales at an early age , which at that time was under the control of the area aroundWaterford- originating clans of DŽisi. [24] This was Aidan one among many Irish who were trained there. Numerous Vitae refer to it as those of Finian von Clonard or Brendan von Clonfert . [25] Presumably closed Aidan his training with the ordination into Menevia. [26]

Then Aid‡n returned to Ireland, apparently first near the present Ardamine in the north of County Wexford . There and in numerous other places in the southwest of Ireland church foundations are attributed to him. Likewise in his home in Drumlane and Rossinver , County Leitrim . His most important foundation should be that of Ferns. The Vitae emphasize the close connection between Aid‡n and Brandubh, the then King of Leinster , but this may also be due to the authors' attempt to increase Aid‡n's rank. [27]But the connection is also seen as a sign of the giving and taking that developed in his time between the ruler and the founder of the monastery, who gives the land to the rulers and expects his salvation to be saved. [28]

It can be assumed that Aid‡n led the monastic community in Ferns similar to what was usual with David, who adopted the principle of the ora et labora , which included heavy field work. The Vitae report how he sows barley , grinds wheat and orchards. Also the livestock with cattle and sheep is mentioned. [27]

Aid‡n's place of death is controversial, with both Ferns and Rossinver claiming it, but Ferns is more likely. His tomb is unknown. [29]

The worship of Aidan certainly began in Ferns immediately after his death. Its importance, however, increased only with the spread of his Vitae from the 12th century. [31] In addition to January 31, other sites of worship are common at some sites. So is his to St. Edan's well in Clongeen thought on May 15, in Kilnahue is Maodh—g's day celebrated on 15 August, a tradition from the 17th century called January 3 (for a memorial in Rossinver although this be a typo In Wales, Aid‡n is also worshiped on 28th February. The feast day of Aidan is also mentioned in a hagiography of Fintan in Rheinau .[32] Aid‡n is also mentioned in hagiographies for other saints. For example, Rhigyfarch's Vita by David dates back to 1090 and also mentions Aid‡n as a student. [33] A summary of the CV appeared in the Nova Legenda Anglie of John of Tynemouth . [34]

Both the Cathedral of the Diocese of Cashel and Ossory of the Church of Ireland, which is still in Ferns, and the Cathedral of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Ferns , relocated to Enniscorthy , are dedicated to Aid‡n. Other churches dedicated to him in County Wexford include Ardamine, Clone, Clongeen, Coolhull and Kilnahue. [35] In Halwyn , Cornwall , was erected in his honor in 1313 a chapel that has not survived. [36] In Pembrokeshire there are also some Madocbut it is not clear whether they refer to Aid‡n or a Welsh saint of the same name, who then moved on to Cornwall and possibly Brittany . [37]

Aus Bernhards Ehe mit Heilwig von Are-Hochstaden (* 1150, â€  1196), Tochter des Grafen Otto von Are-Hochstaden, gingen folgende Kinder hervor:
English Bio:
Bernhard II to the lip (* 1140 at Lipperode Castle ,   1224 in Mesothen ) was the founder of the country's Lippe rule and the planned cities Lippstadt and Lemgo . He entered after 1194 in the Cistercian monastery Marienfeld , was around 1210 abbot in the monastery DŸnamŸnde and 1218 Bishop of Selonien .

Bernhard II was the son of Hermann I and the nephew Bernhard I , who were first referred to as "Noble to the lip". He developed in the course of his life to one of the most important and influential Westphalian personalities of the Staufer period . He probably owes all the sovereign rights and special rights of the "Lords of the Lippe".

The Years Before the Saxon War (1140-1177) 
Bernhard II visited before taking office in 1167 probably the cathedral school in Hildesheim (there are no exact sources), where he later worked as a canon . The training he received at this school outstripped those of other noblemen of his day. In 1163 he was called back to the lip after the death of his older brother Heinrich. He received a befitting chivalric training, probably partly at the court of Henry the Lion in Brunswick , and was knighted .

The reign in Lippe he took over after the death of his father Hermann I and his brother Bernhard I in the army of Emperor Frederick I before Rome . The possession existed at this time already from the original possession of the family near the today's city Lippstadt as well as large parts of the country Lippe. He married in 1167 Heilwig, Countess of Are , who belonged to the Rhenish nobility and was related in further relationship with the House of Staufer. The uncle of his wife, Friedrich von Ahre , was at that time bishop of MŸnster (1152-1168) and became a good friend of the young nobleman. About Friedrich von Ahre and about his cousin, Herrmann von Ahre , theAbbot of the monastery Cappenberg , existed relatively close connections with the archbishop of Cologne , Philip I von Heinsberg , who was Bernhard's feudal lord .

The Saxon War 
The period from 1177 to 1181 was marked by the Saxon War , in which the differences of opinion of the Saxon Duke Henry the Lion and the Cologne Archbishop Philipp von Heinsberg culminated. Despite his close ties and the proximity to Cologne Bernhard II fought together with his cousin Widukind von Rheda as a follower of Henry the Lion in Westphalia and so also drew the enmity of his lord and most other nobles of Westphalia. During the war Bernhard II became one of Henry's closest companions to the lion. At the same time, however, he also cultivated his good relations with the new bishop of MŸnster, Hermann II.who became a close advisor to Emperor Barbarossa during his term of office (1173 to 1202) from about 1180 and thus became an important mediator for Bernhard II after the end of the war.

From 1179 onwards Bernhard II destroyed the possessions of the archbishop of Cologne in his near surroundings. Above all, the just under construction Medebach was destroyed. The city of Soest was able to fend off an attack due to the newly built city walls. Following this, Bernhard's troops turned in support of the Saxon army under the leadership of Count Gunzelin of Schwerin in northern Westphalia against a united army of allied with the Cologne princes, the bishop of OsnabrŸck and the counts of Tecklenburg and Ravensburg , whom the counts of Arnsberg and the Counts of Schwalenbergcame to help. The winner of this battle on the Halerfeld , ten kilometers from OsnabrŸck, remained the Saxon army.

After this battle, however, were in the course of a thrust of Cologne against the followers of Henry 1177 the center of the possessions Bernhard II, the former market district near the Lippe ford (now Nicolaiviertel in Lippstadt) and the former Nicolaikirche and its castle destroyed. Bernhard II himself was expelled and fled to the court of Henry the Lion. About him Bernhard II learned the basics of urban planning, especially the hydraulic engineering know. His impressions he collected in Brunswick and Hildesheim , later in the defense and expansion of the city Neuhaldensleben near Magdeburg . He defended until 1181 the fortress of the Duke in Haldenslebenwhich was besieged by troops of Emperor Barbarossa. He had to give up this fortress when the opponents congested the river Ehre and thus submerged the fortress. Bernhard II and his entourage were free to leave.

The years between 1181 and 1184 
Henry the Lion was ostracized in 1180 on the court day at Gelnhausen and had to leave Germany. From this point on, the tradition of the life of Bernard II breaks off and begins again in 1184. The current version of his return to the Lippe faces a version by the historian Paul Leidinger , who assumes that Bernhard II accompanied the Saxon Duke into exile at the English royal court in Normandy . From there, he returned in the opinion of Leidingers back in 1184 and met on his Hoftag in Cologne on the Cologne Archbishop and new Duke of Westphalia Philipp von Heinsberg.

Leidinger justified his presentation of the story by the fact that for the time in question sources about Widukind of Rheda exist, which had never separated from Bernhard II. Especially the document for the foundation of the monastery Marienfeld indicates the separation of the two friends. In addition, a relief of the Lippstadt Marienkirche obviously shows Bernhard II on a pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela , which he allegedly undertook with Henry the Lion.

The return of Bernhard II and the foundation of Lippstadt 
At the time of Bernhard II's return, the former Marktviertel on the Lippe had probably been rebuilt. Although Bernhard had always fought on the side of Henry the Lion in the previous battles, he came to the then very rare privilege to build a city in the center of his possessions with the permission of Emperor Barbarossa. These were returned to him in the course of clarifications with Philipp von Heinsberg.

Perhaps Bernhard II met at Pentecost 1184 at the Imperial Festival in Mainz with Barbarossa. For the festival of the sword-lead of the imperial sons, the entire nobility of the country gathered with retinue; According to different sources between 20,000 and 70,000 people are said to have been gathered. After a storm, however, the festival was already canceled on Whit Monday, and the emperor retired with his entourage to Gelnhausen . According to a tradition of the poet Justinus Lippiensis , the life of Bernard II later in his as Lippiflorum ( Lippische Rose, after the coat of arms of the gentleman to the lip) named work reflected, Bernhard II was also on this feast. He is said to have attracted attention of the Emperor by his noble demeanor and to have been asked by him to express a wish. Bernhard's wish was to build a city on the lip, and Barbarossa should have granted him that wish. This story is certainly a bit flowery, but there is little doubt about the imperial permission to found a city. It was probably thanks to the Emperor's advisor, Bishop Hermann II of MŸnster, that this happened, and he was probably also instrumental in mediating with the Archbishop of Cologne.

Bernhard II founded in 1185 (according to other sources already 1184) the city of Lippe (now Lippstadt in the district of Soest ) as the first planned city of Westphalia. After her model he founded in 1190 as the second city in the country Lippe Lemgo. During this time Bernhard II was also involved in the founding of the monastery Marienfeld (founded in 1185).

His friend Widukind of Rheda took part in 1189 with Emperor Barbarossa at the Third Crusade and died on this. As Widukinds heir Bernhard received the rule over Rheda, and he was transferred to the bailiwick of the monasteries Liesborn and Freckenhorst .

Around 1192 Bernhard II obtained the permission to build within the episcopal Forstbanngebietes the Falkenburg on Falkenberg, with all rights between the bishopric Paderborn and him were divided. Became incapacitated by an illness Bernhard in 1194 handed over the rule of his son Hermann II (* 1170) and then went as a monk in the Cistercian monastery founded by him in 1185 Marienfeld. Around 1210 he became Abbot in DŸnamŸnde and finally from 1218 to 1224 Bishop of Selonien in the Baltic States . Bernhard II died at the end of April 1224, probably in Selburg, the capital of his diocese, or in Mesoythen. He was buried in the monastery of DŸnamŸnde .

The saga of the punishment of God 
Tradition has it Bernhard in the time of his exercise of power by robbing and burning his subjects have done a great deal wrong. For this, God punished him with lameness on both feet. The penitent Bernhard then humbly went into the care and care of Cistercian monks and had become because of his healing himself also Cistercian monk. [1]

The coat anecdote 
Modern bŠnkelsŠnger tell the coat anecdote of Bernhard from Lipperland. According to this Bernhard should have come too late to a party. [2] As no seats were available, Bernhard and his entourage sat on their coats. After the meeting, they left their coats. When asked why they left the coats, he replied that it was not common in Lipperland to take the chairs with them. The next day, he is said to have been given seating by the Emperor (Barbarossa) himself.

Name: Lambert  â€  zwischen und Semgallen und Selonien danach nur noch Semgallen
German Bio: Lambert (lateinisch Lambertus, lettisch Lamberts; â€  zwischen 1227 und 1234) war der zweite Bischof von Semgallen und Selonien im heutigen Lettland.  Lambert kam mÃ¶glicherweise aus Solre im Hennegau, heute an der belgisch-franzÃ¶sischen Grenze. Sein VorgÃ¤nger Bernhard zur Lippe war 1218 zum ersten Bischof fÃ¼r Selonien und Semgallen ernannt worden, ob er jemals tatsÃ¤chlich in diesem Gebiet tÃ¤tig war, ist unklar.[1] Dieser starb im FrÃ¼hjahr 1224. Ende jenen Jahres wurde eine BestÃ¤tigungsurkunde fÃ¼r die Grenzen des Bistums Selonien durch Papst Honorius III. ausgestellt.[2] Der Bischof wurde nicht mit Namen genannt, es kÃ¶nnte bereits Lambert gewesen sein. In den Jahren 1225 und 1226 erschien er mehrmals als Zeuge in Urkunden in Riga. Im April jenen Jahres trat er Selonien als Bistumsgebiet an Bischof Albert von Riga ab und erhielt ganz Semgallen von diesem zugewiesen.[3] Auch von Lambert sind keine Informationen Ã¼ber eine TÃ¤tigkeit oder einen Aufenthalt in seinem Bistum Ã¼berliefert.[4] 1227 war er als Begleitung des Legaten Wilhelm von Modena in Livland unterwegs.  1232 wurde erstmals Balduin als neuer Bischof von Semgallen genannt, 1234 wurde Lambert als verstorben bezeichnet. Von ihm ist ein Siegel als Bischof von Selonien erhalten.
English Bio:
Lambert (Latin Lambertus , Latvian Lamberts ;   interlocutory 1227 and 1234 ) was the second Bishop of Semgallen and Selonien in today's Latvia .

Lambert may have come from Solre in Hainaut , today at the Belgian-French border. His predecessor Bernhard zur Lippe had been appointed the first bishop for Selonia and Semgallen in 1218, whether he ever actually worked in this area is unclear. [1] He died in the spring of 1224. end of that year was a confirmation certificate for the boundaries of the diocese Selonien by Pope Honorius III. displayed. [2] The bishop was not called by name, it could already have been Lambert. In 1225 and 1226 he appeared several times as a witness in documents in Riga . In April of that year he joined Seloni as a diocesan territory to Bishop Albert of Rigafrom and received all of Semgallen assigned by this. [3] Also from Lambert are any information about an activity or a stay handed in his diocese. In 1227 he was traveling in Livonia as an escort of legate William of Modena .

In 1232 Balduin was first mentioned as the new bishop of Semgallen, in 1234 Lambert was described as deceased. From him a seal is preserved as Bishop of Selonien.

Name: Arnold, O.Cist. â€  frÃ¼hestens 1246â€“1247
German Bio: Arnold von Semgallen SOCist (* um 1200; â€  nach 1261) war 1246 bis 1247 Bischof von Semgallen und danach Auxiliarbischof im Rheinland.  Arnold gehÃ¶rte dem Zisterzienserorden an und wurde 1246 Bischof des livlÃ¤ndischen Bistums Semgallen, das im heutigen Erzbistum Kaunas aufging. Er wurde offenbar durch die kriegerischen Auseinandersetzungen in seinem Bistum von dort vertrieben und erhielt 1247 in Heinrich von LÃ¼tzelburg einen Amtsnachfolger, von dem man aber nicht weiÃŸ, ob er sich je in seinem Sprengel aufhielt.  Arnold von Semgallen ging in den Westen Deutschlands und betÃ¤tigte sich in den rheinischen DiÃ¶zesen KÃ¶ln, Mainz, Trier und LÃ¼ttich als Weihbischof. Zwischen 1247 und 1261 taucht er hier hÃ¤ufig urkundlich auf, besonders bei der Erteilung von AblÃ¤ssen.[1] 1247 weihte er im Beisein von Erzbischof Konrad von Hochstaden und vieler hoher KirchenfÃ¼rsten die Basilika St. Kunibert zu KÃ¶ln,[2] im gleichen Jahr einen Altar im Kloster Marienstatt und am 26. September 1257 den Hochaltar der KÃ¶lner St. Lupuskirche.[3]  1248 nahm er an der Wahl des GegenkÃ¶nigs Wilhelm von Holland teil; Papst Innozenz IV. bedankte sich bei ihm und seinen MitbrÃ¼dern ausdrÃ¼cklich fÃ¼r die dadurch gehabten MÃ¼hen.[4]  1253 war Arnold von Semgallen Mitkonsekrator der Klosterkirche Morimond, am 10. Mai 1254 weihte er die damals im Mainzer Erzbistum gelegene Abteikirche Otterberg.[5][6]  Mit Datum vom 14. Mai 1261 gewÃ¤hrte Arnold von Semgallen als Generalvikar des erwÃ¤hlten LÃ¼tticher Bischofs Heinrich III. von Geldern AblÃ¤sse fÃ¼r das Karmeliterkloster KÃ¶ln. Damit tritt er letztmals urkundlich in Erscheinung und nennt sich hierbei â€žehemaliger Bischof von Semgallenâ€œ. Ãœber sein Todesdatum bzw. die -umstÃ¤nde ist nichts bekannt.[7]
English Bio:
Arnold of Semgallen SOCist (* 1200,   after 1261) was from 1246 to 1247 Bishop of Semgallen and then Auxiliary Bishop in the Rhineland.

Arnold belonged to the Cistercian Order and in 1246 became bishop of the Livonian diocese of Semgallen, which was absorbed in the archdiocese of Kaunas today . He was evidently expelled from there by the warlike conflicts in his diocese and received in 1247 in Heinrich von LŸtzelburg an office successor, but of whom one does not know whether he was ever in his parish.

Arnold von Semgallen went to the west of Germany and worked in the Rhenish dioceses of Cologne , Mainz , Trier and Lige as Auxiliary Bishop . Between 1247 and 1261, he often appears here in documents, especially in the issue of indulgences . [1] in 1247 he consecrated in the presence of Archbishop Konrad von Hochstaden and many high prelates of the Basilica of St. Kunibert of Cologne , [2] in the same year an altar in the monastery Marie Instead , and on 26 September 1257 the high altar of Cologne's St. Lupus Church .[3]

In 1248 he took part in the election of the antagonist William of Holland ; Pope Innocent IV expressly thanked him and his confreres for their efforts. [4]

In 1253, Arnold von Semgallen was co- consecrator of the monastery church of Morimond . On May 10, 1254, he consecrated the abbey church Otterberg, which was then located in the Mainz Archdiocese . [5] [6]

With date of May 14, 1261 granted Arnold of Semgallen as Vicar General of the chosen Liege Bishop Henry III. from Geldern indulgences for the Karmeliterkloster Cologne . With this he appears for the last time in documentary form and calls himself "former bishop of Semgallen". About his date of death or the circumstances nothing is known. [7]

Name: Heinrich von LÃ¼tzelburg, O.F.M. â€  1247â€“1251 auch Bischof von Kurland, Bischof von Chiemsee
German Bio: Heinrich von LÃ¼tzelburg OFM (â€  8. Februar 1274) war 1247 bis 1251 Bischof von Semgallen, 1251 bis 1263 Bischof von Kurland und 1263 bis 1274 Bischof von Chiemsee.  Heinrich, dessen Geburtsjahr nicht bekannt ist, entstammte dem Geschlecht der LÃ¼tzelburger und gehÃ¶rte dem Orden der Franziskaner an. Im Dezember 1247 Ã¼bertrug Papst Innozenz IV. Heinrich von LÃ¼tzelburg das livlÃ¤ndische Bistum Semgallen. Die Bischofsweihe sollte im pÃ¤pstlichen Auftrag durch den Erzbischof von PreuÃŸen, Livland und Estland, Albert Suerbeer, erfolgen. Nachdem dieser dem Auftrag nicht nachkam, wurde Heinrich von seinem Onkel, dem Mainzer Erzbischof Siegfried III. von Eppstein in Mainz geweiht. Es ist nicht bekannt, ob sich Heinrich je in Semgallen aufgehalten hat. FÃ¼r 1249 ist jedenfalls ein Aufenthalt in Petershausen bei Konstanz belegt, wo er einen Altar weihte. Im selben Jahr konsekrierte er zwei AltÃ¤re in der Kirche von Zoffingen bei Bern und erteilte auf der KÃ¤stenburg den Zisterzienserinnen des Klosters Lichtenthal AblÃ¤sse.  Nachdem das Bistum Semgallen am 3. MÃ¤rz 1251 aufgehoben und dem Erzbistum Riga zugeschlagen worden war, erhielt Heinrich von Papst Innozenz IV. das vakante Bistum Kurland. Dort sollte er u.Â a. zusammen mit dem Bischof von Ã–sel die Einhaltung des pÃ¤pstlichen Schutzversprechens Ã¼berwachen, das dem litauischen GroÃŸfÃ¼rsten Mindowe abgegeben wurde. In Absprache mit Gunther von WÃ¼llersleben, dem Hochmeister des Deutschen Ordens, grÃ¼ndete Heinrich die Burg Memel, die als Bischofssitz dienen sollte. Nach der Teilung Kurlands lieÃŸ er vom Hochmeister die Grenzen seines Sprengels festlegen und begab sich, vermutlich in Begleitung des Bischofs von Ã–sel nach Nordwestdeutschland und Frankreich. Belegt sind Aufenthalte in LÃ¼beck und Sens, wo er Verhandlungen mit dem livlÃ¤ndischen Hochmeister des Deutschen Ordens fÃ¼hrte. Im FrÃ¼hjahr 1255 setzte er sich in Hachenborn in Hessen fÃ¼r einen Wiederaufbau des abgebrannten Augustiner-Frauenklosters ein. Im April 1257 war er in seiner DiÃ¶zese und sollte im selben Jahr im Auftrag des Papstes Alexander IV. in Livland als Prediger fÃ¼r den Kreuzzug werben. Zusammen mit dem livlÃ¤ndischen Ordensmeister Burkhard von Hornhausen regelte er 1258 in Memel die Pfarrorganisation der dem Orden unterworfenen Teile Kurlands. Vermutlich wegen des Kurenaufstandes und EinfÃ¤lle der Litauer verlieÃŸ er nach der Schlacht an der Durbe 1260 seine DiÃ¶zese. Jedenfalls ist sein Aufenthalt im selben Jahr in KÃ¶ln bezeugt, als er dort die Kirche des Minoritenklosters konsekrierte. Mit einer undatierten Urkunde, die vermutlich 1262 ausgestellt worden war, bestÃ¤tigte er dem Domkapitel von Riga dessen Besitzungen, um die es spÃ¤ter immer wieder zu Streitigkeiten kam.  Obwohl das Recht der Ernennung und Investitur der BischÃ¶fe von Chiemsee dem Salzburger Erzbischof zustand, ernannte Papst Urban IV. nach dem Tod des Chiemseer Bischofs Heinrich am 13. Februar 1263 Heinrich von LÃ¼tzelburg zu dessen Nachfolger. Die Einmischung des Papstes war wegen des damals herrschenden Salzburger Kirchenstreits, bei dem es um den Elekten Philipp von Spanheim ging, gerechtfertigt. Zwar wandte sich Heinrich nicht gegen Philipp von Spanheim, unterstÃ¼tzte jedoch Wladislaw von Schlesien, der 1267 von seinem frÃ¼heren Hofmeister und nunmehrigen Bischof von Passau Petrus unter Assistenz Heinrichs geweiht wurde. An der im selben Jahr erfolgten AussÃ¶hnung mit Philipp von Spanheim war auch Heinrich beteiligt.  Von Heinrichs Amtshandlungen ist bekannt, dass er 1267 im Zisterzienserkloster Raitenhaslach den Altar in der Kapelle der Heiligen Simon und Judas ThaddÃ¤us weihte und 1268 der Pfarrei Pillersee die bisherigen Privilegien bestÃ¤tigte. 1271 gewÃ¤hrte er AblÃ¤sse fÃ¼r den Dominikusaltar in der Kirche des Frauenklosters Lienz, fÃ¼r den Bau der Kirche in Heiligenblut und fÃ¼r die Maria-Magdalena-Kapelle in Ridnaun, die durch ein Feuer zerstÃ¶rt worden war.  Heinrich von LÃ¼tzelburg starb am 8. Februar 1274. Sein Leichnam wurde vermutlich in der Klosterkirche Herrenchiemsee beigesetzt.  RÃ¼diger von Bergheim-RadeckÂ | AlbertÂ | Albert Suerbeer (Administrator)Â | Heinrich von Bilversheim (Administrator)Â | HeinrichÂ | Heinrich von LÃ¼tzelburgÂ | Johann von EnnsthalÂ | Konrad von HimbergÂ | Friedrich von FronauÂ | Adalbert von FohnsdorfÂ | Ulrich von MontpreisÂ | Konrad von LiechtensteinÂ | Gerhoh von WaldeckÂ | Hugo von SchÃ¤rfenbergÂ | Ludwig RadlkofenÂ | FriedrichÂ | Georg von NeubergÂ | Eckart von PerneggÂ | Engelmar ChrelÂ | Friedrich DeysÂ | Johann EbserÂ | Silvester PfliegerÂ | Ulrich von PlankenfelsÂ | Bernhard von KraiburgÂ | Georg AltdorferÂ | Ludwig Ebmer
English Bio:
Heinrich von LŸtzelburg OFM (  8 February 1274 ) was from 1247 to 1251 Bishop of Semgallen , 1251 to 1263 Bishop of Courland and 1263 to 1274 Bishop of Chiemsee .

Heinrich, whose birth year is unknown, came from the LŸtzelburg family and belonged to the Order of the Franciscans . In December 1247, Pope Innocent IV of Henry LŸtzelburg transferred the Livonian diocese of Zemgale. The episcopal ordination should be on behalf of the papal order of the Archbishop of Prussia , Livonia and Estonia , Albert Suerbeer . After this did not fulfill the order, Heinrich was of his uncle, the Archbishop of Mainz Siegfried III. from Eppstein in Mainzconsecrated. It is not known if Henry ever stayed in Semgallen. In any case, for 1249 a stay in Petershausen near Konstanz is occupied, where he consecrated an altar. In the same year he consecrated two altars in the church of Zoffingen near Bern and gave at the KŠsten castle the Cistercian nuns of the monastery Lichtenthal indulgences .

After the diocese of Semigall was repealed on March 3, 1251 and added to the Archdiocese of Riga , received by Henry of Pope Innocent IV, the vacant diocese of Courland . There he should u. a. supervise, together with the Bishop of …sel, the observance of the papal vow made to the Lithuanian Grand Duke Mindowe . In agreement with Gunther von WŸllersleben , the Grand Master of the Teutonic Order , Henry founded the castle Memel , which was to serve as a bishopric. After the division of Kurlandhe had the Grand Master set the boundaries of his brig and went, probably accompanied by the Bishop of Osel to Northwest Germany and France. Occupations are documented in LŸbeck and Sens , where he negotiated with the Livonian Grand Master of the Teutonic Order. In the spring of 1255 he sat down in Hachenborn in Hesse for a reconstruction of the burned Augustinian nunnery. In April 1257 he was in his diocese and was to promote in the same year on behalf of Pope Alexander IV in Livonia as a preacher for the crusade . Together with the Livonian Master of the Order Burkhard von Hornhausenhe regulated in 1258 in Memel the parish organization of the religious subjects of Kurland. Presumably because of the Kuren Rebellion and incursions of the Lithuanians he left after the Battle of Durbe in 1260 his diocese. In any case, his stay in the same year in Cologne is attested when he consecrated there the church of the Minorite monastery. With an undated document, which was probably issued in 1262, he confirmed the Domkapitel of Riga whose possessions, around which it came again and again to disputes.

Although the right of appointment and investiture of the bishops of Chiemsee was the Archbishop of Salzburg, Pope Urban IV appointed after the death of the Chiemsee Bishop Henry on 13 February 1263 Heinrich von LŸtzelburg his successor. The intervention of the pope was justified because of the then prevailing Salzburg church dispute, which was about the Elekten Philipp von Spanheim , justified. Although Henry did not turn against Philipp von Spanheim, but supported Vladislav of Silesia , in 1267 by his former courtmaster and now bishop of Passau Peterwas consecrated under the assistance of Henry. Heinrich also took part in the reconciliation with Philipp von Spanheim in the same year.

From Henry's official acts it is known that in 1267 in the Cistercian monastery Raitenhaslach he consecrated the altar in the chapel of Saints Simon and Judas ThaddŠus and in 1268 the parish Pillersee confirmed the previous privileges. In 1271 he granted indulgences for the Dominican altar in the church of the Lienz nunnery , for the construction of the church in Heiligenblut and for the Maria Magdalena chapel in Ridnaun , which had been destroyed by fire.

Heinrich von LŸtzelburg died on February 8, 1274. His body was probably buried in the monastery church Herrenchiemsee .

English Bio:
Georg Radziwill (Polish Jerzy Radziwi__ , born May 31, 1556 in Vilnius , Lithuania ,   January 21, 1600 in Rome , German Georg Radziwill , Lithuanian also Jurgis Radvila ) was a cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church .

Radziwi__s parents were Miko_aj "Czarny" Radziwi__ and El_bieta Szyd_owiecka. He studied in Leipzig and Rome.

On December 17, 1574 he was appointed Coadjutor Bishop of Archdiocese Willna and was on December 31, 1579 successor of Walerian Protasewicz as Bishop of Willna, who died on the same day; he became governor ( namiestnik ) of Livonia . On April 10, 1583, he received the sacrament of Holy Orders from Bishop Cyprian Wilinski, OP to the auxiliary bishop in Vilnius .

On December 12, 1583 appointed him Pope Gregory XIII. to the College of Cardinals . Cardinal Alberto Bolognetti received the episcopal consecration on January 6, 1573, Apostolic Nuncio to Poland, with co- consecrators Melchior Giedroyc, Bishop of _emaitija (Zmudz) ( Lithuania ) and Bishop Cyprian Wilinski, who had already ordained him as a priest. The solemn installation of the cardinal priest in his titular church San Sistoin Rome took place on July 14, 1586. On August 9, 1591, he was appointed Bishop of Krakow and introduced on May 25, 1592 in the Wawel Cathedral of his diocese.

In 1592 Radziwi__ became advisor to King Sigismund III. Wasa from Poland .

Bernard Maciejowski wurde 1586 zum Priester geweiht und am 8. Juni 1587 zum Bischof von Åuck bestellt. Die Konsekration fand am 24. Januar 1588 durch den Erzbischof von Gnesen StanisÅ‚aw Karnkowski statt. Am 23. Mai 1600 wurde er zum Bischof von Krakau bestellt. Am 9. Juni 1604 wurde er von Papst Clemens VIII. zum Kardinal kreiert und am 7. Januar 1605 als Kardinalpriester in San Giovanni a Porta Latina installiert. Am 31. English Bio:
Bernard Maciejowski (* 1548 in Ma_opolska , Poland ,   January 19, 1608 in Krakow ) was Cardinal , Archbishop of Gniezno and Primate of Poland .

Bernard Maciejowski was ordained a priest in 1586 and appointed Bishop of _uck on June 8, 1587 . The consecration took place on 24 January 1588 by the Archbishop of Gniezno Stanis_aw Karnkowski . On May 23, 1600 he was appointed bishop of Krakow . On June 9, 1604, he was created Cardinal by Pope Clement VIII and installed on January 7, 1605 as a cardinal priest in San Giovanni a Porta Latina . On July 31, 1606 he became Archbishop of Gniezno and Primate of Poland.

Name: Johannes Strote OP Weihbischof in KÃ¶ln
German Bio:
Johann Strote (  1350) war Weihbischof in Kšln.

†ber Johannes Strote ist nur bekannt, dass er am 5. MŠrz 1327 von Papst Johannes XXII. Zum Orden der Dominikaner gehšrte. wurde zum Titularbischof von Scopiensis und Weihbischof in Kšln ernannt und starb 1350. [1]
English Bio:
Johann Strote (  1350 ) was Auxiliary Bishop in Cologne .

About Johannes Strote is only known that he belonged to the Order of the Dominicans , on 5 March 1327 by Pope John XXII. was appointed Titular Bishop of Scopiensis and Auxiliary Bishop in Cologne and died in 1350. [1]

Name: Johannes Kaiode OESA
German Bio:
Johannes Kaiode (  vor dem 22. Oktober 1354) war Weihbischof in Kšln.

Der Augustiner wurde am 14. MŠrz 1352 in Kšln zum Titularbischof von Skopje und Weihbischof ernannt.
English Bio:
Johannes Kaiode (  before October 22, 1354 ) was Auxiliary Bishop in Cologne .

The Augustinian was appointed Titular Bishop of Skopje and Auxiliary Bishop in Cologne on March 14, 1352 , but died before October 22, 1354. [1]

Name: Johannes von Sieberg OCist Weihbischof in KÃ¶ln
German Bio:
Johann (es) von Syberg OCist auch John von Sieberg (Siegburg) (  30. September oder 1. Oktober 1383 - nach anderen Quellen: Ende September 1366 - in Altenberg) war Weihbischof in Kšln.

Johann (es) stammte aus der Kšlner Patrizierfamilie aus Syberg. [2] Der Mšnch der Zisterzienserabtei Altenberg wird bis 1356 mit Pontifikalfunktionen erwŠhnt, also als Weihbischof in der Erzdišzese Kšln. Nachdem er einige Jahre als Hilfsbischof in Mainz tŠtig gewesen war, zog er sich in sein Kloster in Altenberg zurŸck, in dessen Kirche er auch begraben liegt. Er war Titularbischof von Skopje.
English Bio:
Johann (es) of Syberg OCist also John of Sieberg (Siegburg) (  September 30 or October 1, 1383 - according to other sources: the end of September 1366 [1] - in Altenberg ) was auxiliary bishop in Cologne .

Johann (es) came from the Cologne Patrician family of Syberg . [2] The monk of the Cistercian Abbey Altenberg is mentioned to 1356 with Pontifikalfunktionen, so as auxiliary bishop in the archdiocese of Cologne. After being active as auxiliary bishop in Mainz for a few years , he retired to his monastery in Altenberg, in whose church he is also buried. He was Titular Bishop of Skopje .

Name: PjetÃ«r Bogdani
German Bio:
Pjet‘r Bogdani (italienisch Pietro Bogdano, * um 1630 in Gur i Hasit bei Kuk‘s;   Dezember 1689 in Pri_tina) war Bischof von Shkodra und Erzbischof von Skopje sowie ein bedeutender Autor der frŸhen albanischen Literatur. Sein 1685 entstandenes Buch Cuneus Prophetarum ist das erste bedeutende Prosawerk in albanischer Sprache.

Pjet‘r Bogdanis Familie gehšrte zur schmalen Elite der katholischen Albaner. Seine erste Ausbildung erhielt der junge Bogdani im Franziskanerkloster von Tschiprowzi im Nordwesten Bulgariens. SpŠter studierte er am Illyrischen Seminar von Loreto in Italien. 1651Ð1654 wirkte er als Gemeindepfarrer im nordalbanischen Pult, danach studierte er bis 1656 am Seminar der Propagandakongregation in Rom, wo er die DoktorwŸrden sowohl in Philosophie als auch in Theologie erwarb.

Am 6. MŠrz 1656 wurde er zum Bischof von Shkodra und zum Administrator des Erzbistums Antivari ernannt. In Shkodra wirkte er bis 1677 als Bischof, die Administratur von Antivari versah er bis 1671. WŠhrend des …sterreichisch-TŸrkischen Krieges musste Bogdani Shkodra verlassen. Als Oberhaupt der albanischen Katholiken galt er nicht zu Unrecht als Sympathisant der Habsburger. Von 1664 bis 1669 lebte er in den bei Shkodra gelegenen Dšrfern Barbullush und Rjoll.

Am 8. November 1677 folgte er seinem Onkel Andrea Bogdani als Erzbischof von Skopje nach. Seine antitŸrkische Haltung, sein hohes Amt in der katholischen Kirche und nicht zuletzt weil er die Spitze der christlichen Rebellion 1690 in Kosovo bildete, musste Pjet‘r Bogdani von den osmanischen Machthabern nach Ragusa fliehen. Von dort ging er fŸr einige Zeit nach Venedig und Padua. In Padua wurde Bogdani freundlich von Kardinal Gregorio Barbarigo aufgenommen, in dessen Diensten er 22 Jahre zuvor gestanden hatte. Kardinal Barbarigo war an der Kurie zustŠndig fŸr die Angelegenheiten der katholischen Kirche in den LŠndern des Ostens, und er interessierte sich fŸr die Kulturen des Balkans und der Levante. Deshalb fšrderte er auch die literarische TŠtigkeit Bogdanis und finanzierte den Druck von dessen Werken.

Nachdem Bogdani sein Hauptwerk Cuneus Prophetarum hatte in Padua drucken lassen, kehrte er im MŠrz 1686 auf den Balkan zurŸck. Dort engagierte er sich fŸr den Aufstand der christlichen Bewohner gegen die osmanische Herrschaft. Als die šsterreichische Armee 1689 im Gro§en TŸrkenkrieg das Kosovo erreichte, fŸhrte er ihr mehrere tausend albanische Freiwillige zu, die an der Eroberung Prizrens teilnahmen. Im Dezember 1689 erlag Bogdani in Pri_tina einer Krankheit und wurde in der dortigen Gro§en Moschee, die in eine Kirche umgewandelt wurde, begraben. Sein Grab wurde spŠter von osmanischen Soldaten zerstšrt und die Gebeine auf der Stra§e entsorgt.

Der Cuneus Prophetarum (dt. ãDie Schar der ProphetenÒ) ist eine aus zwei Teilen bestehende theologische Abhandlung. Dem ersten Teil liegen Texte des Alten Testaments zugrunde, der zweite beschŠftigt sich mit dem Leben Jesu. Zuerst befasst sich Bogdani mit der Erschaffung des Menschen. Dann folgt ein langer Abschnitt Ÿber die Prophetie, dem das Werk auch seinen Titel verdankt. Im Zentrum stehen die Propheten der Bibel, daneben sind in Versform auch die Vorhersagen von verschiedenen heidnischen Sibyllen aufgenommen, die nach Bogdanis Darstellung ebenso auf das Kommen des Messias hinweisen. Der neutestamentliche Teil behandelt in den einzelnen Kapiteln verschiedene Aspekte des Wirkens Christi: sein Leben, seine Wundertaten, den Tod am Kreuz, die Auferstehung und die Wiederkunft am Ende der Zeiten. Im Anhang finden sich ein kurzer Abschnitt aus dem Buch Daniel in acht verschiedenen Sprachen und eine kurze Familiengeschichte der Bogdani.

Pjet‘r Bogdani hatte das albanische Manuskript seines Buches schon fertig nach Padua mitgebracht. Vermutlich damit es die pŠpstlichen Zensurbehšrden leichter ŸberprŸfen konnten, verlangte die Kongregation De Propaganda Fide vor der Drucklegung eine italienische †bersetzung. Daran arbeitete Bogdani im Jahr 1685. Schlie§lich wurde sein Buch zweisprachig gedruckt, wobei die beiden Versionen in Spalten nebeneinander standen. Der lange parallele Text ist bis heute eine wichtige Quelle fŸr die Albanologie. FŸr den albanischen Text benutzte Bogdani das lateinische Alphabet, das er um einige kyrillische Buchstaben fŸr besondere Laute seiner Muttersprache ergŠnzte. Als sprachliche Vorlagen dienten ihm die wenigen albanischsprachigen BŸcher von Pjet‘r Budi, Lek‘ Matr‘nga und Frang Bardhi, die sich damals im Besitz der ršmischen Propagandakongregation befanden.

Der Cuneus Prophetarum wurde 1691 und 1702 in Venedig nachgedruckt.
English Bio:
Pjet‘r Bogdani (Italian Pietro Bogdano, * 1630 in Gur i Hasit at Kuk‘s,   December 1689 in Pri_tina) was Bishop of Shkodra and Archbishop of Skopje and a major author of early Albanian literature. His 1635 book Cuneus Prophetarum is the first significant prose work in Albanian language.

Pjet‘r Bogdani's family belonged to the narrow elite of Catholic Albanians. His first education was given by the young Bogdani in the Franciscan monastery of Chiprovtsi in northwestern Bulgaria. Later he studied at the Illyric Seminary of Loreto in Italy. 1651-1654 he worked as a parish priest in the North Albanian desk, then he studied until 1656 at the Seminary of the Propaganda Congregation in Rome, where he earned his doctorate in both philosophy and theology.

On March 6, 1656 he was appointed bishop of Shkodra and administrator of the archbishopric Antivari. In Shkodra he worked until 1677 as a bishop, the administration of Antivari he provided until 1671. During the Austro-Turkish War Bogdani had to leave Shkodra. As head of the Albanian Catholics, he was not wrongly considered a sympathizer of the Habsburgs. From 1664 to 1669 he lived in the villages of Barbullush and Rjoll near Shkodra.

On November 8, 1677, he succeeded his uncle Andrea Bogdani as Archbishop of Skopje. His anti-Turkish stance, his high office in the Catholic Church and not least because he was the head of the Christian rebellion in Kosovo in 1690, had to flee Pjet‘r Bogdani from the Ottoman rulers to Ragusa. From there he went to Venice and Padua for a while. In Padua Bogdani was kindly received by Cardinal Gregorio Barbarigo, in whose service he had been 22 years earlier. Cardinal Barbarigo was in charge of the affairs of the Catholic Church in the Eastern countries at the Curia, and he was interested in the cultures of the Balkans and the Levant. Therefore, he also promoted the literary activity of Bogdani and financed the printing of his works.

After Bogdani had his major work Cuneus Prophetarum printed in Padua, he returned to the Balkans in March 1686. There he committed himself to the revolt of the Christian inhabitants against the Ottoman rule. When the Austrian army reached Kosovo in 1689 in the Great Turkish War, he led her several thousand Albanian volunteers who participated in the conquest of Prizren. In December 1689 Bogdani died in Pristina of a disease and was buried in the local Great Mosque, which was converted into a church. His grave was later destroyed by Ottoman soldiers and disposed of the bones on the street.

The Cuneus Prophetarum is a two-part theological treatise. The first part is based on texts of the Old Testament, the second deals with the life of Jesus. First, Bogdani deals with the creation of man. Then follows a long section on prophecy, to which the work owes its title. In the center are the prophets of the Bible, in addition, the predictions of various pagan sibyls are included in verse form, which also point to the coming of the Messiah according to Bogdani's presentation. In the individual chapters, the New Testament part deals with various aspects of the work of Christ: his life, his miracles, the death on the cross, the resurrection, and the return at the end of time. Attached is a short section from the book of Daniel in eight different languages __and a short family history of the Bogdani.

Pjet‘r Bogdani had already brought the Albanian manuscript of his book to Padua. Presumably to make it easier for the papal censors to verify, the Congregation De Propaganda Fide requested an Italian translation before going to press. That's what Bogdani was working on in 1685. Finally, his book was printed in two languages, the two versions standing side by side in columns. The long parallel text is still an important source for albanology. For the Albanian text Bogdani used the Latin alphabet, which he added to some Cyrillic letters for special sounds of his mother tongue. As linguistic templates served him the few Albanian -language books by Pjet‘r Budi, Lek‘ Matr‘nga and Frang Bardhi, which were then in the possession of the Roman propaganda Congregation.

The Cuneus Prophetarum was reprinted in Venice in 1691 and 1702.

Name: Kliment
German Bio:
Kliment von Ohrid (bulg. _______ ________/Kliment Ochridski, maz. _______ ________/Kliment Ohridski; * um 840;   27. Juli 916 in Ohrid) war ein Gelehrter und SchŸler der Slawenapostel Kyrill und Method, KlostergrŸnder und Erzbischof von ãBelica und OhridÒ.

Kliment nahm an Methodius' Mission im Gro§mŠhrischen Reich teil. Nach dessen Tod war er FŸhrer der slawischen Partei in der Auseinandersetzung mit den lateinischen Klerikern, die aus dem Ostfrankenreich gekommen waren. Nach einer kurzen Zeit im GefŠngnis wurde er vermutlich 885 aus Gro§mŠhren vertrieben und wandte sich zusammen mit Angelarij und Naum in das Erste Bulgarische Reich.

Zar Boris I. und seinem Nachfolger Zar Simeon I.[1][2] betrauten die beiden Mšnche mit der Unterrichtung kŸnftiger bulgarischer Kleriker in dem gerade erst zum Christentum bekehrten Land. Nach der Annahme des Christentums war zunŠchst das Griechische, das von byzantinischen Missionaren eingefŸhrt worden war, die Kirchensprache in Bulgarien. Um den byzantinischen Einfluss auf seinen Staat zurŸckzudrŠngen, war Boris I. an der Etablierung der slawischen Sprache im Gottesdienst interessiert.

ZunŠchst unter alleiniger Leitung Kliments wurde am Ohridsee die Schule von Ohrid errichtet. SpŠter unterstŸtzte ihn Naum, der anfangs die Schulen in Pliska und Preslaw leitete. In den von ihnen errichteten Schulen wurde das Altkirchenslawisch als Liturgiesprache unterrichtet. Sie machten aus Ohrid, neben Pliska und Preslaw, ein weiteres kirchliches und kulturelles Zentrum, indem sie Kirchen bauten, Klšster (u. a. die Klšster ãPantaleimonÒ und Sveti Naum) errichteten und die Schule erweiterten, in der zahlreiche Kleriker ausgebildet wurden. Die Schule von Ohrid hat einen Gro§teil der ã(alt)bulgarischenÒ Literatur hervorgebracht[3]. Kliment soll der †berlieferung nach zwischen 886 und 893 3.500[4] SchŸler in der neuen Schriftsprache unterwiesen haben.

Ihm wird hŠufig auch die Entwicklung des kyrillischen Alphabets zugeschrieben, jedoch bedeutet eine entsprechend gedeutete Nachricht in der Legenda Ochridica tatsŠchlich wohl nur, dass er die glagolitische Schrift reformiert hat.[5]

Nach einem Streit mit dem Zaren Simeon I. wurde er 893 zum Bischof des entlegenen Orts Drembica (heute Velika an der bulgarischen SchwarzmeerkŸste; nach einer anderen Theorie jedoch das viel nŠher liegende Belica bei Struga) ernannt, was einer Verbannung nahekam. SpŠter erlangte Kliment wieder die Gunst des Herrschers und wurde Erzbischof von Ohrid. Er grŸndete das Pantaleimon-Kloster in Varo_, heute ein Stadtteil von Ohrid.

Nach seinem Tod im Jahr 916 wurde er in der Kirche St. Pantaleimon bei Ohrid bestattet. Als die Osmanen diese Kirche im 15. Jahrhundert in eine Moschee umwandelten, wurden Kliments Gebeine in die Ohrider Kirche Sveta Bogorodica Perivlepta umgebettet. Seine gro§e Verehrung fŸhrte unter Zar Samuil zur Kanonisation als Heiliger (Hauptfest 27. Juli). Nach dem Wiederaufbau der St. Pantaleimon-Kirche auf dem heute als ãPlao_nikÒ bekannten Areal liegen seine Gebeine wieder dort an der alten Stelle.

Heute tragen mehrere Kirchen, die UniversitŠten von Sofia und Bitola, sowie die bulgarische St.-Kliment-Ohridski-Station auf der antarktischen Livingston-Insel[6] und Mount Ohridsky auf der antarktischen Alexander-I.-Insel seinen Namen.
English Bio:
Kliment Ohrid (Bulg _______ ________ / Kliment Ochridski, maz. _______ ________ / Kliment Ohridski * * 840,   July 27, 916 in Ohrid) was a scholar and disciple of the Slavic apostles Cyril and Methodius, monastery founder and archbishop of "Belica and Ohrid ".

Kliment participated in Methodius' mission in the Great Moravian Empire. After his death he was leader of the Slavic party in the conflict with the Latin clerics, who had come from the Eastern France. After a brief spell in jail, he was presumably expelled from Greater Moravia in 885 and, together with Angelarij and Naum, turned to the First Bulgarian Empire.

Tsar Boris I and his successor Zar Simeon I. [1] [2] entrusted the two monks with the information of future Bulgarian clerics in the just converted to Christianity land. After the adoption of Christianity, the Greek, introduced by Byzantine missionaries, was the church language in Bulgaria. In order to suppress the Byzantine influence on his state, Boris I was interested in the establishment of the Slavic language in worship.

Initially, under Kliment's sole direction, Ohrid's school was built at Ohrid. Later he was assisted by Naum, who initially headed the schools in Pliska and Preslaw. In the schools they built, Old Church Slavonic was taught as a liturgical language. They made Ohrid, next to Pliska and Preslaw, another ecclesiastical and cultural center by building churches, building monasteries (including the monasteries of Pantaleimon and Sveti Naum) and expanding the school, where numerous clerics were trained. The Ohrid School has produced much of the "(old) Bulgarian" literature [3]. Kliment is said to have taught according to the tradition between 886 and 893 3,500 [4] students in the new written language.

It is often attributed to the development of the Cyrillic alphabet, but a correspondingly interpreted message in the Legenda Ochridica actually only means that he has reformed the Glagolitic script.

After a quarrel with Tsar Simeon I, he was appointed Bishop of the remote town of Drembica (today Velika on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast in 893, but according to another theory, the much closer to Belica at Struga), which was close to a banishment. Later, Kliment regained the ruler's favor and became archbishop of Ohrid. He founded the Pantaleimon Monastery in Varo_, today a district of Ohrid.

After his death in 916, he was buried in the church of St. Pantaleimon at Ohrid. When the Ottomans converted this church into a mosque in the 15th century, Kliment's bones were reburied into the Ohrid church of Sveta Bogorodica Perivlepta. His great veneration led under Zar Samuil to canonization as a saint (main festival July 27). After the reconstruction of the St. Pantaleimon church on today known as "Plao_nik" area his bones are back there in the old place.

Today, several churches, the universities of Sofia and Bitola, as well as the Bulgarian St. Kliment-Ohridski station on the Antarctic Livingston Island and Mount Ohridsky on the Antarctic Alexander I island bear his name.

English Bio:
Johann I. Debranin (Bulgarian ____ ________,   1037) was a Bulgarian clergyman of the 11th century.

He was a bishop under Tsar Samuil, and remained in office thereafter, making him the first Slavic archbishop of Ohrid after the fall of the First Bulgarian Empire. After that, the area belonged to the Byzantine province of Bulgaria.

According to the French historian du Cange, Johann was born near the village of Debar in what is now Macedonia. [4] When Emperor Basileios II conquered Bulgaria in 1018, he decided to subjugate the previously autokephal Bulgarian Orthodox Church and established the Archdiocese of Ohrid. Johann became the first Archbishop of Ohrid. Before that, he was Hegumen in a monastery in Debar. [4] He remained in office until his death in 1037.

English Bio:
Leo I. Carigradjanin (also: Leo of Ohrid, Leon of Achrida, Lav Ohridski (Liv), Greek ____ _____¹____¹__ __________, ____ _ ', Bulgarian ___ I ________; ____; ___ I;   1056) was a leading Byzantine cleric and archbishop von Ohrid and representative of the views of the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople in the theological confrontation with the Holy See, at the end of which is the 1054 Islamic Schism.

About childhood and youth Leo's nothing is known. After 1025 he was appointed Archbishop of Ohrid. Before that he was a chartophylax (Å administrative officer / archivist) in the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople. [1]

Under Patriarch Michael I (1043-1059) Leo was sent to Southern Italy as a spokesman for Constantinople for theological debates with Roman clerics. He reported on his views in a letter to Bishop John of Trani (1053). However, this letter was addressed additionally to the Pope and all Latin bishops. Leo clarified in this letter for the first time the estrangement between the Eastern and Western Church by different liturgical and disciplinary aspects. and condemned various practices of the Western Church, such as eating "strangled" flesh, blood, fasting on Sunday, and other liturgical differences. [1] The most important distinction, however, was the use of unleavened bread for the Eucharist. This custom became a persistent argument in letters to Cardinal Humbert of Silva Candida, which eventually led to Humbert's posting to Constantinople and in 1054 sealed the schism between Rome and Byzantium, leading to their mutual anathema and division into two geographically separate churches. 3]

English Bio:
Theophylactic of Ohrid (Greek ___________ ________, Bulgarian _________ ________, also: Theophylactic of Bulgaria) (born about 1055, died after 1107) was a Greek, Byzantine cleric, archbishop of Ohrid and commentator of the Bible.

Theophylact was probably born in Chalkida, Euboea, in the middle of the 11th century. He was ordained a deacon in Constantinople. There he gained great reputation as a scholar and became a teacher of Constantine X, the son of Michael VII. For him, he wrote the education of princes. In 1078 he went as archbishop of Ohrid to Bulgaria.

Ohrid was then one of the most important cities of the Bulgarian Empire, which had been conquered by the Byzantines six years earlier. In this challenging position in an occupied territory on the fringes of the Byzantine Empire, for over 20 years he very carefully and dynamically performed his pastoral duties. Although he was a Byzantine by education and appearance, he was a meticulous archbishop of the Bulgarian Church, who defended their interests and independence. He acted determined to protect his diocese from the teachings of the Paulikians and Bogomils and won respect and love of the Bulgarians. [1]

In his letters, he often complains about the bad manners of the Bulgarians and tried to give up his office, but without success. His letters are a valuable source for the economic, social and political history of Bulgaria and Byzantine prosopography. In it appear constant complaints about the "barbaric" environment, while Theophylact himself was deeply involved in the development of local cultural development. Among other things, he created an Encomium (Lobschrift) on 15 martyrs of Tiberiupolis and a Vita of Kliment of Ohrid. In his letters, he also reported that the constant wars between the Byzantine Empire and the Pechenegs, Magyars and Normans had destroyed a large part of the food and drove many people to flee.

He died after 1107.

In the Orthodox churches of Serbia, Bulgaria, Greece, and Russia, he is revered as a saint. His memorial day is on December 31st. [3] [4]

works

Title page of a Latin translation of Theophylact's Bible Commentaries
His commentaries on the Gospels, Acts of the Apostles, Paul's Epistles, and the Book of the Twelve are based on the teachings of John Chrysostom, but they claim their place in exegetical literature for their accuracy, sobriety, accuracy, and balance. Other surviving works are 530 letters, various homilies and orations as well as the Vita by Kliment von Ohrid. A careful edition of his works was edited by JFBM de Rossi (4 vols. Fol., Venice). This was from J.-P. Migne in the Patrologia Graeca vols. 123-6 (1869) reprinted.

Thomas Aquinas included parts of Theophylact's writings in his Catena Aurea, which is a collection of commentaries on the four Gospels of the Fathers of the Church.

In the early sixteenth century, his Bible commentary had an important impact on the Novum Testamentum and the Erasmus of Rotterdam annotations, though erroneously referred to Erasmus as "Vulgarius" in his early New Testament edition. Theophylactic Commentaries on the Gospel were published in Greek in Rome in 1542 and translated into Latin in the 1520s by Catholic (Porsena) and Protestant (Oecolampadius) translators. Modern translations are available in Greek, Russian, Serbian, Bulgarian, Romanian. This reflects the great influence on orthodox theology. Nikolai Velimirovic, a Bishop of Ohrid, writes: "Theophylactic" Commentaries on the Gospels and other New Testament books ... are the best works of their kind to those of St. John Chrysostom, and they are still with us today read a great profit. "[4]

The first English translation (and thus the first in a modern Western European language) was The Explanation of the Gospels. It was edited by Chrysostom Press (see below).

English Bio:
Leo II Mung (also: Lev Philosopher, Middle Greek ____ _ _______, Bulgarian: ____ ________, ___ ____) was Archbishop of Ohrid 1108-1120.

Leo was a Romani Jew, and student of the famous rabbi Tobia ben Elieser, before he converted to Orthodox Christianity. As a great scholar - hence the nickname "The Philosopher" - he was sent by the Patriarch of Constantinople as a missionary in the area that today belongs to the southwestern Ukraine. He spoke several languages. [3] Soon thereafter, he was appointed Archbishop of Ohrid, succeeding Theophylact of Ohrid. Little is known about his life. [4]

Leo commissioned an icon known to this day, the Bogorodica od Blagovestenie; he received the honorary title Didaskalos ton Ethnon.

English Bio:
Demetrios Chomatenos, also Chomatianos (Greek _________ _________ or __________, bl. In the 13th century) was a Byzantine priest, judge and archbishop of Ohrid between 1216 and 1236. He led the title of "Archbishop of Iustiniana Prima and Bulgaria". [1]

Chomatos had an extensive legal education, which enabled him to exert great influence as a judge, mediator, confessor and adviser to the Byzantine imperial family. This is characteristic of a time when judicial authority has increasingly been transferred from the weak secular institutions to the clergy of the Orthodox Church. He had full access to the Codex Justinianus as a lawyer and was thus a representative of the legal Renaissance during the Macedonian era of the Byzantine Empire.

About 150 acts of his cases have survived and give legal historians a comprehensive picture of contemporary justice.

An important role played Chomatenos also in the clashes of the two great successor states of the Byzantine Empire after the Fourth Crusade, the Despotate Epirus and the Empire Nikaia. Together with John Apokaukos (_______ _¹_______, about 1155-1233) and Georgios Bardanis (________ ________, Metropolitan of Corfu about 1219-1238) encouraged Chomatenos the epirotic independence of Nikaia. In 1225 or 1227 it was Chomatos, who crowned Theodore Komnenos Doukas to Byzantine counter-emperor in Thessaloniki.

English Bio:
Konstantinos Kabasilas (Middle Greek ____________ _________, before 1235-after 1259) was a Byzantine cleric in the middle of the 13th century. Before 1235 he was Archbishop of Strumica and then became Metropolitan of Dyrrhachium. In the 1250s he was appointed Archbishop of Ohrid.

He was the brother of Johannes Kabasilas, an official at the court of the Despot of Epirus, Michael II Komnenos Doukas, and Theodoros Kabasilas, another supporter of Michael II. Because of this close connection he came under suspicion of the Emperor of Nikaia Theodore II and was imprisoned until 1259. Michael VIII Palaiologos put him back into freedom and allowed him to return to his episcopal see. [4]
